description: "Backgrounds and comments on a case where two directors of the Christchurch based building company Balmoral Homes Ltd, pleaded guilty to multiple charges of breaching the Fair Trading Act."

Title: "Manufacturer receives a hose down"
description: "Comments on the case against Methven Ltd who have pleaded guilty to nine breaches of the Fair Trading Act for misleading consumers about the potential savings gained when using the Satinjet shower product range."

Title: "Pensioner determined to stop thief getting his car"
description: "Pensioner determined to stop thief getting his car"

Author: "Sharpe, Marty"
Title: "Breeder shocked his mare gave fatal kick"
description: "Breeder shocked his mare gave fatal kick"

Author: "Field, Michael,"
Title: "Banks in tears at boy's inquest"
description: "Banks in tears at boy's inquest"

Title: "Shooting of famer deliberate and not random act, say police"
description: "Shooting of famer deliberate and not random act, say police"

Title: "In-form Van Gisbergen has high hopes"
description: "In-form Van Gisbergen has high hopes"

Author: "Worthington, Sam"
Title: "Reid looking for a pick-me-up after tough start to Premier League"
description: "Reid looking for a pick-me-up after tough start to Premier League"

Author: "Millmow, Jonathan"
Title: "And the silver goes to ... a good Kean young man"
description: "And the silver goes to ... a good Kean young man"

Author: "Rae, Sally"
Title: "Adventure in the high country"
description: "Highlights the huts and tracks on Otematata Station that have been opened up to the public. Backgrounds the Cameron family's ownership of the station and the promotion of their new venture."

Author: "Benson, Nigel"
Title: "Dunedin story strikes home for UK judges"
description: "Reports on  the University of Otago science department librarian who has won the Kinglake Publishing Ltd Unpublished Author competition with a crime novel set in Dunedin."

Author: "Taylor, Phil,"
Title: "Ex-cop says chief pressured him to change search evidence; Police wined and dined Thomas jury, says QC"
description: "Reports on Ross Meurant's claim of how he was pressured by the police commissioner to change important evidence to the Crewe Royal Commission to suit the police case. Briefly reports on the conduct of the Crewe murder-case jurors and police behaviour. Suggests that how the case was handled should be looked at, so that mistakes that were made will not be repeated."

Author: "Taylor, Phil,"
Title: "Breaker Meurant"
description: "Talks to the ex-police officer, member of the Red Squad and National MP about his colourful career, and discusses why he has 'turned whistleblower' in helping Rochelle Crewe in her bid to have the case involving the murder of her parents re-opened."

Author: "Nissen, Wendyl"
Title: "Nut bar is, on the whole, nice and natural"
description: "Analyses the contents of the nut bars made by Nice & Natural, which results in a relatively positive report. Highlights the best aspects of the product, and gives recommendations. Notes that all the healthier points made don't necessarily apply to all the flavours in the range."

Author: "Cumming, Geoffrey"
Title: "Motat pulled in two directions"
description: "Debates the future of the Auckland transport museum, citing the opinions of Ian Hambly, representing management, and Alan Curtis as a volunteer of the organisation. Points specifically to Motat's increasing focus on entertainment. Provides a brief outline of the Motat Society."

Author: "Briggs, Billy"
Title: "Scotland's hatchet man tasked with improving Health"
description: "Profiles the newly-appointed Director-General of Health in NZ, Dr Kevin Woods, who became a controversial figure in Scotland after he was tasked with restructuring Scotland's health service and improving care. Suggests concern about how he will manage the health system in NZ. Provides an overview of Dr Woods' career and credentials."

Author: "Hewitson, Michele"
Title: "Shaun Quincey"
description: "Talks about Quincey's experience of being the second-only person to row solo across the Tasman (the first being his father, in 1977)."

Author: "Stevens, Nicholas"
Title: "First the dream, then the bombshell"
description: "Expresses the author's concern over KiwiRail's intention to turn the Mainline Steam building, an industrial building in the heart of Auckland city, into a bus park. Explains how an imaginative restoration of the building could instead benefit the whole community"

Author: "Marshall, Jonathan"
Title: "P-lab claim adds to woes after studio explosion"
description: "P-lab claim adds to woes after studio explosion"

Author: "Veltkamp Smith, Pat"
Title: "World War II flying hero worked hard for Southland community"
description: "World War II flying hero worked hard for Southland community"

Author: "Johnston, Chris"
Title: "Top motor trade apprentice gets into gear with racing legend Murphy"
description: "Top motor trade apprentice gets into gear with racing legend Murphy"

Title: "Baking venture a piece of cake for Lilia Apelinga"
description: "Baking venture a piece of cake for Lilia Apelinga"

Author: "Aldridge, Joseph"
Title: "Prestigious award assures rocking good time"
description: "Prestigious award assures rocking good time"

Title: "Committed to rugby throughout New Zealand"
description: "Committed to rugby throughout New Zealand"

Title: "Fine red wine story makes for good book"
description: "Fine red wine story makes for good book"

Author: "Crayton-Brown, Kimberley"
Title: "Chopper down : mechanical failure cited as crash cause; Tributes flow for helicopter crash pair"
description: "Chopper down : mechanical failure cited as crash cause; Tributes flow for helicopter crash pair"

Title: "Kiwi cartoonist graced top Vic papers"
description: "Kiwi cartoonist graced top Vic papers"

Author: "Hembry, Owen"
Author (detailed): "Owen Hembry, Anne Gibson and Joelle Thomson"
Title: "Pressure's not over yet, insiders say; Perfect timing : out before the crash; Three brands thriving in tough market"
description: "Looks at the state of the wine industry in the midst of the recession, with failures, receiverships, purchases and takovers causing a stir. Briefly covers the luck of Anthony Beverley, the Wellington businessman who sold his Marlborough vineyard to Montana 4 years ago, quitting well before the crash. Profiles 3 new wine producers who are thriving despite the current market situation, including artist Dick Frizzell's label."

Author: "Veltkamp Smith, Pat"
Title: "Potter leaves legacy in city art gallery"
description: "Potter leaves legacy in city art gallery"

Author: "Lynch, Keith"
Title: "Family forgive son's killer at sentencing"
description: "Family forgive son's killer at sentencing"

Author: "Dudding, Adam"
Title: "New stem cell surgery helps the blind to see"
description: "Explains how revolutionary stem cell techniques now allow surgeons to restore sight to the blind. Reports that Professor Charles McGhee and his colleagues have performed the operation on five subjects, in each case taking healthy stem cells from a patient's uninjured eye and growing them for up to three weeks on amniotic membrane taken from a human placenta, before reimplanting the lab grown cells back into the injured eye. Includes the story of Aparna Unnikrishnan who who had a new cornea grafted from a deceased donor and a graft of her own laboratory stem cells which meant the corneal transplant had a fighting chance of lasting five years, if not more. Indicates this surgical technique will be shown on a documentary series called Situation critical on TV One at 8pm on Wednesday."

Title: "Top-ranked nurse valued for improving health care"
description: "Top-ranked nurse valued for improving health care"

Author: "Law, Tina"
Title: "Farmer and father a racing enthusiast"
description: "Farmer and father a racing enthusiast"

Author: "Harries, Julie"
Title: "To market, to market to buy ... everything"
description: "Highlights the authors' favourite Auckland traditional and farmers' markets. Includes common-sense tips for market shopping."

Author: "Sell, Bronwyn"
Title: "Round the mountain"
description: "Highlights the growing popularity of ministure trains, with people of all ages. Lists where you can ride miniature trains in the northern half of the North Island."

Author: "Perrott, Alan"
Title: "And it's 'goodnight' from him"
description: "Talks to the television presenter about his 40-year career in the industry, 27 of them hosting 'Fair go', as he enters retirement."

Author: "Jewell, Stephen"
Title: "Made in Manhattan"
description: "Talks to TV One's New York correspondent about his career reoorting on some of the world's biggest stories, and how he has managed to find the time dueing his busy schedule to write a novel."

Author: "Hubbard, Anthony"
Title: "A very Kiwi kind of protest"
description: "Looks at the group calling themselves 'Save Our Farms', (John McKearney, Gary Bulog, Tony Bouchier and Sir Bruce Slane) a lobby group who are in opposition to the sale of farmland to foreigners. Examines their background and what motivates them to lobby the Government about who should have ownership of large tracts of NZ land. Includes a timeline of farmland sold to foreigners from 1999-2008 through to October 2010."

Author: "Hill, Rebecca Barry."
Title: "Stitches in time"
description: "Talks to Douglas Lloyd Jenkins, co-author with Lucy Hammonds and Claire Regnault of a new book on the history of NZ fashion, which reveals that the 7-decade industry in this country is not merely about clothes."

Author: "Knight, Kim,"
Title: "Drawn to war"
description: "Reveals that a number of Peter McIntyre's drawing have come to light in a Cornwall cottage, discovered by Claire Colvin and now up for sale in Parnell, Auckland. Includes 20 never-before exhibited works containing 12 portraits, only four were labelled by the artist and a further four have been identified and research for the identity of the remaining is ongoing. Claire Colvin, daughter of Neville Colvin a well known NZ cartoonist, explains how they came to be in her possession and background is given about Peter McIntyre the artist. Includes milestones of Peter McIntyre's life and career."

Author: "Booker, Jarrod"
Title: "Hunting for the good kids within"
description: "Reports on a boot camp near Christchurch, the first of the Government's Military Activity Camps (MAC) for serious repeat youth offenders. Describes the 8-week programme, daily routines, the point system used for privileges, and the main issue that surface in the first week. Speaks to some of the teenagers and staff."

Author: "Laxon, Andrew"
Title: "We don't know how lucky we are"
description: "Considers NZ's level of prosperity (fourth highest in the world) according to the Legatum Institute run in London by expatriate Christopher Chandler. Examines the think-tank's ratings on NZ's economy, entrepreneurship, governance, education, health, safety, personal freedom, and social capital. Seeks comment from Professor Marilyn Waring on the reasons such tables are outdated and not useful."

Author: "Stone, Andrew"
Title: "How anti-apartheid crusader turned TP"
description: "Profiles the sports journalist and author. Discusses his biography, which reveals his affair with a South African politician, and talks about some of his other (32) books. Speaks to son Jock McLean about the decision to include family secrets in the book, his father's numerous by-lines, and his scoop on All Black Keith Murdoch. Provides biographical material on the McLean family."

Author: "Hewitson, Michele"
Title: "Andrew Little"
description: "Interviews the union leader (Engineering, Printing and Manufacturing Union) and soon to be Labour MP. Discusses his family background, his views on the dispute involving Actors' Equity and the making of The Hobbit, his centrist views, what sort of politician he thinks he will be, and his predilection for puns."

Author: "Christian, Dionne"
Title: "Party like there's no tomorrow"
description: "Reviews Cabaret, performed by the Auckland Theatre Company and directed by Michael Hurst, Salon Perdu Spiegeltent, Auckland Viaduct, 30 October-20 November."

Author: "McNamara, T. J."
Title: "Winging it works ... for some"
description: "Reviews A rock that was taught it was a bird, a show by Dan Arps, Kim Beom, Layla Rudneva, and Koki Tanaka, at Artspace, until 20 November. Reviews Aesop's Kiwi fables, illustrative paintings by Ray Ching, at Artis Gallery, until 13 November. Reviews Come here Palangi, paintings by Glen Wolfgramm, at Orexart, until 13 November. Reviews Frame, abstract paintings by Kathryn Stevens, at Whitespace, until 6 November. Reviews Skin and bone, lithographs by John Pusateri, at Seed Gallery, until 31 October."

Author: "Rae, Bernadette"
Title: "Stiefel will lead in leaps and bounds"
description: "Profiles the next artistic director of the Royal NZ Ballet (RNZB). Discusses why he impressed the RNZB board, his early career and consequent international dancing experience, his dancing partner (Gillian Murphy), and his teaching background."

Author: "Simpson, Peter,"
Title: "Generous bunch reveal trade secrets"
description: "Generous bunch reveal trade secrets"

Author: "Gillies, Abby"
Title: "Drink-driver crashes into roadside picnic"
description: "Drink-driver crashes into roadside picnic"

Author: "Falconer, Phoebe"
Title: "Hero who always put others first"
description: "Hero who always put others first"

Author: "Black, Joanne"
Title: "Saving the KiwiSavers"
description: "Takes a look at how much those NZers who are signed up to KiwiSaver are getting from the scheme, given that half of all NZ households have at least one member in the scheme. Talks to people who, for various reasons, have opted out of the scheme. Mentions the trend for parents to sign their children up for KiwiSaver, and what influences this trend. Compares the annual returns of the best saver plans with those of the worst."

Author: "Thomas, Sarah"
Title: "The star next door"
description: "Chronicles the career of Rhys Darby from his time in NZ doing stand-up comedy then in 2007 playing the role of band manager in Flight of the Conchords with Jemaine Clement and Bret McKenzie followed by roles in 'Yes man' with Jim Carrey and Richard Curtis's 'The boat that rocked'. Describes how he came to comedy and the influence of his family life on his career and keeping him grounded in a nice way. Notes he has two romcoms ahead, 'Coming and going' and 'Lovebirds' and as yet an unconfirmed role in 'The office'."

Author: "Barnett, Sarah"
Title: "Nature of hope"
description: "Talks to the Canadian and leading biodiversity spokesman about the fate of fish, in particular, within the environment. Mentions Suzuki's newest book 'The legacy: an elder's vision or our sustainable future', and gives details of his tour, which extends to NZ in November."

Author: "Forbes, Michael"
Title: "The mayor who aims to patch up Whanganui's reputation"
description: "Talks to new mayor of Whanganui, Annette Main who discusses the reputation the city has for gangs. States that the city's reputation needs to be improved."

Author: "Wichtel, Diana"
Title: "Along came Jones"
description: "Records an intense exchange with the author of the Booker Prize-shortlisted 'Mr Pip', on the release of his latest novel."

Title: "Forgotten splendour"
description: "Book review of Dress circle : New Zealand fashion design since 1940 by Douglas Lloyd Jenkins, Claire Regnault, Lucy Hammonds and a discussion of the history of NZ fashion."

Author: "McCrystal, John"
Title: "Pages reveal life of colonial labourers"
description: "Pages reveal life of colonial labourers"

Author: "Bourke, Chris"
Title: "Close encounters"
description: "Reviews a new book which chronicles NZ's rich and often uncelebrated history of live gigs, by everyone from Gene Vincent to Lady Gaga."

Author: "Biss, Roderick"
Title: "The man with the baton"
description: "Talks to the Finland-born music director of the NZ Symphony Orchestra about his background and involvement in the orchestra's development, ahead of its biggest-ever overseas tour."

Author: "Morton, Frances"
Title: "Lobby power; Free trip home for drinkers"
description: "Investigates the role of the alcohol and hospitality industries in keeping NZ's drink-driving limit unchanged. Talks to Progressive leader Jim Anderton and Conrad Bollinger (author of 'Grog's own country') and others about the lobbying of politicians and the historical influence of the alcohol industry; wine writer and broadcaster Keith Stewart about the denial of responsibility within the alcohol industry; and Hospitality Association chief executive Bruce Robertson and Distilled Spirits Association chief executive Thomas Chin about the data supporting a lowering of the drink-drive limit and personal responsibility. Notes the people talked to for the article and member of the public who have agreed to sign-up for the 'Herald on Sunday's' 'Two drinks max' campaign. Talks to the owner of the Mangawhai Tavern in Northland about providing a free pick-up and drop-off service to patrons."

Title: "Derby dream comes true; Victory caps day for NZ industry"
description: "Derby dream comes true; Victory caps day for NZ industry"

Author: "Somerset, Guy"
Title: "Apocalypse now"
description: "Reviews the debut novel by TVNZ US correspondent Tim Wilson, which took him 7 years to write."

Author: "Alderson, Andrew"
Title: "Former stroke happy to join volunteer army"
description: "Former stroke happy to join volunteer army"

Author: "Chug, Kiran"
Title: "Team effort to keep the chilly draughts at bay"
description: "Reports on the Theodorou family of Island Bay who have won a house energy makeover. Lists the percentages of heat loss currently at their uninsulated home. States the changes, which will take place to provide a home that will be as energy efficient as possible."

Title: "Dark days"
description: "Extract of John Kirwan's book, 'All Blacks don't cry written with Margie Thomson."

Author: "McCrystal, John"
Title: "Stalking his darling"
description: "Reviews 'The collector's dream' by Pierre Furlan, set in NZ. [Print exclusive]"

Author: "Fitzsimons, Tom"
Title: "New mayor's dream ride"
description: "Discusses Wellington's new mayor's proposal to equip the city with a modern tram system. Looks at the plans, costs and advantages."

Author: "Brown, Michael"
Title: "Founding player hanging up Breaker boots"
description: "Founding player hanging up Breaker boots"

Author: "Murray, Sarah"
Title: "Way back when"
description: "Asks George Henare to describe the context of the photo where he is standing in the doorway of his home aged four along with his great grandmother, the home being located in Whakaangiangi Valley, East Cape in 1948."

Author: "Venter, Nick"
Title: "Great helmsman looks back"
description: "Profiles ex-prime minister Jim Bolger who will soon be retiring as chairman of NZ Post and Kiwibank. Looks back at many of Mr Bolger's achievements."

Author: "Jackson, Kerri"
Title: "The cook & the baker"
description: "Talks to Dean Brettschneider (the baker) and Mark McDonough (the cook) about their new book. Provides two recipes from the book, 'savoury garden and vegetable cheese twist' and 'beetroot, grilled lamb and haloumi salad'."

Author: "Horsley, Francesca"
Title: "Call to Tempo"
description: "Reviews Tempo: New Zealand's Festival of Dance, staged in Auckland in October 2010."

Author: "Eleven, Beck"
Title: "Out in uniform"
description: "Talks to several NZ military personnel about being openly gay in the Forces. Compares the NZ open gay policy to the American Forces Don't Ask, Don't Tell (DADT) policy."

Author: "Boniface, Linley"
Title: "Going with the flow"
description: "Focuses on platelet-rich plasma therapy (PRP), also called vampire therapy or Dracula therapy, which is a new procedure used to treat everything from sports injuries and surgical wounds to wrinkles and stretch marks. Explains it as being based on the benefits of platelets, which contain growth factors that contribute to tissue repair. Describes the procedure as the patient's blood being extracted and separated into red cells and platelets, with the platelets then being used to form a concentrated compound that is injected back into the patent's body. Includes a number of facts about blood. Considers the advantages and disadvantages of this type of therapy."

Author: "Cone, Deborah Hill"
Title: "Funny business"
description: "Reviews the new stand-up comedy series 'A night at the classic'."

Author: "MacDonald, Nikki"
Title: "The money pit"
description: "Features Zealandia, Karori's wildlife sanctuary and its success stories. Discusses the sanctuary's financial performance and their plans to become financially self-sufficient. Talks about its growing tourism emphasis and how this might affect the conservation."

Author: "Bowden, Jennifer"
Title: "When the ads attack"
description: "Advises that today's children are being inundated with unhealthy messages about food. Argues that there are sensible ways of going about protecting our children from a lifetime of ill health and potential social isolation. Suggests that a high percentage of NZ's caregivers agree that the advertising of unhealthy products, by appealing to children, should be stopped."

Author: "Hansford, Dave"
Title: "In pursuit of prized Chatham pork"
description: "Tells the story of a days pig hunting with Bruce Tuanui in the southern Chatham Island. Features the capture of a very large wild boar but at the cost of 3 hunting dogs."

Author: "Harvey, Sarah"
Title: "Tears for Rose at heartfelt service"
description: "Tears for Rose at heartfelt service"

Author: "Pepperell, Susan"
Title: "Apprentice helping beat the baby blues"
description: "Apprentice helping beat the baby blues"

Title: "Hot stuff cooking in Kel's kitchen"
description: "Hot stuff cooking in Kel's kitchen"

Title: "Determined writer comes out on top"
description: "Determined writer comes out on top"

Author: "Kilgallon, Steve"
Title: "Price : I bawled like a baby"
description: "Reviews the 2010 edition of the autobiography by former Warriors player and captain Steve Price (with Ben Blaschke)."

Author: "Kilgallon, Steve"
Title: "'Surgeon' keen to cut path to Olympics"
description: "'Surgeon' keen to cut path to Olympics"

Author: "Broatch, Mark"
Title: "Looking through a different lens"
description: "Talks to the winner of the Open division of the 2010 'Sunday star-times' Short Story Awards."

Author: "Hume, Tim,"
Title: "Rewarding the early bird"
description: "Discusses the plan to turn NZ into an international financial service hub. Talks to Hugh Stevens, head of BNP Paribas NZ and member of the development group investigating the proposal."

Author: "Gilchrist, Shane"
Title: "Pole dancing"
description: "Previews the 1889 light opera showing at the Mayfair Theatre, Dundedin,  6-11 November, and at the Oamaru Opera House, 13 November. Talks to director Alan Spencer about his career in musical theatre and his expertise in Gilbert and Sullivan operas."

Author: "Mackenzie, Dene"
Title: "Ageing NZ burden for GDP; Saving : what the experts say"
description: "Highlights concerns raised by ratings agency Standard and Poor's (S&P) in their report 'Global ageing 2010: New Zealand' that the ageing population in NZ and Australia could create future spending pressures on governments and undermine the long-term fiscal position of both countries. Asks three savings specialists (Damian Foster, Forsyth Barr Kiwisaver specialist; Craig Myles, Myles Wealth Management principal; Peter Smith, Kepler Group principal) why S&P's claims should be taken seriously."

Author: "McMurran, Alistair"
Title: "Ingram sets eyes firmly on prize"
description: "Ingram sets eyes firmly on prize"

Author: "Porteous, Debbie"
Title: "Making a drama is always a drama"
description: "Looks at what the film industry is worth to Otago. Asks local film and tourism figures how NZ losing Peter Jackson's The Hobbit films would affect the region."

Author: "Hubbard, Anthony"
Title: "Pilgrimage to middle earth"
description: "Examines the influence the Lord of the Rings movies have had on attracting tourists to NZ. Briefly compares the tourism benefits of hosting the Olympic Games to hosting movie productions."

Author: "Katterns, Tanya"
Title: "Another crash haunts brother of injured teen"
description: "Another crash haunts brother of injured teen"

Author: "Dungey, Kim"
Title: "For your edification"
description: "Talks to the publishers of a new walking guide, Architecture Dunedin, which features the stories behind Dunedin's architecture. Notes the 44-page booklet, which features some 70 buildings, will be distributed free. Comments on the depth and breadth of architectural styles in the central city."

Author: "Cook Marjorie"
Title: "Going west"
description: "Recounts the life of Dinny Nolan and his campaign to get the Haast Pass road between Central Otago and Westland completed."

Author: "McLean, Elspeth"
Title: "Could cardiac model solve neuro debate?"
description: "Ponders whether the dispute over neurosurgery services in the South Island could be solved by following a model used in the 1990s to determine a similar issue over the location of cardiac services in Otago and Southland. Talks to cardiac surgeon Richard Brunton about the pivotal role played by David Caygill."

Author: "Cook, Marjorie"
Title: "The Haast travellers' tales"
description: "Talks with Greymouth's Les McKenzie, Haast farmer John Cowan and Betty Eggeling on the eve of the 50th anniversary of the opening of the Haast road. Records their memories and associations with the area and the building of the road. Lists some of the planned events as part of the 50th anniversary."

Author: "Woulfe, Catherine"
Title: "Unchained melodies"
description: "Talks to the Melbourne-based NZ singer-songwriter about her music."

Author: "Cumming, Geoffrey"
Title: "A question of scale"
description: "Discusses the decision by the NZ fishing industry to increase catches in two vulnerable fisheries and the international backlash. Covers the state of orange roughy and hoki stocks in NZ. Looks at the impact and rationale of NZ's quota management system (QMS)."

Author: "Kay, Martin"
Title: "Serious burns didn't stop rescue hero"
description: "Serious burns didn't stop rescue hero"

Author: "Gilchrist, Shane"
Title: "Conjuring a spell or two"
description: "Reviews the debut album Spells by Auckland songwriter Claire Duncan, otherwise known as Dear Time's Waste."

Author: "Hart, Anna"
Title: "Couplier than thou"
description: "Discusses the status of couples as a social unit and the growing pressure to be the perfect couple. Talks about couple ranking and competitive 'coupledom', or the need to demonstrate a perfect relationship especially on social media sites."

Author: "Williscroft, Colin"
Title: "Satisfaction in repair job well done"
description: "Interviews heritage stonemason Keith Hinds about his career as a stonemason and identifies the skills required."

Author: "Jones, Nicholas"
Title: "Fly guys"
description: "Meets some pigeon-racing enthusiasts from the Henderson Racing Pigeon Club in West Auckland. Talks about the decline of the sport in NZ."

Author: "Murray, Sarah"
Title: "Way back when"
description: "Recalls some memories from around the time a photograph was taken of the fashion entrepreneur in Tatuanui, Morrinsville, 1993."

Author: "Smithies, Grant"
Title: "First Ladi"
description: "Talks to Karoline Tamati about the her new album."

Author: "McCrone, John"
Title: "Hub of the nation"
description: "Reports on author's weeklong visit to the parliament building. Mentions the day-to-day programme of the process of parliament and its MP's. Tells of authors visit to most of the MP's chambers including Prime Minister John Key's office."

Author: "Vandervis, Lee"
Title: "Influence a mayoralty option"
description: "Asks the question whether the role of mayor is largely a ceremonial figurehead or a critical player in all the activities of local government? Illustrates his point of view with the operation of Dunedin City Council and the executive power invested in the role of mayor."

Author: "Harris, Anthony"
Title: "Wasp adapted to its prey"
description: "Describes the characteristics, habitat and life cycle of the beetle predator Podagritus parrotti."

Author: "Fox, Rebecca"
Title: "Kiwi : Orokonui move will raise profile"
description: "Looks at the bird on which we base our national identity, on the eve of the release of about eight Haast tokoeka in the Orokonui Ecosanctuary. Describes the Haast tokoeka and highlights the different types of kiwi on a map."

Author: "Harrison, Pete"
Title: "Plastics ingredient linked to gender abnormalities in boys"
description: "Reports on a study that focuses on a group of chemical known as phthalates, six of which have been virtually banned in toys in the European Union since 1999 over fears they can damage the sexual development of children. Phthalates are a range of chemicals regularly used to make plastics more flexible and occur in a wide range of industrial and domestic products. Reports on the possible connection between impaired male fertility and phthalates and the banning them from particular products (cosmetics and paints). Discusses how phthalates enters the human body and the current process on how to decide which of these chemicals need to be withdrawn from the manufacture of plastics."

Author: "Price, Mark"
Title: "Pleased to be of service"
description: "Talks to the former MP, mayor and councillor about the rough and tumble of a public life. Includes a fact file on his career."

Title: "Answering the call : stories in stone"
description: "Uses a grave in Dunedin's Northern Cemetery to profile the electrical engineer who moved to NZ from Scotland in 1875."

Author: "Dungey, Kim"
Title: "Not shaking with fear"
description: "Talks to a Parkinson's patient, in the lead up to Parkinson's Awareness Week, about how it affects her daily life and her attitude towards it. Includes a list of facts about the neuro-degenerative condition."

Author: "Price, Mark"
Title: "Uniform of a traitor"
description: "Talks to author Adrian Weale about NZer Lance Corporal Roy Courlander, who toured prisoner of war camps throughout Germany and Austria, gathering recruits on behalf on the Waffen-SS. Casts light on a group of six Maori soldiers who "volunteered" to join the British Free Corps who fought alongside the Germans against the communist Soviet Union. Highlights a corps uniform that could be somewhere in NZ."

Author: "Stone, Andrew"
Title: "Sportwriter's secrets no longer 'on tour'"
description: "Profiles the sports journalist and author. Discusses his biography, which reveals his affair with a South African politician, and talks about some of his other (32) books. Speaks to son Jock McLean about the decision to include family secrets in the book, his father's numerous by-lines, and his scoop on All Black Keith Murdoch. Provides biographical material on the McLean family."

Author: "Gilchrist, Shane"
Title: "Living with a lost child"
description: "Talks to the director about her debut feature film and how, although it might deal with bleak subject matter, at its heart is a tale of human resilience."

Author: "Reid, Neil"
Title: "Capill having therapy for sex offending but must stay in jail"
description: "Capill having therapy for sex offending but must stay in jail"

Title: "Officer who knocked over biker named"
description: "Officer who knocked over biker named"

Author: "Donoghue, Tim"
Title: "Nine poachers convicted for 1182 paua"
description: "Nine poachers convicted for 1182 paua"

Author: "Wild, Jill"
Title: "Daily struggles are now daily joys for Felix"
description: "Daily struggles are now daily joys for Felix"

Title: "Teenage diver breaks her own NZ record by nearly 25 points"
description: "Teenage diver breaks her own NZ record by nearly 25 points"

Author: "Wood, Linda"
Title: "Captain TJ caps off a great year"
description: "Captain TJ caps off a great year"

Author: "Wood, Linda"
Title: "Weenink sets her sights on under-21 team selection"
description: "Weenink sets her sights on under-21 team selection"

Author: "Carpinter, Bernard"
Title: "Bamber drives off with the top prizes in China"
description: "Bamber drives off with the top prizes in China"

Author: "Van Beynen, Martin"
Title: "Power struggle"
description: "Tells of the Mokihinui River and the approval being granted for Meridian Energy to build a dam on the Mokihinui River, on the West Coast. Mentions Department of Conservation (DOC), Forest & Bird and Whitewater NZ are appealing and the Environment Court is expected to hear the case in 2012. Reports of the environmental impact, and the importance of power supply to the West Coast the proposed dam will have, as well as the dam giving Southerners the freedom from relying on Northern supply."

Author: "Benson, Nigel"
Title: "Three of five new laureates have Otago links"
description: "Announces the 2010 Arts Foundation Laureates Awards, held in Dunedin for the first time. Notes three of the recipients who are from Dunedin: actor Stuart Devenie, choreographer Michael Parmenter, and cinematographer Leon Narbey. Mentions the other recipients, composer Gareth Farr and ceramicist John Parker. Describes briefly the nature of the awards and this year's selection panel."

Author: "Smith, Charmian"
Title: "A pioneer in pinot noir"
description: "Talks to the wine grower about his book chronicling the 30-year story of how he and his wife Helen (Brady) moved from journalism and the city life to rural grape growing and wine making. Comments on the advantages of cooperating with other southern grape growers, the magical feel of the Gibbston area in Central Otago, and three wine companies he has founded."

Title: "Obituary: Christchurch punk pioneer inspired many"
description: "Tells the life of Anthony (Tony) Peake, who died in Adelaide from cancer. Reports on his move from Adelaide to Christchurch at the age of 25, and his love for all kinds of music especially punk."

Author: "Gibb, John"
Title: "Researchers don't sugar the pill"
description: "Reports on the work of University of Otago biochemist Associate Professor Tony Merriman on the genetic risk factors of gout in the NZ population. Comments on the high levels of fructose in foods, especially soft drinks, and related health problems. Notes the massive amounts of sugar and fructose now consumed in NZ, and explains some of their effects on the body."

Author: "Stevenson, Rebecca"
Title: "HR solutions put the user first"
description: "Talks to entrepreneur Donald Hastie and his ERMLive business launched in 2006. Tells of Donald's wanting to create human-resources software solutions with a key component, a focus on the user."

Author: "Smith, Charmian"
Title: "Driven by her passion"
description: "Speaks to the 2010 Burns Fellow at the University of Otago about her career in dance, her studies in law, and now her need to write, following a master's degree in creative writing at Auckland University. Explains the 'Fabo' internet writing project she is involved with and how her other stories come about. Touches on the novel she is writing, following her first title, Weathered bones. Mentions she is working on a collaboration of words and dance with Suzanne Cowan."

Author: "Fox, Rebecca"
Title: "Award for passion that spans 20 years"
description: "Award for passion that spans 20 years"

Author: "Gibb, John"
Title: "Therapy hope for paralysis"
description: "Reports on a new drug therapy discovered by University of Otago and American researchers that could help restore mobility to stroke victims. Notes the study results were published in the on-line edition of Nature. Explains the state of the drug's development, its side effects, and the new information it reveals about brain function."

Author: "Hunter, Tim"
Title: "Conflicting stories"
description: "Tells of Forsyth Barr having been the lead manager (salesman for an issuer of stock) and investing twice as much assets in securities that have now been written off, namely Credit Sails, South Canterbury Finance and Strategic Finance."

Author: "Eleven, Beck"
Title: "Majorly gay"
description: "Profiles four gay and lesbian military personnel on life in the NZDF (New Zealand Defence Force). Mentions DEFGLIS NZ (Defence Force Gay and Lesbian Information Service) being formed to advise subordinates or newly enlisted people wondering about the best way to break their news to colleagues."

Author: "Davidson, Meg"
Title: "It really is as easy as riding a bike; Biking for beginners : Leith Valley"
description: "Shares some tips for adults who are learning to ride a bicycle from scratch. Includes information on cardiovascular fitness. Describes a cycle route in the Leith Valley."

Author: "Easton, Paul"
Title: "A trim, or short back and sides?; Animal love tail a feline start to drama career"
description: "Reports on changes to be made to the 2011 edition of the annual fringe festival, including the decision to abolish the Fringe Festival Awards, raise the entry fee and hire a new event management firm, The Conference Company. Seeks comment from Fringe Arts Trust chairwoman Miranda Clayton, Footnote Dance director Deirdre Tarrant, former festival publicist Phil Reed and Wellington mayor Celia Wade-Brown. Sums up key events since the first festival in 1990. Talks to the actress who staged the original play 'A Love Tail' at the 2010 festival."

Author: "Hartevelt, John"
Title: "Howard tells of his role in reviving Anzac friendship"
description: "Talks to former Australian prime minister John Howard. Reflects on the last decade of the Anzac relationship and his working relationships with former NZ prime minister Helen Clark and former US president George W. Bush. Includes excerpts from his new book 'John Howard : Lazarus rising'."

Author: "Chug, Kiran"
Title: "Pressure builds to make any day an eDay"
description: "Talks to Lawrence Zwimpfer, the organiser of eDay, to be held this year on 6 Nov 2010. Informs that the event is now in its fourth year of collecting and recycling electronic waste. Talks to him about his concerns that the success of the event might actually be causing damage by creating an expectation that the region is solving its e-waste problems. Seeks comment from Martyn Pinckard of the Ministry for the Environment about the Waste Minimisation Fund and its plans for a long-term solution for electronic waste."

Author: "Sharpe, Marty"
Title: "Frontier town 'still a great place to live'; A former gang man recalls the violence behind town's earlier bid clear its path; Visitors ask : where are the marauding gangs?"
description: "Reports on renewed violence between the Mongrel Mob and Black Power gangs in the district that is prompting leaders to consider whether to seek a ban on gang patches. Talks to Ali Hole and Geoff Hole, the proprietors of the Gaiety Theatre, about their impressions of the township and the changes that have occurred over the past 50 years. Seeks comment from other residents including the senior sergeant, the rural hospital doctor, the deputy mayor, Wairoa College principal Brian Simpson and cafe owner Angie Whitworth. Includes demographic and other information about the district. Talks to the former Black Power member, now a chef, about his time in the gang during the 1980s and his decision to leave the town after a shootout between the two gangs in 1988 resulted in the deaths of two cousins. Lists other instances of gang-related violence since 1988."

Author: "Anderson, Vicki"
Title: "Driving miss crazy"
description: "Tells about author riding around Christchurch with taxi driver who tells of true confessions of individuals who ride in his taxi from gangsters and hookers to communists and lesbian catfights."

Author: "Nichols, Lane"
Title: "From a trickle to a torrent; Repaired house failed and had to be fixed all over again"
description: "Investigates the extent of leaky building problems in the city, including high-profile cases such as luxury apartments and Westpac Stadium. Talks to lawyer Dan Parker and to Greg Orchard and Steve Cody of the Wellington City Council about how the situation occurred and what is being done by the council, the Government and others to remedy the problems. Speaks to John Gray, president of the Home Owners and Buyers Assn, about the shortcomings of the Financial Assistance Package offered by central Government, and his own experiences of a leaky home in Auckland."

Author: "Hewitson, Michele"
Title: "Richard O'Brien"
description: "Interviews the creator of The Rocky Horror Picture Show about his return to NZ, where he was raised, to narrate the show. Discusses his reaction to celebrity status, his sexuality, the Frank-N-Furter character in the show, family, and his feelings about love."

Author: "Fox, Andrea"
Title: "A crying shame"
description: "Talks to the Chinese national, who is also a NZ citizen, about her role in the Chinese-backed bid to buy the Crafar farming empire out of receivership through her company Natural Dairy. Discusses her business career and the 'unwise' choices that have led to charges under the Companies Act for the collapse of property investor Dynasty Group and the Serious Fraud Office probe into the Crafar bid."

Author: "Van der Stoep, Leigh"
Title: "Widower's 'hatred' for man who hit picnickers"
description: "Widower's 'hatred' for man who hit picnickers"

Author: "Lewis, Rebecca"
Title: "Answers on missing yachtie have to wait for two weeks"
description: "Answers on missing yachtie have to wait for two weeks"

Author: "Macdonald, Nikki"
Title: "On the tip of his tongue"
description: "Presents a brief profile of French author Yann Apperry, who has recently taken up a five-month residence at Randell Cottage, Thorndon."

Author: "Cumming, Geoffrey"
Title: "Mission to save the city"
description: "Talks to the heritage building advocate about his seven-year campaign to protect Auckland historic architecture.  Names the old Kauri Timber Co building and other structures he has helped save from demolition. Explains why he sees kaitiakitanga (guardianship) as important and financially viable. Notes his architectural background, his devotion to preservation, and his active relationship with the city council. Discusses the council's points system for evaluating building protection."

Author: "Rothwell, Kimberley"
Title: "Soldiers of fortune"
description: "Focuses on the award-winning TV3 comedy-drama that is coming to an end on 9 Nov 2010 after six seasons. Talks to co-creator Rachel Lang, television reviewer Jane Bowron and lead actress Robyn Malcolm, and characters Siobhan Marshall, Antonia Prebble, Tammy Davis, Antony Starr and Shane Cortese about the enduring popularity of the show and what it means to NZers. Discusses their characters and the actors' future plans. Includes a list of 'Top ten outrageous moments' by Dominion Post TV critic Jane Bowron."

Author: "Cardy, Tom"
Title: "Beautiful dreamer"
description: "Talks to the film-maker about his soon-to-be-published 'semi-memoir', written with Lani-rain Feltham and Louis Nowra. Informs that the book also serves as a visual chronicle of his work."

Author: "Grunwell, Rachel"
Title: "Principal faces 64 fraud counts"
description: "Principal faces 64 fraud counts"

Author: "Barnett, Shaun"
Title: "Harbour cruise"
description: "Explores the harbour via sea kayak with Wellington historian Chris Maclean. Focuses on the history of Matiu/Somes Island."

Author: "Barton, Chris"
Title: "Family counts the cost of ageing"
description: "Reports on the family of Anne (Eileen) Harper who filed a complaint about the level of care the 100-year-old woman received from a Tauranga rest home, Cedar Manor.  Cites comments from Green MP Sue Kedgley about her concerns over staff shortages in the aged care sector. Considers the vagueness of General Standards for rest homes. Reviews the health care given and notes the difficulty in diagnosing scabies. Provides statistics on aged care in NZ."

Author: "Collins, Simon"
Title: "Cheaper ACC with a catch"
description: "Announces a consultation document by the Accident Compensation Corporation (ACC) that proposes a reduction in taxpayer benefits in exchange for lower annual levies. Reminds of the law change this year that gives ACC the power to vary employer levies according to their accident record."

Author: "Morton, Frances"
Title: "Making their mark"
description: "Examines the mainstreaming of tattoos in society, with a move away from the domain of sailors, convicts and tribal leaders. Talks to people involved in the tattooing industry, including tattoo artist Dan Smith who stars on the reality television show 'LA ink', about the changing clientele, and to some of the new clients such as Ellen Harris, a Ngaruawahia grandmother, who got her first tattoo at the age of 71. Points out the downside of tattoos, talking to Dr Michael Lamont, CEO of the Mangere Community Health Trust, about tattoo removals. Briefly outlines the history of tattooing and tattoo mistakes some celebrities have made."

Author: "Johnston, Martin"
Title: "Clients feel pain of ACC cuts"
description: "Reports on Accident Compensation Corporation (ACC) cutbacks on health treatment and the consequent drop in spending on claims. Documents the concerns of advocates who believe ACC's decision making is flawed. Notes government acknowledgement that cutbacks will increase public hospital surgery waiting lists. Quotes Labour Party views that the restrictions are excessive, describing the case of a rocksaw operator who has been turned down for a hearing aid subsidy."

Author: "Christian, Dionne"
Title: "Amusing ourselves to death"
description: "Preview the plays 'Little white men', written by Joel Herbert and performed by Outfit Theatre Company,  at the Basement Theatre, 8-13 November; 'The idea of America', by Sam Shore, at Tapac, Western Springs, 10-14 November; and 'Passage', by Fiona Graham, at Herald Theatre, 11-20 November."

Author: "Phare, Jane"
Title: "Guilt and loathing in a small town"
description: "Recalls the events of the Aramoana massacre twenty years on from the killing of 13 people by gunman David Gray. Talks to survivor Julie-Anne Tamati (then Bryson) about her experience of the massacre and the guilt she feels surrounding the deaths, and to Mike Kyne, one of the anti-terrorist squad members who shot Gray."

Author: "McNamara, T. J."
Title: "Ambitious foray into white interior"
description: "Reviews 'Modern standards' by Peter Robinson, Sue Crockford Gallery, Auckland, until 8 November 2010. Reviews 'Living halls' by Fiona Jack and 'Lava' by Mark Adams, at Two Rooms, Auckland, until 13 November 2010. Reviews 'Something/nothing' by Allan McDonald, Anna Miles Gallery, Auckland, until 20 November 2010. Reviews 'Mall' by Ruth Cleland and 'Attempts at imperfection' by Simon Esling, Gus Fisher Gallery, Auckland,until 27 November 2010."

Title: "Flavour burst"
description: "Reviews the cookbook showcasing the diversity and quality of food in NZ. Includes two recipes from the book."

Author: "Dart, William"
Title: "Contralto brings her special style to Bach"
description: "Talks to contralto Kate Spence who is singing in the Auckland Choral performance of Bach's Mass in B Minor, 6 November 2010. Touches on some of her operatic roles."

Author: "Falconer, Phoebe"
Title: "Dapper frontman had comic streak"
description: "Dapper frontman had comic streak"

Author: "Yeoman, Paula"
Title: "Charity begins at home"
description: "Talks to singer-songwriter Monique Rhodes about the release of  'So this is Christmas', an album of well-known carols covered by NZ musicians for charity. Reviews two other albums."

Author: "Cone, Deborah Hill"
Title: "School of rap, Dunedin style"
description: "Reviews the new reality televion series that aims to turn some Dunedin high school students into hip-hop stars."

Author: "Janssen, Peter"
Title: "Walk this way"
description: "Extract from a book by Peter Janssen, describing ten of the 200 NZ walks featured in his work."

Author: "Smith, Jacqueline"
Title: "What 'Fortune' told us"
description: "Previews the final instalment of the NZ television drama. Chronicles the show's six-year success. Solicits academic views on the culture and stereotypes it portrays. Notes the opening of an exhibition at Auckland Museum based on the drama. Presents lessons that co-creator Rachel Lang says may be learnt from the West Auckland sub-culture."

Author: "Calder, Peter"
Title: "Aligning his stars"
description: "Speaks to film-maker Michael Bennett before the screening of his film in November 2010. Explains why he was inspired by Otara, South Auckland, as a setting, and why he chose a multistrand narrative to convey the stories he wrote with co-writer Gavin Strawhan. Touches on the film's genesis."

Author: "Kara, Scott"
Title: "Take you back to Myspace"
description: "Notifies of a revamp of the social network site. Reports on its popularity with local bands and its emphasis on discovery and discussion of cultural trends, especially entertainment. Compares the website to Facebook. Reviews briefly the Mubi application which collects independent and festival movies and enables fans to chat to each other."

Author: "Hill, Rebecca Barry."
Title: "Heart-throbs and happy endings"
description: "Details a meeting between a literary agent and aspiring romance author Soraya Nicholas, organised by the Romance Writers of NZ (RWNZ) at their annual conference. Cites tips from Natalie Anderson, who writes for the Mills & Boon Harlequin Sexy Sensation line and USA Today. Enumerates the market share of romance books in the US. Describes RWNZ President Abby Gaines' ideas about what makes a good romance and the difficulty of writing one. Asks some authors why they write in this genre."

Author: "Dudding, Adam"
Title: "The heat is on; Freeze frame"
description: "Investigates the pitfalls of celebrity endorsement of products or services, considering the risks in terms of damaged reputations to both the company and the endorser when the product becomes the subject of criticism or has unsubstantiated claims exposed. Looks especially at the endorsement of the breast cancer screening tool, clinical thermography, by former marathon champion Allison Roe, and the objections expressed by doctors and mainstream breast cancer organisations. Points to other celebrity endorsement highs and lows over the past decade, both in NZ and overseas.   Relates the experience of undergoing clinical thermography."

Author: "Hubbard, Anthony"
Title: "Heroes of the small screen"
description: "Speaks to managing director of Auckland-based computer graphics company Oktobor Animation, Bruce Everett, and to computer graphics boss of US children's television network Nickelodeon, Dean Hoff, about the NZ company's contract to provide the digital work on the network's 'The Penguins of Madagascar' series.  Talks about the advantages of using Kiwi digital expertise both in TV and in movies."

Author: "Hill, Rebecca Barry."
Title: "Home sweet home"
description: "Talks to John Walsh about his book in which he interviews 23 NZ architects and explores, in collaboration with photographer Patrick Reynolds, the houses they build for themselves. Delves into the typical architect personality."

Author: "Green, Paula,"
Title: "Childhood lends setting for tale"
description: "Childhood lends setting for tale"

Author: "McCrystal, John"
Title: "Enter into the spirit of suspended belief"
description: "Enter into the spirit of suspended belief"

Author: "Corry, Lucy"
Title: "What I do"
description: "The ice cream delivery man for Tip Top describes a typical day."

Author: "Murray, Sarah"
Title: "See ya, city"
description: "Chats to four former city-dwelling women who have opted for a quieter life in the country about their lifestyle choices."

Author: "Laugesen, Ruth"
Title: "Too hot to handle"
description: "Discusses research findings on the health effects of a lack of vitamin D, and the difficulty of reconciling this with NZ's high rate of melanoma. Talks to epidemiologists Robert Scragg (University of Auckland) and Brian Cox (University of Otago) about the uncertainty of the links between low vitamin D and disorders such as colorectal cancer, cardiovascular disease and other chronic illnesses, noting recommendations from the Cancer Society on sun exposure and changes in people's behaviour. Talks to dermatologist Louise Reiche on her advice on optimum exposure, and notes holes and disagreements about knowledge on sun exposure and vitamin D fortification as well as upcoming research projects. Gives a case study of a melanoma survivor and statistics on the incidence of the cancer.  Lists the Cancer Society's new recommendations on sun exposure."

Author: "McKenzie, Hamish"
Title: "It's getting better"
description: "Reports on a YouTube channel supporting gay teens, often in danger of bullying and suicide. Describes how it was developed by American columnist Dan Savage and its reception overseas. Looks at bullying of gay teens in NZ and gives the reaction of Thomas Hamilton of Rainbow Youth to the project."

Author: "Gribben, Trish"
Title: "The light in their eyes"
description: "Reports on a Cambodian eye clinic restoring sight to charity patients with the help of three Kiwis - optometrists John Veal and Mike Webber and ophthalmologist David Sabiston. Describes their trips to Phnom Penh with Rose Charities NZ and the work done, sometimes under trying conditions. Looks at the ophthalmologist care in Cambodia and the effects of the clinic, describing its history and conditions and briefly profiling Cambodian doctor Hang Vra. Describes the ongoing work of Rose Charities."

Author: "Lomas, David"
Title: "Fighting for Haane"
description: "Recounts in detail the story of the capture by Sergeant Haane Manahi of the Takrouna Pinnacle in Tunisia, 19 May 1943, the recommendations that he be awarded a Victoria Cross (VC) for this and the downgrading of this to a Distinguished Conduct Medal (DCM). Talks to Paul Moon, author of a new book on the subject, on why Manahi was denied a VC, noting the actions of Maori Battalion Second Lieutenant Moana Ngarimu a few weeks earlier for which he was awarded a VC and relaying Moon's dismissal of claims of war crimes committed during Manahi's assault."

Author: "De Lacy, Hugh"
Title: "'Floating on a sea of oil'"
description: "Explains how hydrocarbons lurking beneath our recently expanded exclusive economic zone (EEZ) could make NZ the richest country on earth. Mentions overseas companies OMV, Anadarko and Petrobas as exploring for hydrocarbons in and around NZ."

Author: "Hutching, Chris"
Title: "Ironies in foreign ownership debate"
description: "Compares National and Labour's stand on foreign ownership of land. Outlines sales of farmlands from the latest Real Estate Institute rural market report."

Title: "Changes proposed for investment regime"
description: "Outlines changes to NZ's overseas investment regime and looks at how it works."

Author: "Lynch, Keith"
Title: "Cyclist dies on familiar corner"
description: "Cyclist dies on familiar corner"

Author: "Fletcher, Richard"
Title: "Business on the side proved a problem"
description: "Comments on the judgements made in 'Scott v Globe Holdings Ltd' [2010] (NZCA 431) over a breach of an exclusivity obligation contract. Discusses some of the principles involved in summary judgements and counter-claims."

Author: "Bradley, Antonio"
Title: "Prison guard faces corruption charges"
description: "Prison guard faces corruption charges"

Author: "Todd, Rebecca"
Title: "Short life gives rise to cookbook"
description: "Short life gives rise to cookbook"

Author: "Gilbert, Jo"
Title: "Pasifika pupils win top business award"
description: "Pasifika pupils win top business award"

Author: "McCrone, John"
Title: "Paradise found; Unexplored playground"
description: "Backgrounds the acquisition of St James Station in North Canterbury by the Government's Nature Heritage Fund and the plan to open it up to the public with very few restrictions. Talks to DOC (Department of Conservation) staff about the plans. Visits the St James Conservation Area to investigate."

Author: "Law, Tina"
Title: "The face of Canterbury public health"
description: "Presents an obituary for NZ's longest-serving medical officer of health."

Author: "Crean, Mike"
Title: "Fine soldier and fine New Zealander"
description: "Pays tribute to the retired army officer who fought for justice on behalf of those who served in Vietnam and were affected by Agent Orange."

Author: "Glass, Amy"
Title: "Dedicated Karamea couple married for 72 years"
description: "Presents an obituary for a devoted Karamea couple."

Author: "Oxenbridge, Faith"
Title: "Keeping it real"
description: "Reviews a stage play by Carl Nixon, directed by Greg Cooper, Court Theatre, Christchurch, until 27 Nov 2010."

Title: "Supporter of arts, lifelong volunteer"
description: "Presents an obituary for the former Canterbury resident and lifelong supporter of the arts."

Author: "Crean, Mike"
Title: "Bishop had a heart for the needy"
description: "Presents an obituary for the former Anglican Bishop of Christchurch."

Author: "Wood, Alan"
Title: "Nine varied lives of Black Cat's helmsman"
description: "Nine varied lives of Black Cat's helmsman"

Author: "Wallace, Neal"
Title: "Time nigh for meat co-ops' high noon; Farmers getting in behind their co-operatives"
description: "Highlights the continued antipathy between the Dunedin- and Invercargill-based meat co-operatives over a potential merger. Overviews the situation and reports that farmers appear to be entrenching themselves in support of their respective companies. Suggests that it is time for shareholders to force the issue one way or the other."

Author: "Fox, Andrea"
Title: "A crying shame"
description: "Talks to the Chinese national, who is also a NZ citizen, about her role in the Chinese-backed bid to buy the Crafar farming empire out of receivership through her company Natural Dairy. Discusses her business career and the 'unwise' choices that have led to charges under the Companies Act for the collapse of property investor Dynasty Group and the Serious Fraud Office probe into the Crafar bid."

Author: "Fox, Andrea"
Title: "Wang's Crafar deal 'served up over meal'"
description: "Backgrounds the May Wang fronted Chinese-backed Natural Dairy bid to buy the in-receivership Crafar family farming estate, providing a breakdown of the key points and dates."

Author: "Price, Mark"
Title: "Move over Avatar; Taking the chief home; The eyes have it for 3-D"
description: "Talks to Wanaka-based film-maker Rachael Wilson about the process of making a 3-D documentary film about the now-deceased 108-year-old chief of Yakel Village, Tanna Island, Vanuatu. Discusses the changes to the once-isolated village as a result of increased civilisation. Informs that the film might be the first NZ feature-length 3-D film and may be completed by the end of 2010. Speaks to Graham McArthur of the Video Factory, Dunedin, about the specific post-production challenges of 3-D films."

Author: "McCarthy, David"
Title: "Timing, luck keys to wins : Nyhan"
description: "Timing, luck keys to wins : Nyhan"

Author: "Price, Mark"
Title: "Keeping them honest"
description: "Profiles the most prolific letter writer to the Otago Daily Times. Focuses on his persistent criticism of decisions taken by the Dunedin City Council over the past decade."

Author: "Vine, Geoffrey"
Title: "'Inside story' of botched investigation adds little; Dying man's sweet and sour, whispers and growls"
description: "'Inside story' of botched investigation adds little; Dying man's sweet and sour, whispers and growls"

Author: "Gilchrist, Shane"
Title: "From strike to thunder"
description: "Talks to Invercargill-raised, Dunedin-based brothers and 'sonic explorers' Adam Falconer and Rob Falconer about the release of their debut album 'III', released by Monkey Killer Records on vinyl and via download."

Author: "Eleven, Beck"
Title: "Beauty and the beasts"
description: "Looks at the preparation and grooming of animals competing at the Canterbury A&P (Agricultural & Pastoral) Show."

Author: "Bruce, David"
Title: "Chosen by a job she could relate to"
description: "Interviews the TrustPower community relations representative for the South Island about her job."

Author: "Anderson, Vicki"
Title: "Horse sense"
description: "Talks to horse trainer Stan Moore about his hope of having a horse in the NZ Trotting Cup for the first time with nine-year-old gelding Fake Chance (also known as Herbie)."

Author: "Croot, James"
Title: "Father's plunge into despair avoids melodrama"
description: "Reviews the film that relocates British author Stephen Blanchard's 'The paraffin child' to the west of Auckland."

Author: "Wallace, Neal"
Title: "Scientist says rewards from genetic research are huge"
description: "Profiles the Southland-raised scientist at AgResearch, Invermay. Overviews his career at AgResearch and elsewhere, and describes his contributions to genetic-based research that have resulted in productivity gains for farm livestock."

Author: "Ash, Julie"
Title: "Pilgrims flock to shrine in Wainui backyard"
description: "Reveals the find of a statue of the Indian saint Sai Baba of Shirdi (1836-1918), among other objects, in the backyard of Wainuiomata resident John Peters. Describes how the discovery has sparked the building of a shrine that is now visited by devotees worldwide."

Author: "Newton, Kate"
Title: "The real truth about the people's paper"
description: "Talks to former staff member Redmer Yska about the 'Truth', liquidated in 2009, and the book he has written about the newspaper's 100-year history. Describes the weekly's influence on NZ journalism. Recounts well-known NZers who worked there, the political crusades of certain editors, and the 'revelation' that alienated many readers. Accounts for the paper's eventual decline."

Title: "'I want him shamed and named and put away'"
description: "Speaks to two sexually abused people who shun anonymity, and why they do so. Describes how the experience shaped their lives, their feelings towards their abusers, their emphasis on speaking out, and their views on healing and justice. Cites the comments of Brenda Cheyne about the need for rapists to recover, as well as rape victims. Profiles one abuser, Allan Davis, who died in February this year. Contains a brief list of the lessons learned by one of the victims, and places to go for help."

Author: "Dann, Julie"
Title: "Diver survives brush with stingray"
description: "Diver survives brush with stingray"

Author: "Reid, Neil"
Title: "Booze ban would hit grassroots funding"
description: "Looks into the SPARC 2010 scoping study, 'Alcohol and sport', that questions the liquor industry's close ties with sport and the warning that banning alcohol sponsorship of sport will put the future of many clubs at risk."

Author: "Smith, Jacqueline"
Title: "How the West was won"
description: "Previews the final instalment of the NZ television drama. Chronicles the show's six-year success. Solicits academic views on the culture and stereotypes it portrays. Notes the opening of an exhibition at Auckland Museum based on the drama. Presents lessons that co-creator Rachel Lang says may be learnt from the West Auckland sub-culture."

Author: "Morton, Frances"
Title: "Building a supercity"
description: "Considers wish lists from a number of leading Aucklanders including Len Brown looking at what they would like to see in the new supercity."

Author: "Smith, Charmian"
Title: "Material progress"
description: "Talks to the textile artist and curator about her career as a tapestry weaver. Informs of her exhibition 'Margery Blackman : Woven tapestries 1976-2010', Brett McDowell Gallery, Dunedin, 12-25 Nov 2010."

Author: "Chug, Kiran"
Title: "1080 : is it too toxic to last?"
description: "Documents the recent two-day drop of 1080 in the Tararua Forest Park, citing Department of Conservation (DOC) reasons for its continued use in the control of pests that threaten native bird life. Notes the drop in TB-infected animals. Presents arguments for banning the poison. Describes alternative pest control methods, including the use of the preservative sodium nitrite, and fertility-reducing biocontrols. Explains what 1080 is."

Author: "Dignan, James"
Title: "Art seen"
description: "Reviews 'Provisioning' by Jenna Packer, Milford Galleries Dunedin, until 24 Dec 2010. Reviews 'Wind shadows' by Angela Burns, Gallery De Novo, Dunedin, until 18 Nov 2010. Reviews 'Outside the Octagon' by various artists, The Artist's Room, Dunedin."

Title: "Suicide message killed by jailhouse rock ban"
description: "Suicide message killed by jailhouse rock ban"

Author: "Schouten, Hank,"
Title: "Former teacher had an inspiringly positive outlook"
description: "Former teacher had an inspiringly positive outlook"

Author: "Marshall, Jonathan"
Title: "The king of the crime lawyers loses own case"
description: "The king of the crime lawyers loses own case"

Author: "Harvey, Sarah"
Title: "First democratic elections risk unsettling balance in Tonga; Power to the people"
description: "Discusses the upcoming democratic elections in Tonga. Backgrounds the historical nature of the elections for the Tongan people. Talks to parliamentary candidate Posesi Bloomfield about what democracy means for Tongans. Touches on the growing concern that violence may occur in Tonga as the balance of power is threatened by the elections."

Author: "Macdonald, Nikki"
Title: "Inmates find hope in faith"
description: "Recounts a visit to NZ's only faith-based unit at Rimutaka Prison. Talks to some of the 60 self-supervised inmates there. Describes the unit's administration by Prison Fellowship (PFNZ), and outlines some of its activities and programmes, such as the post-release programme that pairs prisoners with volunteer mentors. Includes the stories of two inmates on this programme, and talks to volunteers. Touches on the recent death of unit founder Pat Lewis and its effect on some of the inmates."

Author: "Hembry, Owen"
Author (detailed): "Owen Hembry, Michael Dickison and Isaac Davison"
Title: "Billion-dollar crisis; Airborne pest could be hard to eradicate"
description: "Reports on the recent outbreak of Pseudomonas syringae pv. actinidiae (Psa), an airborne canker disease of kiwifruit vines that has been confirmed in several Te Puke orchards and suspected in other orchards. Talks to Zespri chief executive Lain Jager and general manager of supply chain Sally Gardiner about their initial response to news of the unexpected outbreak. Seeks comment from MAF Biosecurity director general Barry O'Neill, NZ Kiwifruit Growers Incorporated president Peter Ombler, and others in the kiwifruit and related industries. Informs that officials from MAF Biosecurity NZ are uncertain that the disease can be eradicated.  Speaks to Minister of Agriculture David Carter and plant pathologist John Young, who believes that Psa could have been in NZ for years."

Author: "Dudding, Adam"
Title: "Our bright sparks"
description: "Talks to Dr David Krofcheck, a senior physics lecturer at Auckland University, about the NZ involvement in the experiments conducted by the European Organization for Nuclear Research (CERN) using the Large Hadron Collider (LHC)."

Author: "Hartevelt, John"
Title: "'I'm never bored but you may be'"
description: "Speaks to Sir Geoffrey Palmer on the eve of his retirement as Law Commission president. Discusses his voluminous writing, his discomfort in politics, and his anxiety at the constitutional changes made by the current Government. Touches on his views of the United Nations, his extensive dealings in constitutional law, and his stormy relationship with National Party leader Jim Bolger. Notifies of an upcoming biography on the former prime minister and features several excerpts."

Author: "Knight, Kim,"
Title: "The big catch"
description: "Discusses the proposed closure of parts of the Pacific Ocean to purse seine fishing boats (boats with large nets that surround schools of fish and cinch at the bottom) catching tuna. Talks about NZ's role in the debate."

Author: "Hubbard, Anthony"
Title: "Spooky business"
description: "Talks to the author of a new book about the Truth newspaper and some of the 'exposes' it published about national security issues."

Author: "Stock, Rob"
Title: "Bringing out your inner cheesemaker"
description: "Talks to the founder of iMake (previously Brewcraft) about the company's move into DIY cheesemaking kits under the Mad Millie brand."

Author: "Dekker, Diana"
Title: "Out of the cold"
description: "Discusses the flights to the Antarctic over the last three decades by almost 50 NZ writers, artists, and journalists. Describes some of the creative works that have resulted. Illustrates how this body of work has transformed NZers' views of the continent. Informs the costs of such trips and who is in the 2010 contingent. Talks to past participants, ceramic artist Raewyn Atkinson and poet Chris Orsman."

Author: "Palmer, Rebecca"
Title: "Bold ambition"
description: "Interviews Chris Parkin about his various occupations as property developer, hotelier, Wellington city councillor, art collector and patron. Talks about his childhood, his bent for mechanical objects, and his preservation and refurbishing of the Museum Hotel. Notes his plans for a new National Art Gallery, describes his contribution to Wellington's cultural life, airs his strong capitalist leanings, and hints at his desire to help charities."

Author: "Johnston, Martin"
Title: "Ascent into history"
description: "Highlights an upcoming climbing expedition to Aoraki-Mt Cook by the duo to re-enact the experience of past explorers. Talks to the Coast-to-Coast champion (who will be using modern equipment) and the commercial flower grower and adventure racing competitor (who will be attired in historic gear). Describes previous attempts in the 19th century by those seeking to be the first to reach the summit of Aoraki, focusing on the many attempts made by the North Canterbury pair. Mentions other retro-style climbing expeditions in NZ and overseas."

Author: "Laxon, Andrew"
Title: "Failure is not an option with pass-for-cash scams; What's going wrong : critics speak out"
description: "Focuses on claims by whistle-blowers that some schools for overseas students are ''visa factories' offering fake qualifications for back-door immigrants'. Talks to current and former staff members at several institutions about the extent of the scam, and its implications for the reputation of the lucrative international education industry. Cites comments from Prof Chris Moore, Pro Vice-Chancellor of the Massey University School of Business about problems there with students arriving with fake diplomas. Reports that the Immigration Service is proposing policy changes to tighten standards, and describes changes that have occurred in Australia after the publication of a report into international education. Seeks views of critics about the main weaknesses of the current system."

Author: "Philp, Matt,"
Title: "Power play"
description: "Explores Tonga's move to switch to solar energy. Notes the assistance from the NZ Aid programme, Meridian Energy, and the International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA), which supports the local government's 10-year initiative (Tonga Energy Road Map) to cut reliance on diesel by 50% in three years. Cites the comments of retiring Prime Minister Fred Vaka'uta Sevele on his support for the project. Describes a successful solar-powered resort on Fafa Island."

Author: "Gilchrist, Shane"
Title: "A novel approach"
description: "Talks to the emeritus professor of politics at the University of Otago about his soon-to-be-published book, subtitled 'Around the world in 200 books'. Describes his aim to persuade people to read great works of literature, and suggests five books to start with. Mentions that he intends  that the book will be the first of a trilogy aimed at providing people with a breadth of knowledge. Touches on his international expertise in the field of intelligence."

Author: "Williamson, Cameron"
Title: "Endurance test"
description: "Chats to Kevin Biggar about his latest adventure book describing a 52-day trek to the South Pole with fellow adventurer Jamie Fitzgerald. Reflects on his boyhood in Levin, his career, the friendship-threatening events of the trip, and the lessons learned that fuel his success as a motivational speaker."

Author: "Price, Mark"
Title: "Search for traitor's uniform"
description: "Reports on the new book 'The SS : A new history' by British author Adrian Weale, which tells the story of Nazi sympathisers. Focuses on the NZ lance corporal who was court martialled for treason for gathering recruits in Germany and Austria on behalf of the SS. Raises the possibility that the SS uniform in which he was captured might be stashed in an NZ school or with a theatre group. Includes information about six unnamed Maori prisoners of war who volunteered to fight for the Germans but were turned down."

Author: "Hewitson, Michele"
Title: "Michele Hewitson interview : Ian Mune"
description: "Interviews the eccentric actor about his recently published autobiography."

Author: "Woulfe, Catherine"
Title: "The food fight"
description: "Explores the idea that we have become disconnected from our food, forgetting where it comes from, how to buy it, how to cook it, and even how to eat it. Talks to Rob Hamlin, a senior lecturer in food marketing at the University of Otago, about the growing hunger for information about food and the 'dirty tricks' played by marketers and retailers; product designer Elizabeth Vanderburg about the launch of her online nationwide farmer's market; chef Jamie Oliver about the joy of cooking; and Christchurch GP David Lovell-Smith about eating according to hunger, not mealtimes."

Author: "Kara, Scott"
Title: "A bird in the hand"
description: "Talks to the Christchurch-raised musician about his second album, comprising seven interpretations of bird songs written by the late Hirini Melbourne."

Author: "Crisp, Carlton"
Title: "Extreme snacking"
description: "Looks at the burgeoning subculture of junk food or snacking experimenters. Talks to a number of experimenters, including Englishman Pete Wilcox of PimpThatSnack.com, about extreme snacking. Provides photos of some of the experiments including a hamburger made out of cake and a giant Snickers bar."

Author: "Gifford, Adam"
Title: "Refusing to do the frangipani thing"
description: "Talks to the artist about his three recent residencies in Rarotonga, Taiwan and Titirangi, and their influence on his current work. Describes his current exhibition, which features multiple interchangeable panels, Whitespace, Auckland, to 27 Nov 2010."

Author: "McNamara, T. J."
Title: "Colour abstraction enchanting to the eye"
description: "Reviews 'Colour codes' by Sara Hughes, Gow Langsford Gallery, Auckland, to 27 Nov 2010.  Reviews 'You can't kill me I'm notorious' by Andre Hemer, Antoinette Godkin Gallery, Auckland, to 4 Dec 2010. Reviews 'Abundance' by Ann Robinson, FHE Galleries, Auckland, to 3 Dec 2010. Reviews 'Contxt' by Anah Dunsheath, Sanderson Contemporary Art, Auckland, to 21 Nov 2010."

Author: "Rae, Bernadette"
Title: "Top five come together for 21st bash"
description: "Reports that five of NZ's top choreographers are combining their talents in a celebration marking the 21st year of the contemporary dance programme at the institute. Traces the history of the programme and discusses the contributions of the choreographers."

Author: "Reed, Megan Nicol"
Title: "Hooked on a feeling"
description: "Talks to the TV and radio host about why he believes becoming wheelchair-bound because of multiple sclerous was the best thing that ever happened to him."

Author: "Dart, William"
Title: "Unseen art gives voice to concert halls' best"
description: "Talks to the Yorkshireman and two of his colleagues from Global Piano Services about the skill required to be a piano technician."

Author: "Kamm, Rebecca"
Title: "The drink that could"
description: "Investigates the origins of the NZ herbal drink Ch'i, 'the drink that knows its own name'."

Author: "Drinnan, John"
Title: "Riding high; Firm favourite a rising force at TVNZ"
description: "Talks to the long-time director about her career and influence. Explores reasons for her popularity with the current Government. Provides information about her life and her past and current directorships."

Author: "Murray, Sarah"
Title: "Way back when"
description: "Recalls some memories of the actress from around the time a photo was taken of her as a seven year old at Disneyland (California)."

Author: "Braunias, Steve"
Title: "Hut valley"
description: "Talks about the author's trip to Antarctica and visiting Discovery hut, one of three legendary huts built for the great Antarctic explorers Robert Falcon Scott and Ernest Shackleton in the 1900s. Mentions the photographic work of Jane Ussher and her new book 'Still life'."

Author: "Tapaleao, Vaimoana"
Title: "Bling fitting reward for devotion at death's door"
description: "Bling fitting reward for devotion at death's door"

Author: "Ihaka, James"
Title: "Cruise ship's plight beats NZ magician"
description: "Cruise ship's plight beats NZ magician"

Author: "Savage, Jared"
Title: "Drug kingpin's dole-queue cover"
description: "Drug kingpin's dole-queue cover"

Title: "Murderer saw marriage or flight as way out; The 111 calls"
description: "Murderer saw marriage or flight as way out; The 111 calls"

Author: "Tahana, Yvonne"
Title: "Don't blame my haka - composer hits back at critics"
description: "Don't blame my haka - composer hits back at critics"

Author: "Bennett, Adam"
Title: "Labour accuses top broadband official"
description: "Labour accuses top broadband official"

Author: "Irvine, Katherine"
Title: "Student's multifunctional garments on show"
description: "Student's multifunctional garments on show"

Author: "Thornton, Peter"
Title: "Multisport fanatics' incredible journey"
description: "Multisport fanatics' incredible journey"

Author: "Bridgeman, Shelley"
Title: "Facing the future"
description: "Talks to five people who immigrated to NZ, and why they decided to become citizens."

Author: "Falconer, Phoebe"
Title: "Generations past and future mingle"
description: "Generations past and future mingle"

Author: "Wichtel, Diana"
Title: "Getting down with Mister Brown"
description: "Interviews the first mayor of the Auckland 'super-city'. Looks at his first day and discusses plans for the city, including addressing transport issues. Portrays his personal and family life and some of the issues encountered in the campaign. Discusses his relationship with the Central Government."

Author: "Hartevelt, John"
Title: "The reluctant politician"
description: "Talks with Sir Geoffrey Palmer, who after 30 years as President of the Law Commission is retiring. Mentions his new biography, which reveals a man who has filled key roles in government and in shaping the nation's law."

Author: "Black, Joanne"
Title: "The whole Truth"
description: "Talks to historian Redmer Yska, author of a new book on the history of tabloid newspaper Truth. Examines the newspaper's editorial biases and the details behind the journalism on the high profile 1970s stories about a conspiracy involing Norman Kirk and Bill Sutch to socialise NZ. Gives an overview of the newspaper's history, inculding its working class stance, sensationalism, and editorial direction under board chairman James Dunn.
