Title: "Fun and laughter at the last girls' night"
description: "Fun and laughter at the last girls' night"

Author: "Priest, Ceana"
Title: "Bethune targets child activists"
description: "Bethune targets child activists"

Author: "Pegden, Evan"
Title: "Classic bikes keep star racer young"
description: "Classic bikes keep star racer young"

Title: "Ex-wife seeks answer to 54-year old mystery"
description: "Ex-wife seeks answer to 54-year old mystery"

Author: "Burke, Roy"
Title: "Pacifist fought for his beliefs"
description: "Pacifist fought for his beliefs"

Author: "Pegden, Evan"
Title: "Smith set to make mark against Magpies"
description: "Smith set to make mark against Magpies"

Author: "Leaman, Aaron"
Title: "Jilted lover's $250,000 blackmail revenge"
description: "Jilted lover's $250,000 blackmail revenge"

Author: "Cook, Marjorie"
Title: "Hours going up, minutes coming down"
description: "Talks to the adventurous duo who are training for the 'Speed Fly 8000', a world-first attempt to climb an 8000-foot peak in the Himalayas and descend via a specialised 'speed wing', which combines the characteristics of a paraglider and a skydive wing."

Author: "Grunwell, Rachel"
Title: "How long should baby be in care?; Dad happy at home with kids"
description: "Looks into the issues around an expected report from the Children's Commissioner investigating which types of early childcare are providing the safest and most nuturing environments. Talks to one of the few men in NZ who provides home-based childcare."

Title: "Black Caps skipper bowls them over again"
description: "Black Caps skipper bowls them over again"

Title: "The best advice I ever got"
description: "Interviews several prominent NZers on useful personal and professional advice they have received during their lives.  Talks to Prime Minister John Key on lessons from his mother; to businessman Sir Robert Jones on the influence of a sixth-form teacher; and more briefly to other NZers (Oscar Kightley, Phil Goff, Bob McKerrow, Emily Perkins, Roger Hall, Dick Frizzell, Annabel White, Neil Ieremia, Margaret Mahy, Abigail Boyle, Gareth Farr, Janet Lucas, Shane Jones, Mary Holm, Doug Sellman, Ray Avery, John Psathas, Paul Callaghan, Peter Chrisp, Gin Wigmore, Cameron Bennett, Mary Devine, Michael Houstoun, Jim Mora, Jenny Morel, Astar, Tariana Turia, John Chen, Aaron Short, Judith Collins, Trevor Mallard, Roger Kerr and Billy Apple)."

Author: "Meng-Yee Carolyne"
Title: "A look back"
description: "Revisits some of the faces who appeared in the paper in 2010. Includes biographical material."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "Cold comfort?"
description: "Discusses the difficulties faced by receivers PricewaterhouseCoopers in seeking insurance compensation for the Pike River Mine disaster. Gives comments from John Dow, chairman of Pike River Coal Mine, and histories of previous disputes and delayed payouts of insurance liability for mining accidents. Notes the issues surrounding the possible $100 million claim."

Author: "Thomas, Jacqui"
Title: "Going off on an adventure of a lifetime"
description: "Writes of her travel experiences backpacking for a year around the world with her 7-year-old daughter."

Author: "Morton, Frances"
Title: "A jumbo splash ..."
description: "Reflects on the life of the Auckland Zoo elephant a year after her death in Aug 2009."

Author: "Slade, Maria"
Title: "Hamiltonian to drive super city makeover"
description: "Writes of the image problems of the man behind the new body in charge of driving Auckland's growth - Auckland Tourism, Events and Economic Development. Includes biographical material."

Author: "Fox, Rebecca"
Title: "Region's wildlife : rules of engagement"
description: "Warns beachgoers to be prepared for encounters with the special wildlife in the region during the summer months. Seeks comment from Dept of Conservation biodiversity assets programme manager David Agnew. Includes a diary of wildlife on Otago Peninsula in Jan and Feb 2011. Provides guidelines for respecting the needs of marine wildlife on the peninsula, including yellow-eyed penguins, blue penguins, sea lions and fur seals."

Title: "The year in images 2010"
description: "Reproduces news images illustrating national and international stories of note for 2010."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "Nature ground zero"
description: "Notes the devastating effects of settlement and agriculture on the native ecosystems and biodiversity of Canterbury. Discusses the work of 'Greening Waipara', a coalition of ecologists and local vineyard owners in the Waipara Valley area of North Canterbury (Mud House, Torlesse Wines', Waipara Springs, Pegasus Bay) to use biological engineering to reduce chemical use on grape vines, increase biodiversity and reintroduce native species, restoring balance to the farming area."

Author: "Wallace, Neal"
Title: "Exciting territory ahead for GPS firm"
description: "Features the Mosgiel-based GPS firm recently named as the Otago Daily Times 2010 Business of the Year. Speaks to founder and management director Colin Brown about the technology, which he describes as a 'global positioning guidance and mapping system for use in challenging environments', particularly in agriculture. Describes the reasons for the success of the firm, which is expanding globally."

Author: "Brown, Michael"
Title: "The gift that kept giving"
description: "Gives a personal insight into the success of the All Whites and NZ football at the World Cup."

Author: "Johns, Geraldine"
Title: "Dr Simon Moroney"
description: "Profiles expatriate NZer Simon Moroney, now CEO and chairman of biotechnology firm MorphoSys in Germany. Looks at the activity of MorphoSys, including the drugs currently being developed.  Give Moroney's comments on the advantages of growing up as a Kiwi, and on his hopes for future pharmaceutical breakthroughs."

Author: "Williams, Dave"
Title: "Tough in the South"
description: "Looks back on the events that made major headlines in NZ during 2010."

Author: "Hilpern, Kate"
Title: "Boozer's body of evidence"
description: "Explains the various reasons and causes for alcohol hangovers. Looks at symptoms and prevention. Discusses toxins, dehydration, withdrawal, and possible cures."

Author: "Barton, Chris"
Title: "The price of freedom"
description: "Investigates the issue of voluntary unionism in NZ universities since the government in 1999 allowed students how to choose whether to belong to their union or not. Today the government is about to pass the Education (Freedom of Association) Amendment Bill outlawing universal membership and forcing all tertiary institutions to follow Auckland's lead. Studies the effects of voluntary membership on the student union's financial health and their ability to supply services to their members. Includes arguments for and against voluntary membership."

Author: "Boniface, Linley"
Title: "No man's land"
description: "Discusses depression in men. Looks at recent research from the University of Otago suggesting that depression has a stronger impact on men than on women, that women are more likely to seek treatment and have coping networks, and that doctors should consider the struggles men might face in dealing with depression."

Author: "Price, Mark"
Title: "Country boy makes bad"
description: "Talks to the Milton-born author about his new novel, depicting the life of an undercover banker working with drug cartels in Mexico and South America. Claims that the novel is about his own life and contains more truth than fiction. Includes a brief extract from the novel."

Author: "Hueber, Andre"
Author (detailed): "Andre Hueber and Leigh van der Stoep"
Title: "Loving dad found dead in the water"
description: "Loving dad found dead in the water"

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "Got their WoJo working"
description: "Profiles innovative Wellington fabric company, The Formery, who have just landed a huge deal to supply Starbucks worldwide with a fabric blending NZ wool and used jute from coffee sacks. Describes the run of serendipity that led to the deal, and the company's plans for the future. Gives comments from OECD expert Andrew Wyckoff on what goes into commercial innovation."

Author: "Barnett, Geoffrey"
Author (detailed): "Geoffrey Barnett, Clive Trotman and Ian Williams"
Title: "Kiwi chicks : New Zealand's female musicians tell their stories; Superb survey from every angle; Must-read account of one of NZ's finest actors"
description: "Kiwi chicks : New Zealand's female musicians tell their stories; Superb survey from every angle; Must-read account of one of NZ's finest actors"

Author: "Slade, Maria"
Title: "Flights recapture early aviation era"
description: "Talks to Captain Geoff Cooper and his wife Jessica about their Auckland flying business using a vintage DC3 (ZK-DAK), the kind of aircraft NAC was built on and one of only two airworthy examples."

Author: "Brown, Michael"
Title: "Dean back for another Tour of duty"
description: "Talks to the cyclist about his 2010 year."

Author: "Alderson, Andrew"
Title: "Doing it the Wright way"
description: "Looks at how the new Black Caps coach has adapted to new coaching environments in the past."

Author: "Lapsley, John"
Title: "Electric-fence shock therapy has failed me"
description: "Confesses that he is a compulsive television spectator of the Black Caps, despite their unreliable form."

Author: "Wallace, Neal"
Title: "Accountant leads way in seizing the chances"
description: "Profiles the Gore-born and raised head of tax at Keogh McCormack.  Discusses the platforms he is using to promote business opportunities for young professionals in the city and wider province. Informs that he won the future business leader award at the recent 2010 Westpac Otago Chamber of Commerce Business Excellence Awards. Lists facts about his life and career."

Title: "Ticking the boxes"
description: "Suggests 25 things to do in the province this summer."

Author: "Donaldson, Peter"
Title: "Awash with yachts; The Neilson philosophy; So you want to be an entrepreneur"
description: "Talks to the former Dunedin resident who now owns over 180 yachts in the Greek islands, as part of his London-based business Sailing Holidays Ltd. Describes his upbringing some of his family history and his love of motorcycling. Relates how he and his wife built up the business from scratch. Shares his business philosophy.  Offers advice to budding entrepreneurs."

Author: "Rae, Sally"
Title: "Willow Park a family affair"
description: "Talks to the couple about the story of their rural North Otago home, 'Willow Park', home to three families since it was built by the Scotland-born settler in 1880 and sold to the grandparents of the current owner in 1928. Describes the challenge of restoring the home after their marriage in 1973."

Author: "Laugesen, Ruth"
Title: "Acting up"
description: "Talks to various industry figures about the disputes involving the actors' boycott of 'The Hobbit' (Peter Jackson), actors' unions, and the business of making movies in NZ. Interviews CEO of South Pacific Pictures John Barnett about the negotiations and his criticisms of Robyn Malcolm and Jennifer Ward-Lealand. Interviews actor Robyn Malcolm about the stresses of acting as a spokesperson for Actors' Equity and conflicts with Barnett. Lays out the story of the dispute, resulting from international concern by the Federation of International Actors with Warner Brothers over the production of the Hobbit, including comments on pay rates, residuals, and actors' working conditions. Looks at what working actors get paid in NZ, lists NZ films coming up, and lists productions in the pipeline."

Author: "Rae, Sally"
Title: "Olivia grew up to be a cowgirl"
description: "Talks to the Western Southland-raised rodeo enthusiast about her chances of becoming the first woman to win an all-around NZ open rodeo title. Discusses her beloved horse, Waylon Jennings. Includes information about rodeo events and terminology, and lists the dates of Southern rodeos over summer."

Title: "Last flight for Central topdressing pilot"
description: "Last flight for Central topdressing pilot"

Author: "Morgan, Jared"
Title: "Southland man takes top air force command"
description: "Southland man takes top air force command"

Title: "Devery happy to do without horses"
description: "Devery happy to do without horses"

Title: "Budding scientist wins PM's award"
description: "Budding scientist wins PM's award"

Title: "Not easy to step back after a life in the racing industry"
description: "Not easy to step back after a life in the racing industry"

description: "Island gig payback for 90-year-old love's minders"

description: "Reveals the extent of his enthusiasm for gardening."

description: "Friendly, disrespectful, caring. loving"

description: "Judge took high office in NZ and the Pacific"

description: "Lean advocate for Parafed Otago, 45 years on"

Title: "Frost crossing town to stadium position"
description: "Frost crossing town to stadium position"

Title: "49 years of hams - he prefers turkey"
description: "49 years of hams - he prefers turkey"

Author: "Savage, Jared"
Title: "Rising from the ashes"
description: "Chronicles the recovery of David Beanland, the fireman who was court up in the Tamahere cool store explosion April 5, 2008. Outlines how his face was badly burned and the reconstructive and plastic surgery that has taken place since the accident. Interviews David and his surgeon, Zac Moaveni about what has been involved in David's recovery. Gives some background to the night of the fire callout to the Icepak cool store at the Tamahere site."

Author: "Jones, Lea"
Title: "Drink-drive : no escape; No escaping drink-driving facts; It can't happen to me - can it?; How many drinks are too many?"
description: "Focuses on the problem of drinking and driving. Includes statistics about alcohol-related harm. Accompanies Dunedin Constable Chris Gaffaney on traffic patrol to ascertain what motivates alcohol-impaired drivers. Describes attempts by people in Otago and Southland to beat the evidential breath-alcohol machine. Participates in an experiment with four others to determine how much they could drink before exceeding the legal driving limit."

Title: "Crosby cooking up a few yarns; Deadly serious advice"
description: "Talks to the first-time author and ex-motorcycle racer about the success of his book. Reveals his plan to write a cookbook. Includes an extract from 'Croz : larrikin biker'."

Author: "Emmerson, Rod"
Title: "Giants and a genius among men ..."
description: "Reviews the works of Ron Mueck exhibiting at the Christchurch Art Gallery until 23rd January 2011. Works include Wild man, In a marital bed, Self portrait."

Author: "Gilchrist, Shane"
Author (detailed): "Shane Gilchrist, Jeff Harford and Mark Orton"
Title: "The sound of 2010"
description: "Showcases their top albums of the year, including albums by the Auckland-based and Dunedin-based bands and the Melbourne-based singer."

Author: "Seconi, Adrian"
Title: "Record still stacks up"
description: "Profiles the Australian-born cricketing legend who represented Otago for 27 seasons between 1888 and 1914."

Author: "Cumming, Geoffrey"
Title: "Eat less, feel full? It's food for thought"
description: "Reports that scientists believe compounds in food which keep us feeling full for longer may hold the key to fighting obesity epidemic. Indicates scientists at Plant & Food Research, the University of Auckland and Massey University are trying to identify foods that can prevent us overeating by manipulating the natural signals that tell the brain the body has had enough to eat."

Author: "Loughrey, David"
Title: "Jim Harland : a man of myriad ventures"
description: "Talks to the outgoing chief executive of the council about the achievements and challenges of his decade-long tenure."

Author: "Skellett, Chris"
Title: "Donkeys show us the way"
description: "Shares some of the lessons he learned from keeping donkeys as pets. Explains how to interpret their sometimes-obstinate behaviour. Recalls a recent visit to the Donkey Sanctuary in Salcombe, England."

Author: "Taonui, Rawiri"
Title: "Year of struggles - and triumphs"
description: "Reviews 2010 from a MaÃÑori perspective, noting achievements and failures in the areas of politics, education, health, sport, and entertainment."

Author: "Nicolson, Don"
Title: "NZ farmers experienced the best and the worst in 2010"
description: "Looks back on the main issues affecting sheep, beef, and dairy farmers in 2010, touching on climate, natural disasters, rural-urban misunderstanding, farming ethics, and government compliance."

Author: "Benson, Nigel"
Title: "Kiwi rogues, rascals and renegades; Rogues, rascals, renegades"
description: "Lists and briefly profiles 25 NZ anti-heroes of the past and present."

Author: "Pepperell, Susan"
Title: "How to keep the kids at bay"
description: "Suggests 50 activities to offer to children during the school holidays, whether families are at home, on a  trip, and or at a holiday venue."

Author: "Braunias, Steve"
Title: "The year beneath the earth"
description: "Reflects on the events of the year, dominated by the Christchurch earthquake and the Pike River mining explosion. Touches on overseas visitors to NZ (Hillary Clinton, Justin Bieber), the industrial dispute surrounding  the filming of The Hobbit, public service scandals, private fraudsters, sporting achievements, and a setting straight of the life of one of the miners killed at Pike River."

Author: "Knight, Kim,"
Title: "Waxing lyrical"
description: "Features NZ locations and excerpts from songs that NZ songwriters have penned about them, including Auckland, Hamilton, Te Awamutu, Taumarunui, Picton, Christchurch, Central Otago, and Dunedin."

Author: "Stanley, Ben"
Title: "Tina's big night out set for take-off"
description: "Tina's big night out set for take-off"

description: "Quake-rattled chickens lay again"

Title: "Witnesses recall driver's manner"
description: "Witnesses recall driver's manner"

Title: "Coppins has last international race"
description: "Coppins has last international race"

Author: "Hartley, Simon"
Title: "Business is healthy"
description: "Features the Queenstown-based, multi-award-winning doctor recruitment company. Talks to the New Plymouth-born managing director about the fast-growing business, which has expanded into Australia. Mentions the role of his Dunedin-raised wife in the enterprise."

Author: "Rudd, Allison"
Title: "A view into the past"
description: "Visits the former holiday home of the late brewer Charles Speight. Talks to the current owner about the renovations she carried out with her late husband and Timaru heritage architect Barrie Bracefield. Mentions that she is the owner of the antiques business Broad Bay China."

Author: "Lewis, John"
Title: "World champion axe man; Cutting-edge sport has origins in medieval wood processing"
description: "Talks to the world champion competitive wood chopper about his success in the sport. Includes a list of terminology and gives the Southland-Otago Bushcraft meeting dates. Explains the medieval origins of the sport."

Author: "Wall, Tony"
Title: "No town for old men"
description: "Interviews Taihape residents about the closure of the town's rest home and the scaling back of hospital services, questioning the shutting down of a facility that received a $2 million upgrade two years ago. Discusses the operation and liquidation of the Otaihape Health Trust, and outlines both sides of a debate over whether the Trust was set up to fail."

Author: "Sides, Alexandra"
Title: "The end of a holiday"
description: "Features the second-place entry in an annual short story contest, with comments by Charlotte Grimshaw."

Author: "Smellie, Pattrick"
Title: "How our world has changed since the turn of the century; It's not easy being green"
description: "Examines societal changes and trends over the past decade, based on the first NZ 'State of the Nation' report issued by Australian polling company Roy Morgan Research. Includes trends about the status of environmentalism."

Author: "Hunt, Tom"
Title: "Disturbing images won't keep new chief censor awake at night"
description: "Interviews the new chief censor."

Author: "Jacobson, Julie"
Title: "Opening the door to memories"
description: "Recalls summers during her childhood in Christchurch, New Plymouth and Wellington, and good times during her flatting days."

Author: "Macdonald, Nikki"
Title: "Food tour beyond the vines"
description: "Meets local food artisans in the region, including an olive grower, food tour operators, cherry orchardists, beekeepers and a third-generation cheesemaker. Talks to the skipper of the Greenshell Mussel Cruise."

Author: "Coventry, David"
Title: "Shipton-Pearce"
description: "Presents an extract from the as-yet unpublished novel 'Shipton-Pearce', drafted during the 2010 International Institute of Modern Letters programme at Victoria University of Wellington."

Author: "Hansford, Dave"
Title: "On the edge of the Strait"
description: "Ventures along the coastal track to Red Rocks/Pariwhero, on the wild south coast. Describes its features. Explains how to get there and what to bring."

Author: "Steward, Ian"
Title: "Dutton leaves a legacy of wit and engagement"
description: "Dutton leaves a legacy of wit and engagement"

Author: "Pepperell, Susan"
Title: "Perfect population storm on horizon"
description: "Speaks to the head of Waikato University's National Institute of Demographic and Economic Analysis (Nidea), Professor Natalie Jackson, and to employment experts, about the gap in the workforce of 20-35-year-old people. Considers whether retiring baby boomers, young NZers staying overseas, and migration will exacerbate or mitigate this gap."

Author: "Catherall, Sarah"
Title: "Making camp the old way"
description: "Features two families who have taken an unorthodox approach to camping holidays. Talks to the architect and his wife about their purchase of a canvas teepee, and to the head of operations at TradeMe about restoring and refitting a 1970 VW Kombi van."

Author: "Palmer, Rebecca"
Title: "Gidday, diary"
description: "Talks to the creators of the Kiwi Diary 2011 about the process of bringing their idea to fruition, starting with the self-published first diary in 2005."

Author: "Dudding, Adam"
Title: "What are the chances?"
description: "Looks at the human preoccupation with prediction, and supplies statistics on the chances of NZers sustaining certain injuries, encountering personal risks, experiencing natural disasters, winning lotteries, and predicting political, financial and sports outcomes."

Author: "Keir, Anna"
Title: "Stalking Ella Ryman"
description: "Reproduces the entry in the 'Sunday Star-Times' short story competition that won third place."

Author: "Rodley, Aidan"
Title: "Jockey begs for return of 'livelihood'"
description: "Jockey begs for return of 'livelihood'"

Author: "Braunias, Steve"
Title: "The final cigarette"

Talks to the children of the couple who were given permission to use the original musterer's hut 55 years ago. Seeks comment from younger family members."

Mentions a decision by NZ Judge Rob Murfitt in the case of a young girl, and reveals some names that NZ birth registration officials had blocked. Explains restrictions prohibiting names that are 'underdesirable in the public interest under the provisions of the NZ Births Deaths and Marriages Act. Lists the 10 most popular names for boys and girls."

Title: "A book about books; Rich reading through ages of British writing"
description: "Presents a truncated version of an interview with the emeritus professor of politics at the University of Otago. Includes an edited extract from his book 'The Torchlight List : around the world in 200 books'."

Author: "Mooney, Paul"
Title: "The sounds of 2010"
description: "Features their top albums of the year, all of which are from overseas."

Title: "Otago's fast slow bowler"
description: "Profiles the late cricketer, considered to be one of the best slow bowlers in Otago history. Overviews his record in club cricket and exploits as a NZ representative during the 1950s."

Title: "Make mine a pint of sauv bitter"
description: "Studies new hop varieties that have been developed for their aromas at Plant and Food Research's Motueka research centre since the 1980s. Details the revival of hop growing in Motueka, the growth of hops exports, and the increasing use of new varieties in boutique and craft beers in NZ and overseas since the 1990s.  Describes the hop plant and the different roles it plays in beer brewing. Focuses on the Nelson sauvin variety that is used in pilsners and pale ales. Talks to NZ brewers about their use of new hop varieties."

Title: "Winding down to gone"
description: "Talks to the jeweller and owner of Contemporary Jewellery Gallery, who is closing his Stuart St store in Feb 2011 due to declining health. Discusses his entry into the profession while he was still the chief city planner for the Dunedin City Council."

Considers the growing enthusiasm for dances such as zumba as a form of exercise and states that, although there are many physical and psychological advantages to this, the rising popularity of dance has been matched by a rising injury rate. Suggests warm-ups and stretching are the key to preventing dance injuries."

Author: "Johansson, Jon,"
Title: "Constitutional cop-out"
description: "Criticises Prime Minister John Key for not taking the opportunity to undertake a meaningful constitutional review.  Lays out the history of the constitutional review, entered into under the 2008 confidence and supply agreement between National and the Maori Party. Comments on issues raised by the role of the Treaty of Waitangi (Tiriti o Waitangi) in NZ, and the drawbacks of the design of the constitutional review that make it unlikely to address these and other issues, such as republicanism. Advocates for a wider, participatory review, stating that Key is being timid in not accepting such a process."

Author: "Wichtel, Diana"
Title: "Driving to Treblinka"
description: "Recounts travelling to Poland, in which her father survived the Holocaust against the Jews during World War 2. Relates the story of her father, Benjamin Wichtel, who survived as a Jew in German-occupied Poland . Looks at nostalgic Jewish-themed locations, museums and memorabilia in Krakow, and relates her impressions of a visit to the former concentration-extermination camps of Auschwitz-Birkenau. Comments on the tensions of history that the memory of Jews at such locations means for post-war Poland.  Visits the destroyed extermination camp at Treblinka, and the former Jewish ghetto in Warsaw. Looks at the International Tracing Service, making Nazi archives on mass murder and other activities open to posterity."

Author: "Boniface, Linley"
Title: "The sounds of silence"
description: "Discusses tinnitus. Notes its incidence in NZ, and describes two types - subjective tinnitus heard only by the sufferer and objective tinnitus which can be heard by others.  Notes causes (noise-induced hearing loss, age-related hearing loss, etc) and possible treatments, including low-level noise generators."

Author: "Bowden, Jennifer"

description: "Discusses questions on red meat in the diet.  Looks at the nutritional problems of low consumption of red meat or vegetarianism, such as zinc and iron deficiencies, and the problems in consuming large portions. Discusses the need for children to regularly consume protein, suggesting a range of protein sources."

Talks to speech language therapist Roz Young of the Stuttering Treatment and Research Trust (START), noting the problems and psychological consequences of stuttering, and the physical basis (neurological) for the disorder. Looks at intervention and treatment, discussing START's use of the Lidcombe Program for retraining preschoolers and young school children. Notes some prominent NZers who overcame stuttering."

Title: "A waiting game"
description: "Reports on the shortage of available organs for transplant due to NZ's historically low level of organ donation, exacerbated by the effects of the decreasing road toll and other factors. Describes work under way by the Ministry of Health and Dunedin list MP Michael Woodhouse to increase live donor rates. Talks to people on the waiting list for an organ transplant, to the parents of deceased 20-year-old man Sean Coe, whose organs were transplanted into four people, and to a man who received a new kidney. Touches on Maori cultural rituals regarding organ donation. Provides facts about how parts of the body are used for transplantation, a graph of international donor rates and information about who is eligible to donate."

description: "Describes the tropical Pacific weather pattern La NinÃÉa, noting its two major cycles in recent Australasian history. Explains the use of the Southern Oscillation Index (SOI) in predicting La Nina events. Outlines the most common outcome for NZ weather of this phenomenon. Briefly explains also the El NinÃÉo pattern. Contains speculations by weather experts on the effect of warmer world temperatures on both weather episodes."

Notes his use of aeronautical software, and the contribution of his wife, Jane Burry, to the design's geometries. Includes a time line of the church's history. Talks to fund manager Allan McKenzie and farmers and longtime conservationists Bruce McKenzie and Sue McKenzie about the significance of preserving part of the rare lowland forest, which will be protected and open to the public. Speaks to Paul Cashmore of the Dept of Conservation about the presence of the rare native plant the woodrose (also known as the dactylanthus and pua o te reinga)."

Title: "Beyond the water wars; smoothing the waters"
description: "Outlines the debate about irrigation in Canterbury between farmers and conservationists. Reminds about the Government's sacking of Environment Canterbury last year and examines how decisions about water use will be made in 2011, focusing on the Resource Management Act (RMA), the Canterbury Water Management Strategy (CWMS), and Canterbury's ten local water zone committees. Describes the contention surrounding the appointment of committee members. Details the Hurunui Water Project (HWP) and who is supporting it. Touches on the problems of nitrate levels in Canterbury groundwater."

Title: "Policeman out on his own - and loving it"
description: "Talks to the sole-charge officer for the NZ Police, based in an isolated settlement in the Central police region, midway between Dannevirke and Pahiatua in the Tararua District. Accompanies him on his beat and describes a typical day on the job. Seeks views from local residents and Central district commander Russell Gibson about his value to the community. Provides facts about sole-charge police stations in NZ."

Author: "Gilchrist, Shane"
Title: "Stuttering takes a lifetime of control; How an All Black conquered his demons"
description: "Focuses on the topical issue of stuttering, as prompted by the performance of Colin Firth as King George VI in 'The King's speech'. Talks to Parents Inc founder Ian Grant about his lifelong battle with stuttering. Relates the stuttering experience of the former All Black."

Author: "Hartevelt, John"
Title: "A silver tsunami"
description: "Documents the number of 65-year-olds who will start collecting superannuation in 2011. Follows up with more statistics from a review of retirement income policy released in December 2010 by Retirement Commisioner Diana Crossan. Considers the possibility of raising the retirement age. Anticipates a report from a Government-appointed savings working group, commenting on the saving habits of older NZers. Evaluates the Kiwisaver scheme. Offers advice on retirement from entrepreneur Michael Hill and dancer Sir Jon Trimmer. Highlights the savings plans of two couples, one in their late twenties and the other in their late fifties."

Author: "Todd, Rebecca"
Title: "Determined to beat the odds"
description: "Covers the four weeks to recovery from a bout of transverse myelitis experienced by Michael O'Sullivan of Christchurch, from paralysis to walking on his own. Details the neurological disorder caused by inflammation of the spinal cord. Lists its symptoms and describes the Transitionz rehabilitation programme that smooths the discharge preparation process for patients like O'Sullivan."

Author: "Crean, Mike"
Title: "Skilful fighter pilot had great courage"
description: "Skilful fighter pilot had great courage"

Author: "Hubbard, Anthony"
Title: "Heavy weather"
description: "Profiles the new NZ Chief of Defence Force, Major General Richard Rhys Jones and asks whether he has the credentials and skills to be to enable him to carry out what the present government have asked him to do. Reports he has been tasked with the responsibility of implementing a report written by Rod Deane that has called for huge savings. Ascertains his views on where NZ's future alliances should be. Presents his views on the war in Afghanistan and the reasons NZ is involved in such a war. Comments on the latest problems the defence forces have been experiencing with their armoured vehicles and navy vessels. Includes a column by Time Hume, 'Afghanistan : worse before it gets better' where he talks to David Petraeus the top military commander in Afghanistan."

Notes they are outstanding in that many of whom are in the IT field, have a global outlook on business, and work with international networks. Introduces the following business leaders: Sam Morgan (founder of Trade Me); Jeremy Moon (founder of Icebreaker clothing); Derek Handley and Geoffrey Handley (of Hyperfactory and Pacific Connections); Sarah Kennedy (former Healtheries chief executive);  Catherine de Groot and Sarah Gibbs (skincare Trilogy founders); Graham Mitchell (Crown Fibre Holdings chief executive); Selwyn Hayes (tax manager);  Tim Alpe (Jucy Rentals chief executive); Miki Szikszai (Snapper smartcard chief executive); and Ira Bing (investor)."

Title: "Say that again ..."
description: "Looks into the phenomenon of stuttering, relating the stories of NZers who have the speech disorder. Talks to Monica Bennett, Barry Hay, John Hunt, actor David McPhail, and Youth Court Judge Andrew Becroft about their childhood experiences, techniques used and what they still find irritating. Discusses the 'naturalness' technique, the Speak Easy Association support group, and relays the advice of two speech therapists."

Author: "Hart, Anna"
Title: "Great expectations"
description: "Presents an outsider's view of the traditional Kiwi OE (overseas experience or 'extended working holiday') that many young NZers participate in. Relates it is not just to have a break and a holiday in a different place but for many it is an opportunity to make a familial and cultural connection to their past. Comments that many consider it a challenge, a test of their resilience rite of passage. Looks at how the young travellers view their experience, whether they consider it 'successful' or not and compares it with the attitude of young people coming from Europe to NZ with the idea of having OE."

Author: "Clifton, Jane,"
Title: "Ambition Kiwi-style"
description: "Looks at New Zealanders' distinct attitude to success and ambition, revealing that it is not necessarily money that drives us. Briefly touches on some of the more famous NZ individuals such as Sir Edmund Hillary and Peter Jackson. Highlights keen ambition in one young NZer, five years old, who opted for the money an ice-cream treat would cost her mother, instead of the treat itself, after being told that if she wanted a pony she would have to save for it. Claims that half of NZers consider themselves ambitious."

Author: "Clifton, Jane,"
Title: "The world of difference"
description: "Summarises the differences in consumerism and its related emotions, between NZ, British and American studies, taken fron the book 'Doing anthropology in consumer research', by American anthropologists Patricia Sunderland and Rita Denny."

Author: "Hartevelt, John"
Title: "Who's going to pay for the oldies?"
description: "Documents the number of 65-year-olds who will start collecting superannuation in 2011. Follows up with more statistics from a review of retirement income policy released in December 2010 by Retirement Commisioner Diana Crossan. Considers the possibility of raising the retirement age. Anticipates a report from a Government-appointed savings working group, commenting on the saving habits of older NZers. Evaluates the Kiwisaver scheme. Offers advice on retirement from entrepreneur Michael Hill and dancer Sir Jon Trimmer. Highlights the savings plans of two couples, one in their late twenties and the other in their late fifties."

Author: "Harris, Catherine"
Title: "Future looks global; The future for up-and-coming business leaders looks global"
description: "Presents brief profiles of and provides industry comments on twelve young successful NZ corporates. Notes they are outstanding in that many of whom are in the IT field, have a global outlook on business, and work with international networks. Introduces the following business leaders: Sam Morgan (founder of Trade Me); Jeremy Moon (founder of Icebreaker clothing); Derek Handley and Geoffrey Handley (of Hyperfactory and Pacific Connections); Sarah Kennedy (former Healtheries chief executive);  Catherine de Groot and Sarah Gibbs (skincare Trilogy founders); Graham Mitchell (Crown Fibre Holdings chief executive); Selwyn Hayes (tax manager);  Tim Alpe (Jucy Rentals chief executive); Miki Szikszai (Snapper smartcard chief executive); and Ira Bing (investor)."

Author: "Corry, Lucy"
Title: "Foodie hot spots in the valley"
description: "Features boutique food producers in Petone, Eastbourne and Lower Hutt, and talks to the proprietors of these businesses."

Author: "Johns, Geraldine"
Title: "Bouchier's law"
description: "Overviews the life and career of Judge Josephine Bouchier, on the eve of her retirement from the bench. Touches on her being the first member of the NZ judiciary to take maternity leave while serving on the bench, and how she made a successful career as a judge despite some dertermined criticism. Briefly mentions what the rest of the small number of NZ female judges are doing now."

Author: "Philp, Matt,"
Title: "Locked and loaded"
description: "Features the reinvention of the Lockwood home. Overviews its history, beginning with its invention in the 1950s by the Dutch immigrants Joe La Grouw and Johannes van Loghem. Talks to company chief executive Bryce Heard about the changes made to the homes and its challenge to reposition itself in the urban market, and to Joe La Grouw Jr about the sturdy design of the homes and the legacy of his father."

Author: "Gardner, Chris"
Title: "Rainmaker recalls success in the skies"
description: "Rainmaker recalls success in the skies"

Author: "Tozer, Katherine"
Title: "Life on the road with a team of dogs"
description: "Life on the road with a team of dogs"

Author: "Manson, Bess"
Title: "Dan Wootton"
description: "Continues the series on successful NZers proudly flying the flag overseas. Focuses on show business journalist Wootton, originally from Lower Hutt but now residing in London, and describes how he came to be one of the more high-profile British journalists, making and breaking friendships with a wide range of celebrities."

Author: "Hansford, Dave"
Title: "Pony express"
description: "Reports on his recent experience of horse trekking at Patuna Farms, on the Ruakokopatuna River. Provides details of how to get to the farms."

Author: "Catherall, Sarah"
Title: "Get your kit on"
description: "Features the award-winning kitset bach designed by Andre Hodgskin of Architex NZ, known as the 'ipad'. Talks to the architect and to one of the owners about its features."

Title: "Contractor supports agrecovery scheme : Quality seals the deal"
description: "Contractor supports agrecovery scheme : Quality seals the deal"

Author: "Somerset, Guy"
Title: "Robo pop"
description: "Talks to Greg Locke, electronic engineer and creator of The Trons, a self-playing robotic musical group, about the pros and cons of his unusual creation."

Author: "Blundell, Sally,"
Title: "Off the beaten track"
description: "Previews the fifth biennial exhibition of site-specific outdoor works on Waiheke Island, entitled 'Headland: sculpture on the Gulf'. Talks to artist A.D. Schierning and curator Heather Galbraith."

Author: "Boniface, Linley"
Title: "Age matters"
description: "Wonders if celebrities' late motherhood is sending the wrong messages about women's fertility. Reveals research suggests that the best age period to have children is between 20 and 35; with NZ's current average age set at 30, we are at the top of the international table for age at first pregnancy. Adds that we also have the highest vasectomy rate in the world. Suggests that women, even young women in their teens, need to better plan for parenthood the way they would the other aspects of their adult lives."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "Great wool revival?"
description: "Looks at the recent improvement in the state of the NZ wool industry."

Author: "McLean, Elspeth"
Title: "Odd case of the professor's luggage"
description: "Talks to the Glasgow-born emeritus professor of oral medicine and oral surgery at the University of Otago School of Dentistry. Discusses some of the unusual items he has carried in his luggage over the years for his research. Mentions his voluntary work in the hospice movement, and describes his importation of Scottish pinhead oatmeal and haggis."

Author: "McLean, Elspeth"
Title: "War-zone nursing 'hard work'"
description: "Talks to the nurse who has recently returned from a six-month stint in war-torn northwest Pakistan as part of her secondment to the International Committee of the Red Cross. Touches on her next assignment in Kandahar, Afghanistan."

Author: "Rudd, Allison"
Title: "Where dental patients never experience pain"
description: "Features the new simulation unit at the University of Otago dental school, enabling dental students to practice on mannequins with the help of computers. Talks to clinical services and faculties associate dean Dr Warwick Duncan about the new facility."

Author: "Gilchrist, Shane"
Title: "Getting the words out"
description: "Focuses on the topical issue of stuttering, as prompted by the performance of Colin Firth as King George VI in 'The King's speech'. Talks to Parents Inc founder Ian Grant about his lifelong battle with stuttering. Relates the stuttering experience of the former All Black."

Author: "Price, Mark"
Title: "Through the looking glass"
description: "Talks to the retired school principal who spearheaded the initiative in the early 2000s to create lively window displays in 16 empty shops in Princes St, Dunedin. Informs that the city council is proposing to again improve the look of empty shops as part of its proposed expenditure for the Rugby World Cup."

Author: "Barton, Chris"
Title: "Glory to Gaudi"
description: "Highlights the Barcelona basilica, Sagrada Familia, designed by Catalan architect Antonio Gaudi and due for completion by 2026. Informs of the role of NZ architect Mark Burry in contributing design work to the building, describing how he became involved in the project 31 years ago. Notes his use of aeronautical software, and the contribution of his wife, Jane Burry, to the design's geometries. Includes a time line of the church's history. Touches on the controversy surrounding the building and its consecration by Pope Benedict XVI in 2010."

Author: "James, Bryan"
Title: "'Warts and all' portrait of an enthusiast; Non-fiction"
description: "'Warts and all' portrait of an enthusiast; Non-fiction"

description: "Talks to the man who is the 'Artist in the Terminal' at Dunedin International Airport, 27 Jan-25 Mar 2011. Visits his studio in Cumberland St and describes some of his recent projects, including the airport exhibition 'Presence : loops, lines and light', comprising 15 large abstract paintings. Speaks to airport chief executive John McCall about the 'Artist in the Terminal' programme."

description: "Discusses the changes in food prices and how this has affected what people buy and eat. Looks at the causes behind the rising prices for many foods such as dairy products in NZ, wheat, corn, sugar, cocoa and coffee. Comments also in the increase of people growing their own vegetables and wanting to know more about where their food comes from."

Title: "Dog put down after boy attacked"

Author: "Lomas, David"
Title: "Flying the flag : Bob McKerrow"
description: "Profiles Bob McKerrow, originally from Dunedin now living in Colombo, Sri Lanka, Head of Delegation for the Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies. Looks back at his 40 years of humanitarian work across the globe."

Author: "Lomas, David"
Title: "Bob McKerrow"
description: "Profiles Bob McKerrow, originally from Dunedin now living in Colombo, Sri Lanka, Head of Delegation for the Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies. Looks back at his 40 years of humanitarian work across the globe."

Author: "Boniface, Linley"
Title: "Bitter pills"
description: "Comments on the system for assessing medicines and asks whether we can trust drug companies to be open and honest in releasing the results of their trials. Outlines the findings of research, which suggest that the current system for assessing the safety and effectiveness of drugs is ‚Äúwholly inadequate‚Äù and ‚Äúethically dubious‚Äù."

Author: "Blundell, Kay"
Title: "Rail upgrade on track for completion"
description: "Reports that after four years, there is light at the end of the tunnel for the $550 million overhaul of Wellington's regional railway system. Outlines how and where the money has been spent."

Author: "Chug, Kiran"
Title: "A watery treasure"
description: "Overviews the ecological significance of NZ's wetlands, given that decades of draining them for development and farming has left the country with only a tiny part of what once existed of these valuable areas. Lists the six sites designated as wetlands of national importance under the Ramsar Convention on Wetlands, with a surface area of 55,512 hectares."

Author: "Bowden, Jennifer"
Title: "Weasel words"
description: "Informs of the meaning behind food labels such as 'no added sugar', 'cholesterol-free', 'low-fat' or 'fat-reduced', 'low in salt/sodium', 'lite/light', 'gluten-free', 'organic' and 'free range'."

Author: "Donoghue, Tim"
Title: "Adoptee spurred battle for law reform to enable access to birth information"
description: "Adoptee spurred battle for law reform to enable access to birth information"

Author: "Ralston, Bill"
Title: "A woman's guide to men (and vice versa)"
description: "Provides a light-hearted look at the differences between men and women behaviourally with a view to understanding them better."

Author: "Burgess, Dave"
Title: "100 days : how the new mayors stack up"
description: "Talks to the newly-elected group of mayors for the Wellington region, to discover how they have managed their first 100 days in office, and reveal their top priorities for the current term."

Author: "McCrystal, John"
Title: "Making tracks"
description: "Narrates a journey taken over three days on bicycles along the Otago rail trail, starting from Clyde, moving on to Alexander, Lauder, Oturehua and Middlemarch."

Author: "Macdonald, Nikki"
Title: "Her brilliant sporting career took off on a wonky knee"
description: "Talks to the first woman secretary-general of NZ's Olympic Committee, about her career history, her aspirations and goals, and how she intends to plan for the next 18 months in the lead-up to the 2012 London Olympics."

Author: "Vine, Gillian"
Title: "Long voyage to a Mediterranean island"
description: "Reports on the opening of the Mediterranean Garden at the botanic garden, 12 Dec 2010. Backgrounds the planning and development over 15 years to bring the garden to fruition."

Author: "Hunter, Tim"
Title: "Key gambles on privatisation"
description: "Examines the potential issues around the PM's decision to sell off shares to the public of four state-owned power companies: Meridian, Mighty River Power, Genesis and Solid Energy. States John Key's reasoning behind the decision is partially due to the state of the country's debt, which places it in the company of other developed countries such as Greece and Ireland, both of which have been in major economic strife as a result of the recession. Discusses the implications of such a government venture."

Author: "Nash, Kieran"
Title: "Wilma's fury leaves heroes in its wake"
description: "Reports on the destruction wreaked by Cyclone Wilma in Northland, the Coromandel and the Bay of Plenty, 28-29 Jan 2011. Talks to local residents in Marua, Kaeo, Onetangi, Pipiwai, Whangamata, Tauranga and Haruru. Includes a map showing rainfall amounts and wind velocities in the upper North Island, and satellite images showing the progress of the storm over a 12-hour period."

Author: "Van der Stoep, Leigh"
Title: "'Stamp out dangerous bug'"
description: "Investigates new concerns about campylobacter levels in fresh chicken. Presents results of a scientific survey of 10 packets of fresh chicken from five Auckland stores, which were tested at an independent commercial laboratory. Cites comment from University of Otago associate professor of public health Dr Michael Baker, two retailers, a spokesman for Food Safety Minister Kate Wilkinson and Poultry Industry Association chief Michael Brooks. Seeks reaction from three shoppers. Provides facts about campylobacter."

Author: "Hume, Tim,"
Title: "Helping troublesome teens; Scientist, businesswoman in running"
description: "Tells the story of Steve Boxer who has been nominated for New Zealander of the Year for his work carried out by MYND (Mentoring Youth New Direction). MYND takes at risk youth and tries to give them a new direction in life. Profiles two other candidates for the award, Sir Paul Callaghan and Peri Drysdale."

Author: "Risk, Louise"
Title: "Roller-skating nana just sharing fun"
description: "Roller-skating nana just sharing fun"

Author: "Keane, Camilla"
Title: "Tiger mums' little trophies; Hard work is the answer"
description: "Investigates the phenomenon of 'tiger mothers', characterised by an exacting approach to parenting. Reports that the debate over parenting styles has been reignited by the new bestselling book 'Battle hymn of the tiger mother', by Chinese-American Amy Chua. Talks to several Asian immigrants about their experiences of parenting or being a child of demanding parents. Speaks to Dr Carina Meares of Massey University about her research project on economic integration by migrants to NZ. Seeks comment from Westlake Boys High School principal David Ferguson and family therapist Diane Levy. Cites views of the high-profile public lawyer who emigrated from Taiwan with her family over 40 years ago."

Author: "Reed, Megan Nicol"
Title: "Roll models"
description: "Talks to three newly qualified teachers about their memories of their experience of school, their views on national standards and what sort of teachers they wnat to be."

Author: "Dekker, Diana"
Title: "Creature feature"
description: "Talks to storyteller Moira Wairama about how she finally snared the taniwha that created Wellington's harbour, capturing its story in two books, in MaÃÑori and English."

Author: "Neems, Jeff"
Title: "Walker's run to the top : Fairfield boy becomes Stan the man"
description: "Walker's run to the top : Fairfield boy becomes Stan the man"

Author: "Bradley, Lisa"
Title: "Trouble in campground paradise; Windfall brings 50 years of family memories"
description: "Assesses whether NZers' love of camping has diminished. Talks to campground owners, Dept of Conservation staff and campers about recent changes and trends. Chats to the widow and daughter Jann Butler about the man who restored a 1934 Bedford bus as a holiday vehicle."

Author: "Burke, Roy"
Title: "Outdoors man worked hard for city"
description: "Outdoors man worked hard for city"

Author: "Hubbard, Anthony"
Title: "Mind the gap"
description: "Reports from the book, 'The spirit level' (Richard Wilkinson and Kate Pickett) that countries with the biggest gulf between rich and poor also tend to be those with the worst social problems. Asks where does this leave NZ. Shows NZ fits this model and explains the detail of the book's assumptions."

Author: "Yeoman, Paula"
Title: "One love, to last lifetime"
description: "Previews the fourth annual reggae, soul and R'n'B music festival, Rotorua, 5 Feb 2011. Talks to promoter Jackie Sanders about the popularity of the event, and its headline act Maxi Priest. Chats to Chris King of Universal Music about the enduring popularity of reggae in NZ. Speaks to Logan Bell of Katchafire and Scott Towers (aka Chopper Reedz) of Fat Freddy's Drop about the popularity of their music. Seeks comment from Maxi Priest about his upcoming appearance at the festival."

Title: "Fitness trainer impresses judges"
description: "Fitness trainer impresses judges"

Author: "Christensen, Paul"
Title: "The junk stops here"
description: "Reports on how, as concern grows about childhood obesity, some schools are fighting back by teaching pupils to grow healthy food. Asks if we are doing enough nonetheless, to keep children safe from the 'junk food juggernaut'."

Author: "Evans, Ryan"
Title: "Bike champ's a family man at heart"
description: "Bike champ's a family man at heart"

description: "Veteran calls it quits with the Phoenix"

Author: "Long, David"

description: "Gudsell goes to top of the team"

Author: "Light, Liz"
Title: "Honour thy chiefs"
description: "Visits the site of an alternative celebration to Waitangi Day, to be held at Mangungu, 12 Feb 2011. Talks to Mita Harris about the treaty signing at the Mangungu Mission House, 12 Feb 1840. Describes the colourful 19th century publican at NZ's oldest pub, the Horeke Hotel."

Author: "Whelan, Arthur"
Title: "Burning ambition"
description: "Talks to Ant Sang who is best known for his work on bro'Town and has just finished a 190-page graphic novel, Shaolin burning taking the reader through the process of the books creation."

Author: "Catherall, Sarah"
Title: "In business, naturally"
description: "Talks to the Wellington mother and natural skincare entrepreneur about what motivated her to start her Antipodes range of products."

Author: "Crean, Julie"
Author (detailed): "Julie Crean, Paul Lewis and Andrew Alderson"
Title: "Summer in the city; Five best day trips; Best 'boutique' golf courses"
description: "Showcases activities and attractions in the city, including best sculpture trails, best 'off the leash' dog walking spots, best short walks, best city parks, best camping spots within 90 minutes of the city and best winery vists. Includes the five best day trips and five best activities for kids, and the six best 'boutique' golf courses."

Author: "Jackson, Kerri"
Title: "Backyard wonder"
description: "Showcases activities on the island, including where to stay and eat. Reports on her two-day stay for her 40th birthday."

Title: "Courting flavour; Holding court"
description: "Presents a guide to some of the best food courts in the city, according to the team of tasters."

Author: "Nash, Kieran"
Title: "Auckland Anniversary Day Regatta 2011"
description: "Spotlights the annual anniversary day regatta that is in its 171st year, Auckland, 31 Jan 2011. Talks to the yachting legend about her participation over the years. Overviews the history of the event. Seeks comment from local tugboat enthusiast Baden Pascoe about the annual tugboat race. Chats to several competitors in the radio-controlled yacht race sponsored by Oceanbridge. Speaks to regatta chair Eric Mahoney about the big-name classic yachts participating in the race, including 'Rainbow', 'Ranger', 'Tawera' and 'Thelma'. Talks to the athlete who is now an ambassador for the Spirit of Adventure Trust about her experience aboard the iconic yacht 'Spirit of New Zealand' as a teenager. Describes the recent makeover of the yacht. Anticipates the 2011 Auckland Seafood Festival, 29-31 Jan 2011. Discusses the dragon boat and waka ama competitions at the regatta. Informs that the 'HMNZS Wellington' will lead the regatta this year, and provides facts about the new patrol vessel."

Author: "Murray, Sarah"
Title: "What I do"
description: "Talks to Karen Thurston who is a Plunket nurse with her own young child to look after. Describes the routine of her day of readying her daughter for day-care and then going on to meet young mothers and the support she provides."

Talks to former Christchurch mayor Garry Moore, Christchurch East MP Lianne Dalziel, Christchurch mayor Bob Parker and Christchurch City Council chief executive Tony Marryatt and Minister of Earthquake Recovery Gerry Brownlee. Talks to people who have either been directly involved with the Pike River Mine or who have had specialist knowledge of underground coal mining. Reports on some of the economic and structural problems affecting the mine before the disaster, including evidence of serious internal tensions among company directors. Describes the pressure that workers and the company faced to meet production targets. Divulges that October bills were not paid after the explosion, even when the company appeared to be solvent at the time."

Mentions celebratory activities for the 50th anniversary, starting on 25 Feb 2011."

description: "Asks whether the National Government should sell state assets in order to pay off the country's debt. Looks at the pros and cons of such a strategy. Indicates the National Government may campaign to sell up to 49% of four state owned power companies. (Mighty River Power, Meridian, Genesis and Solid Energy). Uses Contact Energy as a case study with discussion associated around the number of present NZ shareholders and percentage of holdings by NZers. Includes a table of public assets which have been sold since March 1988 through to May 1999."

description: "Looks back on the life and work of the expat artist who forged a successful career as a graphic designer, children's book illustrator and book cover designer. Talks about 'The imaginative life and times of Graham Percy' exhibition, which tours NZ over the next two years, and the release of a new biography about the artist."

description: "Reviews 'The wonder of existence' by Herb Foley at Orezart (to 28 February), 'Transcryption' by 'et al' at Michael Lett (to 19 March) and 'New paintings' by Winston Roeth at the Jensen Gallery (to 19 March)."

Author: "Chug, Kiran"

description: "Reports that applications for nationally significant projects, such as the Mokihinui hydro scheme, may be handled differently in the future. Suggests proposals to streamline consent process, as required by the Resource Management Act, have raised fears big commercial developments could too easily gain access to the conservation estate."

Author: "Christian, Dionne"

description: "Looks forward to the second Auckland Fringe held at various venues throughout the city from 25 February to 13 March 2011."

description: "Talks to the US screenwriter of the Oscar-nominated film The king's speech, David Seidler. Also speaks to his NZ son about their sometimes fractious relationship, living between Rotorua and Malibu, and his reaction to the idea of a motion picture about a stutterer and his speech therapist."

description: "Explores the phenomenon of noise levels in cities, noting the debate between local residents, such as Auckland central city resident Tim Coffey, and CBD event organisers and attendees, such as Laneway Festival concertgoer Flex Webster. Looks into the soundproofing requirements of construction companies. Tests inner city Auckland for decibel readings using a sound meter. Produces evidence of international anti-noise activism. Presents some scientific facts on soundwaves and hearing."

Author: "Falconer, Phoebe"

description: "Presents an obituary for one of NZ's most respected historians and authors, who was particularly admired for her works on the Tuhoe people."

Author: "Morton, Frances"

description: "Reports on the risk and economic costs of foodborne illness, following the death of NZ tourist Sarah Carter from food poisoning in Thailand. Provides statistics of food poisoning deaths in NZ since 1997. Notes the cause and symptoms of the most common foodborne illnesses, and lists basic food safety rules. Warns of the consequences of humans eating pet food."

Author: "Gibson, Anne"

Title: "A quick word ..."

description: "Talks to NZ actor Rhys Darby about his switch from comedy to a romantic role, in the leadup to the release of the film Love Birds on 24 February 2011. Seeks comment from production designer Andrew McAlpine and director Paul Murphy about the opportunity to showcase Auckland scenery and use ducks as a love interest."

Mentions the monthly retirement savings needed for those on the average salary (depending on what age the saving starts). Includes economist Gareth Morgan's opinions on the state of the property market, current and future."

Disscusses the opposing views of the two writers and the arguments behind them."

Talks to Teri Puketapu about the process for the waka to be returned to the Wellington City Council. Gives some examples of their treatment and how they were portrayed in the series but focuses on Dakota Biddle along with comment about Michaela Steenkamp and Danielle Hayes."

Author: "Anderson, Vicki"
Title: "Life after reality"
description: "Takes a look at some of the realities for young women who want to embark on a career of modelling by starting out on the reality TV series, New Zealand's Next Top Model. Includes comments from other local residents as to why they choose to live in such an isolated location. Notes Ngawi's Big Three fishing competition this weekend is held over three days drawing hundreds of fishermen from as far a field as Auckland and Taranaki."

Title: "Facing up to the formidable"
description: "Gives a personal view of a mountain bike race that has been described as 'brutal, unforgiving, savage, never-ending and cruel'. Reports that 1000 riders will participate in the 50 kilometre race. Details a dry run the author had over the course with an experienced guide. Karapoti Challenge starts at Karapoti Park north of Upper Hutt at 10am on March 5."

Indicates the show she will be putting on at the Isaac Theatre Royal in Christchurch on Saturday will try and cover all the different kinds of music she has played over the years, from gypsy favourites, to soulful classical and jazz ballads to Celtic and funky."

Outlines in detail why Ballantynes has survived as a business while many similar stores in Christchurch and in the rest of NZ have closed or failed."

Title: "Paget jumps at chance to boost ranking"
description: "Paget jumps at chance to boost ranking"

description: "Reports in the wake of the September 2010 Christchurch earthquake Dunedin is taking a look at their own heritage buildings and how much they might lose if they were to experience a significant earthquake. Takes stock of the number of Historic Places Trust category one buildings, how many of those are earthquake strengthened, the number of heritage visitors that come to Dunedin and the economic benefit that brings. Assesses the likelihood of an earthquake in Dunedin considering the location of fault lines in the area and what the city has experienced so far. Comments on the current policy of Dunedin City Council with regard to earthquake strengthening of buildings."

Author (detailed): "Kim Knight, additional reporting by Anthony Hubbard"
Title: "Hunger pains; Hunger pains : a Sunday Star-Times special investigation"
description: "Investigates the issue of hunger in NZ. Looks at NZ's poverty statistics, the increasing use of food banks in the main cities, and the effects of people's inability to purchase healthy food. Talks to two beneficiaries about how they feed themselves. Cites the response of Christchurch City Missioner Michael Gorman to the Government's approach that people can pay bills if they budget properly. Itemises the contents of a food bank parcel and lists the top ten reasons for people to use food banks. Challenges the myths about ways the poor might economise. Asks members of the National, Labour, Greens, ACT, and Progressive parties for their policies on food security."

Author: "Moore, Dave"
Title: "Time for some road sense"
description: "Informs of the present strategies for reducing the road toll and suggests depletion in the NZ road toll must be predicated on a cohesive safety plan instead of an occasional blitz on this and a clamp down on that. Outlines a list of what the author considers to be areas of concern and part of a cohesive safety plan. Cerate some police presence, target more than just speed and alcohol, educate people about indicating, teach people to filter and merge, educate driver about proper lane use, make cyclists use cycle lanes, advertise speed cameras, test drivers properly, lock drunk drivers up, jail for failing to stop, encourage modern, safe cars and stop blaming the roads."

Author: "Macfie, Rebecca"
Title: "Quake : 12.51, Tuesday, February 22, 2011; Fatal failure"
description: "Covers the effects of the devastating 6.3 magnitude earthquake, which has caused irrevocable damage and killed a substantial number of people, principally in the Central Business District. Ask why, concentrating on the CBD, did so many major buildings fall so catastrophically. Briefly profiles some of the stories of those who had close calls in the earthquake, and considers what long-lasting effects the ruination of Christchurch city will have on its residents."

Author: "Macfie, Rebecca"
Title: "Quake : 12.51, Tuesday, February 22, 2011; Fatal failure"
description: "Covers the effects of the devastating 6.3 magnitude earthquake, which has caused irrevocable damage and killed a substantial number of people, principally in the Central Business District. Asks why, concentrating on the CBD, did so many major buildings fall so catastrophically. Briefly profiles some of the stories of those who had close calls in the earthquake, and considers what long-lasting effects the ruination of Christchurch city will have on its residents."

Author: "Meng-Yee, Carolyne"
Title: "Headaches on new plane"
description: "Reports on some the issues with the Air NZ Boeing 777-300 jet including passengers forced to wait for their meals, as cabin crew struggle to dish up in the narrower economy class aisles, Skycouch 'cuddle class', which was unveiled more than a year ago has yet to be approved by Civil Aviation Authority."

Author: "Clifton, Jane,"
Title: "The bottom line"
description: "Looks at where the money is going to come from to fix Christchurch and how this will affect what happens. Suggests that taxpayers may question the policy of guaranteeing to restore the ground, asking instead whether to simply accept that some places are too unstable to be built on. Considers this in light of the Earthquake Commission being the only major insurer in the world to insure the ground beneath buildings affected by an earthquake."

Author: "Burgess, Michael"
Title: "It's life in the fast lane now"
description: "Tells of Catherine Latu, who plays for Mystics netball team, and looking forward to starting with NZ team after standing down for 4 years while representing for Samoa."

Author: "Somerset, Guy"
Title: "The lost boys"
description: "Talks to David Cohen, author of 'Little criminals: the story of a New Zealand boys' home', about his time at Epuni Boys' Home in Lower Hutt. Relates some of the experiences he and other boys endured."

Title: "Silver winner in great Nick"
description: "Tells of Olympic hero Nick Willis getting his rightful Beijing Silver medal and show good mile form at fundraising meet at Newtown Park. Mentions Willis finishing third at the 2008 Beijing Olympics, but was elevated to Silver after Rashid Ramzi tested positive for a blood-boosting drug."

Author: "Orange, Claudia"
Title: "Dame Judith Binney, 1940-2011"
description: "Pays tribute to the teacher, professor and scholar, particularly lauded for her work 'Encircled lands: Te Urewera 1820-1921'."

description: "Penney's NBA dream ends after Spurs release him"

Author: "Gibb, John"
Title: "Taonga show for Shanghai"
description: "Reports on preparations for an Otago Museum exhibition of MaÃÑori treasures at the Shanghai Museum from 21 July 2011. Notes the visit by two administrative officials from Shangai Museum to view the exhibits. Talks to co-curator Associate Professor John Broughton about this first showing of MaÃÑori taonga in China."

Author: "Roberts, Hugh,"
Title: "Chocks away; A widower's lament"
description: "Book reviews of 2 volumes of poetry. [Print exclusive]"

Title: "Light as a feather"

Author: "McMurran, Alistair"

description: "Bond the king of Ruataniwha with two more titles; aggressive Strack defends her crown"

Author: "Amery, Mark"
Title: "Perfume-ance art"
description: "Talks to internationally-renowned NZ artist Dane Mitchell about his series of installations centering around 'the smell of an empty room'. Explains that the idea is to encourage thinking about how personal perception is, and the tension that is possible between something that is concealed, and something that is revealed."

Author: "Boniface, Linley"
Title: "Struck down early"
description: "Asks whether NZ is following in the steps of the US in relation to the trend that strokes in the young and middle-aged are on the rise, due particularly to the obesity epidemic and smoking."

Author: "Oldham, Stu"
Title: "History still stands"
description: "Talks to University of Otago Associate Professor Alexander Trapeznik about best and worst of the historic buildings in Dunedin's waterfront business and industrial precinct, noting those that have been preserved, those that are in disrepair and those that have been lost. Warns of the potential demise of some of the commercial buildings, noting the ironic reason that many have survived. Backgrounds the history of the mercantile heritage precincts and their links to the region's early business development. Touches on problems of heritage tourism. Provides a diagram featuring 59 historic waterfront buildings."

Author: "Carr, Rose"
Title: "Obliviously obese"
description: "Warns NZers of the dangers of being obese despite having a 'normal' BMI, given that we are among the fattest nations in the developed world."

Author: "Entwisle, Peter"
Title: "Paying the past its due"
description: "Offers advice about the preservation of Dunedin's old buildings, discussing who should do it and who should pay for it.  Notes that the topic of heritage buildings has beome timely in the wake of the Christchurch earthquake (September 4 2010) and the unassisted collapse of the part of the Barron Building in Rattray Street. Recaps Dunedin's record of destroying and preserving its historic buildings. Touches on the deficit in the recording of heritage buildings, mentioning the role of the Historic Places Trust."

Author: "Paul, Gregor,"
Title: "Something to Tew about"
description: "Tells of NZ Rugby Union expecting to post a $10 million loss in April on top of the almost $16 million deficit last year, which sees chief executive Steve Tew come under heavy criticism."

Author: "Paul, Gregor,"
Title: "Evans ready to answer SOS"
description: "Talks with Nick Evans, ex All Black currently playing for Harlequins, being prepared to step in for Dan Carter if asked."

Author: "Dungey, Kim"
Title: "Costing knowledge"
description: "Examines the cost of tertiary study. Compares student debt and consequent earnings by field of study for 2004 and 2008. Discusses the subjects that lead to the highest earnings. Investigates the main reasons students choose particular courses. Summarises average student loans and expenses. Talks to Dr David Clark about whether education is a good investment, noting his own choice of arts subjects, the skills he acquired,  and his subsequent careers. Reports on students who do not consider earning potential when selecting courses. Speaks to Dr James Maclaurin, head of the philosophy department at the University of Otago, about successful philosophy graduates and the value of philosophy."

Author: "Alderson, Andrew"
Title: "A world away from competing"
description: "Tells of NZ cricket team, how negative selection and failure to do the basics are hurting the team."

Author: "Priestley, Rebecca,"
Title: "Good with gold"
description: "Looks at the work of three NZers - Jim Johnston, Kerstin Lucas and Fern Kelly - to create unique products in the form of nanogold and nanosilver wool, for high-end international markets."

Author: "Wallace, Neal"
Title: "Understated high achiever has cachet"
description: "Features the winner of 2010 Westpac Otago Chamber of Commerce Business Excellence business skills retail category. Profiles the owners - Mat Woods, Paul Highton and Miff Macdiarmid -  and chronicles the history of the sporting retailer."

Author: "Porteous, Debbie"
Author (detailed): "Debbie Porteous, Chris Morris and David Loughrey"
Title: "Refurbishing a numbers game; Dunedin faces hard choices over what buildings to protect; Students could live here; Governing body role to play"
description: "Continues the series on the future of the city's industrial and commercial buildings. Examines the realities of saving heritage buildings such as the high costs, and renovation and reuse issues. Talks to NZ Historical Places Trust Otago-Southland area manager Owen Graham who believes that the city may have to pick the most significant buildings and town precincts to protect, rather than trying to save everything. Suggests two possible uses for the Donald Reid warehouse: student accommodation or the Otago Regional Council headquarters. Includes the views of historical buildings author Lois Galer on the subject."

Author: "Light, Liz"
Title: "Rare and beautiful"
description: "Tells of Westland's kotuku colony in Waitangi Roto Stream in Southern Westland."

Author: "Van Beynen, Martin"
Title: "12.51pm : the opening act of a city's tragedy"
description: "Looks back on the four days after the 6.3 magnitude earthquake struck the city touching on the stories of survival and tragedy."

Author: "Anderson, Vicki"
Title: "Mum, I thought you were dead"
description: "Recalls the experiences of the reporter and her daughter during and after the magnitude-6.3 earthquake."

Author: "Steeman, Marta"
Author (detailed): "Marta Steeman, Tamlyn Stewart and Tom Pullar-Strecker"
Title: "Recovery : first phase is survival"
description: "Reports that businesses in the central business district (CBD) of the city are assessing the damage caused by the earthquake and looking forward."

Author: "McCrone, John"
Title: "A shaky future"
description: "Presents the author's experience of the earthquake while discussing the issues surrounding the rebuilding of the city suggesting that two issues stand out: the extent of the infrastructure rebuild and the question of what to rebuild."

Author: "Fitzsimons, Tom"
Title: "Pockets of pain and hope"
description: "Visits the coastal suburb of Redcliffs to talk to some of the residents about their experiences during and after the earthquake."

Author: "Milne, Jonathan"
Title: "Brick by brick, we'll return"
description: "Tells of the Christchurch Cathedral collapsing under the earthquake, but has the hopes of locals and those who grew up in Canterbury to rebuild and restore the Cathedral."

Author: "Fisher, David"
Title: "Seconds to flee as six floors fall"
description: "Talks with Mary-Anne Jackson, one of the survivors working in the CTV building that collapsed in the Christchurch earthquake and took most of her colleagues."

Author: "Fisher, David"
Title: "Path back brings deeper despair"
description: "Tells of the residents of Kaiapoi, Bexley, and Avonside still have cracked walls and portable toilets from last year's quake (September 4 2010), and whether they will ever recover."

Author: "McCormick, Gary,"
Title: "The city was the colour of death"
description: "Gives authors account of the Christchurch earthquake."

Author: "Fisher, David"
Title: "The search for life in The Void"
description: "Tells of specialised search teams tunnel through the darkness to find surviviors of the quake."

Author: "Woodham, Kerre"
Title: "Their spirit is strong"
description: "Gives authors recount of the day of the Christchurch earthquake (Feb 22 2011)."

Author: "Van Beynen, Martin"
Title: "Ripping guts from out city"
description: "Presents the observations of the reporter about the impact of the earthquake on the city. Talks about his experiences during and after the earthquake."

Author: "Cronshaw, Tim"
Title: "Buried alive in rubble"
description: "Talks about how the farming editor survived being buried in 'The Press' building after its top floor collapsed during the magnitude-6.3 earthquake."

Author: "Eleven, Beck"
Title: "Why? : We'll never know"
description: "Talks about the reporter's experiences during and after the earthquake."

Author: "Quigley, Sarah"
Title: "Quake pain felt in Berlin"
description: "Recounts the author's experience of watching news coverage of the earthquake via live internet streaming while living in Berlin."

Author: "Bennett, Joe,"
Title: "There goes the neighbourhood"
description: "Describes the author's experiences during and after the earthquake. Talks about the damage caused to the town."

Author: "Cheng, Derek"
Title: "My 26 hours trapped in the rubble"
description: "My 26 hours trapped in the rubble"

Author: "Trevett, Claire"
Title: "Wedding brings smiles in tying times"
description: "Wedding brings smiles in tying times"

Author: "Koubaridis, Andrew"
Title: "Bricklayer's death carries a dreadful irony"
description: "Bricklayer's death carries a dreadful irony"

Author: "Fitzsimons, Tom"
Title: "Pockets of pain and hope; Redcliffs deals with its disaster"
description: "Visits the coastal suburb of Redcliffs to talk to some of the residents about their experiences during and after the earthquake."

Author: "Bennett, Joe,"
Title: "Like a rabbit in a dog's jaws"
description: "Describes the experiences of the resident and author during and after the earthquake. Talks about the damage caused to the town."

Author: "Steeman, Marta"
Author (detailed): "Marta Steeman, Tamlyn Stewart and Tom Pullar-Strecker"
Title: "Businesses go for it to survive"
description: "Reports on the relocation of Christchurch businesses to areas outside the CBD. Describes the measures discussed so far to aid business recovery. Details the transition plans of several businesses: Verkerks, Ballantynes, Independent Fisheries, Ngai Tahu Holdings, Silver Fern Farms, Jade Software and Tait Electronics."

Author: "Taylor, Phil,"
Title: "On two wheels through the rubble"
description: "Takes a journey on a bicycle through the reporter's hometown the day after the earthquake struck, visiting the hill suburbs running east to Sumner. Talks to various residents along the way about their earthquake experiences."

Author: "Shennan, Jennifer"
Title: "Royal New Zealand Ballet's duplicated performances a real achievement"
description: "Reviews the Royal NZ Ballet performances of Verdi Variations and Pinocchio, Opera House, Wellington."

Author: "Dart, William"
Title: "Music makes nobel salute"
description: "Reviews the Auckland Philharmonia Orchestra's Thursday concert (24 February 2011)."

Author: "Rae, Bernadette"
Title: "What it takes to be a winner"
