Author: "Laugesen, Ruth"
Title: "Beating cancer - beyond chemotherapy"
description: "Investigates the claim that the right mental attitude, a healthy diet, exercise and meditation can help beat cancer. Talks to investment banker Rob Cameron about his experience in battling metastatic lung cancer. Discusses his diet and his positive attitude towards chemotherapy. Talks to a range of oncologists and nutritionists about the scientific evidence regarding the effects of conventional healthy diets, antioxidants, and lifestyle on cancer. Looks at the evidence for support groups and psychological treatment and the maintenance of hope and a positive attitude in improving the quality of life versus the actual life expectancy."

Author: "Laugesen, Ruth"
Title: "Eat pray heal"
description: "Investigates the claim that the right mental attitude, a healthy diet, exercise and meditation can help beat cancer. Talks to investment banker Rob Cameron about his experience in battling metastatic lung cancer. Discusses his diet and his positive attitude towards chemotherapy. Talks to a range of oncologists and nutritionists about the scientific evidence regarding the effects of conventional healthy diets, antioxidants, and lifestyle on cancer. Looks at the evidence for support groups and psychological treatment and the maintenance of hope and a positive attitude in improving the quality of life versus the actual life expectancy."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "More 1080 is needed to save our native birds"
description: "Looks at the decline of NZ's native birds and the effects of mast years where heavy flowering, fruiting and seeding of beech and rimu forests lead to abundance of predators. Describes the subsequent 1080 poisoning regimes required to combat this kind of event and the subsequent survival rates for the different species. Highlights the arguments for and against the use of 1080. Discusses the investigiation and conclusion of the Parliamentary Commissioner for the Environment, Jan Wright, that we should be using much more of it and looks at the criticism that 1080 is hurting the very species it is supposed to be helping."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "Fight or flight"
description: "Looks at the decline of NZ's native birds and the effects of mast years where heavy flowering, fruiting and seeding of beech and rimu forests lead to abundance of predators. Describes the subsequent 1080 poisoning regimes required to combat this kind of event and the subsequent survival rates for the different species. Highlights the arguments for and against the use of 1080. Discusses the investigiation and conclusion of the Parliamentary Commissioner for the Environment, Jan Wright, that we should be using much more of it and looks at the criticism that 1080 is hurting the very species it is supposed to be helping."

Title: "David Hartnell"
description: "Visits the columnist's Auckland house and talks about his career and his new memoir."

Author: "Wichtel, Diana"
Title: "That's Hartnell with two 'l's"
description: "Visits the columnist's Auckland house and talks about his career and his new memoir."

Title: "Tracy Beaker's Kiwi influence"
description: "Talks to children's book author Jacqueline Wilson about her admiration for Katherine Mansfield."

Author: "Ireland, Peter"
Title: "A Man Walks Out of a Bar ... Lucien Rizos: New Zealand photographs review"
description: "Reviews 'A man walks out of a bar ... New Zealand photographs, 1979-1982'."

Author: "Ireland, Peter"
Title: "The New Zealanders"

Title: "Books of the land : recent releases reviewed"
description: "Books of the land : recent releases reviewed"

Author: "Hay, Natasha"
Title: "Indelible ink"
description: "Talks to Jacob Rajan and Justin Lewis about the 15 year history of the local company and how their mask-oriented show work develops. Looks at what it means to be signed by top US agent David Lieberman."

Author: "White, Margo"
Title: "Cancer calling"
description: "Looks at the recent classification of radio frequency electromagnetic fields from mobile phones as being "possibly carcinogenic" to humans by the World Health Organisation and the International Agency for Research on Cancer. Discusses the relative merits of the landline and the cost of cell phones."

Author: "Bowden, Jennifer"
Title: "Is too much salmon bad for you?"
description: "Answers questions about the good fats that salmon contains and the place of coconut milk and cream in a normal diet."

Author: "Bowden, Jennifer"
Title: "Fat chance : can too much of a good thing be bad?"
description: "Answers questions about the good fats that salmon contains and the place of coconut milk and cream in a normal diet."

Author: "Griffin, Peter"
Title: "Google unable to compete with Facebook"
description: "Looks at Google's latest effort to address its social network weakspot called +1."

Author: "Griffin, Peter"
Title: "Social fretwork"
description: "Looks at Google's latest effort to address its social network weakspot called +1."

Author: "Cooper, Michael,"
Title: "William P Foley II and the New Zealand wine industry"
description: "Profiles the wine-based empire in NZ of entrepreneurial American billionaire Bill Foley."

Author: "Cooper, Michael,"
Title: "The quiet American"
description: "Profiles the wine-based empire in NZ of entrepreneurial American billionaire Bill Foley."

Author: "Cairns, Lois"
Title: "Invisible scars of quake trauma"
description: "Discusses the post-earthquake mental issues that are affecting many Christchurch residents. Details the post-disaster relaxation techniques taught by US psychologist Dr James Gordon, and his desire to work in Christchurch. Relays a Christchurch woman's experience of being unable to cope. Documents the ongoing need for counselling in the city, citing the most common mental health problems people are facing. Talks to David Beaumont whose son died in the CTV building about his healing process."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1877"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1877. Recounts the formal opening of the railway line between Oamaru and Christchurch, 1 Feb 1877, the line between Lawrence and Tokomairiro,  2 Apr 1877 and the opening a rail link between Dunedin and Blueskin, 11 Dec 1877. Reports and comments on the first show of the newly-formed Otago Agricultural and Pastoral Association, which opened at Forbury Park, Dunedin, 28 Nov 1877."

Author: "Reed, Megan Nicol"
Title: "Drawn to the danger zone"
description: "Interviews  the TV3 journalist about her self-organised trip to Afghanistan in 2008 and her return 18 months ago from London with her family. Talks about returning to Afghanistan, this time with Nato troops, and how she views the role of a working mother. Explains how she finally made it into journalism and the big stories she has covered since."

Author: "Dudding, Adam"
Title: "Unforgiven"
description: "Interviews the mother of Dunedin murder victim Sophie Elliott. Touches on the foundation ('The Sophie Elliott Foundation') she has set up with husband, Gil Elliot, educating young women about relationship abuse. Describes the process of writing a book about the 2008 murder, and trial, with former Dunedin police officer Bill O'Brien.  Notes the book launch coincides with what would have been Sophie's 26th birthday. Delves into the strain of the murder on family relationships. Explains the relief afforded by the eye movement desensitisation and reprocessing (EMDR) technique used by clinical psychologist Nigel Latta. Supplies brief notes on Clayton Weatherston, convicted for the crime in 2009."

Author: "McLeod, Rosemary"
Title: "Suffer the children"
description: "Explores the incidence of bullying in schools in NZ.  Questions chief Human Rights Commissioner Rosslyn Noonan about the failure of the Ministry of Education to implement recommendations drawn up by the Commission in 2009. Talks to Whanganui parent Pip Houghton-Rountree about her son's experience of being bullied at New Plymouth Boys' High School."

Author: "Van Der Schaaf, Jessica"
Author (detailed): "/ as told to Jessica Van der Schaaf"
Title: "What I do"
description: "Talks to the Matakana artist about her job, inspiration, and why she has to watch out for splinters."

Author: "Forbes, Michael"
Title: "Marice McGregor's tragic path to death; Mulligan : murderer who lied and lied"
description: "Examines the details of the three-week High Court case of the murder of Marice McGregor by Dean Mulligan. Includes her brother's memories of their family and childhood upbringing."

Author: "Greive, Duncan"
Title: "When one door closes ..."
description: "Talks to Ruban Nielson, formerly of art-punk band The Mint Chicks, about his new band, Unknown Mortal Orchestra and their successes in the US. Discusses how he came to sign up with Fat Possum, his relationship with brother and former bandmate Kody Nielson, and the ephipany on his 30th birthday."

Author: "Chug, Kiran"
Title: "Was that a gale, a gust or a tornado?"
description: "Looks at the science behind the terminology used by weather forecasters. Explains terms such as 'weather bomb', 'gales' 'hurricanes' and  'tornadoes'."

Author: "Venter, Nick"
Title: "Burma Bill fought for young MaÃÑori"
description: "Burma Bill fought for young MaÃÑori"

Author: "Donoghue, Tim"
Title: "Business, sportsman and lively character"
description: "Business, sportsman and lively character"

Author: "Macdonald, Nikki"
Title: "The politics of playing god; Pharmac tradeoff may be high price of deal with US"
description: "Notes as NZ enters free-trade negotiations with the United States, the US want major reforms to Pharmac's drug-buying monopoly. Investigates what Pharmac does, how it does it and examines the consequences of their decisions."

Author: "Macdonald, Nikki"
Title: "It's a tricky job, but someone has to do it"
description: "Talks to Matthew Brougham about his time as chief executive of Pharmac from which he has just resigned. Includes a list of Pharmac's top 10 drugs by cost, Pharmac's top 10 drugs by prescription numbers, international generic drug price comparison."

Title: "Cardiac rehab nurse knows firsthand the cost of medicine"
description: "Talks to Paul Peacock who works as a cardiac rehabilitation nurse at Wellington Hospital and coaches heart patients to exercise, eat healthily and take preventative drugs. Notes at 34 he had two stents inserted to unblock a 99 percent blockage in one of his main arteries and now takes preventative drugs for life. Gives his opinion on the system by which Pharmac operates and some of the heart patients he sees."

Author: "Chapman, Katie"
Title: "Driving the road toll down; If you drink, then drive you can't have seen the ads"
description: "Talks to Mark Stables, national adviser for crash investigations, with road fatalities being lower than aveage for this time of the year, 35 percent lower than last year. Ask whether the trend is a sustained trend or whether it is a 'blip'. Notes the strategies being used to prevent road accidents and death and factors that may effect the statistics including ticketing those speeding, fuel prices, safer cars and roads and targeting at risk groups of drivers. Comments on the advertising campaign run by the Transport Agency."

Author: "Macdonald, Nikki"
Title: "Rock'n'roller"
description: "Talks to Sarah Hudson whose work is being exhibited at the Maiden Aotearoa exhibition at Wellington City Gallery and notes her interest in feminism and femininity and particularly interested in how MaÃÑori women were portrayed in early photographs especially those who were commercialised and made into postcards."

Author: "Koubaridis, Andrew"
Title: "Funeral is priority for family of shot man"
description: "Funeral is priority for family of shot man"

Title: "Family at a loss over fatal asthma attack"
description: "Family at a loss over fatal asthma attack"

Author: "Palmer, Rebecca"
Title: "Shear determination"
description: "Reports on new efforts to promote wool over the use of synthetics. Notes the succesful image of merino for fine clothing and high fashion with coarser wool being used for carpets, bedding and upholstery. Indicates the new campaign is going to transform wool's image by positioning the fibre at the high end of the market and notes it is a multi-national effort."

Author: "Palmer, Rebecca"
Title: "Shelf life"
description: "Visits some of Wellington's public libraries and describes what's on offer by talking to library users who walk in through the doors."

Author: "Macdonal, Nikki"
Title: "Storm watch"
description: "Describes the author's experience of being in Wellington during cold southerly weather over a three day period."

Author: "Eleven, Beck"
Title: "There's mud in your eye"
description: "Looks back on last year's Mud, Sweat and Tears challenge held on the Banks Peninsula that was preceded by heavy rain which the organisers called a blessing. Notes the next Mud, sweat and tear challenge will be held at Motukarara Race Course on Sunday, 3 July."

Author: "Brownlee, Gerry,"
Title: "Robust decisions on rebuilding vital for all landowners; How best to deliver the bad news?"
description: "Explains the process behind some of the big decisions to be made on the future of some Christchurch land. Notes where the damage delivered by the September 4 (2010) earthquake was able to be fixed by relatively modest civil works, the February 22 (2011) quake has caused much of the work that was under way to be reconsidered and presents a host of far greater engineering challenges. Includes maps that show the difference in scale between the two events. Includes comment from Vernon Small The Press national affairs editor."

Author: "Sell, David"
Title: "Insight, originality from famed strings"
description: "Reviews the Brentano String Quartet as part of the Chamber Music New Zealand Kaleidoscopes Concert Season in St. Andrew's at Rangi Ruru, Thursday, June 9."

Author: "Matthews, Philip"
Title: "UC : university challenge; In the school of hard knocks"
description: "Investigates the seriousness of the disruption to Canterbury University caused by the Canterbury and Christchurch earthquakes. Reveals the details of the damage to various building on the campus and the likely solutions once all the assessments have been completed. Debates the likelihood the site of the university campus will change. Assesses the number of students the university has lost and how many are likely to return either in term 2 or next year. Describes how students have managed to cope with the disruption, missing out on classes, having classes in different venues and helping out the citizens of Christchurch to remove the debris caused by the liquefaction."

Author: "Todd, Rebecca"
Title: "Fear factor keeps students away"
description: "Investigates the long-term impacts on Christchurch's multimillion dollar international student market caused by the earthquakes in Christchurch and Canterbury."

Author: "Crean, Mike"
Title: "Nasty family surprise"
description: "Outlines how Derek Anderson started a campaign of running a pilot bowel cancer screen-testing project via his Riccarton Rotary Club. Notes how he is a prostate cancer survivor and now his daughter has been diagnosed and is fighting an advanced case of bowel cancer. Reports the very positive response to their pilot screen-testing motivated the project team to lobby the government for extra funding for bowel cancer diagnosis and treatment. Notes the Ministry of Health is planning a similar project for Auckland. Includes a personal note from his daughter, Lisa Mitchell, about how she is coping with the diease."

Author: "Williams, David"
Title: "Flood risk grows as ground slumps and sea rises"
description: "Reports James Hansen, a US climate scientist, says it is "very important" that a city hit by two earthquakes, with subsidence of up to a metre in places thinks about sea level rise when rebuilding. Gives his opinion with regard to sea levels rising if green house gases are not reduced. Backgrounds the evidence to his assertions. Pinpoints those areas where sea rises will have most effect. Present alternative views  which suggest rises in sea levels will not be as great as James Hansen reports."

Author: "Crean, Mike"
Title: "Unheralded story of bravery, endurance"
description: "Unheralded story of bravery, endurance"

Author: "Tutty, Kevin"
Title: "Hockey gold medallist and pioneering coach"
description: "Hockey gold medallist and pioneering coach"

Author: "Eleven, Beck"
Title: "Christchurch gets its man"
description: "Reports that Roger Sutton takes on the helm of Canterbury Earthquake Recovery Authority (Cera) and the positive response he has received by the residents of Christchurch. Details his schooling and his interest in mountain trekking, which his wife has experienced. Assesses the suitability of Roger Sutton to carry out the onerous task of organising the rebuilding of Christchurch and describes what he brings to the position as a person."

Author: "Palmer, Rebecca"
Title: "Shear determination"
description: "Reports on new efforts to promote wool over the use of synthetics. Notes the succesful image of merino for fine clothing and high fashion with coarser wool being used for carpets, bedding and upholstery. Indicates the new campaign is going to transform wool's image by positioning the fibre at the high end of the market and notes it is a multi-national effort."

Author: "Lynch, Keith"
Title: "Ohau I love to snow board"
description: "Describes how snowboarding lifts the spirits of the author during the winter months. Takes the reader through his learning to snowboard at the age of 22 years old in a light-hearted way. Recounts with delight learning to snowboard again on Ohau ski field years later."

Author: "Lewis, John"
Title: "His voice is deep but he flies higher"
description: "Talks to the bass baritone about his life since leaving Dunedin for London over a decade ago to pursue a life in opera."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1879"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1879. Recounts the circumstances of a fatal explosion in the Kaitangata Coal Company mine, Kaitangata, as reported on 22 Feb 1879. Reports on a riot between Orangemen and Catholics, Dunedin, 26 Dec 1879. Sums up the ceremony of the laying of the foundation stone of the new Catholic Cathedral to be erected on Rattray St, 26 Jan 1879. Reports on the arrival to Port Chalmers on the Government steamer 'Hinemoa', carrying MaÃÑori disciples of Te Whiti, who were imprisoned in the Dunedin gaol, 4 Aug 1879. Includes a photograph of the charred remains of the Ross Buildings in the Octagon, Dunedin, after a major fire in Sep 1879."

Author: "Matthews, Lee"
Title: "Educating for a degree of success"
description: "Educating for a degree of success"

Author: "Galloway, Jill"
Title: "Milking till the cows come home"
description: "Milking till the cows come home"

Author: "Dinsdale, Mike"
Title: "North's oldest resident to be farewelled in style"
description: "North's oldest resident to be farewelled in style"

Author: "De Graaf, Peter"
Title: "Fire brigade stalwart dies, age 45"
description: "Fire brigade stalwart dies, age 45"

Author: "Rae, Sally"
Title: "Whole lot of horse sense at White Robe Lodge"
description: "Features the thoroughbred horse stud established in the 1950s and still run by the Anderton family. Talks to Karen Stewart and Sharyn Anderton about their operations, and some of the past and present stallions that have achieved distinction."

Title: "Death means only three Kiwi Battle of Britain pilots left alive"
description: "Death means only three Kiwi Battle of Britain pilots left alive"

Title: "Veteran of key sea battle dies at 88"
description: "Veteran of key sea battle dies at 88"

Author: "Cowdrey, Alice"
Title: "Colour is artist's one constant"
description: "Colour is artist's one constant"

Title: "Tributes flow for slain Nelson man"
description: "Tributes flow for slain Nelson man"

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1878"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1878. Features the Clutha River flood, reported in the 15 Oct 1878 edition. Reports on rising rivers in Canterbury and Otago, 30 Sep 1878. Describes the ceremony for the laying of the foundation stone of the new Town Hall, Dunedin, 25 May 1878. Touches on the release of birds into the city, 28 Aug 1878. Mentions other events during the year."

Author: "Rudd, Allison"
Title: "Whichever way the wind blows; Waitati finds winds of change can be fickle"
description: "Investigates whether public opinion has changed about the presence of wind farms in Otago and Southland. Provides information about wind energy and wind farms that are currently operating or are proposed. Talks to Scott Willis, project manager of the proposed wind farm for the Waikati-Blueskin community, about some of the challenges faced to date."

Author: "Hepburn, Steve"
Title: "Nurturer of OBHS rugby"
description: "Speaks to the retired teacher who has been involved with rugby at Otago Boys' High School for 35 years. Recalls some former students such as Richie McCaw."

Author: "Gilchrist, Shane"
Title: "For the love of Sophie"
description: "Talks to the mother of the young woman who was brutally murdered by her ex-boyfriend, Clayton Weatherston, on 9 Jan 2008. Discusses the book she wrote to help make sense of the tragedy, and the launch of the Sophie Elliott Foundation on 11 Jun 2011, on what would have been her daughter's 26th birthday. Offers advice to others about how to recognise potentially dangerous relationships. Provides additional information about the foundation. Lists a schedule of court appearances by the family in their pursuit of justice.  Describes classic signs of abuse and gives facts about dating violence. Mentions details about the Dunedin launch of the book, 11 Jun 2011."

Author: "Jaquiery, Stephen"
Title: "Shrek - we wool remember"
description: "Reflects on the phenomenon of Shrek, the 'hermit' merino sheep that achieved worldwide fame after being discovered at Bendigo Station on 14 Apr 2004. Estimates that Shrek would have been about 17 years old when he died on 6 Jun 2011."

Author: "James, Bryan"
Title: "[Books]; Essays keep the debate alive; A well-composed tale of music; Plenty of evidence of O'Sullivan's lesson; Fascinating account of how science can catch a killer; Affectionate account of postwar Wellington"
description: "[Books]; Essays keep the debate alive; A well-composed tale of music; Plenty of evidence of O'Sullivan's lesson; Fascinating account of how science can catch a killer; Affectionate account of postwar Wellington"

Title: "Behind the scenes at the museum"
description: "Interviews the director of the Otago Settlers Museum about her career and current role."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1880"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1880. Comments in the 13 Mar 1880 edition on the angry reaction of citizens after a brutal triple murder in the city. Reports on a heated meeting at the Southern Market, 8 Mar 1880, to discuss scarcity of employment. Chronicles the starting of the new clock at Dunedin Town Hall. Includes a photograph of a school vacation at St Clair Beach, Dunedin, during the 1880s."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1881"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1881. Focuses on the fatal wreck of the steamer 'SS Tararua', as reported on 2 May 1881. Informs that the manufacture of a 'Colonial cement' is a budding industry in NZ, 20 May 1881. Announces format changes to the newspaper, 11 Jul 1881. Reports in 1 Jan 1881 that the just-completed Kawarau Bridge is reputed to be the longest in the colony."

Author: "Laugesen, Ruth"
Title: "'You have to drink to be cool'"
description: "Asks teenagers in Wellington in school years 12 and 13 about their drinking habits. Discloses some facts from last year's Law Commission report about changes in teenage drinking behaviour. Ascertains some of the influences attributing to many teenagers deciding to drink excessively."

Author: "Barton, Tim"
Title: "Trentham proves a winner for Duncan"
description: "Trentham proves a winner for Duncan"

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1882"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1882. Reports on the establishment of the Union Brewery, north Dunedin, 21 Sep 1882. Covers a public meeting at St George's Hall, Milton, canvassing opinion on the establishment of a woollen mill, published on 29 Sep 1882. Reports on the opening of the Alexandra bridge, 1 Jun 1882, as reported on 5 Jun. Mentions the NZ origins of the manufacture of barbed wire, reported in the 5 Oct 1882 edition. Includes a 1882 photograph of the 'Dunedin', being loaded with frozen meat for transport from Port Chalmers to Britain. Touches on other events during the year."

Author: "Morris, Deborah"
Title: "Public defenders or private : battle lines are drawn"
description: "Focuses on the opening and expansion of the Public Defence Service (PDS) in Wellington and the fears that it will result in the demise of the independent criminal defence bar. Talks to barristers Noel Sainsbury and Mike Antunovic who see the PDS as a takeover by a government-run legal defence agency."

Author: "Smith, Charmian"
Title: "Renaissance man relishes Dunedin"
description: "Talks to the Australian-raised founder of the society about his love of Renaissance culture and the city since arriving in 2001. Describes the various activities of the group and informs of its annual midwinter concert, 'The Triumph of Mars', Dunedin Public Art Gallery, 17 Jun 2011."

Author: "Clifton, Jane,"
Title: "The booze minefield"
description: "Discusses the issues around the proposed Alcohol Reform Bill, which if passed will raise the minimum age for buying alcohol to 20 years, introduce parental consent."

Author: "McCrone, John"
Title: "Please Mother Nature, are we halfway there yet?"
description: "Asks, after three big earthquakes in the city, what the odds are of a fourth one. Speaks to a number of scientists, including Kelvin Berryman of GNS Science and Professor Jarg Pettinga, head of geological science at Canterbury University, about assessing the hazard of more large earthquakes. Talks about the 6.3 magnitude earthquake that occurred on Monday 13 June 2011."

Author: "Dignan, James"
Title: "Art seen"
description: "Reviews 'Silver linings' by Jane Crisp, The Artist's Room, Dunedin.  Reviews 'Storage systems' by Margaret Feeney, 'Castleland' by Justin Spiers and 'Please God, let my children grow and live happily ever after' by Ro Bradshaw, Blue Oyster Gallery, Dunedin, until 9 Jul 2011.  Reviews 'Otago Art Society annual exhibition', various artists, The Art Station, Dunedin Railway Station, until 30 Jun 2011."

Author: "Gillies, Abby"
Title: "Desperate bid to rescue buried teen"
description: "Desperate bid to rescue buried teen"

Author: "Johns, Geraldine"
Title: "The hard sell"
description: "Looks at recent trends in retail spending in NZ. Finds out the changing ways consumers are shopping and spending and the reasons behind these. Shop owners disclose how the recession and online shopping has affected sales."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1883"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1883. Recounts a rescue effort undertaken by the Government steamers 'Stella' and 'Kekeno' to rescue two crews from boats of the American sealing schooner 'Sarah W. Hunt', which were driven off Campbell Island on 27 Nov 1883. Presents accounts by the crewmen in the 27 Dec 1883 edition. Reports on the first meeting of the shareholders of the Otago Meat-freezing and Produce Company, 15 Oct 1883. Announces the death of the founder of the 'Otago Witness' and the 'Otago Daily Times', 2 Jul 1883. Touches on other events during the year. Includes a photograph of the first Salvation Army Congress, Dunedin, 1883."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "Writing from the edge"
description: "Describes how the relentlessness of the Christchurch earthquakes and the frustration of waiting for insurance companies to make decisions are taking its toll on the residents there."

Author: "Newton, Kate"
Title: "Inside the mind of an arsonist; Detectors sniff out suspicious fires; Fire-lighting urges nipped in the bud"
description: "Investigates what drives an arsonist to light fires, in the wake of the 15 deliberately lit fires that occurred in Wellington (Pauatahanui, Porirua, Tawa, Petone, Wainuiomata, Seatoun, Newtown and Karori) between 4 June 2011 and 10 June 2011. Speaks to a number of experts, including Katarina Fritzon, associate professor of forensic psychology at Bond University in Queensland, Ian Lambie, associate professor of psychology at the University of Auckland and Detective Senior Sergeant Steve Harwood, about the mindset of a serial arsonist. Talks about the motivation of convicted arsonist Alec Kenneth Langley. Looks at the use of photo-ionisation detectors by fire investigators to help detect hydrocarbons, petrol and other accelerants at the scene of suspected arsons. Touches on the NZ Fire Service's awareness and intervention programme that is aimed at people under the age of 18 with 'fire-lighting tendencies'."

Author: "Lomas, David"
Title: "The reluctant inventor"
description: "Talks to Otorohanga Dairy Farmer John Hartstone and son, Tony. Tells the story of how he invented a meter that can accurately measure a cow's milk production and how this has revolutionised dairy farming all over the world."

Author: "Glass, Amy"
Title: "Driver fled scene of fatal crash"
description: "Driver fled scene of fatal crash"

Author: "Wright, Michael"
Title: "Final farewell to passionate family man"
description: "Final farewell to passionate family man"

Title: "A true champion of agribusiness : Queen's Birthday honours"
description: "A true champion of agribusiness : Queen's Birthday honours"

Author: "Sachdeva, Sam"
Title: "Couple's charity saves native bush for Kiwis"
description: "Couple's charity saves native bush for Kiwis"

Author: "Moore, Christopher"
Title: "Cancer is just another project for Doig"
description: "Cancer is just another project for Doig"

Author: "Morton, Frances"
Title: "School daze"
description: "Talks to Auckland high school students about drug taking, the drugs they prefer and their accessibility, and parental drug taking. Compares the drug taking patterns of wealthy and poor students. Gives insights into the electronic measures some parents take to monitor their children. Solicits the views of a drug counsellor and a youth advisory panel member."

Author: "Burgess, Dave"
Title: "2040 : our city's space odyssey"
description: "Assess the Wellington 2040 city strategy and central city framework, 'Wellington 2040: the future of our central city', which will see the Wellington City Council build on the city's strengths and unique features to make it a world-class, smart green city. Talks to Wellington Employers' Chamber of Commerce chief executive Ken Harris and property developer Ian Cassels about their views on the vision. Looks at the goals and achievements of the city's last plan, 1997's 'Our city - our future', which developed a vision for the city in 2020."

Author: "Goile, Aaron"
Title: "Pool training tough for a young scholar"
description: "Pool training tough for a young scholar"

Author: "Priestley, Rebecca,"
Title: "What, me worry?"
description: "Discusses why it's taking so long to do something serious about NZ's carbon emissions. Reveals some recent research on climate change."

Author: "Bowden, Jennifer"
Title: "Fibre in the loop"
description: "Uncovers some statistics about colorectal cancer in NZ and recent research findings from the World Cancer Research Fund (WCRF) 2007 report. Suggests some dietary changes that can help prevent the risk of getting colorectal cancer."

Author: "Stanley, Ben"
Title: "National accolade catches out netball stalwart"
description: "National accolade catches out netball stalwart"

Author: "Smellie, Pattrick"
Title: "The battle for tomorrow's tech"
description: "Reports on the battle over the future of Lower Hutt's Industrial Research Limited (IRL), with a recent suggestion by the University of Auckland's vice-chancellor Professor Stuart McCutcheon to shift the crown-owned science organisation's activities to Auckland or Canterbury universities. Talks to IRL chief executive Shaun Coffey about his strategy for the future of the institution. Briefly explains what IRL does. Compares its annual revenue for 2006 and 2010."

Author: "Dekker, Diana"
Title: "Out of this world"
description: "Talks to the artist about her push to 'sell' real estate in Pioneer City on the Utopia Plains of Mars as part of the Letting Space art series. Notes that the 'Colonial Real Estate Pioneer City' showroom is open until 10 July 2011 in Wellington."

Author: "Catherall, Sarah"
Title: "We love Welly"
description: "Talks to Mike Fitzsimons and Nigel Beckford about the unusual coffee-table book they have created that celebrates Wellington with illustrations by graphic designers Jess Lunnon and Sandi MacKechnie."

Author: "Fitzsimons, Tom"
Title: "Service interrupted"
description: "Investigates whether Wellington can adapt to the $1 billion cuts over the next three years to the public service. Speaks to a number of civic leaders, including Greater Wellington Regional Council chairwoman Fran Wilde, Public Service Association national secretary Richard Wagstaff, and Wellington Employers' Chamber of Commerce chief executive Ken Harris about what effect the cuts will have. Looks back on how the public service cuts in the mid-1980s to mid-1990s changed the city, acknowledging that they had both a negative and a positive impact. Identifies some things Wellington can do to help its situation."

Author: "Catherall, Sarah"
Title: "Spiritual dimensions"
description: "Profiles the award-winning Tennent+Brown Archtiects director who has combined his passions for architecture and spirituality."

Author: "McMillan, Neale"
Title: "Nats in 'poll' position"
description: "Discusses the election changes of the major parties in the forthcoming November 26 election. Outlines the main policies of the parties and touches on the personalities. Speaks to some of the opposition with their views on John Key and the National party."

Author: "McCrone, John"
Title: "A rubbish week"
description: "Asks, after three big earthquakes in the city, what the odds are of a fourth one. Speaks to a number of scientists, including Kelvin Berryman of GNS Science and Professor Jarg Pettinga, head of geological science at Canterbury University, about assessing the hazard of more large earthquakes. Talks about the 6.3 magnitude earthquake that occurred on Monday 13 June 2011."

Author: "Anderson, Vicki"
Title: "Danger in the air?"
description: "Looks at the 15-year battle to have the high-frequency radio mast at Ouruhia, near Bottle Lake, removed because of concerns about its electromagnetic field. Speaks to former Ouruhia resident Penny Hargreaves about the issue and her fight to get the case heard in the High Court. Highlights the recent warning issued by the World Health Organisation that radiofrequency electromagnetic fields could cause cancer. Talks about NZ's approach to the issue, including the NZ standard. Reports on the case of former Ouruhia resident Jan Zervos who believes she developed a tumour on her uterus because of the electromagnetic radiation emitted from the mast. Notes that the 151-metre Radio Network tower was recently removed, after being seriously damaged in the recent series of earthquakes in Canterbury, and replaced with a 25-metre tower for Civil Defence."

Author: "McMillan, Neale"
Title: "The comeback kids"
description: "Considers the prospects of a number of politicians returning to Parliament after being absent and how this could affect dimensions of the House and what issues will be highlighted."

Author: "Matthews, Philip"
Title: "Logic requires spread of 1080"
description: "Considers the findings of the recently released report by the Parliamentary Commissioner for the Environment, Dr Jan Wright, 'Evaluating the use of 1080: predators, poisons and silent forests', which recommends that more 1080 (sodium fluoroacetate) be used in NZ, rather than less. Looks at why the use of 1080 is so controversial."

Author: "Steeman, Marta"
Title: "Brave staff show their mettle"
description: "Visits the engineering company located in Bromley, one of the city's earthquake ravished eastern suburbs. Talks to owners Mike Owens and John East about their plans for the business that will see them move to a new site away from the east of the city. Meets some of the workers, including Tony Reeves, Fran Maulgue and Darrin Horwarth, who talk about their earthquake recovery experiences in the eastern suburbs."

Author: "Woodbury, Mike"
Author (detailed): "Mike Woodbury, Chapman Tripp and Emma Harding."
Title: "KiwiSaver Mk 5"
description: "Covers the key changes being made to KiwiSaver. Includes member tax credits, employer contributions, employee contributions, what won't change and disclosure relief for providers."

Author: "Eleven, Beck"
Title: "Here's mud in your eye"
description: "Recalls taking part in 2010's inaugural 'Mud Sweat and Tears' challenge at the Motukarara Racecourse. Talks to the event's manager Vaughan Utteridge about the rain soaked day that saw around 850 people sliding about the course in cold mud."

Author: "Anderson, Vicki"
Title: "Grin and bare it"
description: "Interviews the veteran broadcaster about the contents of his memoir, including his controversial broadcasting career, his relationship with his mother, and his first paid job in a glue factory."

Author: "Catherall, Sarah"
Title: "Spiritual dimensions"
description: "Profiles the award-winning Tennent+Brown Archtiects director who has combined his passions for architecture and spirituality."

Author: "Kilty, Robyn"
Title: "Adopt a plot"
description: "Talks about reshaping a generous town-house garden that had been designed and planted during the 1970s."

Author: "Agnew, Trevor"
Title: "End of an era"
description: "Reviews the Television NZ (TVNZ) documentary 'Crime queen: Dame Ngaio Marsh'. Laments that the screening was an end of an era for TVNZ. Touches on the scrapping of the TVNZ public service charter."

Author: "Cairns, Lois"
Title: "Battered residents just want out"
description: "Cites a poll showing the number of Christchurch residents wanting to leave the city, following the 6.3 magnitude earthquake that occurred on Monday 13 June 2011. Talks to residents of Liggins Street, Burwood, about the liquefaction, waiting for official word on their homes, neighbours who have left, and the psychological toll. Anticipates a Government announcement on which areas of Christchurch will need to be abandoned."

Author: "Stone, Andrew"
Title: "Revealed : the story of NZ's poshest suburb"
description: "Talks to authors Jenny Carlyon and Diana Morrow about their new book 'A fine prospect : a history of Remuera, Meadowbank and St Johns'."

Author: "Wall, Tony"
Title: "'I just want to fight for the truth'"
description: "Talks to Police College student Li Yu about the campaign to clear her name after accusations two years ago that she, and a fellow Chinese recruit, cheated on an exam. Notes the case will be heard by the Employment Relations Authority at the end of June. Details the events of the case. Discusses criticism of substandard police recruits and discrimination against Asian recruits."

Author: "Roy, Eleanor Ainge"
Title: "'We were barely surviving'"
description: "Profiles the Gordons and their extended whanau (family) who moved in March 2011 from Masterton to Dubbo, New South Wales, to improve their earnings. Discusses how the life and income of the sheep shearing gang is now different. Mentions the NZ shearing awards family members have won. Talks to the father about why he was lured by work in Australia."

Author: "Taylor, Phil,"
Title: "Alcohol and the elite school"
description: "Looks at whether Auckland's elite King's College has a culture of drug and alcohol abuse, in light of the fourth alcohol-related death of a student in less than two years. Speaks to former Auckland mayor John Banks, whose 16-year-old son is a boarder at King's, about underage drinking at the school and the role of the parents. Talks about drinking at school balls."

Author: "Nissen, Wendyl"
Title: "This cheesy snack could prove a good choice"
description: "Analyses the ingredients of Grain Waves golden cheddar flavoured wholegrain chips."

Author: "Dart, William"
Title: "From Mozart to the ends of the universe"
description: "Reviews the launch of the Auckland Philharmonia Orchestra's 'Great classics' series on Thursday night at the Town Hall."

Author: "Kilgallon, Steve"
Title: "Murky waters"
description: "Asks questions about the use of Water Safety Education Foundation funds for non-water-related activities, noting the unsuccessful applications of bodies like Hutt Central School for funds for water based programmes. Raises questions about the source of the Foundation's funds and their grant decisions. Notes further controversy over the Foundation being a gatekeeper for applications to the Lottery Grants Board. Details queries about five pubs in Auckland, Wellington and Lower Hutt, whose poker machines (pokies) provide money to the Foundation. Talks to Swimming NZ chief executive Mike Byrne and Foundation executive director Alan Muir about funding issues and the relationship between the two organisations."

Author: "Trevett, Claire"
Title: "It's crunch time for Hone"
description: "Talks to the three leading 2011 Te Tai Tokerau by-election candidates about their campaigns and each other."

Author: "Woulfe, Catherine"
Title: "Property manager"
description: "Talks to the Dundedin manager of Click Property Management about her family and job."

Author: "Cumming, Geoffrey"
Title: "GM grass may not be so green"
description: "Considers the findings of the Sustainability Council's investigation into the benefits of Government funding for GM (genetically modified) pasture research. Reports that, while millions are being spent on creating new grasses, the benefits remain uncertain. Looks at three research programmes involving grasses with GM and non-GM components that receive taxpayer funding. Mentions how NZ developers of GM grasses have trademarked the term 'cisgenic' to get around regulatory and public resistance to genetic modification."

Author: "Hill, Julie,"
Title: "Whine list"
description: "Presents a catalogue of whinges by writers Julie Hill, Rebecca Kamm, Matt Suddain, Frances Walsh, James Walker, Margot Fluitsma, Margo White and Catherine Woulfe, and illustrators Vincent Konrad and Henrietta Harris. Covers rugby, haircuts, actors, panties, good-looking people, Nigel Latta, shopping trolleys, malls, buying socks and hipster weddings."

Author: "Hewitson, Michele"
Title: "Paul Moon"
description: "Talks to the controversial historian and author about his writing process and hobbies."

Author: "Tailor, Leena"
Title: "Down the rabbit hole"
description: "Talks the NZ born interior designer and general contractor who was NZ's first woman to work as a Playboy bunny.  Describes her life in the US, some of the famous people she has worked for, and her family businesses. Quotes the words Hugh Hefner spoke to her that inspired her career. Touches on her work as a motivational speaker, and her plans to earn a 'damehood' and feature in a reality television show."

Author: "McNamara, T. J."
Title: "Shows on ice are poles apart"
description: "Reviews 'Iceblink' by Peter James Smith at the John Leech Gallery (until 25 Jun 2011), 'The other mother' by Ronnie van Hout at the Ivan Anthony Gallery (until 25 Jun 2011), new sculpture and paper works by Sam Harrison at the Fox/Jensen Gallery (until 1 Jul 2011) and 'Venus' by Andrew Barns-Graham at Sanderson Contemporary Art (until 26 Jun 2011)."

Author: "Dart, William"
Title: "NZSO makes history with live link to Mahler concert"
description: "Speaks to the conductor about his experience with the NZ Symphony Orchestra (NZSO). Talks about the NZSO's first live digital broadcast of one of its performances."

Author: "Thornton, Peter"
Title: "Cancer survivor keeps on running"
description: "Cancer survivor keeps on running"

Author: "Cleaver, Dylan"
Title: "Big Chief's finale"
description: "Talks to the rugby coach on the eve of his final game in charge of the Chiefs. Lists his coaching statistics."

Author: "Kamm, Rebecca"
Title: "The city's slicker"
description: "Looks at the transformation of the downtown area of the city."

Author: "Calder, Peter"
Title: "Dilemmas of an artist"
description: "Talks to writer and director Stephen Sinclair about his latest film."

Author: "Taylor, Phil,"
Title: "Hot shots"
description: "Features the two talented teenage NZ golfers. Talks about their commitment to the game and their plans for the future. Speaks to Rory Moor, Cecila's swing coach, about the work ethic of champion golfers and why Koreans have become a force in world golf. Touches on the somewhat negative reaction of senior golfers to the child prodigies."

Author: "Savage, Jared"
Title: "Flung to death in front of wife"
description: "Flung to death in front of wife"

Author: "Koubaridis, Andrew"
Title: "Victim's gifts lie unopened beneath her parents' tree"
description: "Victim's gifts lie unopened beneath her parents' tree"

Title: "TV man happy with plodder's pace in ironman"
description: "TV man happy with plodder's pace in ironman"

Author: "Koubaridis, Andrew"
Title: "Badly bleeding patients owe lives to St John's return to tourniquets"
description: "Badly bleeding patients owe lives to St John's return to tourniquets"

Author: "Seconi, Adrian"
Title: "Shanks rides hard despite lost Olympic opportunity"
description: "Shanks rides hard despite lost Olympic opportunity"

Author: "Lowe, Robert"
Title: "Kiwi F1 legend Chris Amon drives back into the spotlight"
description: "Kiwi F1 legend Chris Amon drives back into the spotlight"

Author: "Bruce, David"
Title: "'Killer and coward'; Life imprisonment for Oamaru murder; Death highlights danger of young carrying knives"
description: "Reports on aspects of the sentencing of the teenager who murdered another teenaged resident of Oamaru on 1 Apr 2010. Cites comments from victim impact statements of the boy's parents, Jenny Brokenshire and Peter Lewis.  Backgrounds the events leading to the murder."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1884"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1884. Chronicles speeches made at the leavetaking ceremony at the City Council Chamber on 13 Aug 1884 of the 'poet and literary man', as reported on 14 Aug 1884. Describes progress being made on the building of the Leviathan Hotel in the city, 20 Mar 1884. Announces the founding of the New Zealand Commercial Travellers and Warehousemen's Association, 29 Sep 1884. Touches on other events during the year."

Title: "Fresh petition for pardon in abuse case"
description: "Fresh petition for pardon in abuse case"

Author: "Dickison, Michael"
Title: "Injured officer's family to keep vigil by her bedside"
description: "Injured officer's family to keep vigil by her bedside"

Author: "McMurran, Alistair"
Title: "Rowing enthusiast has done it all"
description: "Profiles the man who has been involved with rowing on the local and national level for 54 years."

Title: "Mattise in intensive care after rejection"
description: "Mattise in intensive care after rejection"

Author: "Dungey, Kim"
Title: "Cold comfort harm"
description: "Focuses on health and other problems associated with houses that are damp and cold, and what is being done to address these problems. Talks to a woman who lives in a 1970s townhouse that has recently been insulated as part of the 'Warm Up New Zealand : Heat Smart' programme administered by the Energy Efficiency and Conservation Authority (EECA). Seeks comment from Assoc Prof Bob Lloyd, Prof Philippa Howden-Chapman of the University of Otago, Matt Thomson of EnergySmart, Nick Collins of Beacon Pathway and Robert Vale of Victoria University of Wellington. Overviews the 'Warm Up New Zealand' Government programme. Cites a study indicating the effect of NZ culture and tolerance of cold on NZers' home-heating choices."

Author: "Gilchrist, Shane"
Title: "At the heart of Roxburgh"
description: "Profiles the long-serving chairman of the area committee of the ambulance service. Recalls the origins of the service and the crucial role of volunteers and community funding. Informs of its annual appeal week, 20-26 Jun 2011."

Author: "James, Bryan"
Title: "Gems among King's published and unpublished work; Entertaining and heartfelt memoir with some delightful asides; Salvaging what they could of soldiers' lives, bodies; Academic work provides few insights"
description: "Gems among King's published and unpublished work; Entertaining and heartfelt memoir with some delightful asides; Salvaging what they could of soldiers' lives, bodies; Academic work provides few insights"

Author: "Kara, Scott"
Title: "Grown up and together"
description: "Talks to Shihad frontman Jon Toogood about his new band, a collaboration with Shayne Carter and Julia Deans. Focuses on the recording of their eponymous debut album."

Author: "Gilchrist, Shane"
Title: "The fullness of Hollie"
description: "Talks to the England-born singer-songwriter about the process of recording her debut album, and her upcoming Australasian tour to promote it."

Author: "Stewart, Matt"
Title: "Helping people - it's the real buzz"
description: "Interviews the talent scout of the Queenstown agency Exposure about the nature of her work."

Title: "Gore old boy fought for underdogs"
description: "Gore old boy fought for underdogs"

Author: "Gerken, Sonia"
Title: "Macdonald wins top songwriting award in Gore"
description: "Macdonald wins top songwriting award in Gore"

Author: "Crean, Mike"
Title: "Bluff's famous 'singing princess'"
description: "Bluff's famous 'singing princess'"

Title: "Bob is 'hooked' on the power of electricity"
description: "Bob is 'hooked' on the power of electricity"

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1885"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1885. Comments on progress being made in the Colony to manufacture electric lighting equipment, transmit electric power and install electric lighting in several public buildings and factories, 14 Oct 1885.  Announces the opening on 15 Dec 1885 of the first section of the Catlin River railway. Reports on the ceremonial opening on 11 Feb 1885 of the new Boys High School. Includes a photograph of Speight's Brewery, Dunedin, in the late 1880s. Touches on other events during the year."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1886"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1886. Publishes the text of telegrams from Rotorua and Wellington concerning the eruption of Mt Tarawera, 10 Jun 1886. Includes photographs of the Pink and White Terraces before the eruption. Reports on the 14 Feb 1886 ceremony of dedication of St Joseph's Cathedral. Announces the death on 21 Sep 1886 of the prominent legal practitioner, businessman, Minister and judge, as published on 22 Sep 1886. Comments in the 10 Nov 1886 edition on the success to the colony of the Roslyn Woollen Mills, which opened about 1879."

Author: "Mackenzie, Dene"
Title: "Tweeting a new campaign"
description: "Reflects on the Anthony Weiner political scandal in the US, and expresses hope that NZ politicians and political candidates will make extensive use of Twitter in the upcoming general election. Mentions the use of the Twitter hash tag."

Author: "Hathaway, Jude"
Title: "Wool power"
description: "Focuses on the contributions of Dunedin fashion designers to the global five-year Campaign for Wool, celebrated at the 'Shear Brilliance' cocktail event, Massey University College of Creative Arts, Wellington, Jun 2011."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1887"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1887. Reports on an extensive fire in Princes St on 23 Jan 1887, as reported on 24 Jan 1887. Celebrates the success of fundraising efforts to erect a bronze monument in the Octagon in memory of Robert Burns, 25 May 1887. Describes a 12 Mar tour of the McDonald cement works, Walton Park, 14 Mar 1887. Chronicles the opening to traffic of the new bridge across the Molyneux River, Roxburgh, 5 May 1887 edition. Includes a photograph of the construction of the Wingatui Viaduct."

Author: "South, Gill"
Title: "Life changing trips offer lessons in leadership"
description: "Life changing trips offer lessons in leadership"

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1888"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1888. Reports in the 8 May edition about a public meeting to protest against 'an influx of Chinese into the colony', Princess Theatre, Dunedin, 7 May 1888. Describes the effects in Invercargill and Christchurch of a violent earthquake on 1 Sep felt in the South Island, 3 Sep 1888. Publishes the text of a letter to the editor about a sweatshop in Dunedin, and the reply from the editor after investigating the situation, 20 Oct 1888. Includes a photograph of the Sew Hoy dredge owned by the Shotover Big Beach Gold Mining Co."

Author: "Smith, Charmian"
Title: "There's no place for reality in Kyle's world"
description: "Talks to the award-winning children's author, who is the Creative NZ children's writer in residence at the University of Otago College of Education for 2011. Describes where he gains his inspiration for his book and talks about his most recent project, a young adult novel."

Author: "Koubaridis, Andrew"
Title: "I was screaming for my life : mother of 4-year-old crash victim tells of dramatic escape"
description: "I was screaming for my life : mother of 4-year-old crash victim tells of dramatic escape"

Author: "Body, Ralph"
Title: "Art seen"
description: "Reviews 'Slap happy stick' by Claire Mahoney, Rice and Beans Gallery, Dunedin.  Reviews 'Black holes versus baby universes' by Rachel Taylor, A Gallery, Dunedin, until 8 Jul 2011."

Author: "Davison, Isaac"
Title: "My Xmas gift burnt down my room"
description: "My Xmas gift burnt down my room"

Title: "Creator of 'best website in world' dies"
description: "Creator of 'best website in world' dies"

Author: "Dickison, Michael"
Title: "Star makeup artist going Gaga for NZ"
description: "Star makeup artist going Gaga for NZ"

Title: "Gruesome crash has not stopped rider"
description: "Gruesome crash has not stopped rider"

Author: "Cronshaw, Tim"
Title: "'Rob put himself at risk of being killed - he saved at least three people'"
description: "Recounts the bravery of the Canterbury dairy farmer who crawled into the Payne Gould Corporation (PGC) building in Christchurch to rescue people after the 22 Feb 2011 earthquake. Cites his comments about the courage of those waiting to be saved, and the comments of some of the people he saved. Mentions the reaction of his wife Debbie Mackle to his being in the collapsed building. Notes his feelings on the demolition of the city's damaged buildings."

Author: "Fisher, Amanda"
Title: "Patience and perseverance the recipe for finding a job; Working toward better training"
description: "Interviews 12 graduates of the WelTec patisserie course about their success in finding work after graduation, given the current youth unemployment rate of 18.8%. Talks to the CEOs of WelTec (Linda Sissons) and Business NZ (Phil O'Reilly) about vocational training and the gap between education and work skills."

Author: "Kitchin, Peter"
Title: "Neuroscientist was renowned brain expert"
description: "Neuroscientist was renowned brain expert"

Author: "Donoghue, Tim"
Title: "Mother of Raetihi a great organiser"
description: "Mother of Raetihi a great organiser"

Author: "Pokoney, Cassandra"
Title: "Netball stalwart recognised; Dedication to sport cited; Fight fire with good people - QSM recipient; Community given credit"
description: "Netball stalwart recognised; Dedication to sport cited; Fight fire with good people - QSM recipient; Community given credit"

Author: "Scherer, Karyn"
Title: "Fraud-case financier dies before trial starts"
description: "Fraud-case financier dies before trial starts"

Author: "Kitchin, Peter"
Title: "Successful businessman, sports enthusiast was congenial companion"
description: "Successful businessman, sports enthusiast was congenial companion"

Author: "Pokoney, Cassandra"
Title: "City-born OpShop frontman honoured; Work in Pacific Islands community rewarded; Sheepmilking pioneer's efforts recognised"
description: "City-born OpShop frontman honoured; Work in Pacific Islands community rewarded; Sheepmilking pioneer's efforts recognised"

Author: "Gray, Jamie"
Title: "'Formidable' QC involved in Winebox inquiry dies"
description: "'Formidable' QC involved in Winebox inquiry dies"

Author: "Torrie, Bronwyn"
Title: "Inside the Kilbirnie sports centre"
description: "Talks to Wellington Indoor Community Sports Centre manager Craig Hutchings about the opening of the stadium in August 2011. Discusses the building's design, capacity and cost. Notes the architects, Hugh Tennent and Ewan Brown, and touches on why the building's nickname might become 'the limpet'."

Author: "Pokoney, Cassandra"
Title: "Teamwork behind NZO honour says recipient; Honour shock for St John manager; Lifetime of flax work earns QSM"
description: "Teamwork behind NZO honour says recipient; Honour shock for St John manager; Lifetime of flax work earns QSM"

Author: "Chapman, Katie"
Title: "Where did the time go?"
description: "Reports on a time use survey from Statistics NZ that queried  people aged twelve and over as to their primary activities, 2009-2010. Contrasts how men and women spend their days, and looks at the main preoccupations of the young, working aged, middle aged, and older people. Discusses whether differences have been detected from the last survey in 1998-1999."

Author: "Anthony, John"
Title: "Taranaki firm has roadkill-to-riches tale"
description: "Talks to two NZers who are making a living from possum fur and possum skins:  Stu Bracegirdle of Egmont Skins and Hides, Inglewood, and Pennie Sands of Environmental Products NZ, Stratford. Discusses the ongoing demand for possum fur and products, the use of 1080 poison, and why the fibre is so popular."

Author: "McIntyre, Donna"
Title: "Ecologist helps developers build green"
description: "Ecologist helps developers build green"

Author: "Philp, Matt,"
Title: "Monsters in the virtual closet"
description: "Reports on  two successful social networking sites for children. Talks to UK website developer Michael Acton Smith of Mind Candy about the Moshi Monsters site he created. Lists three reasons for the site's success, noting the brand will soon be launching physical products.  Talks to NZer Melissa Clark-Reynolds about the Wellington-based virtual world of monkey avatars, MiniMonos, that touts environmental values. Asks her how she makes money from the website and how she envisages future demand."

Author: "Koubaridis, Andrew"
Title: "Ex-party president's husband dies in shooting"
description: "Ex-party president's husband dies in shooting"

Author: "Tahana, Yvonne"
Title: "Olympic legend receives Queen's gong"
description: "Olympic legend receives Queen's gong"

Author: "Knox, Johanna"
Title: "When money is time"
description: "Explains the concept of a community time bank and community currency. Talks to Project Lyttelton chairwoman Margaret Jefferies about the town's six year old time bank initiative and how it helped in the aftermath of the recent earthquakes. Describes its origin as NZ's first time bank and how it has been used as a template for others in Kaitaia, Whakatane, Otaki, Gore and two suburbs in Christchurch. Compares the community building banks to local exchange trading systems (Lets), or green dollar schemes. Examines the currencies and organisation of Lets schemes in the Wairarapa, Golden Bay, and Whanganui. Also looks at the Out of our own backyards (Ooooby) organisation for trading homegrown produce, and the Local origin Ashhurst voluntary exchange (Loaves)."

Author: "Tahana, Yvonne"
Title: "Lost Olympian: wife keeps vigil"
description: "Lost Olympian: wife keeps vigil"

Author: "Ihaka, James"
Title: "Crewe case 'killed my marriage and my ex-wife'"
description: "Crewe case 'killed my marriage and my ex-wife'"

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1889"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1889. Features one of a series of articles by reporter Silas Spragg that exposed the sweating system in Dunedin. Includes an interview with a pieceworker, 22 Jan 1889. Lauds the spectacular scenery around Milford Sound, 1 Jan 1889, and includes a photograph taken on Lake Ada. Describes a 'daring aerial display' on 21 Jan at the Caledonian ground by balloonist Professor Baldwin, reported 22 Jan 1889. Reports on a 16 Apr 1889 meeting convened in the Choral Hall by Dr Batchelor to gather support to establish a special women's ward at Dunedin Hospital, 17 Apr 1889."

Author: "Catherall, Sarah"
Title: "Bar room blitz"
description: "Describes the work of the busy architectural designer who has put his stamp on many bars and cafes, especially in Wellington. Details his successful first project, Matterhorn, and notes the awards he has won for this and other projects. Speaks to Steve Gianoutsos about why the designer has been involved in creating his 26 Mojo cafes. Mentions that hospitality is not the only industry that AllistarCox Architecture works in."

Author: "Hughes, Alistair"
Title: "Sweet drams are made of these"
description: "Reflects on his first taste of Glenmorangie whisky in Scotland, subequent samplings of the 'water of life' at other Scottish distilleries, and further whisky-tastings and Burns suppers in NZ."

Author: "Anderson, Vicki"
Title: "No regrets"
description: "Talks to the broadcaster about his career, the people he has upset, and his recent book. Discusses an impoverished childhood in Britian and how he broke into broadcasting, including his unscheduled interview with Peter Ustinov. Touches on his obsessive compulsive disorder, and what he has been doing since resigning from TVNZ."

Author: "Clifton, Jane,"
Title: "Sleight of hand"
description: "Muses over the possibility that international events such as the Rugby World Cup will distract voters from the general election campaign. Comments on the opportunities and risks for Government and the Opposition."

Author: "Clifton, Jane,"
Title: "Rugby World Cup make or break for government"
description: "Muses over the possibility that international events such as the Rugby World Cup will distract voters from the general election campaign. Comments on the opportunities and risks for Government and the Opposition."

Author: "Dekker, Diana"
Title: "Antonio Cacace"
description: "Chats to the Italian born owner of La Bella Italia cafe (Petone) about his family, his passion for (Italian) food, and the award he received for his contribution to the Italian NZ relationship. Reveals he has a chocolate birthmark."

Author: "Catherall, Sarah"
Title: "The shape crusader"
description: "Features houses in Queenstown and Auckland designed by the South African born architect, looking at their uniform cladding and noting that they concern some neighbours. Cites his views about rebuilding earthquake damaged Christchurch."

Author: "Clifton, Jane,"
Title: "Slut power; Walking the talk"
description: "Reports on the feminist campaign 'Slutwalk', marked by a series of protests in NZ and overseas against sexual harassment of women for their choice of dress. Explores the growing backlash to the 'continuing tendency of the Establishment ... to put the responsibility for sexual safety on women'. Discusses the debate over the growing trend toward highly sexualised dress and other choices women make about how they dress. Seeks comment from Green Party MP Sue Kedgley, Victoria University women's studies lecturer Alison Laurie, blogger Emma Hart and University of Auckland professor of women's studies Maureen Molloy about aspects of sexual politics pertaining to women's dress, including the argument that sexy clothing provokes rape, and the nature of social conditioning and masculinity. Talks to Tash Mead and Tess Nichol about why they are going on the Slutwalk, Wellington, 25 Jun 2011."

Author: "Adams, Richard"
Title: "Cross purpose"
description: "Walks the 32 kilometre Southern Crossing, starting at Otaki Forks. Notes the lives recently lost there, details the preparations he made for the trip, and reports on the fate of a mountain biker who was also headed for Kaitoke."

Author: "Risk, Louise"
Title: "'Down there' down under"
description: "Talks to the Auckland born clinical psychologist about her book on people's experience of sex. Touches on her life with the Scottish comedian Billy Connolly, dancing on British television, and her own parenting approach."

Author: "Wichtel, Diana"
Title: "Into the bear pit"
description: "Profiles the former president of the Labour Party and former head of the Engineering, Printing & Manufacturing Union (EPMU). Talks to him and former EPMU colleague Adelia Hallett about his decision to step down from both positions to concentrate on his parliamentary election campaign for the New Plymouth seat. Discusses his upbringing and what he hopes to achieve in politics."

Author: "Wichtel, Diana"
Title: "Andrew Little"
description: "Profiles the former president of the Labour Party and former head of the Engineering, Printing & Manufacturing Union (EPMU). Talks to him and former EPMU colleague Adelia Hallett about his decision to step down from both positions to concentrate on his parliamentary election campaign for the New Plymouth seat. Discusses his upbringing and what he hopes to achieve in politics."

Author: "Harley, Rob"
Title: "Two Sues from Te Awamutu"
description: "Backgrounds his upcoming TV documentary on the aid agency Hagar, spearheaded by former Te Awamutu residents Sue Taylor and Sue Hanna. Discusses their ongoing work to rescue children from child trafficking in Asian countries. Informs that his documentary 'Two Sues' screens on 3 Jul 2011, as part of the new TV1 series 'NZ stories : Project melting pot'."

Author: "Harley, Rob"
Title: "Aid agency Hagar spearheaded by Kiwi women"
description: "Backgrounds his upcoming TV documentary on the aid agency Hagar, spearheaded by former Te Awamutu residents Sue Taylor and Sue Hanna. Discusses their ongoing work to rescue children from child trafficking in Asian countries. Informs that his documentary 'Two Sues' screens on 3 Jul 2011, as part of the new TV1 series 'NZ stories : Project melting pot'."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "Shaky start"
description: "Interviews EQC chief executive officer Ian Simpson. Responds to criticisms that the Commission is not responding quickly enough to Christchurch earthquake claims."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "Ian Simpson interview"
description: "Interviews EQC chief executive officer Ian Simpson. Responds to criticisms that the Commission is not responding quickly enough to Christchurch earthquake claims."

Author: "Smith, Hannah"
Title: "Their finest luncheon hour"
description: "Reviews 'Meet the Churchills' by Paul Baker, directed by Ross Jolly, Circa One, Wellington, until 16 Jul 2011."

Author: "Smith, Hannah"
Title: "Meet the Churchills by Paul Baker"
description: "Reviews 'Meet the Churchills' by Paul Baker, directed by Ross Jolly, Circa One, Wellington, until 16 Jul 2011."

Author: "White, Margo"
Title: "Sight for poor eyes"
description: "Tells the story of the woman with macular degeneration whose eyesight was restored by switching to the drug Lucentis. Informs that she, her husband and retinal specialist Dianne Sharp have established a new trust, Macular Degeneration New Zealand, to attract attention to the disease and available treatments."

Author: "White, Margo"
Title: "Macular degeneration"
description: "Tells the story of the woman with macular degeneration whose eyesight was restored by switching to the drug Lucentis. Informs that she, her husband and retinal specialist Dianne Sharp have established a new trust, Macular Degeneration New Zealand, to attract attention to the disease and available treatments."

Author: "Bowden, Jennifer"
Title: "A good hearty drink"
description: "Answers a reader's question about whether healthy people should switch from full-fat to low-fat milk."

Author: "Bowden, Jennifer"
Title: "Low fat milk"
description: "Answers a reader's question about whether healthy people should switch from full-fat to low-fat milk."

Author: "Jacobs, Lauraine"
Title: "Press on"
description: "Focuses on the health benefits of olive oil, and mentions two NZ producers of high-quality extra virgin olive oil (evoo). Includes recipes and wine matches for salmon steaks with olive oil and oyster sauce, and marinated tomatoes with feta and crisp toast."

Author: "Jacobs, Lauraine"
Title: "Cooking with olive oil"
description: "Focuses on the health benefits of olive oil, and mentions two NZ producers of high-quality extra virgin olive oil (evoo). Includes recipes and wine matches for salmon steaks with olive oil and oyster sauce, and marinated tomatoes with feta and crisp toast."

Author: "Cooper, Michael,"
Title: "Pride of place"
description: "Interviews the wine writer-turned-winemaker for the Central Otago winery. Explains the particular charms of Central Otago pinot noir. Presents tasting notes for Gibbston Valley Central Otago Pinot Noir 2009."

Author: "Cooper, Michael,"
Title: "Gibbston Valley's Christopher Keys"
description: "Interviews the wine writer-turned-winemaker for the Central Otago winery. Explains the particular charms of Central Otago pinot noir. Presents tasting notes for Gibbston Valley Central Otago Pinot Noir 2009."

Author: "Cronshaw, Tim"
Title: "Cold sweat; Life-saver put aside his fears"
description: "Recounts the bravery of the Canterbury dairy farmer who crawled into the Payne Gould Corporation (PGC) building in Christchurch to rescue people after the 22 Feb 2011 earthquake. Cites his comments about the courage of those waiting to be saved, and the comments of some of the people he saved. Mentions the reaction of his wife Debbie Mackle to his being in the collapsed building. Notes his feelings on the demolition of the city's damaged buildings."

Author: "Gillies, Abby"
Title: "Stocked to buyers tastes"
description: "Notes supermarkets stock their shelves with products according to the expected preferences of their customers. Includes a list of consumer goods that are among the most frequently shoplifted from suermarket shelves."

Author: "Morton, Jamie"
Title: "Life-saving machine proves worth at gym"
description: "Life-saving machine proves worth at gym"

Author: "Booker, Jarrod"
Title: "Parents' burden lifted as quake victim identified"
description: "Parents' burden lifted as quake victim identified"

Author: "McCrone, John"
Title: "Relish the power of a new generation"
description: "Muses on different styles of political activism of baby boomers and Generation Y youth. Exemplifies the latter, describing the formation of the Student Volunteer Army (Sam Johnson), the Rebuild Christchurch website (Deon Swiggs),  the TEDxChChEQ conference (YChCh, Raf Manji), and the White Elephant Trust (Ant Rohan).  Cites examples where city council consultation with youth has not been fruitful. Reports on the US generated 2006 Cone Millenial Cause Study that sets out the characteristics of baby boomers, Generation X and Generation Y, noting the optimism and social entrepreneurship of the latter. Talks to Canterbury University Vice Chancellor Rod Carr about the need to adapt to and nourish the collaborative and active style of Gen Y."

Author: "Binning, Elizabeth"
Title: "Mother's biggest helper is the boss"
description: "Mother's biggest helper is the boss"

Title: "Jiving Kiwi gran a video star in Aussie"
description: "Jiving Kiwi gran a video star in Aussie"

Title: "Murder accused : blows deliberate"
description: "Murder accused : blows deliberate"

Author: "Williams, David"
Title: "Piecing together a life"
description: "Talks to a Christchurch woman whose mother died in the 22 Feb 2011earthquake. Describes her experience of hearing details about her mother's death at the inquest for those who died in the collapsed CTV building just when the 13 Jun 2011earthquake struck. Remembers her mother and recalls the encouraging words of Prince William on showing him a photograph of her. Contains biographical material."

Author: "Jackson, Greg"
Title: "Earthquakes rekindle community bonds"
description: "Explains how emergency aid operations began after the Christchurch earthquakes. Lists the NGO 's Disaster Relief Forum (NDRF) members  in Christchurch and how they worked together with international and official organisations and community led groups. Gives examples of multiple organisations collaborating successfully with community groups, such as Rotary and the Salvation Army. Cites comments by international disaster rebuild expert Peter Kenyon on Christchurch's post-quake response."

Author: "Morton, Frances"
Title: "Deathly driveways"
description: "Notes every year five young children die and twelve are injured after being knocked over by a car in a driveway, often by their own parents. Examines what can be done to increase the safety of children and the driveways. Indicates the Child and Youth Mortality Review Committee is conducting a study into slow-moving vehicle deaths that is due out in August this year. Details high risk-best design of driveway and house configurations."

Author: "Deane, Steve"
Title: "Sonny Bill in tune for heavy effort"
description: "Sonny Bill in tune for heavy effort"

Author: "Gillies, Abby"
Title: "City's people rocked to core and living on the edge"
description: "Having left Christchurch after the first earthquake in September the author returns after the February 22nd quake and finds most of her old haunts have been irreparably damaged or flattened completely. Visits the eastern suburbs where residents relate their feelings and plans for the future."

Author: "Hockley, Lorraine"
Title: "Feeling alive on a bike in US"
description: "Talks to the Nelson potter of Pumpshed Pottery about visiting the US several months a year to tour on his Honda motorbike, attend motorbike rallies and visit his American girlfriend Marti Foxworthy. Touches on the consideration of US drivers, how he feels energised when bike touring there, and his plans to make it his home."

Title: "Last-minute reprieve for bedraggled sailors"
description: "Last-minute reprieve for bedraggled sailors"

Author: "Crean, Mike"
Title: "Sociable socialist nephrologist"
description: "Sociable socialist nephrologist"

Author: "Crean, Mike"
Title: "Respected lawyer used his knowledge for many causes"
description: "Respected lawyer used his knowledge for many causes"

Author: "Clement, Diana"
Title: "A fit family is a happy family"
description: "Notes getting fit with children is a way to foster togetherness within a family. Illustrates the ways some parents are involved in getting fit and also including their children in their activities, or parents being  involved in their children's activities, such as fun runs or mixed-age five-a-side football."

Author: "Knox, Johanna"
Title: "When money is time"
description: "Explains the concept of a community time bank and community currency. Talks to Project Lyttelton chairwoman Margaret Jefferies about the town's six year old time bank initiative and how it helped in the aftermath of the recent earthquakes. Describes its origin as NZ's first time bank and how it has been used as a template for others in Kaitaia, Whakatane, Otaki, Gore and two suburbs in Christchurch. Compares the community building banks to local exchange trading systems (Lets), or green dollar schemes. Examines the currencies and organisation of Lets schemes in the Wairarapa, Golden Bay, and Whanganui. Also looks at the Out of our own backyards (Ooooby) organisation for trading homegrown produce, and the Local origin Ashhurst voluntary exchange (Loaves)."

Author: "Philp, Matt,"
Title: "Monsters in the virtual closet"
description: "Reports on  two successful social networking sites for children. Talks to UK website developer Michael Acton Smith of Mind Candy about the Moshi Monsters site he created. Lists three reasons for the site's success, noting the brand will soon be launching physical products.  Talks to NZer Melissa Clark-Reynolds about the Wellington-based virtual world of monkey avatars, MiniMonos, that touts environmental values. Asks her how she makes money from the website and how she envisages future demand."

Author: "Hughes, Alistair"
Title: "Sweet drams are made of these"
description: "Reflects on his first taste of Glenmorangie whisky in Scotland, subequent samplings of the 'water of life' at other Scottish distilleries, and further whisky-tastings and Burns suppers in NZ."

Author: "Catherall, Sarah"
Title: "The shape crusader"
description: "Features houses in Queenstown and Auckland designed by the South African born architect, looking at their uniform cladding and noting that they concern some neighbours. Cites his views about rebuilding earthquake damaged Christchurch."

Author: "Wright, Danielle"
Title: "It's the journey that counts"
description: "Describes the author's and her son's trip on the Overlander from Auckland to Wellington via Hamilton, National Park, Palmerston North."

Author: "Matthews, Philip"
Title: "The poets' own bible"
description: "Reviews a book of poems taken from Bill Manhire's online anthology that has selected 25 NZ poems each year for the past 10 years."

Author: "Binning, Elizabeth"
Title: "It's all thanks to mum, says high-achieving teen"
description: "It's all thanks to mum, says high-achieving teen"

Author: "Tahana, Yvonne"
Title: "Super Nan keen to market Maori dolls"
description: "Super Nan keen to market Maori dolls"

Author: "Tahana, Yvonne"
Title: "Olympians mourn best mate killed in air crash"
description: "Olympians mourn best mate killed in air crash"

Author: "Mackay, Janetta"
Title: "Designer adds celebrity touch to Massey campaign"
description: "Designer adds celebrity touch to Massey campaign"

Author: "Marquet, Sarah"
Title: "Former politician chooses Cromwell"
description: "Talks to the former Otago Regional Council chairwoman about her decision to pursue a career in real estate. Overviews her career, much of it spent in community service."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1891"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1891. Summarises the contents of a telegram received from Bluff on 6 Jul 1891 concerning the rescue of castaways from the barque 'Compadre', brought from the Auckland Islands to Bluff aboard the sealing schooner 'Janet Ramsay', as reported in the 7 Jul 1981 edition.  Reports on a 3 Nov 1891 meeting of Salvation Army members to welcome founder and organiser General Booth to Dunedin, 4 Nov 1891. Describes damage to St Clair Esplanade and Ocean Beach from severe weather and high seas over a period of a few days, reported on 9 Jun 1891.
