Title: "It's like living with extended family"
description: "It's like living with extended family"

Title: "New Zealand's longest serving female MP dies"
description: "New Zealand's longest serving female MP dies"

Author: "Matthews, Philip"
Title: "Quakes' many stories to go on the record"
description: "Reports on how the experience of the Christchurch earthquakes will become the most comprehensively studied and archived disaster in NZ's history. Speaks to National Library of NZ associate chief librarian Ronald Milne about how the library has been steadily working to amass an earthquake archive, which includes an oral history project, commissioned photographs, harvesting of earthquake-related websites, and earthquake-related ephemera. Backgrounds the launch of the Ministry of Culture and Heritage's new web project called 'Quake Stories'. Talks to Paul Millar, an associate professor in the College of Arts at Canterbury University, about the plans for the 'Ceismic consortium', which will see Canterbury build up a unique archive of quake experiences."

Author: "Irvine, Denise"
Title: "It's all arranged with the family"
description: "Talks to two Sikh couples in the Waikato who are in arranged marriages. Describes the modern day process of arranging marriage. Conveys the couples' feelings about arranged versus 'love' marriages. Introduces the uncle of the two husbands, Harkrishen Kung, who received a Queen's Service Medal in 2011 for his work in Indian community. Gives approximate statistics for arranged marriages in NZ, noting the recent creation of a culturally arranged marriage visa."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1923"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1923. Chronicles the effects of a significant flood in the city beginning on 21 Apr 1923, as reported in the 23 Apr 1923 edition. Includes a photograph of flood waters in Cumberland Street, Dunedin. Relays news from Rome on 19 Jun 1923 of the eruption of Mount Etna, as reported in the 20 Jun 1923 edition. Reports on celebrations marking the completion of the Otira tunnel linking the East and West Coasts of the South Island, 4 Aug 1923, as published on 6 Aug 1923."

Author: "Crean, Mike"
Title: "Peace champion and widely cited scholar"
description: "Peace champion and widely cited scholar"

Author: "Hathaway, Jude"
Title: "Make way for steampunk"
description: "Reports on proceedings at the 2011 Hokonui Design Awards, Gore, late Jul 2011. Lauds the creativity of finalists in the schools and steampunk sections, as well as the diversity of entries and the quality of entries in the menswear section. Seeks comments from co-ordinator Heather Paterson and the judging panel. Lists award winners."

Author: "Crean, Mike"
Title: "Research paved way for top-notch wine industry"
description: "Research paved way for top-notch wine industry"

Author: "Smith, Charmian"
Title: "Exciting books for adventurous cooks"
description: "Exciting books for adventurous cooks"

Author: "Fox, Andrea"
Title: "Fonterra rockets on milky way; Fonterra delivering the goods, but at a price"
description: "Questions whether the world's leading dairy exporter has lived up to the hype that surrounded its formation in Oct 2001. Talks to a number of economic and industry experts about the performance of the company. Outlines the company's position in the NZ and world dairy markets."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1924"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1924. Sums up proceedings of a 4 Nov 1924 meeting of the Dunedin Presbytery on the matter of Sabbath desecration, as reported in the 5 Nov 1924 edition. Reports that the Alliance of Labour requested that the Minister of Labour introduce legislation to make a 44-hour week compulsory, 30 Jul 1924. Reports that the National Council of Women called on the Dunedin City Council on 2 Jul 1924 to provide low-rent housing for very poor citizens, as reported on 4 Jul 1924. Includes a photograph of workmen laying foundations for asphalt in Crawford Street, Dunedin. Touches on other events during the year."

Author: "Brown, Giles"
Title: "Waiting game"
description: "Visits the NZ Defence Force members stationed in the independent nation. Looks at how they spend their time on base. Looks into the current problems facing the people of Dili. Briefly outlines the history of violence in East Timor. Notes the number of NZ troops and police stationed in Dili."

Author: "Smith, Charmian"
Title: "Concern for heritage inspires artist"
description: "Talks to the Wanganui-raised artist about 'Preoccupied', his survey exhibition of works from 1998, Monumental Gallery, Dunedin, until 4 Sep 2011. Informs that the exhibition (originally entitled 'Reverb') had been installed at the Centre of Contemporary Art (CoCA), Christchurch, but was disrupted by the 22 Feb 2011 earthquake. Discusses his involvement in saving heritage buildings and how he incorporates this interest into his paintings. Touches on the current situation for the arts communities in Christchurch after the earthquakes."

Author: "Jopp, Julie"
Title: "Art seen"
description: "Reviews 'Parallel', various artists, Milford Galleries Dunedin, until 17 Aug 2011.  Reviews Edinburgh Realty Premier Art Awards, various artists, Otago Art Society, Dunedin Railway Station, until 28 Aug 2011."

Author: "Cooper, Tracey"
Title: "Taking on Billy T"
description: "Speaks to the director about the difficulty in trying to explain one of NZ's best-loved comedians in the documentary film 'Billy T: te movie'. Reminisces about the life and career of the award-winning entertainer. Lists some of the key moments in his life."

Author: "Fitzsimons, Tom"
Title: "Winners' circle"
description: "Talks to four NZ Post Book Awards winners about their writing, their winning books, and their plans for the future."

Author: "Frances, Helen"
Title: "Building resilience"
description: "Speaks to the architect about how he managed to build his sustainable York Bay house. Briefly outlines some of the sustainability factors he took into consideration."

Author: "Birss, Neill"
Title: "An investor with the golden touch"
description: "Profiles the late Ian Urquhart who had a talent for investment."

Author: "De Lacy, Hugh"
Title: "Sparks fly over ACC changes"
description: "Comments on the changes being planned by government to introduce some competition to the provision of accident compensation. Outlines the main plans. Looks at the historical background of NZ's accident compensation framework."

Author: "Hutching, Chris"
Title: "Trust deregistration prompts questions"
description: "Explains why and when the Charities Commission reviews a trust status. Discusses the recent high-profile deregistration of the Queenstown Lakes Community Housing Trust and considers future implications from this."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1925"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1925. Reports in the 14 Jan 1925 edition that motor vehicle owners have been slow to register, despite registration being compulsory under the Motor Vehicles Act 1924. Updates the status of the infantile paralysis outbreak in the region and in NZ, 4 Mar 1925. Reports in the 3 Jun 1925 edition on a meeting held the previous evening by the Women Citizens' Association on the 'alarming prevalence of drinking among women'. Chronicles proceedings on the opening day of the South Seas Exhibition, Dunedin, 17 Nov 1925, as reported on 18 Nov 1925. Includes a photograph of part of the crowd on opening day."

Title: "Synthetic cannabis causing workplace dangers"
description: "Highlights the dangers to the workplace posed by workers taking readily available legal synthetic cannabis products. Points out some of the negative effects of Kronic and other similar drugs. States that increasing numbers of corporations are now including random tests for these drugs in the workplace. Outlines what synthetic cannabinoids are."

Author: "Laugesen, Ruth"
Title: "New Zealand settlers : people of the land?"
description: "Challenges the old clicheÃÅ that the countryside is the backbone of NZ. Argues that from the earliest days of European settlement the reality has been a flight from the lonely countryside to the towns. Notes that for MaÃÑori the shift to the cities happened much later. Looks at what drove the escape from the countryside. Asks why NZers still look backwards so longingly. Looks into the modern rural lifestyle, where the isolation is lessening."

Author: "Doesburg, Anthony"
Title: "Radio revolution : digital radio in New Zealand"
description: "Looks into the impending transformation of the analogue radio by 21st-century digital technology. Describes some of the usability features. Observes the successful uptake of digital radio in Australia. Considers some of the hurdles for digital radio in NZ. Mentions a trial covering parts of Wellington and Auckland."

Author: "Black, Joanne"
Title: "Digital security and the Privacy Act"
description: "Speaks to Law commissioner John Burrows about the power of the Privacy Act in the rapidly changing digital age. Talks about the proposed recommendations of the Law Commission's review of the Act, which includes making blagging (impersonating someone to get information from a third party) illegal."

Author: "Torrie, Bronwyn"
Title: "Tide turns for Porirua Harbour"
description: "Speaks to the Porirua Harbour strategy co-ordinator about the 'Porirua Harbour catchment strategy and action plan' that aims to reverse decades of neglect and damage to the harbour. Touches on his connection to the area and his career. Outlines the three main issues for the harbour: sediment build-up, pollution and loss of vegetation and habitats. Mentions some things locals can do to help."

Author: "Matthews, Philip"
Title: "Archivists dig quake stories out of rubble"
description: "Reports on how the experience of the Christchurch earthquakes will become the most comprehensively studied and archived disaster in NZ's history. Speaks to National Library of NZ associate chief librarian Ronald Milne about how the library has been steadily working to amass an earthquake archive, which includes an oral history project, commissioned photographs, harvesting of earthquake-related websites, and earthquake-related ephemera. Backgrounds the launch of the Ministry of Culture and Heritage's new web project called 'Quake Stories'. Talks to Paul Millar, an associate professor in the College of Arts at Canterbury University, about the plans for the 'Ceismic consortium', which will see Canterbury build up a unique archive of quake experiences."

Author: "Chug, Kiran"
Title: "Not quite a box of birds"
description: "Speaks to researchers about how convincing people to stop feeding the pigeons (Spanish rock pigeons) in the city's parks and open spaces could be enough to banish the feral birds. Looks ahead to problems that could be presented by other birds, including kaka from the Zealandia sanctuary."

Title: "Capill release bid stuns victim support groups"
description: "Capill release bid stuns victim support groups"

Author: "Nichols, Lane"
Title: "Can budget be better?; 'Fiction' puzzles Air NZ; Passenger hits back at Jetstar"
description: "Questions if low prices should mean low standards for budget airlines. Reports on how the stringent check-in rules and schedule disruptions of budget carrier Jetstar, a Qantas subsidiary, have sparked a spate of passenger complaints and negative headlines. Highlights a number of examples. Briefly outlines the fate of previous budget airlines that have tried to succeed in the NZ aviation market against the national carrier Air NZ. Speaks to Consumer NZ chief executive Sue Chetwin and to Jetstar Airlines Australia and NZ chief executive David Hall about the crucial role budget airlines play in promoting competition. Touches on the overseas situation. Lists the Jetstar rules for check-in and boarding, travelling with children, special assistance and baggage. Speaks to Air NZ chief executive Rob Fyfe about how the airline had to battle a series of malicious rumours that emerged from the Australian market suggesting the airline was operating unsafely by continuing to fly during the 2011 Chilean ash cloud saga. Talks to an angry Jetstar passenger about his experience with the airline."

Title: "Phil's big thrill as family four trot into battle at Oamaru"
description: "Phil's big thrill as family four trot into battle at Oamaru"

description: "Web search expert aims for success"

Author: "Wall, Tony"
Title: "Jewel of the coast"

Author: "Knight, Kim,"
Title: "Amazing space"
description: "Previews the photographic exhibition 'Illuminate our place' organised by Geoff Ross and featuring photographs by NZ celebrities, including reality television celebrity Phil Keoghan. Notes the works in the Auckland exhibition will be sold on Trade Me from 11Aug. Touches on Keoghan's Coromandel beach message to Prime Minister John Key."

Title: "Along came Bobbie ... ; the cruellest fate"
description: "Talks to a mother whose two sons died from complications due to metachromatic leukodystrophy (MLD).  Discusses how she feels about having another son, the difficulties she encountered caring for her sick sons as a single parent, and her hopes for a NZ originated cure for the disease. Includes fact about MLD and organisational support."

Looks at overseas research into the effects of sport on voting. Talks to political scientists about possible effects in NZ politics, how interested NZers are in rugby today, and whether politicians take the Cup into account."

Author: "Hartevelt, John"
Title: "War against prying eyes"
description: "Looks at what protection there is in law for online privacy, as more NZers upload personal information with the use of social networking sites and online trading. Outlines the key recommendations for change from the Law Commission's review of the Privacy Act, which will close loopholes and gaps in the statutes law. Touches on some recent privacy cases in NZ and overseas."

Title: "Environmental health officer"

description: "Reviews 'Tupaia: the remarkable story of Captain Cook's Polynesian navigator'. Explains Tupaia's place in Pacific history."

description: "Reviews 'New Zealand by design: a history of New Zealand product design', which sets out to answer the question: 'Is it yet possible to distinguish the essence of NZ product design?'"

Title: "Mother help"

Title: "Tinnitus : facts and figures"

Title: "Latitude 37 interview"
description: "Talks to the musician, part of the Australasian Latitude 37 chamber music trio, about his enthusiasm for the baroque period and its parallels with standard jazz performance. Notes that the trio will be on tour 14 Aug to 3 Sep 2011."

description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1926. Talks to a well-known citizen who expresses concern about the behaviour and attitudes of NZ juveniles and adolescents, as printed on 26 Oct 1926. Reports on the existence of stills producing illicit 'moonshine' whisky for sale in Southland and Otago, 9 Jun 1926. Describes a 'disastrous' fire on 4 Sep 1926 that destroyed the stewards' stand at the Wingatui racecourse, as reported on 6 Sep 1926. Touches on other events during the year. Includes a photograph of Port Chalmers from Scott Monument, looking towards Portobello."

Title: "Science mentor's mark indelible"
description: "Pays tribute to the late University of Otago chemistry lecturer. Touches on his upbringing in the Gore area. Seeks comments from colleagues and describes his activities in the community."

Author: "Campbell, Frank"
Title: "Teacher served God and society with enthusiasm"
description: "Eulogises his late sister. Traces her upbringing in Dunedin, her entry in the Sisters of Mercy community in 1947 and her substantial contribution to the Otago and Southland community as a teacher in primary schools and Dunedin Prison."

Title: "Humble, collaborative and respected leader"
description: "Sums up tributes from colleagues to the late Chief District Court judge."

Author: "Meikle, Hayden"
Title: "Oliver driven by thirst for knowledge"
description: "Interviews the former All Black, Highlanders and Otago hooker about his acceptance to Cambridge University to study part time for Executive MBA, while also working for a finance company in London. Touches on his future plans and comments on the present All Black and Otago teams and the end of Carisbrook stadium."

Author: "Dickison, Michael"
Title: "Williams tells of demons and fears"
description: "Williams tells of demons and fears"

description: "Tracks down the 56 Otago and Southland secondary school pupils from 29 area schools who won Class Act awards for excellence in 2004 to find out what they are doing now. Focuses on the Cambridge University PhD candidate in physics and the exploration geologist who is working in Tasmania and Namibia. Presents brief profiles of each of the students."

Title: "Life rich in promise ends after trip to see dinosaurs"

description: "Book review.  Reviews 'New Zealand film : an illustrated history', edited by Diane Pivac with Frank Stark and Lawrence McDonald."

Author: "Gilchrist, Shane"
Title: "The medium is still the message"
description: "Speaks to New York-based film maker Morgan Spurlock about his latest documentary 'POM Wonderful presents : The Greatest movie ever sold', a satire about the insidious use of product placement, financed largely through product placement. Notes that the film will screen as part of the New Zealand International Film Festival, showing at the Regent Theatre, Dunedin on 9 and 11 Aug 2011. Provides facts about Morgan Spurlock and the history of product placement."

Author: "Gilchrist, Shane"
Title: "Finest film no-one has seen"
description: "Talks to the director of the award-winning 1988 film about its re-release as part of the New Zealand International Film Festival. Recalls his directorial feature film debut, his fascination with China, and the history of the Chinese goldminers in Otago that inspired the film. Notes that Leon Narbey will attend the film in Dunedin, 10 Aug 2011, and also give a public lecture at the Dunedin School of Art, 11 Aug 2011."

Author: "Kara, Scott"
Title: "Inspired by collaboration"
description: "Talks to the singer-songwriter about the making of her new album, a collaboration with musician Mara TK. Seeks his views and notes that this is the first of a series of collaborations with other artists."

Author: "Jaquiery, Stephen"
Title: "Worthwhile work in the outdoors"
description: "Interviews the kakapo ranger for the Department of Conservation, working on Codfish Island. Describes the training, physical requirements and other aspects of her work."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1927"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1927.  Reports on the visit to Dunedin by the Duke and Duchess of York, published on 17 and 19 Mar 1927. Includes a photograph of the occasion. Relays news from Paris of the arrival of Captain Charles Lindbergh in Le Bourget after a non-stop solo flight from New York, as reported on 24 May 1927. Comments on the introduction of daylight savings in the 7 Nov 1927 edition. Touches on other events during the year."

Author: "Rae, Sally"
Title: "Food verifying goes global"
description: "Talks to the chief executive of the Dunedin-based company about its pioneering systems to verify food origin. Discusses the history of the company, its global connections and how it goes about its work."

Title: "NZ-born heroine 'White Mouse' dies aged 98"
description: "Traces the life of the late NZ-born World War 2 heroine who was awarded the LeÃÅgion d'Honneur, three Croix de Guerre, a French Resistance Medal, the George Medal (Britain), and the US Medal of Freedom for her intelligence work in Germany for the Allies. Describes her activities during the war and her reaction to being in the spotlight in later years. Notes that she was made a Companion of the Order of Australia in 2004 and awarded the NZ Returned and Services Association's Band in Gold in 2006."

description: "'Brutal' act gets six-year jail term"

Title: "The battle of Manners St; the colour question"
description: "Reveals information found in Archives NZ files about the tensions accompanying the arrival of US servicemen in NZ 69 years ago, noting that the government censored press coverage of any incidents. Focuses on the larger brawls, one in Manners St and another in Cuba St, seen as a racially motivated incident involving MaÃÑori soldiers. Provides statistics on the stationing of the US soldiers in NZ. Documents advice given by the British high commission to the NZ government in 1943 regarding the treatment of black US soldiers in NZ."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1928"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1928. Relays news from London about a successful test transmission of television signals across the Atlantic to New York, 9 Apr 1928. Reports on 13 and 14 Aug 1928 that the NZ boxer won the Olympic Welterweight Championship in Amsterdam, 11 Aug 1928. Reports in the 12 Sep 1928 edition on the reaction to the arrival in Christchurch of aviator Charles Kingsford-Smith, on the last leg of his historic trip from California to NZ via Sydney. Touches on other events during the year. Includes a photograph of the view from the top of Mailer Street, Dunedin, in 1928."

Author: "Meikle, Hayden"
Title: "'Challenge' part of our game"
description: "Interviews Mario Wynands of co-founder of the gaming company Sidhe, about the upcoming release of the game 'All Blacks Rugby Challenge'."

Title: "Technology goes along on holiday : what a bonus"
description: "Comments on the features of several devices, including the TomTom VIA and the Motorola DEFY and the HTC Sensation smartphones, both of which are Android devices on the Telecom network."

Author: "Fensome, Alex"
Title: "Buried treasure, or horror?"
description: "Investigates the possible extraction of shale gas by L&M Energy in the Waiau basin using hydraulic fracturing, of fracking. Notes the protests in Taranaki over the process there, and reports of environmental pollution from wells using the process in Pennsylvania. Talks to Ohai farmer John Hogg about the wells on his land testing for coal seam gas and how he feels about it. Cites the comments of academics and politicians on the environmental concerns of fracking. Illustrates the process of extracting shale gas through hydraulic fracturing, and sums up the pros and cons of the procedure."

Author: "Chug, Kiran"
Title: "Sharing from the garden"
description: "Reports on a public meeting held by the Sustainability Trust that affirmed the growing movement of community gardens in Wellington. Talks to community projects manager Christina Bellis about the reasons for the popularity of the urban food movement. Discusses the future of orchard planting on public land, now underway in some Wellington suburbs. Looks at other community gardens in Cannons Creek (Wesley Community), Newtown and Mt Victoria (Innermost Gardens), and Brooklyn (Mokai Kainga MaÃÑori Centre Charitable Trust)."

Author: "Dennis, Abby"
Author (detailed): "Abby Dennis, Meghan Scanlan and Greer Paterson"
Title: "It's simple to be safe on Facebook; No act of kindness to Earth is wasted; Christchurch quakes show technology's worth"
description: "Presents essays from three pupils at Roxburgh Area School on the topics of Facebook safety, environmental preservation and the value of technology."

Author: "Clifton, Jane,"
Title: "Land of milk & money"
description: "Refers to recent events in NZ surrounding the questionable pricing of certain products such as milk and the Rugby World Cup Adidas jersey."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1929"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1929.  Focuses on the aftermath of the shipwreck of the Union Steamship Company steamer 'Manuka' on 16 Dec 1929, as reported on 18 Dec 1929. Describes the effects of a cyclone on Greymouth, 7 Dec 1929, and includes a photograph of the wreck. Briefly sums up the effects of the stock market crash on Wall Street, New York, 29 Oct 1929. Touches on other events during the year."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "Shackled"
description: "Summarises the current situation of the global financial crisis. Compares the US and European economies to NZ's. Looks at the reasons for the global financial crisis and forecasts how the world can get over this. Highlights NZ's position concentrating on relationships with China and Australia. Considers how the KiwiSaver may be affected."

Title: "Buried teen big on family, says mother-to-be"
description: "Buried teen big on family, says mother-to-be"

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1930"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1930.  Reports in the 17 Feb 1930 edition on the official opening of the Dunedin Town Hall on 156 Feb 1930. Describes issues raised by about 100 unemployed people who marched to the Dunedin Town Hall on 17 Apr 1930 to discuss their grievances with Mayor R. S. Black, as reported on 19 Apr 1930. Briefly reports in the 5 Nov 1930 edition on the win by NZ racehorse Phar Lap in the Melbourne Cup, and includes a 1930s era photograph of the horse and jockey Jim Pike. Announces the opening of the first transtasman radiotelephony service on 26 Nov 1930, and reproduces the conversation between the Acting Prime Minister of Australia and Minister of Native Affairs Sir Apirana Ngata. Touches on other events during the year."

Author: "Dastgheib, Shabnam"
Title: "Ten years after Tampa"
description: "Follows the lives of some of the 460 odd Afghani asylum seekers of the persecuted Hazara ethnic group who were settled in New Zealand ten years ago. Details their rescue at sea by Arne Rinnan, captain of the Norwegian MV Tampa,  and notes the subsequent political ramifications. Talks to the refugees about their experience in NZ and how they have fared since arriving here."

Author: "Lomas, David"
Title: "The last of the gang"
description: "Talks to notorious NZ criminal Peter Fulcher about his past. Reveals information about Terry Clark, drug dealing, violence, sex and money."

Author: "Du Fresne, Karl"
Title: "Survival in our broadcast jungle"
description: "Discusses the current situation with public television in NZ. Warns that the Government's decision to end funding for the non-commercial digital channels (TVNZ6 and TVNZ7) and the passing of the Television NZ Amendment Bill is bringing the extinction of public television closer."

Author: "Smith, Charmian"
Title: "Still on the beat; Conductor back with his 'favourite'"
description: "Talks to the principal guest conductor of the Southern Sinfonia about his impressions of how orchestral music has changed during his 50 years as a conductor. Informs of the upcoming concert by the Southern Sinfonia, Dunedin Town Hall, 13 Aug 2011."

Author: "Leask, Anna,"
Title: "Death brings holiday toll to one"
description: "Death brings holiday toll to one"

Author: "Forbes, Michael"
Title: "Treasure trove for the fans; First XV : rugby's great relics"
description: "Celebrates the opening of the New Zealand Rugby Museum, which has been relocated to the Te Manawa museum, Palmerston North. Talks to director Stephen Berg about the aims for the musuem and the rugby related activities for visitors. Showcases fifteen of the museum's most treasured rugby memorabilia."

Author: "Dignan, James"
Title: "Art seen"
description: "Reviews 'We are here' by Juliet Novena Sorrel, Otago School of Art Gallery, Dunedin, until 12 Aug 2011. Reviews 'Picture gallery' by Max Oettli, Temple Gallery, Dunedin, until 30 Aug 2011.  Reviews 'Hard on the heels' by Peter Bush, Otago Museum, Dunedin."

Showcases his lino inlayed table that will feature in Martin Bosely's restaurant during the Wellington on a Plate event. Chronicles the career of the UK born collage artist, describes some of his earlier decorative art work, and reveals where he sources his materials."

description: "Presents Fleur de Thier's latest new contemporary dance work, Tilt, showing at Fletcher Building Dome, Christchurch, August 19-21."

Author: "Bennett, Adam"
Title: "Scandal-hit ex-MP is off to North America"
description: "Scandal-hit ex-MP is off to North America"

description: "Discusses sleep patterns and the biological clock of human beings. Reports on recent research on sleep patterns connected with sunlight. Warns of the health risks associated with working during the night instead of daytime."

Profiles two children with egg and/or peanut allergies and explains how their mothers deal with the issue. Advises that guidelines for feeding infants have changed and early introduction of some allergenic foods is now recommended. Describes the tendency for people with skin and respiratory allergies to develop other allergies (atopic march). Explains how the immune system works, speculating that systems might be underworked because of modern, cleaner lifestyles."

description: "Sun shines after all for Miriama"

Author: "Masters, Catherine"
Title: "The careful rebel : part 1, Phil Goff : the untold story"
description: "Describes the making of the man. Speaks to the Labour Party leader, members of his family, including his father Bruce and older sister Linda, and others who knew and worked with him over the years, including childhood friends, teachers, and political colleagues and opponents. Talks about his upbringing in the 1950s and 1960s, his work effort, the influence of his paternal grandmother, Jessie, on his political leanings, his school years where he started to really think about NZ and its history, becoming an active member in Labour Youth, his time at the University of Auckland, and his family. Lists eight things that people may not know about the opposition leader."

Lists 'The factory' performers. Notes that the musical is on at the Mangere Arts Centre 13 Aug to 10 Sep 2011."

Considers the re-regulatory responses aimed at dealing with the problems in the building, finance and mining industries. Touches on how NZ's stance is regarded internationally."

Relates what is possible under the current law and Law Commissioner president, Sir Grant Hammond, notes the size of the problem is difficult to assess as repossession is treated as a civil matter. Cites a number of instances where essential household goods had been repossessed for relatively small amounts of money owing."

Savage in Wellington and covers some of his remarks made in a speech at the railway station. Acknowledges the change of government from National to Labour and considers the arrangements being made. description: "Talks to filmmaker Ian Mune about his movie, 'Billy T: te movie', portraying the life of musician and comedian Billy T. James. Discusses what aspects the film covers, Mune's relationship with the subject, and how the idea for the project originated. Touches on the timelessness of the comedian's humour. Includes a set of facts about his career."

Talks to a number of people about the way they find pleasure, through sex, dance, reading and others. Explains the physiological and psychological aspects of the sensation of pleasure."

Title: "Death of a sailor"

Discusses the findings of the 2008 Coles Inquiry into the incident. Details the inquest process and the frustration of the Solomon family over lack of accountability. Outlines the criticism that responsibility for the incident extends to the contractor (Tenix), certifier (Lloyds Register) and the Labour Government at the time. Examines some of the ship's defects, focusing on the operation of the rescue boat launch system. Explores in detail who was responsible for the ship's flawed components and why they failed to be identified during certification and testing, citing statements by experts at the inquest."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1941"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1941. Reports on the fatal shooting of three policemen by Stanley Graham at Koiterangi (Kowhitirangi, West Coast) (9 Oct) and his subsequent shooting and death after 11 days on the run (20 Oct), the digging of trenches in Dunedin to provide shelters in the event of the city being bombed from the air or the sea (15 Oct), and the bombing of Pearl Harbour, Honolulu and Guam by Japanese airplanes (8 Dec). Briefly reports on women taxi drivers in the city (11 Oct), the bombing of Germany by R.A.F. bombers (14 Oct), and the awarding of the Victoria Cross to Second-lieutenant Charles Hazlitt Upham and Sergeant Alfred Clive Hulme."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1938"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by this newspaper in 1938.   Revisits the Government announcement of the new health and superannuation plan, 4 Apr 1938; criticism of the city of Dunedin as the dirtiest in New Zealand, 18 Feb 1938; the devastation by flood of the Kopuawhara railway construction camp, 20 Feb 1938; and the Minister of Lands decision regarding the fate of Molesworth Station, 1 Apr 1938."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1939"

Mulholland to the Farmers' Union conference at Balclutha regarding the desperate plight of sheep farmers, 16 Mar 1939; and a move by the Federation of New Zealand Justices of the Peace to minimise or prevent abortion, 16 Mar 1939."

Title: "Saving the kiwi; bid to aid rarest kiwi quickens"
description: "Describes how Department of Conservation staff go about carrying out Operation Nest Egg, a  project in the Okarito kiwi sanctuary aimed at protecting the critically endangered rowi kiwi (Apteryx rowi).  Checks out the removal of eggs from nests, the efficacy of using 1080 bait for pest control, the main predators, the use of tracking transmitters, and egg incubation at the Franz Josef wildlife centre."

Author: "Cronshaw, Tim"
Title: "Cheese at heart of life on the farm"
description: "Talks to the cheesemaker at Sherrington Grange, Mahau Sound,  about her family's cheesemaking background and her cheesemaking dairy.  Checks out her raw materials and production methods. Mentions her use of heritage family recipes and describes the varieties she is known for. Touches on the honeymaking and tourism activities of other Harper family members, her cheesemaking classes and her stall at the Marlborough farmers' market."

Author: "Hyland, Adrian"
Title: "Hard graft in high-stakes world of college sport [part 1]"
description: "Visits Mt Albert Grammar School and looks at its rugby history. Talks to former All Black and old boy Bryan Williams about the success of their rugby academy, and first XV coach Charlie McAlister about the high-performance coaching programme he runs. Highlights last year's school rugby national final between MAGS and Hamilton Boys. Lists the former students who have become All Blacks."

Author: "Watkins, Tracy"
Title: "In search of the real Phil Goff"
description: "Follows Phil Goff, leader of the Labour Party, on a walkabout though a street in Te Atatu and describes his reception from various shopkeepers and pedestrians. Alludes to the conversation had at food banks and budget advisers on his itinerary."

Author: "Sachdeva, Sam"
Title: "Experts like what they see"
description: "Interviews two speakers at the International Speakers Series in Christchurch about their ideas for rebuilding the city after the earthquakes. Talks to Timaru born, London based architect Sam Martin about his concept of a park along the Avon River and his ideas for a central earthquake information centre. Talks to Victorian Bushfire Reconstruction and Recovery Authority  planner Kerry O'Neill about lessons learned in Victoria and her views on draft plans for Christchurch. Profiles briefly participants in the International Speakers Series being held at the University of Canterbury, 27-30 Aug."

Author: "Douglass, Malcolm"
Title: "The Draft Plan : five key matters"
description: "Presents opinion by the town planner on the post-earthquake Draft Plan document created by the Christchurch City Council. Sets out the five issues that the author considers need immediate resolution, focusing on council resources, public transportation, and development strategies. Provides a summary of the author's credentials."

Author: "Peka, June"
Title: "Faith in 'big one' was never shaken"
description: "Tells the story, on the anniversary of the 4 September Darfield earthquake, of the connection between a large antique oriental green vase and the author's mother, who had a vivid interest in seismology."

Title: "Kermadec inspirations"
description: "Reports in May 2011 nine artists set off on a week-long expedition to the northernmost reaches on NZ waters the Kermadec Islands. Notes the group was arranged by a US-led environment group which wants the area to become the world's largest ocean sanctuary. Recognises that the Kemadec Island hardly feature in NZ art unlike Antarctica and NZ's sub-Antarctic islands but an exhibition of the art has now opened at Wellington City Gallery. Includes images of the art with some comments by the artists."

Title: "The tiger and the toilet roll"
description: "Notes Greenpeace is investigating the source material for the manufacture of toilet paper sold in NZ claiming that some of it originates from Indonesian rainforests. Points out the location of this habitat  destruction is home to the critically endangered Sumatran tiger. Discusses the credentials of the various certifying bodies, PEFC (Programme for the Endorsement of Forest Certification), FSC (Forestry Stewardship Council) who purport support the manufacture of sustainable paper products."

Author: "Dekker, Diana"
Title: "Lost togs catalyst for writing career"

Title: "Something to sing about"

Discusses sponsorship, typical costs of production, surtitles, lean sopranos, ticket prices and audiences. Looks at the risks of staging lesser known operas, and the effect of low fees on NZ singers. Touches on the condition of Christchurch opera venues. Mentions the 6 Oct appearance of Placido Domingo at an earthquake recovery concert in Christchurch."

Talks to Antique Bottle and Collectors Club president Barry Hancox about the reasons people collect, his own preferences for china and photography items, and what he wants done with his collection.  Talks to Catherine Saunders about her appreciation of antique glass and why she joined a collectors' club."

Author: "Du Fresne, Karl"
Title: "Back on track"
description: "Profiles the Nelson born singer and music producer. Discusses his mid-career disenchantment with the music industry, and his recently released album."

Author: "Corry, Lucy"

description: "Meets the fish seller who set up a seafood supply business, Yellow Brick Road, after working for NZ Trade and Enterprise in Los Angeles. Talks about NZ chefs' preferences for fish, the fishing industry in NZ and the business awards she has won."

Talks to his father Bill Solomon about the "handed-up" evidence that was not made public and the Navy's reluctance to address identified hazards. Recounts the events that led to the sailor's death during the training exercise. Details the various certification, testing and verification issues regarding the safety of the vessel and the Rhib (Rigid hulled inflatable boat) operation under which Solomon was trapped and drowned."

Falconer to Dunedin Hospital (27 Jul, 1943); an Auckland wharf worker who claimed he was employed to do nothing (20 Aug, 1943); and the commencement of the rationing of butter and margarine (29 Oct, 1943)."

Author: "Hyland, Adrian"
Title: "Zoning cramps side's style [part 3]"
description: "Visits Auckland Grammar School (AGS). Revisits the 2010 match against St Peter's College and highlights the size advantage the St Peter's players had. Asks former old boy Grant Fox if he would have been an All Black if he had not gone to AGS. Looks at the socio-economic reasons behind their recent inability to maintain their "perennial champions" tag, including how new zoning has meant more boys who are not from a rugby population stock. Lists the former students who have become All Blacks."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "No more cheap home insurance"
description: "Looks at the effect of the recent Christchurch earthquakes on home insurance premiums and reinsurance. Supplies figures on the insurance cost of recent natural disasters. Looks at increases in contracting with international reinsurers and why some reinsurers are withdrawing from the market. Asks if NZ households may eventually be without comprehensive protection or be refused insurance on the basis of house inspections. Gives tips on what to look for when buying insurance and outlines the key issues arising from claims in Christchurch. Touches on how insurance company AMI has fared in the wake of the recent earthquakes."

Author: "Chug, Kiran"
Title: "What's all the flap about?; Best option for Happy Feet not clear"
description: "Investigates the issue of human intervention when wild animals need help to survive. Illustrates with the recent case of an emperor penguin from Antarctica appearing lost and becoming ill on Peka Peka Beach, north of Wellington and the subsequent help that it was afforded by Department of Conservation and Wellington Zoo staff. Asks how assured is the penguin's future after all the attention."

Title: "Busy passport fraudster busted : I never thought it was wrong"

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "Shocker; we were warned"
description: "Reviews Christchurch one year after its 4 Sep 2010 earthquake.  Relates the upheaval experienced by former Avonside resident and leader of citizens' group CanCern Leanne Curtis, whose house was in the red zone. Calculates the financial losses facing many red-zoned house owners.  Looks at how Kaiapoi couple Tetumu Rolleston and Luana Belworthy and their seven children have fared after their house was destroyed.  Describes the state of the building industry in Christchurch, noting the effects of delays in construction.  Points out the wary response of the insurance industry. Informs of a controversial geotechnical report published in 1991 and headed by now chief executive of Solid Energy Don Elder that warned of Christchurch's earthquake and liquefaction risks."

Title: "Our cup runneth over"

Title: "Miserable, close to death; A choppy farewell likely in cold southern seas; Bleak struggle for survival"
description: "Describes the assessment and treatment of the emperor penguin's health, indicating it was in very poor health after eating sand and debris it found on the beach. Relates the penguin was discovered on Peka Peka Beach by a member of the public. Mentions the penguin needed X-rays, painkillers, antibiotics, drugs to prevent stomach ulcers, anaesthetics, four flushing operations, anti-fungal medication, electrolyte substances, an endoscopy and a chilled room at five degrees Celsius along with 500 kg of fresh ice each day. Reports once Happy Feet's health recovered and regained his appetite he gained weight rapidly and became more difficult to handle. Notes Dr. Argilla will accompany Happy Feet on the Tangaroa ship taking a full medical kit with her to guard against any eventuality before his release. Explains the options for releasing Happy Feet (emperor penguin) from NIWA's (National Institute of Water and Atmosphere) research vessel, are either an aquaslide down the back of the ship  or if the water is calm enough, he could be released from NIWA's inflatable work boat which will be lowered by crane to sea level. Summarises the life cycle of the emperor penguin, the parents cooperatively looking after the egg and chick over the winter months with parents subsequently take turns foraging at sea. As the chicks grow they start to form creÃÄches and at five months old between December and January they make the journey to the edge of the pack ice and swim out to sea."

Author: "Abict, Jaimee"
Title: "The children's crisis"
description: "Interviews NZ aid worker Tristan Clements about co-ordinating relief at the Dadaab Camp, eastern Kenya. Describes his work, the effect of the relief effort and how NZers can help."

Author: "Levy, Danya"
Title: "The new political networking"
description: "Reports on how, with the general election fast approaching, political parties are using social media to circumvent new election spending rules. Report this year political parties will use digital media such as Twitter, Facebook and videos on YouTube which they hope will 'go viral' so they can get more exposure within the spending cap. Claire Robinson, Associate professor of Communication Design assesses each party's approach to the new technology and finds some parties and politicians are more adept than others in using this media. Discusses the issues associated with regulations around what is considered a political advert and what is not."

Author: "Johns, Geraldine"
Title: "Bligh spirit"
description: "Talks to historian Anne Salmond about her biography of Captain William Bligh. Discusses his personality, his sailings in the South Pacific, and his reaction to the mutiny on the ship 'Bounty'. Reflects on the experience of teenagers going to sea some 200 years ago. Reveals the author's attraction to her subject."

Author: "Perrott, Alan"
Title: "The enforcer"
description: "Recounts the newly appointed coach of St Kentigen's 1st IV, Tim Connolly's first impressions of the teenage rugby player. Outlines his early development and eventual selection for the All Blacks. Talks about his struggle to cope with the pressures of becoming an All Black too early, including his life outside rugby and his drink-drive conviction in 2008. Tells how he used these experiences as motivation to get back into the All Blacks and his focus on the upcoming World Cup."

Author: "Bridgeman, Shelley"
Title: "Bad hair days"
description: "Talks to freelance hairdresser Amelia Motuliki and Aucklander Kesiah Warner about the nature of their relationships with their clients or hairdressers. Offers some advice on how to break and move on from such a relationship."

Title: "Photo essay competition : finalists"

Discusses sponsorship, typical costs of production, surtitles, lean sopranos, ticket prices and audiences. Looks at the risks of staging lesser known operas, and the effect of low fees on NZ singers. Touches on the condition of Christchurch opera venues. Mentions the 6 Oct appearance of Placido Domingo at an earthquake recovery concert in Christchurch."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1944"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1944. Reports and comments on the observations of Brigadier L.M. Inglis, who was in command of the NZ Division during the time of Lieutenant-general Sir Bernard Freyberg, about NZ's war effort and matters of morale on the home front (9 Feb), the Allied bombing of the German occupied Benedictine Monastery on Monte Cassino, Italy (17 Feb), and the re-opening of the hotel bars in Invercargill after a period of 38 years of no licence (2 Jul). Touches on exemptions from the recently raised school leaving age of 15 years (12 Feb), the introduction of the Annual Holidays Bill in the House of Representatives, which allowed an annual holiday of two weeks on full pay (16 Mar), and the discovery of the fossil bones of an extinct type of whale in a line of cliffs at Duntroon in North Otago (no date)."

Author: "Price, Mark"
Title: "Taking aim at tobacco; Enjoying a smoke as sun sets"
description: "Reports on the plan of 'Aspire 25' for NZ to be tobacco-free by 2025. Talks to the group's leader Professor Richard Edwards, head of the public health department of the University of Otago's Wellington School of Medicine, about the public support for banning cigarette sales, the need for extremely good support for people wanting to quit, and the argument that smokers die younger and therefore save the country money. Lists the leading members of Aspire 25. Touches on a 2007 study by University of Otago researchers that found smokers in poorer areas smoked more of their cigarettes than smokers in wealthier areas. Includes a response by the columnist who is an unrepentant smoker."

Author: "Gilchrist, Shane"
Title: "Taking aim at the inane"
description: "Focuses on the NZ Skeptics. Speaks to NZ Skeptics media spokeswoman Vicki Hyde about the aims of the non-profit incorporated society, which she likens to a Consumer's Institute for the mind. Talks about the lack of science-based knowledge within the media. Touches on some of the poor or shoddy science the Skeptics have issues with. Mentions the society's 2011 'Bent Spoon Award' for journalistic gullibility, which was awarded to media outlets and personalities who took Ken Ring's earthquake prediction claims at face value. Notes that the NZ Skeptics 2011 annual conference is being held in Christchurch on 27-28 Aug."

Title: "Stung"
description: "Reports on the phenomenon of NZ customers being charged higher prices than those overseas for online purchases, giving examples of price differences for products.  Gives the reasons why NZers are charged more, including the nature of the NZ market, and territorial licensing agreements and geoblocking barriers that direct NZ buyers to local online sites who charge considerably higher prices. Notes that there are currently no laws against the different prices. Mentions some ways of getting around the blocks."

description: "Reports on the major overhaul of how assaults on mental health workers are recorded by the Auckland District Health Board. Investigates attacks on hospital staff by acute mental health patients at Auckland's frontline mental health unit Te Whetu Tawera."

Author: "Taylor, Cliff"
Title: "Foul note to food that's fresh forever; It all sounds creepy to young mum"
description: "Reports on the discovery of a substance called bisin which, when used as a preservative, could keep food fresh virtually indefinitely. Speaks to Professor Conrad Perera, director of food science at the University of Auckland's School of Chemical Sciences, about the substance, which is produced by a bacterium known as Bifidobacterium longum. Talks about the preservatives currently used in food in NZ. Speaks to journalist and new mum Nicola Shepheard about her response to the reports of the long-lasting preservative power of bisin."

Author: "Johns, Geraldine"
Title: "Fighting 'toxic uncertainty'"
description: "Talks to Dr Bruce Arroll, head of general practice at University of Auckland's school of medicine, about his diagnosis of acute myeloid leukaemia. Highlights the difficult emotions experienced while waiting for information and undergoing treatment. Outlines the process of his treatment. Mentions the camaraderie Arroll felt with other cancer patients and his admiration of the public health system."

Author: "Young, Audrey"
Title: "UN vote pulls big names to forum"
description: "Anticipates the Pacific Islands Forum to be held 7-8 Sep, 2011, in Auckland. Explains the reasons for the attendance of Hungarian and relative of Archduke Franz Ferdinand, Georg von Habsburg, and of other non-Pacific representatives. Notes the deliberate decision to segue the forum into the Rugby World Cup event. Touches on the contrast between the 2011 forum and the first meeting in 1971."

Title: "Aviation's golden age yet to come : Sims"
description: "Aviation's golden age yet to come : Sims"

Author: "Laxon, Andrew"
Title: "Alarm at soaring use of 'happy pills'"
description: "Reports on the increasing prescription of antidepressants for children and teenagers. Acknowledges the concerns of the effects of such drugs on suicidal thinking. Notes the calls by Green Party's Sue Kedgley for warning labels on drug packets. Touches on cases involving the effects of fluoxetine, including the death of Auckland teenager Toran Henry. Gives 2010 statistics for antidepressant prescription to children and adolescents."

Author: "Leggat, David"
Title: "Kean sets a personal best to make it into 100m semifinals"
description: "Kean sets a personal best to make it into 100m semifinals"

Author: "Herrick, Linda"
Title: "Hotere's homage heralds a glittering new dawn"
description: "Peruses the NZ collection at the reopening of the Auckland Art Gallery, focusing on the Ralph Hotere Godwit/Kuaka work that is accompanied by a recording of his singing. Talks to contemporary art curator Natasha Conland about the exhibition of NZ art spanning 45 years, including some that is on display for the first time."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "Kickback mountain"
description: "Reports on the risk to businesses of staff being involved in bribery and the need for businesses to establish effective code of ethics policies and ethics training for staff. Notes that the introduction of the UK's Bribery Act means that NZ companies operating in the UK could be liable for failing to prevent bribery."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1947"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1947. Reports and comments on the deadly fire at the J. Ballantyne and Co (Ballantynes) department store in Christchurch (18 Nov), an edgy calm in Palestine on the eve of partition and the creation of the Jewish State (3 Dec), the last tram to run on the Stuart Street (Dunedin) line (1 Aug), and a lack of heavier cars, particularly American or Canadian brands, reaching the market with the Government buying most of them on arrival (15 Nov)."

Author: "Laugesen, Ruth"
Title: "Goodbye graffiti"
description: "Highlights the youth murals on walls around the town of Opotiki painted by primary and secondary students, overseen by Shona Hammond Boys, who runs an art club for school children. Notes that Hammond Boys and Constable Ian Dodds planned the murals and funding from the police and the Ministry of Social Development. Reports that behaviour and confidence of the artists, some who had been taggers, improved and the incidence of graffiti almost stopped. Mentions that resource consent has been gained for a mussel farm off the Opotiki coast, improving potential for employment in the town."

Author: "Christian, Dionne"
Title: "A burst of sunshine in the golden weather"
description: "Reviews the play by Bruce Mason, directed by Murray Lynch and performed by the Auckland Theatre Company (Maidment Theatre until 24 Sep) as part of the REAL NZ Festival. Talks to Keisha Castle-Hughes about stage acting. Observes how the one-man show has been adapted to a cast of nine."

Title: "Play on!"
description: "Recounts the prolific history of rugby themed songs in NZ with many professionally published and widely known. Highlights the history of the origin and performance of the most well known song 'On the Ball'. Lists a few rugby songs from recent decades, noting that there are now very few rugby songs composed. Mentions an early print copy of 'On the Ball' at the NZ Rugby Museum, Palmerston North, and a vintage sound recording of it at Radio NZ Sound Archives."
