description: "Talks to Dr Bruce Arroll, head of general practice at University of Auckland's school of medicine, about his diagnosis of acute myeloid leukaemia. Highlights the difficult emotions experienced while waiting for information and undergoing treatment. Outlines the process of his treatment. Mentions the camaraderie Arroll felt with other cancer patients and his admiration of the public health system."

Author: "Laugesen, Ruth"
Title: "Opotiki youth murals feed artistic talent"
description: "Highlights the youth murals on walls around the town of Opotiki painted by primary and secondary students, overseen by Shona Hammond Boys, who runs an art club for school children. Notes that Hammond Boys and Constable Ian Dodds planned the murals and funding from the police and the Ministry of Social Development. Reports that behaviour and confidence of the artists, some who had been taggers, improved and the incidence of graffiti almost stopped. Mentions that resource consent has been gained for a mussel farm off the Opotiki coast, improving potential for employment in the town."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "The dark side of corporate hospitality"
description: "Reports on the risk to businesses of staff being involved in bribery and the need for businesses to establish effective code of ethics policies and ethics training for staff. Notes that the introduction of the UK's Bribery Act means that NZ companies operating in the UK could be liable for failing to prevent bribery."

Author: "Taylor, Lindis"
Title: "Cavalleria rusticana and Pagliacci review"
description: "Reviews 'Cavalleria rusticana' and 'Pagliacci' performed by the NBR NZ Opera, St James Theatre Wellington, 27 Aug-3 Sep, Aotea Centre Auckland, 15-25 Sep."

Author: "Wood, Andrew Paul,"
Title: "The pressure of sunlight falling by Fiona Pardington"
description: "The pressure of sunlight falling by Fiona Pardington"

Author: "Ralston, Bill"
Title: "Price-gouging online Kiwis"
description: "Reports on the phenomenon of NZ customers being charged higher prices than those overseas for online purchases, giving examples of price differences for products.  Gives the reasons why NZers are charged more, including the nature of the NZ market, and territorial licensing agreements and geoblocking barriers that direct NZ buyers to local online sites who charge considerably higher prices. Notes that there are currently no laws against the different prices. Mentions some ways of getting around the blocks."

Author: "Horsley, Francesca"
Title: "Totally random"
description: "Reviews 'Random Acts of God and Other Stories' performed by Corrupt Productions, choreographer Julia Milsom, TelstraClear Club, Christchurch, 27-28 Aug, as part of the Christchurch Arts Festival."

Author: "Horsley, Francesca"
Title: "Random Acts of God and Other Stories review"
description: "Reviews 'Random Acts of God and Other Stories' performed by Corrupt Productions, choreographer Julia Milsom, TelstraClear Club, Christchurch, 27-28 Aug, as part of the Christchurch Arts Festival."

Author: "Conway, Glenn"
Title: "Mayor an optimist in face of misfortune; One year on September 4, 2010"
description: "Interviews the Christchurch mayor one year after the Darfield earthquake. Talks about the effect on the mayoral election, and how he has fared politically, psychologically and personally."

Author: "Leggat, David"
Title: "'Hoodeyes' put best to the test"
description: "'Hoodeyes' put best to the test"

Author: "Heather, Ben"
Title: "Shock to the system; extent of disaster never imagined"
description: "Explores criticism that the EQC was unprepared for the size of Christchurch earthquakes, for multiple earthquakes, and for the number of claims.  Talks to chief executive officer Ian Simpson about EQC's response to an external review (2008) that highlighted inadequacies.  Looks at the post-earthquake functions taken on by the Commission that are outside its mandate.  Asks if the EQC model is sound.  Briefly describes the function of the EQC. Shows statistics for claims and amounts paid for the 2010 and 2011 earthquakes."

Author: "Cleaver, Dylan"
Title: "Tough No 8 always had the special wow factor"
description: "Tough No 8 always had the special wow factor"

Author: "Anderson, Vicki"
Title: "Reading signs before a quake"
description: "Talks to scientist Dr Neil Whitehead about his research into possible indicators of the 4 Sep 2010 Canterbury earthquake.  Notes that  the study of electronic precursors to earthquakes began in Japan after the 1995 Kobe earthquake. Discusses the detection of electromagnetic radiation signals in the ground, in water, in the sky, by animals, by humans, by electronic gadgetry, and in the form of earthquake lights. Mentions a successful earthquake prediction in Chian in 1975. Comments on the response from Cantabrians to his response for information."

Author: "Leggat, David"
Title: "'The Boot' bigger than his legend"
description: "'The Boot' bigger than his legend"

Author: "Anderson, Vicki"
Title: "Home is where the epicentre is"
description: "Talks to Cantabrians whose homes are located close to the epicentres of the earthquakes that struck the area on 4 September 2010, 26 December 2010, 22 February 2011 and 13 June 2011. Discusses their experiences and observations about the earthquakes."

Author: "Crean, Mike"
Title: "Scientist took the shakes out of the quakes"
description: "Scientist took the shakes out of the quakes"

Author: "Birss, Neill"
Title: "Mums & dads down the queue for council bonds"
description: "Informs of highly rated local body bonds to be offered by the new national funding agency to retail investors.  Explains how the issue will work."

Author: "Leech, Robin"
Title: "Astute cattle breeder and A&P judge"
description: "Astute cattle breeder and A&P judge"

Author: "Cleaver, Dylan"
Title: "'Beegee' our first Samoan superstar"
description: "'Beegee' our first Samoan superstar"

Author: "De Lacy, Hugh"
Title: "Shell-shocked in the Shaky Isles"
description: "Observes the impact of the 2010 and 2011 Canterbury/Christchurch earthquakes on the insurance industry.  Talks to Insurance Council of New Zealand (ICNZ) chief executive Chris Ryan, Insurance Brokers Association (IBANZ) chief executive Gary Young, and AMI Insurance chief executive John Balmforth about the costs to insurers and reinsurers.  Highlights the current precarious state of AMI.  Speculates on how high insurance premiums will go up as a result."

Author: "McMillan, Neale"
Title: "Legal aid under review"
description: "Looks at the current review of legal aid in the Legal Assistance (Sustainability) Bill now with the justice and electoral committee."

Author: "Power, J. F."
Title: "Dangerous times"
description: "Remarks on the current volatility of the U.S. dollar and the potential impact of its collapse on the rest of the world.  Comments on insurance coverage for strikes, riots and civil commotions (SRCC) claims in the UK and the lack of such a scheme in NZ."

Author: "Steeman, Marta"
Title: "Recovery stymied by insurance"
description: "Assesses the state of the Canterbury business community one year after the Darfield earthquake. Looks at the effect on CBD businesses of the 22 February 2011 earthquake. Provides some statistics on the state of various industries. Highlights the survival of Sydenham IT company Truescape, sheet metal fabrication shop Prometal, and residential building company Stonewood Homes."

Author: "Rapson, Bevan"
Title: "Super Sid's going, he's still going ..."
description: "Super Sid's going, he's still going ..."

Author: "Hattaway, Peter"
Title: "Falling for the oldest trick"
description: "Details the fraud perpetrated by One Call Flooring carpet installation business owner Ross Davidson and his wife, Wendy Davidson, against Easy Factors International Ltd (EFI) business finance company.  Notes the prison sentences later imposed on the couple.  Mentions Wendy's reduced sentence on appeal because of the mitigating factor of her abuse by her husband."

Author: "Hutching, Chris"
Title: "New commercial dynamic outlined"
description: "Reports on the effect of concerns about seismic risk on commercial property valuations in Wellington, Christchurch, and Auckland."

Title: "Elementary 'oversight' by Vodafone"
description: "Backgrounds and summarises the sentencing of Judge Roderick Joyce in the case of Vodafone's breach of the Fair Trading Act in relation to its Vodafone Live! mobile phone internet service."

Author: "Fletcher, Richard"
Title: "A joint venture puzzle"
description: "Recaps the decision in the case of 'Curtis and another v Gibson and another' [2011] NZCA 373, regarding the breakdown of an ill-defined joint venture (Habode (NZ)) and subsequent claims for a share of the venture's action by an aggrieved party."

Author: "Van Beynen, Martin"
Title: "Lessons learned in city's rescue feats"
description: "Reflects on the 4 September and 22 February earthquakes, recording the faulty, fortunate and educational aspects of the events.  Details the main lessons learned: importance of building in resilience, plans, planning, good pre-existing relationships, exercises, maintaining normal processes, allowing for technology failure and looking after staff."

Author: "Van Beynen, Martin"
Title: "'Fantastic' staff coped with chaos"
description: "Reports on the response and services provided by the Christchurch Hospital Emergency Department (ED) following earthquake in Christchurch. Points out six lessons learned, supplied by ED acting head Mike Ardagh."

Author: "Gorman, Paul,"
Title: "Savage shaking makes science sexy"
description: "Overviews coverage of the Canterbury earthquakes. Observes the public thirst for scientific knowledge sparked by the 4 September 2010 Darfield earthquake. Remarks on some of the egoic responses of scientists to suddenly being in the spotlight."

Author: "Matthews, Philip"
Title: "Beyond repair"
description: "Talks to Louise Deans about the destruction of the Homebush homestead in the Darfield earthquake. Recalls the events of the day, 4 September 2010. Reveals plans to build a new house close to the original site. Recalls Deans family history dating back to William Deans and John Deans taking up a lease in Canterbury in 1843, and the building of the homestead in 1851.  Documents damage to other buildings in Hororata - St John's church and the Hororata Hotel - and notes the creation of the Hororata Community Trust aimed at reviving the community."

Author: "Newton, Kate"
Title: "Man found hanging after wife stabbed to death"
description: "Man found hanging after wife stabbed to death"

Author: "Cairns, Lois"
Title: "Shocked Timaru pays tribute; He takes mystery of failed SCF to the grave"
description: "Shocked Timaru pays tribute; He takes mystery of failed SCF to the grave"

Author: "Mussen, Deidre"
Title: "Stirring send-off for croquet boss"
description: "Stirring send-off for croquet boss"

Author: "Eleven, Beck"
Title: "Oh, how we've changed"
description: "Describes the social and cultural response of Canterbury to the 2010/2011 earthquakes that hit the region. Looks at changes in vocabulary ('munted'), dress and grooming codes, civic identity, house decoration, earthquake music and merchandise, and emergency preparations."

Author: "Corry, Lucy"
Title: "Cracking the nut market"
description: "Features Uncle Joe's, the walnut and hazelnut business of Blenheim residents Malcolm Horwell and Jenny Horwell. Talks about their orchards, their processing business and awards they have won. Conveys their enthusiasm for the health benefits of nuts."

Author: "Glass, Amy"
Title: "Music man sick of people's records"
description: "Music man sick of people's records"

Author: "Akoorie, Natalie"
Title: "Hearty effort in soccer rematch"
description: "Hearty effort in soccer rematch"

Author: "Akoorie, Natalie"
Title: "Delight for young battler after devastation at theft"
description: "Delight for young battler after devastation at theft"

Title: "Family members find man's body on driveway"
description: "Family members find man's body on driveway"

Author: "Shiels, Rosa"
Title: "Solid as a wooden rock"
description: "Highlights the research into earthquake resistant buildings by Structural Timber Innovation Company. Talks to Canterbury University engineer Dr Stefano Pampanin about the structure of the company's headquarters, a wooden building that withstood the 22 February 2011 earthquake. Notes his work with NZ born seismic designer Nigel Priestley, the use made of Greek temple structure, and the reason for focusing on using  wood. Mentions other buildings that use the company's earthquake-resistant technology."

Author: "Plumb, Simon"
Title: "Wada slams NZ supplement claims"
description: "Continues the investigation into whether NZ's elite athletes are being exposed to doping risks because of the way the NZ Academy of Sport (NZAS) is managing its Integria Healthcare sponsored supplements programme. Reports on comments from David Howman, head of the World Anti-Doping Agency (Wada), who has disputed claims from the NZ Olympic Committee and Sparc that the programme is Wada compliant."

Author: "Williams, Lyn"
Title: "The dead tell tales : Roberts Wood 1866-1887"
description: "The dead tell tales : Roberts Wood 1866-1887"

Author: "Lichter, Barry"
Title: "'Nothing horse' on hero run; Gillies' bad injury run blown away by unique Northern double"
description: "'Nothing horse' on hero run; Gillies' bad injury run blown away by unique Northern double"

Author: "Macdonald, Nikki"
Title: "South Sea oddity"
description: "Talks to anthropologist Dame Anne Salmond about her three years of research resulting in the biography, Bligh, Bligh: William Bligh in the South Seas. Notes the story is told from a Polynesian perspective. Discusses Bligh's relationship to Captain James Cook, his seamanship, and his fatal mistakes leading to the 'Bounty' mutiny."

Author: "Twentyman, Maryanne"
Title: "Kayakers find joys of happy hooker"
description: "Kayakers find joys of happy hooker"

Author: "Harper, Glyn,"
Title: "Another forgotten war hero"
description: "Reviews the biography of Major General Sir Andrew Russell, noting the subject may be more neglected than forgotten. Comments on the lack of references."

Author: "Crean, Mike"
Title: "Poetry"
description: "Reviews 'Small holes in the silence: collected works'."

Author: "Lichter, Barry"
Title: "So You Think's prize left in limbo"
description: "Reports on a botched media release by NZ Thoroughbred Racing that mistakenly listed Jimmy Choux's owner (Richard Wood) as breeder-of-the-year instead of the owner of champion galloper So You Think. Talks to the real winner about the humble beginnings of her breeding operation Piper Farm."

Author: "Leggat, David"
Title: "Try-hungry great a head of his time"
description: "Try-hungry great a head of his time"

Author: "Barton, Tim"
Title: "Snow Excuse, Coleman impressive combination"
description: "Snow Excuse, Coleman impressive combination"

Author: "Wratten, Stephen D."
Title: "Of cabbages and wings"
description: "Discusses what Australian viticullturalists are doing to avoid using agrichemicals. Names organic products that NZ gardeners can use for indoor and outdoor plants, focusing on the use of soluble seaweed extract."

Author: "Dudding, Adam"
Title: "Out of the box"
description: "Looks at how broadcasters are attempting to gain back some control of their viewers. Reports that with the advent of the internet, new devices such as smartphones and tablets, and the increasing uptake of personal video recorders (PVRs), television viewers now expect to watch their favourite programmes where, when and however they choose. Speaks to Rick Ellis, chief executive of TVNZ, about the trend of getting foreign programmes to NZ faster and the impact of the internet on television viewing. Talks about pay television network Sky's new channel 'SoHo', which will be devoted to cable-TV material built around programmes from the United States company HBO. Briefly outlines the different options for viewing television programmes."

Author: "Donnell, Ethan"
Title: "'Force' tribute nets Double Droid award"
description: "'Force' tribute nets Double Droid award"

Author: "Tapaleao, Vaimoana"
Title: "'Hoppy' pays tribute to crews of life-saving chopper service"
description: "'Hoppy' pays tribute to crews of life-saving chopper service"

Author: "Corry, Lucy"
Title: "Cracking the nut market"
description: "Features Uncle Joe's, the walnut and hazelnut business of Blenheim residents Malcolm Horwell and Jenny Horwell. Talks about their orchards, their processing business and awards they have won. Conveys their enthusiasm for the health benefits of nuts."

Author: "Kilgallon, Steve"
Title: "Sky high"
description: "Profiles the pay television network's chief executive. Talks about his career and his role in the success of the company."

Author: "Knight, Kim,"
Title: "Photo celebration the next best thing to being there"
description: "Photo celebration the next best thing to being there"

Author: "Fitzsimons, Tom"
Title: "Signs of the times"
description: "Surveys the phenomenon of branding and welcome signs in NZ towns and cities, looking at the origin of self promotion in NZ. Refers to the controversy over Wellington's 'Wellywood' sign. Notes the work of publisher Josh Easby and his photograps of 450 welcome signs. Lists a variety of town slogans. Talks to media experts and academics about whether signs are necessary and what type of sign works best. Discusses the origins and success of Wellington's slogan with former general manager at Saatchi & Saatchi Kim Wicksteed."

Author: "McAvinue, Shawn"
Title: "Hive mentality"
description: "Highlights the popularity of urban beekeeping, talking to people who have taken lessons from the Wellington Beekeepers Association and set up hives in their backyards. Talks to budding beekeepers in Island Bay and a Houghton Bay mead-maker who espouses the benefits of honey, propolis, pollen and mead for injuries and health."

Author: "Kilgallon, Steve"
Title: "'Every day with him is precious'"
description: "Profiles the former rugby player. Talks about the joys of fatherhood and repairing his relationship with his dying father."

Author: "O'Neill, Rob"
Title: "2011 : it's a whole new ball game"
description: "Looks at the business difference between the 1987 and 2011 Rugby World Cup tournaments."

Author: "Shiels, Rosa"
Title: "Solid as a wooden rock"
description: "Highlights the research into earthquake resistant buildings by Structural Timber Innovation Company. Talks to Canterbury University engineer Dr Stefano Pampanin about the structure of the company's headquarters, a wooden building that withstood the 22 February 2011 earthquake. Notes his work with NZ born seismic designer Nigel Priestley, the use made of Greek temple structure, and the reason for focusing on using  wood. Mentions other buildings that use the company's earthquake-resistant technology."

Author: "Kilgallon, Steve"
Title: "It's not just the rugby"
description: "Talks to some of the Rugby World Cup 2011 Ltd staff about their behind the scenes roles."

Author: "Macdonald, Nikki"
Title: "South Sea oddity"
description: "Talks to anthropologist Dame Anne Salmond about her three years of research resulting in the biography, Bligh, Bligh: William Bligh in the South Seas. Notes the story is told from a Polynesian perspective. Discusses Bligh's relationship to Captain James Cook, his seamanship, and his fatal mistakes leading to the 'Bounty' mutiny."

Author: "Murray, Sarah"
Title: "MaiÃÇtre d'"
description: "Explains what a typical day is like for the maiÃÇtre d'."

Author: "Crean, Mike"
Title: "Poetry"
description: "Reviews 'Small holes in the silence: collected works'."

Author: "Gay, Edward"
Title: "Killer caught by DNA seeks sentence cut"
description: "Killer caught by DNA seeks sentence cut"

Author: "Macdonald, Nikki"
Title: "Grim life on the frayed fringe of society"
description: "Surveys the living conditions in city council housing in the wake of the recent discovery of the body of a tenant who had been dead for over a year. Talks to Newtown Park flat residents Sofia Mohammed, Peter Leonard, Kishor Maharaj, and Melanie Schnauer about their experiences. Gives statistics on the demographic makeup of the council's 3500 tenants."

Author: "Torrie, Bronwyn"
Title: "Where you stand as the law tightens its web"
description: "Presents a series of questions and answers regarding the Copyright Law coming into effect 8 Sep 2011. Guides parents who may be unaware that the downloading of internet material by their children will become illegal. Looks at peer-to-peer file sharing, liability, fines, and other aspects of the law."

Author: "Chug, Kiran"
Title: "Long-overlooked jewel shines anew"
description: "Reports on the weed and pest eradication scheme currently underway on Taputeranga Island on city's south coast. Notes the Rita Angus artwork inspired by the island. Talks to Mayor Celia Wade-Brown about kayaking to the island. Gives island details and pest management plan specifications."

Author: "Dekker, Diana"
Title: "An enigma with a plethora of creative talents"
description: "An enigma with a plethora of creative talents"

Author: "Crean, Mike"
Title: "Scientist's quake bearings were 'NZ's greatest technological gift to the world'"
description: "Scientist's quake bearings were 'NZ's greatest technological gift to the world'"

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1948"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1948. Reports and comments on the call of the Royal Commission on Racing and Gaming for the granting of authority to the Racing and Trotting Conferences to establish a totalisator off-course betting scheme by the operation of totalisator agencies where they were warranted (7 Jan), inspection of the first sheets of finished stamps in the Otago centennial issue received by the Post and Telegraphy Department (20 Jan), and the proclamation of the Jewish State of Israel in Palestine, which was recognised by the United States and resulted in the issuing of a formal declaration of a 'state of war against Palestine Jewry' by the Arab League General Secretariat (17 May). Touches on the assassination of Mahatma Gandhi (31 Jan), the rationing of petrol by the Government (16 Feb), and the destruction of the eastern wing of the Tourist Department's hostel at Milford Sound by fire (16 Feb). Includes a photo of the Exchange, Princes and High Streets, Dunedin."

Author: "Donoghue, Tim"
Title: "Working her magic behind the scenes"
description: "Working her magic behind the scenes"

Author: "Kay, Martin"
Title: "Police covert and specialised units were his forte"
description: "Police covert and specialised units were his forte"

Author: "Leggat, David"
Title: "McClennan starts with sights on top prize"
description: "McClennan starts with sights on top prize"

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1949"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1949. Reports and comments on a heat wave in Dunedin and other parts of Otago (8 Feb), the Minister of Finance's decision to increase substantially the importation of motor vehicles over the 1948 licence values (10 May), and the ongoing destruction of the Fiordland forest by animals (27 Oct). Touches on an eruption of Mount Ngauruhoe (10 Feb), the take over of the Invermay property at North Taieri by the Government as an agricultural and research station for Otago (4 Jun), the carrying of the proposal that compulsory military training should be introduced in NZ (4 Aug), and congratulations to Mr John Bennetts, of Roxburgh, on his record of 50 years as a member of the Tuapeka County Council (4 Oct). Includes a photograph of the terrace crowd at Carisbrook on 13 Aug for Otago's Ranfurly Shield defence over Southland."

Author: "Catherall, Sarah"
Title: "9/11; imperatives of 9/11aftermath"
description: "Assesses the aftermath of the Islamic terrorism attacks in the US on 11 Sep 2001, talking to Security Intelligence Service director Warren Tucker about the repercussions for security measures in NZ. Speaks with intelligence expert Paul Buchanan about NZ's resulting closer ties with the United States. Touches on the tougher airport screening procedures implemented since 9/11, talking to Aviation Security Service head Mark Everitt about the response of NZers to the restrictions, and about improved screening technology. Speaks to a Muslim priest and a NZ couple about their airport experiences."

Author: "Booker, Jarrod"
Title: "Back in business despite all the setbacks"
description: "Back in business despite all the setbacks"

Author: "Booker, Jarrod"
Title: "Against the flow... and happy about it"
description: "Against the flow... and happy about it"

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1950"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1950. Announces North Korea formally declaring war on the South Korea and reports of the invasion. Informs of the K Force troops sailing on the Ormonde from Wellington bound for Korea to support the UN effort. Reports on a demonstration of aerial sowing of fertiliser at the Invermay Experimental and Research Station, North Taieri."

Title: "Dedicated family man killed in head-on collision"
description: "Dedicated family man killed in head-on collision"

Author: "Levy, Danya"
Title: "A Dunne deal in Ohariu?"
description: "Checks out the Ohariu electorate, noting that voting there will decide the future of the UnitedFuture Party. Comments on the blatant support for incumbent candidate Peter Dunne by the National Party. Lists Ohariu voting results since 2002. Profiles the candidates contesting the seat: Charles Chauvel (Labour Party), Katrina Shanks (National Party) and Peter Dunne (UnitedFuture Party). Polls electorate voters on being asked by Prime Minister John Keys to support Peter Dunne."

Author: "Johns, Geraldine"
Title: "Anne Salmond interview"
description: "Interviews historian Anne Salmond about her biography of Captain William Bligh. Discusses his personality, his sailings in the South Pacific, and his reaction to the mutiny on the ship 'Bounty'. Reflects on the experience of teenagers going to sea some 200 years ago. Reveals the author's attraction to her subject."

Author: "Abict, Jaimee"
Title: "Kenya's Dadaab Camp - Tristan Clements interview"
description: "Interviews NZ aid worker Tristan Clements about co-ordinating relief at the Dadaab Camp, Kenya. Describes his work, the effect of the relief effort and how NZers can help."

Author: "Grant, Nick"
Title: "The Factory review"
description: "Reviews 'The factory', a musical written and directed by Vela Manusaute and Anapela Polataivao, and playing at the Mangere Arts Centre, Auckland, until 30 Sep 2011."

Author: "McGechan, Andy,"
Title: "Courtney puts lads in their place"
description: "Courtney puts lads in their place"

Author: "Blundell, Sally,"
Title: "Auckland Art Gallery reopens"
description: "Describes the redeveloped Auckland Art Gallery and previews its opening on 3 Sep 2011. Notes its new learning centre where visitors can explore the work of featured artists. Previews the release on 3 Sep of two books on NZ art."

Author: "Ralston, Bill"
Title: "The Rugby World Cup owes me"
description: "Estimates that various costs associated with the Rugby World Cup 2011 will keep taxpayers paying for the event for years to come. Lists spending costs from central and local government.  Provides a tongue-in-cheek description of sponsorship for the event. Describes the Living Legend project and other events associated with the games."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1951"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1951. Reports and comments on the waterfront strikes which began as a reaction to a proposal by employers to suspend all waterside workers who refused to work overtime (14 Feb - 11 Jun), the public disinterest in the Korean conflict [war] (which began on 25 Jun 1950) despite NZ involvement (25 Oct), and the farewell for Dunedin's Roslyn cable car line (27 Oct)."

Author: "Cunliffe, Simon"
Title: "Waiting for Godot returns to Dunedin's Globe Theatre"
description: "Reviews the production of 'Waiting for Godot', directed by Richard Huber and playing at the Dunedin Globe Theatre, 18-28 Aug 2011."

Author: "White, Margo"
Title: "What your hands say about your health"
description: "Explains the diagnostic clues that the palms and fingers can provide, listing some physical ailments and how they are expressed in this part of the body."

Author: "Palenski, Ron"
Title: "Webb Ellis 'admirable cricketer' but not the inventor of rugby"
description: "Looks into the myth that William Webb Ellis began the sport of rugby by picking up a football and running with it, which has been given a new lease on life with the introduction of the Rugby World Cup."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "Christchurch 12 months on"
description: "Reviews Christchurch one year after its 4 Sep 2010 earthquake.  Relates the upheaval experienced by former Avonside resident and leader of citizens' group CanCern Leanne Curtis, whose house was in the red zone. Calculates the financial losses facing many red-zoned house owners.  Looks at how Kaiapoi couple Tetumu Rolleston and Luana Belworthy and their seven children have fared after their house was destroyed.  Describes the state of the building industry in Christchurch, noting the effects of delays in construction.  Points out the wary response of the insurance industry. Informs of a controversial geotechnical report published in 1991 and headed by now chief executive of Solid Energy Don Elder that warned of Christchurch's earthquake and liquefaction risks."

Author: "Bowden, Jennifer"
Title: "Avoiding diverticulitis"
description: "Explains diverticulitis, describing how the bowel inflammation manifests and the best ways to prevent it."

Author: "Packer, Ann,"
Title: "Children and young adult books including Act of Faith and Resurrection review"
description: "Children and young adult books including Act of Faith and Resurrection review"

Author: "Cresswell, Lyell,"
Title: "A Search for Tradition by Douglas Lilburn review"
description: "A Search for Tradition by Douglas Lilburn review"

Author: "Priestley, Rebecca,"
Title: "So long, Happy Feet"
description: "Follows the journey of the penguin found at Peka Peka Beach, describing its rescue and care by penguin expert and Wellington Zoo manager of veterinary science Lisa Argilla and its popularity with the media and public. Provides information on the penguin breed. Anticipates Happy Feet's release in Aug 2011 from Niwa research vessel Tangaroa and its tracking for the next six months."

Author: "Lewis, John"
Title: "Breakdancing battle a bone breaker"
description: "Breakdancing battle a bone breaker"

Title: "Navy drinking issues in spotlight"
description: "Navy drinking issues in spotlight"

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1952"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1952. Records the death of King George Vl and the return to England as sovereign of Princess Elizabeth (7-8 Feb 1952). Covers the destruction by fire of two blocks of Dunedin buildings, including the Hayman Building, with an accompanying photo (29 Apr 1952). Reports on the explosion of a hydrogen bomb by the United States on a Pacific atoll in the Eniwetok group, including eye-witness accounts (10 Nov 1952). Touches on other events during the year."

Author: "Van Kempen, Lynda"
Title: "Firefighter died serving community"
description: "Eulogises the Central Otago firefighter who died on the way to attending a fire as a member of the Dunstan Rural Fire Brigade."

Author: "Pegden, Evan"
Title: "Bay open winner attributes win to her short game"
description: "Bay open winner attributes win to her short game"

Author: "Romanos, Amelia"
Title: "Old friends from way back meet up"
description: "Old friends from way back meet up"

Author: "Savage, Jared"
Title: "AUT tightens security after senior executive's fraud charges"
description: "AUT tightens security after senior executive's fraud charges"

Author: "Galloway, Jill"

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1953"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1953. Announces the coronation of Queen Elizabeth ll and subsequent celebrations (3 Jun 1953). Reports on calls to limit Sunday sport and entertainment by the conference of the Associated Churches of Christ, Lower Hutt, noting the reaction of Dunedin sporting groups to holding sports events on Sundays (8 Apr 1953). Confirms the death toll resulting from the plunging of the Wellington-Auckland express into the Whangaehu River after the Tangiwai railway bridge was swept away by water sweeping down from Mt Ruapehu (20 Dec 1953) [24 Dec 1953].  Celebrates the machine shearing record set by W. Godfrey Bowen, who shore 456 sheep in nine hours. Mentions other events during the year. Includes a photo of the wrecked Wellington-Auckland express."

description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1954. Delights at the reception given to Queen Elizabeth and the Duke of Edinburgh on their visit to Dunedin, and later in Milton and Balclutha (26 Jan 1954). Informs of the crash of a BOAC Comet Jet Airliner into the sea off the Italian island of Elba, noting the Comet's crash history (12 Jan 1954). Describes the diversion of the Clutha River through the Roxburgh hydroelectric project (3 Jun 1954). Touches on other events during the year."

description: "Talks to the principal of Papakura High School, which had the highest number of stand-downs over the past two-and-a-half years, about how the high numbers of students being caught with drugs is a result of strict enforcement strategies. Highlights the growing trend of drug incidents at primary and intermediate schools. Gives a brief explanation of hotboxing where students deliberately close all the windows of a classroom and smoke it out with cannabis smoke."

Author: "Nash, Kieran"
Title: "Waterfront woes and the $2 billion fix : Auckland's draft waterfront plan; New Wynyard Quarter a hit with families; Coast to coast : what's planned"
description: "Looks at the new draft waterfront plan and how people have six weeks to submit ideas, lobby or protest before submissions close on Oct 25, the same time as the end of the Rugby World Cup. Highlights some of the ideas in the draft plan and what sort of work would need to be done to achieve them. Talks to Warren Tuohey, who remains skeptical about the timing of the release of the plans, and city planner Ludo Campbell-Reid about his vision for Auckland's harbour edge. Reports on the success of Auckland's Wynyard Quarter. Outlines the various plans (including waterfronts) of Orakei, Devonport-Takapuna, Maungakiekie, Albert-Eden and Waiheke."

Title: "A royal pin-up for Key's big 5-0"
description: "A royal pin-up for Key's big 5-0"

Author: "Stone, Andrew"
Title: "Fallout from September 11 still drifting over us"
description: "Reports on the impact of the 9/11 Terrorist Attacks on NZ. Talks to Rosemary Lozowsky about her son John who died when American Airlines Flight 11 slammed into the World Trade Centre's North Tower, NZ Army soldier Major Cordwell about his deployments to Afghanistan, human rights advocate Tim McBride about the post-9/11 laws with human rights and privacy implications, NZ-based American Christina Crews about the attitude of NZers at the time of the attacks, a number of Muslim students about Islamophobia in NZ, and to lawyer Debra Manning about Ahmed Zaoui, her Algerian refugee client."

Title: "Whatever the news, residents say not knowing is worse"
description: "Focuses on the orange stickered Parklands and Queenspark suburbs awaiting Government decisions on properties there. Talks to residents Don Haggitt, Cecilia Murphy and Dion Murphy, and Fiona Macpherson about the state of their properties and how the waiting is affecting them."

description: "Reviews the 2007 Ruatoki Valley terror raid case. Suggests that the evidence against those arrested for terror activities ranges from the absurd to the terrifying."

Title: "Murder accused 'feared for life'"
description: "Murder accused 'feared for life'"

Title: "Dark side of a warrior culture"
description: "Writes about the Maori gang culture side of NZ that visitors for the Rugby World Cup are unlikely to see. Discusses the place of gangs in society and talks to different gang leaders about the changing ways of the Mongrel Mob and Black Power gangs. Mentions the discussion around the idea of the 'warrior gene' or the 'warrior ethos' suppposedly prevalent among Maori."

Author: "Hewitson, Michele"
Title: "Al Brown"
description: "Talks to the chef about his new Auckland eatery, his career, and being a 'celebrity' chef."

Title: "#*@k not again!"
description: "Notes how there is a chance of the All Blacks not winning this years Rugby World Cup. Reports on previous examples of NZ sports teams failing to come through and win tournaments. Includes the 1992 Cricket World Cup semifinal, the 1999 Netball World Championships final, the Highlanders in the 1999 Super 12 final, the 2003 America's Cup, and the 1988 League World Cup final."

Author: "McAllister, Janet"
Title: "Like a good exhibition, gallery itself challenges assumptions"
description: "Talks about the new Auckland Art Gallery."

Author: "Burgess, Michael"
Title: "Tutaia still haunted by final defeat"
description: "Tutaia still haunted by final defeat"

Author: "Van Beynen, Martin"
Title: "Death in the classroom"
description: "Visits Toyama, Japan, to talk to students and staff of the Toyama College of Foreign Languages about their experience of the 22 Feb 2011 earthquake which destroyed Christchurch's  CTV building in which they were attending English classes at King's Education language school. Talks to College deputy director Kuniaki Kawahata about reconciling the death of his daughter Kyoko Kawahata in the earthquake. Speaks with four Japanese survivors of the quake and a NZer language teacher. Records the experience of the parents while in Christchurch to recover their children's bodies. Remarks on the resilience of the students who have resumed their studies in Japan. Relays the experience of NZ firefighter Paul Rodwell who rescued Japanese students from the CTV building."

Author: "Luke, Peter"
Title: "Finding truth in shades of grey"
description: "Looks back on his 25 year career as senior editorial and political writer at The Press. Assesses the politicians he most respects."

Author: "McCrone, John"
Title: "Muddying the waters"
description: "Examines the Government's management of national water resources, focusing on the National Policy Statement (NPS) announced early 2011. Presents criticisms of the NPS by Massey freshwater ecologist Mike Joy, Green Party co-leader Russel Norman and others.  Touches on the perceived failure of the multi-level process that replaced the Resource Management Act (RMA). Sets out the views of Environment Minister Nick Smith, outlining how the multi-level system works and why he believes decisions are best made at regional level. Focuses on Canterbury which faces issues of both water extraction and nutrient leaching, describing on the progress made by the Hurunui-Waiau zone committee"

Author: "Reid, Graham,"
Title: "Heed children of night"
description: "Talks to curator Bronwyn Lloyd about the 'Lugosi's children' exhibition, which explores whether the melancholy found in NZ film, painting and music can also be found in the applied arts and crafts. Notes that the exhibition is on at Auckland's Objectspace until 1 Oct 2011."

Author: "Gaynor, Brian"
Title: "Rugby these days is a big-money game"
description: "Analyses the business aspect of the 2011 Rugby World Cup for NZ and the International Rugby Board (IRB)."

Author: "Hill, Rebecca Barry"

description: "Talks to the forensic scientist about her job, which she has written about in her new book."

Author: "Mackenzie, Dene"
Title: "Job creation seen in stadium"
description: "Talks to Ian Taylor, director of Animation Research Ltd., about the development of software that produces three-dimensional images of urban areas. Relates how surveying students at the University of Otago in a third year remote sensing technologies paper had undertaken a photogrammetry project that had help build a 3-D model of Dunedin city. Indicates the software could be used in sports analysis carried out within the Dunedin sports stadium (Forsyth Barr Stadium) to create employment for young people in Dunedin."

Author: "Cole, Charles"
Title: "Hear our voices, we entreat"
description: "Describes and rates each of the national anthems sung before matches in the Rugby World Cup 2011, commenting on their patriotic overtones."

Title: "Player with a sharp intellect for cricket"
description: "Player with a sharp intellect for cricket"

description: "Talks to University of Canterbury marketing lecturer Ekant Veer about his research into Facebook. Notes the three types of antisocial behaviour it encourages.  Touches on the reasons for the success of some business Facebook pages."

Title: "The path less travelled"
description: "Looks at the life of the late Allan Hubbard, who recently died in a car crash, focusing on his impoverished childhood, his motives for his extensive charitable giving, and the growth of his businesses including South Canterbury Finance (SCF). Notes the financial and management problems within SCF. Comments that Hubbard's controlling management style compounded the financial problems of SCF."

description: "Talks to German born Frank Nagel about his background in 'katenschinken' (making farmhouse-style dry-cured smallgoods), and his gourmet sausage making factory  in Te Aroha West. Touches on his move from Germany with NZ wife Sheryn Cook. Describes his gluten-free Frank's Sausages, noting the international flavours he produces and the outlets he supplies."

Tells the story of how David tracked down the artist, and of his experience of meeting her and her family. Notes he has returned to Italy to see the area where his father commanded troops in battle south of Florence, winning a Military Cross and American Silver Star for his efforts."

Author: "Black, Joanne"
Title: "In a hole"
description: "Reports that while parts of the Australian economy, such as the mining industry, are booming most other parts of the economy are suffering. Explains that because of the high rate of the Australian dollar, fuelled by the booming mining industry, the exporting, farming, tourism and related industries have slumped. Notes that, apart from a few industries, work is very hard to find for Australians and migrants. Talks to Australians and NZers in Australia about the effects of the partial economic slump, and the effects of the mining boom."

Title: "That sinking feeling; The pretenders"
description: "Reports that the very low polling of Phil Goff and Labour makes it extremely difficult for Labour to win or do well in the election when faced with the high popularity of John Key and National. Talks to Phil Goff about the difficulties facing Labour in the 2011 election, his campaign plan and media speculation on leadership challenges. Talks to political scientists about likely results for 2011, and what the public want to see in a leader and how this compares with Phil Goff's and John Key's personal style. Examines different approaches for a political party to regain office after election defeat. Gives the pros and cons of the politics and personalities of likely contenders for Labour leadership after the election; David Cunliffe, David Parker, Andrew Little, Shane Jones, David Shearer."

description: "Talks to managers of speed-dating services and speed-dating participants about the advantages of speed-dating, especially compared to the downsides of internet dating. Notes how speed-dating works and that there are speed-dating nights for niche participants such as sporty types, solo parents, Christians, seniors and the university educated. Reports that there can be problems matching enough men and women in the right age bracket."

Compares current social dysfunction such as the UK riots to the dark subject matter of Cross' books and relates Cross' views on social ills and the themes of his books. Title: "HART plan for first test"
description: "Reveals that the newspaper has sourced documents showing plans by members of the Halt All Racist Tours (HART) movement to stop the test against the South African Springbok rugby team in Christchurch on 15 Aug 1981. Documents the involvement in the tour protest of two members who went on to ministerial positions in the Labour Party. Informs of a body of work given to the National Library of New Zealand that includes written statements from NZers on both sides of the tour debate. Shows that many police officers working to contain the anti-tour protests were themselves opposed to the tour.  Talks to Wellingtonian Dan O'Dea and Aucklander David Howard about their reasons for attending test matches."

Title: "Home truths on kids and booze"
description: "Reports on a UK study that gauges the effect of 'tough love' parenting on children's use of alcohol. Presents statistics on the alcohol-related deaths of NZ youth between 2005-2007. Talks to National Addiction Centre director Professor Doug Sellman about an Australasian study that underscores the positive effect on youth of parent's behaviour rather than their verbal advice. Laments the placing of alcohol in supermarkets. Reveals how he approached the issue of alcohol with his own sons."

Title: "View from the top"
description: "Interviews Prime Minister John Key. Discusses his way of speaking, his early ambition, and his first term as prime minister.  Looks at what he has learnt from his role, his aversion to appearing coldhearted, and why NZ still seems to support  him. Gives answers to some trivial questions about wine, clothes purchases, Prince William, among other topics."

Author: "Kilgallon, Steve"
Title: "A force for good"
description: "Speaks for three hours with the social worker and boxing champion who runs the Naenae Boxing Academy and keeps youngsters away from crime. Uncovers who is heroes are. Covers the story of his life so far, and conveys his own philosophy that 'life is just a story'. Also talks to his son, David Graham, and fellow coach Grant Quinn."

Author: "Pegden, Evan"
Title: "Kahui keen to grab his spot against Boks"
description: "Kahui keen to grab his spot against Boks"

Author: "Price, Mark"
Title: "Talking a good game; Armchair sportsmen, arise!"
description: "Focuses on the television broadcasting teams who will be commentating on the 2011 Rugby World Cup. Speaks to veteran rugby broadcaster Keith Quinn and to Sky television's host broadcast project director Kevin Cameron about what makes a smooth commentary. Talks about the findings of a paper published in the 'Journal of sports science and medicine' that analysed the statistics generated in test and Super 12 matches to find out what makes one rugby team better than another. Presents the results of an 'Otago daily times' poll of rugby fans about the most preferred commentator for the Rugby World Cup final. Talks to Professor Bob Hancox of the Dunedin School of Medicine about whether watching the 64 games of the 2011 Rugby World Cup will lead to television viewers becoming greater participants in sport."

Author: "Murray, Sarah"
Title: "Losing our religion?"
description: "Visits Rugby World Cup 2011 fan Luke Herlihy to see the 25 seat grandstand he built in the garage of his Auckland flat. Talks to non-fan Wellingtonian Chris Wilson about his personal experience of rugby related violence and the music festivals he has organised to provide alternative cultural activities. Speaks to Yugoslavian born Nele Nikovic about the underfunding of sports other than rugby. Also talks to a fan who quit his job to follow the Russian rugby team on tour (James Walsh), and a young super fan who would like to be a sports commentator (Jack Sandelin)."

Author: "Kilgallon, Steve"
Title: "Stick it to 'em"
description: "Talks to the advertising worker about his fourth 'Stickmen' comic strip book. Chats about his other ventures on the Auckland music channel Max TV and stints on mainstream television and radio. Mentions well known advertising ideas he dreamed up."

Title: "Waikato piano student on way to noted contest"
description: "Waikato piano student on way to noted contest"

Touches on the cause and symptoms of scarlet fever. Notes that the 'historic place' listing does not legally protect the property."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1956"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1956. Reports and comments on the formation of the new lake behind the Roxburgh dam (21 Jul), the start of anti-polio-myelitis vaccinations in Dunedin (25 Sep), the arrival of the American destroyer escort U.S.S. 'Borough' in Dunedin (4 Oct), the flight of four United States Navy Operation 'Deepfreeze' Dakota aircraft from Taieri to McMurdo Sound in Antarctica (18 Oct), and the farewell of the NZ Antarctic expedition, led by Sir Edmund Hillary, as it sailed from Bluff (22 Dec)."

Reports and comments on the arrival of Sir Edmund Hillary's NZ Antarctic party at the South Pole (4 Jan), Dunedin's welcome to Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother (12 Feb), building of a new temporary earth dam across the outlet of Lake Hawea, which marked at important step in the construction of the large lake dam designed to store water for the Roxburgh generators (25 Mar), and Hon A. H. Nordmeyer's delivery of the 'worst ever Budget' (27 Jun). Touches on the start of P.A.Y.E. taxation (29 Mar), six persons in NZ having returnable incomes of more than ¬£50,000 in the year 1954-55 (2 Apr), the discontinuation of compulsory military training after 31 Mar 1959 (28 Jun), and the skating season in Central Otago being underway, with an official frost reading at the Ophir weather station of 28.8deg (4 Jul)."

Title: "Fighting a losing battle against the national bulge"
description: "Talks to Robyn Toomath, anti-obesity campaigner, senior doctor and reviews her work over the last ten years. Comments on the few programmes that have been implemented to control obesity and the government's response. Discusses the issue of personal responsibility versus genetic predisposition with regard to the cause of obesity. Notes comments from columnists about Robyn Toothmath's strategies. Includes her views on hospital management and impending move up to Auckland to a new job."

Praises the creations of former Dunedin designer Toni Darling, who is now living in Melbourne. Lists tricks for wearing trousers."

Author: "MacIntyre, Dave"
Title: "Burning it up on the motorways"
description: "Reports on the Government's committment to infrastructure spending with its focus on land transport over rail and coastal shipping options. Discusses the Government Policy Statement on Land Transport Funding (GPS), which sets out the Government's priorities for expenditure over the next ten years. Looks at the key building block of the GPS initiatives, the seven Roads of National Significance (RONS). Highlights the views of the Labour Party, the Maritime Union and the NZ Shipping Federation. Lists the seven RONS."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1959"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1959.  Reports on a dramatic rescue of all six survivors of two air crashes in the Lammerlaw Mountains (13 Jul). Describes a 9 Dec fire that destroyed the Arthur Barnett department store, Dunedin (10 Dec), and includes a photograph and a list of major fires in Dunedin between 1940 and 1955. Reports that the Railways Department is refusing to install electricity at the small town at Tahakopa (28 Mar). Touches on other events during the year."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1960"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1960.  Reports on a revolt by more than 200 inmates at Auckland Prison (12 Apr). Details developments in the crisis between the US and the Soviet Union after the US U-2 aircraft was shot down over the Soviet Union on 1 May (11 May edition). Touches on the victories by runners Peter Snell and Murray Halberg at the 1960 Rome Olympics (3 Sep), and includes a photograph of Peter Snell crossing the finish line in the 800 metre race. Celebrates the opening of the Haast road linking the isolated South Westland township with Otago (14 Nov)."

Title: "From pro sports to opera singer"
description: "Talks to the NZ-born bass-baritone with Opera Australia, who will be performing in two concerts in Ranfurly and Dunedin on 16 and 22 Sep, respectively. Mentions his previous career as a professional sportsman."

Title: "Art seen"

Reviews 'Heaven and Eart : Goldheart ritual womb'  by James Robinson, Glue Gallery, Dunedin, until 2 Oct 2011.  Reviews 'Grieving over a dead fish : Secret men's business'  by Hannah Joynt, Temple Gallery, Dunedin."

Author: "McCrone, John"
Title: "All aboard"
description: "Presents statistics on world population forecasts for the end of Oct 2011. Backgrounds population growth on the planet. Tracks how populations change, looking at the trends in the US, China, India and Russia. Informs that NZ's population grows by one person every 14 minutes. Looks at correlations of demographics and war. Talks to Lincoln University ecologist Steve Wratten about the earth being beyond its carrying capacity, the damage done by agrichemicals, and the need to practise agroecology. Notes international moves to buy up resources in Africa.  Considers the effect of urban drift. Highlights the exponential effect of knowledge transfer to developing countries, citing the impact of new technologies such as those developed by Sir Ray Avery and Medicine Mondiale."

Author: "Matthews, Philip"
Title: "Wellsprings of memory"
description: "Reports on 'The city as memory', and 'Imagined futures' panel discussions held in Christchurch under the auspices of the Scape public art biennial and Christchurch Arts Festival. Notes the poignancy of the discussion topics given the earthquake damage sustained on 22 Feb 2011. Summarises the views of the panellists art historian Jonathan Mane-Wheoki (on pre-earthquake Christchurch); landscape architect Di Lucas (on pre-human Canterbury); artist Anton Parsons, architect William Fulton (on the city's architectural influences); and Lyttelton sound artist and academic Bruce Russell (on social history and preserving ruins). Also presents the observations of landscape architect William Field (on public artworks created for Scape); Melbourne artist Ash Keating (on his installation Gardensity); Christchurch City Council urban design advisor Hugh Nicholson (on urban design); Auckland architectural critic and lecturer Bill McKay (about the pace of rebuilding); and Australian writer Simon Sellars (about urban renewal)."

Title: "Nightmare on the RWC express"
description: "Speaks to a number of people who took the train to the 2011 Rugby World Cup opening celebrations at the Viaduct and the opening ceremony and game at Eden Park about their experiences of the 'horrifying' night where trains became extremely overcrowded, stopping before the scheduled stations or unable to leave. Provides a breakdown of the various incidents and the times they occurred."

Author: "Forbes, Michael"
Title: "In search of farming with clean waterways"
description: "Asserts a middle ground must be found between environment and industry before scientific innovation and policy can be developed towards keeping NZs waterways clean. Notes the 15th instalment of the International Water Association's Diffuse Pollution Specialist conference in Rotorua next week will discuss developments for controlling diffuse pollution, the type that runs off land into waterways, rather than entering directly from discharge points. Comments on the importance of wetland in agricultural landscapes and outlines the innovation occurring in the management of wetlands."

Title: "Killer's mother blames system failings"

Title: "Bacon and eggs and the Great Escape : a life story"

Title: "Chip 'n' dip a nostalgia trip"
description: "Analyses the ingredients of NestleÃÅ's 'reduce cream' and Maggi's 'onion soup mix', which are used to make the traditional NZ onion dip for potato chips."
