Author: "Plumb, Simon"
Title: "Drug bombshell hits elite sport : Crown agency Sparc faces serious questions over a banned substance; Sports academy lets banned substance in"
description: "Looks at the repercussions in NZ of the International Olympic Committee confirming a banned drug (the amphetamine, octopamine) is included in a product (Red8 Thermotone) that has been provided to elite Kiwi athletes via the NZ Academy of Sport's official sports supplements programme. Highlights the report by Wellington barrister Tim Castle that cleared the supplement Thermotone and the verification by the manufacturer, Integria Healthcare, that there is nothing in their product that could result in a positive dope test. Talks to David Howman of the World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA) who says how the latest revelation creates "very serious problems". Suggests that pressure is mounting on the Minister of Sport, Murray McCully, to take appropriate action."

Title: "Going, going, gone ..."
description: "Displays visual scenes of central Christchurch, showing the buildings that have been demolished or are slated to be pulled down."

Author: "Chug, Kiran"
Title: "Smash safety; Triple threat : alcohol, speed, fatigue"
description: "Reveals for the Wellington region details of a five year analysis by the NZ Transport Agency of where crashes are happening and why. Documents those involved, pedestrians, motor-cyclists, cyclists, motorist and the seriousness of the accidents and the injuries sustained. Highlights the high danger spots throughout Wellington for various road users."

Author: "Stone, Andrew"
Title: "Affair of state"
description: "Talks to the speechwriter who become David Lange's second wife about her new book 'At the turning point : my political life with David Lange'."

Author: "Leggat, David"
Title: "Carrington leaves world's best paddlers in wake : Kiwi's stunning performance no surprise to those who know her best"
description: "Carrington leaves world's best paddlers in wake : Kiwi's stunning performance no surprise to those who know her best"

Author: "Hewitson, Michele"
Title: "Jesse Peach"
description: "Talks to the TV reporter and theatre director, who started the Peach Theatre Company, about his work."

Author: "Crean, Mike"
Title: "A soldier's bravery now in print"
description: "Reports on the launch in Christchurch of the English version of  'To the gateways of Florence: New Zealand forces in Tuscany 1944'. Notes the contribution by Dianne Harris who wrote the story of her father's experience in Tuscany. Acknowledges the work of the book's editors, Stefano Fusi and his NZ wife Jill Gabriel, who researched the long forgotten role that New Zealand soldiers played in Tuscany. Recounts the launch of the book's Italian version in Casciano in 2009 and the emotional reception given to NZ veterans Jack Cummins, Doug Leckie, and MaÃÑori Battalion historian Monty Soutar."

Author: "Bond, Sarah"
Title: "Drawing on experiences"
description: "Chats to the award-winning book illustrator and author about the twists and turns of his career. Discusses the influences and mentors who steered him towards art and drawing. Focuses on the impact of stints working at McMurdo Sound, Antarctica, and at Edinburgh Zoo. Reveals the subject of his first published illustration."

Author: "Kilgallon, Steve"
Title: "Marathon effort on road to rehab"
description: "Talks to Onehunga gas main blast victim Ian Winson about his slow recovery from his injuries."

Author: "Kilgallon, Steve"
Title: "Ancient process gives Originals leader pride of place"
description: "Ancient process gives Originals leader pride of place"

Author: "Crean, Mike"
Title: "Air force man had a love of engineering"
description: "Air force man had a love of engineering"

Title: "V8 racer steps up to help arthritis appeal"
description: "V8 racer steps up to help arthritis appeal"

Author: "Hinton, Marc"
Title: "JK's greatest try"
description: "Talks to the ex-All Black and current Japan coach about his 80-metre try in the opening game of the 1987 Rugby World Cup against Italy and the impact it had on the tournament."

Author: "Venter, Nick"
Title: "Former MP looks back, and shakes his head"
description: "Chronicles the downward trend of Mark Peck's political career. Notes his ownership of a cafe 'Little Peckish' In Wellington's Duke's Arcade and comments on the effect of legislation and regulations from both central and local government have on small businesses. Mentions Labour's policy to exclude GST from fruit and vegetables."

Author: "Woulfe, Catherine"
Title: "Traveller"
description: "Talks to Phil Coker who runs the bouncy castle and shooting gallery for the NZ Gypsy Travellers, lives in a house bus, and travels the North Island."

Author: "Murray, Sarah"
Title: "You are here"
description: "Examines the concept of 'checking in' where Facebook users can find out exactly where friends are, at what time and who with, all with the aid of a mobile phone. Talks to Kobus Retief, Zeisha Fremaux, Macala Campbell and Hayden Raw about their reasons for using the smartphone application."

Author: "Gifford, Adam"
Title: "Seen in a foreign light"
description: "Reports on the exhibition 'From Prague to Auckland : the photographs of Frank Hofmann (1916-89)', which celebrates the work of the photographer who fled Czechoslovakia ahead of the Nazi invasion. Notes that the exhibition is on at Auckland's Gus Fisher Gallery to 29 Oct 2011."

Author: "Corry, Lucy"
Title: "Striking oil"
description: "Describes the experience of Mancunians Helen Meehan and John Meehan, who bought into the established olive business 'Olivo', having come from an information and communication technology and accounting background. Indicates two thirds of their Martinborough grove is planted in Barnea, an Israeli variety. Mentions they are experimenting with infused oils and notes NZ cannot compete on a volume basis, hence the emphasis on quality."

Author: "Crean, Mike"
Title: "Climber from 1953 Everest expedition"
description: "Climber from 1953 Everest expedition"

Author: "Shiels, Rosa"
Title: "Staying put"
description: "Talks to immigrants who have settled in Christchurch about whether the recent earthquakes have shaken their resolve to stay in New Zealand. Talks to Britons Rachel Wiscombe and Joe Wiscombe; French brothers and chefs Frederic Berhault, Vincent Berhault and Benjamin Berhault; Americans Kris Woods and Jim Woods; Netherlander Anneke Vollebregt and Brazilian Mikael Ekman; and Britons Maria Romero and Nick Blackburn."

Author: "Anderson, Vicki"
Title: "Sunday afternoon fever"
description: "Introduces the American phenomenon of discos for children and their parents. Talks to the organiser of a 'Baby loves disco' event in Christchurch, Michelle Bush, about what services are provided at these events."

Author: "Barton, Chris"
Title: "Lend me your ears"
description: "Reports on the future of Radio NZ (RNZ), which is the only commercial-free broadcaster in the country. Speaks to RNZ chief executive Peter Cavanagh about the proposal by South Pacific Pictures head John Barnett for RNZ to move into the role of public service television broadcaster. Talks about how RNZ operates under a continued funding freeze."

Author: "Dekker, Diana"
Title: "Looking on the bright side"
description: "Talks to the television producer, singer and songwriter who is singing the national anthem in MaÃÑori at the 2011 Rugby World Cup tournament, as she did in 1999 in Twickenham. Discusses her double mastectomy which she views as an opportunity. Informs of the opening of the Raukatauri Music Therapy Centre in Auckland, set up with her husband George Bradfield to help disabled children like their daughter, Hineraukatauri."

Author: "Ogden, Tristan"
Title: "Grassroots rugby"
description: "Visits Ponsonby RFC, Northcote Birkenhead RFC and the 'Rural rugby exhibition' at the Kauri Museum in Matakohe to discover what gives heartland rugby its heart. Lists some rugby related exhibitions and festivals on in the Auckland region during the 2011 Rugby World Cup."

Author: "Grieve, Duncan"
Title: "Rap's last taboo"
description: "Looks at the Hip Hop industry's attitude to homosexuality. Highlights some musicians who seem to uphold the prevailing culture of homophobia. Talks to Otara MC Pope Bron$ (aka Bronson Sagisagi), an openly gay gangsta rapper, about his journey to rapping and coming out to family and friends."

Author: "Croot, James"
Title: "City untouched in 'laying on of hands' tale"
description: "Reviews the film directed by Patrick Gillies and filmed in pre-earthquake Christchurch."

Author: "Urlich, Peter"
Title: "Sailor rocked our boat"
description: "Pays tribute to the band at its induction into the NZ Music Hall of Fame."

Author: "Dekker, Diana"
Title: "Looking on the bright side"
description: "Talks to Hinewehi Mohi about her singing the national anthem only in MaÃÑori at a Rugby World Cup game in Twickenham just over a decade ago, along with her recent diagnosis with breast cancer. Discusses her daughter's cerebral palsy and observes how on a visit to London she recognised the therapeutic value of music and subsequently she set up, along with her husband, George Bradfield, Raukatauri Music Therapy centre in Auckland for people who suffer from cerebral palsy and other developmentally disabled children."

Author: "Corry, Lucy"
Title: "Striking oil"
description: "Describes the experience of Mancunians Helen Meehan and John Meehan, who bought into the established olive business 'Olivo', having come from an information and communication technology and accounting background. Indicates two thirds of their Martinborough grove is planted in Barnea, an Israeli variety. Mentions they are experimenting with infused oils and notes NZ cannot compete on a volume basis, hence the emphasis on quality."

Author: "Dungey, Kim"
Title: "Side by side through the years"
description: "Visits Belgrave Crescent, in the Dunedin suburb of Roslyn.  Talks to the current and former owners of three adjacent villas that were built in 1910. Describes modifications made to the homes over the years, and touches on the history of each home and names their original owners. Informs that Belgrave Crescent was known as Victoria Crescent until 1915."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1961"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1961. Reports on the inaugural club meeting at Forbury Park (27 Jan).  Announces that the government and representatives of Consolidated Zinc Pty Ltd have negotiated major safeguards to protect the scenic beauty of Lakes Manapouri and Te Anau (26 Apr ). Reports that 10 members of the government crossed the floor of the House of Representatives to vote for an amendment to the Crimes Bill that abolished the death penalty (14 Oct). Mentions the sale of two prize-winning novels in the Otago Daily Times Centennial Novel Contest (14 Nov). Touches on other events during the year. Includes a photograph of crowds gathered to greet the first 'HMNZS Otago' to visit Dunedin, 19 Jan 1961."

Author: "Catherall, Sarah"
Title: "Renewed spaces"
description: "Showcases the work of expatriate architect William Tozer whose architectural firm is exhibiting its renovation of a semi-detached house in the event Open House London. Discusses the work Tozer has done since moving to London in the late 1990s. Notes his recent move to Minneapolis. Briefly outlines his career, including his being shortlisted as the Young Architect of the Year in London in 2006."

Author: "Matthews, Philip"
Title: "A kick up the backside"
description: "Reviews the new novel by Ian Wedde. Announces that the National Library has chosen Wedde as NZ Poet Laureate. Talks to him about the role of poetry in different societies. Touches on his blog to which he has already posted a poem."

Author: "Pope, Margaret"
Title: "A lonely time for Lange"
description: "Extract from Margaret Pope's book 'At the turning point'."

Author: "Hartevelt, John"
Title: "Perfectly pitched for political junkies"
description: "Perfectly pitched for political junkies"

Author: "Hill, Rebecca Barry"
Title: "It's a family affair"
description: "Talks to Neil and Sharon Finn about their band Pajama Club, which evolved from some late-night, time-filling jam sessions when their children left home."

Author: "McFadden, Suzanne"
Title: "Sick, and tired of it"
description: "Focuses on extreme morning sickness (hyperemesis gravidarum), which causes unrelenting vomiting that can result in hospitalisation for dehydration. Speaks to television host Sara Tetro and Auckland woman Bex Lipp about their experiences of the mystery disease that has no cure or little help to ease the symptoms."

Author: "Rothwell, Kimberley"
Title: "Home and away"
description: "Mentions towns and cities that share the same name, Wellington. Locates some of the twenty-one towns, villages and cities called Wellington around the world. Gives some historical background to some in England, Canada, U.S.A., South Africa and Australia."

Author: "Perrott, Alan"
Title: "Walk on boy"
description: "Relates the experience of walking to and from work in the city."

Author: "Catherall, Sarah"
Title: "Renewed spaces"
description: "Showcases the work of expatriate architect William Tozer whose architectural firm is exhibiting its renovation of a semi-detached house in the event Open House London. Discusses the work Tozer has done since moving to London in the late 1990s. Notes his recent move to Minneapolis. Briefly outlines his career, including his being shortlisted as the Young Architect of the Year in London in 2006."

Author: "Jewell, Stephen"
Title: "A full head of steampunk"
description: "Talks to the science fiction writer about why she moved to the United States and her work including 'Phoenix rising', which fits into the steampunk sci-fi sub-genre."

Author: "Kidd, Rob"
Title: "Tributes fly after radio veteran dies surfing"
description: "Tributes fly after radio veteran dies surfing"

Title: "Secrecy surrounds dead soldier's arrival in NZ"
description: "Secrecy surrounds dead soldier's arrival in NZ"

Author: "Williamson, Cameron"
Title: "Drifting on Deadmans Track"
description: "Relates the author's experience of a 400 metre alpine climb up Deadmans Track in the Whanahuia Range finally reaching Rangi Hut. Reveals a disused ski field used in the 1940's and describes the panoramic views of Hawke's Bay to the east and the volcanic plateau on the other with Ruapehu, Tongariro and Ngauruhoe in view."

Author: "Stack, Greg"
Title: "Awards to recognise brave actions on river"
description: "Awards to recognise brave actions on river"

Author: "Matthews, Philip"
Title: "A kick up the backside"
description: "Reviews the new novel by Ian Wedde. Announces that the National Library has chosen Wedde as NZ Poet Laureate. Talks to him about the role of poetry in different societies. Touches on his blog to which he has already posted a poem."

Author: "Taylor, Cliff"
Title: "Metro v macho"
description: "Observes the increasing attention to personal grooming in men, citing the example of body treatments now used by many All Blacks. Explains the term 'metrosexual'.  Touches on changing definitions of masculinity. Confirms with a beauty therapist the popularity of hair removal. Links the rise of metrosexuality with brands and marketing. Presents the opposing views of a model and a comedian on the debate about male beautification. Solicits the views of women on male grooming. Talks to Auckland hairdresser Kurt Counsell about his beauty regimen."

Author: "Edens, John"
Title: "Wife's successful jump, but husband clueless"
description: "Wife's successful jump, but husband clueless"

Author: "Risk, Louise"
Title: "Another mountain to climb and tick off the list"
description: "Another mountain to climb and tick off the list"

Title: "Cancer society spreads floral sunshine; Meet Waikato's daffodil man"
description: "Cancer society spreads floral sunshine; Meet Waikato's daffodil man"

Author: "Anderson, Ian"
Title: "Browne hangs up international boots"
description: "Browne hangs up international boots"

Author: "Webster, Sally"
Title: "Heart care - panacea or placebo?"
description: "Reports on the use of enhanced external counter pulsation (EECP). Lists the benefits that are claimed for the health treatment. Registers the curiosity of New Zealand Medical Association chairman Paul Ockleford who has not heard of the treatment. Talks to Primary Heart Care director Will Hinchcliff about his attempts to have the treatment recognised by NZ health boards and insurers. Notes the treatment costs, and its endorsement by prominent NZers such as Ray Columbus and Tana Umaga."

Author: "Clement, Diana"
Title: "Paws and claws"
description: "Features Auckland owners of unusual pets, talking to Brian Lawton about his Creatures Unlimited business that sources animals for advertising and movie industries. Checks out his bearded dragon, Bruce, as well as a gate-jumping lamb and a pet magpie. Touches on Auckland City Council rules on allowable animals."

Author: "Hurley, Bevan"
Title: "In the running"
description: "Describes how he overcame a less than healthy lifestyle to compete in the London marathon in 2009. Anticipates his entry in the Auckland Marathon on 30 Oct 2011. Gives tips on nutrition, motivation, and training runs. Lists future running events to aim for."

Author: "Chug, Kiran"
Title: "Campaign has widening appeal"
description: "Highlights the change of focus of this year's Department of Conservation's Conservation Week from involving school children planting trees around the country to involving the wider community and businesses. Encourages participation in planting programmes that go beyong Conservation Week and involves clearing, weeding, collecting and growing seedlings and keeping nurseries over many years. Mentions 'living legends' from the rugby world have lent their support to the programme and includes a list of conservation events in the lower North Island."

Author: "Cropp, Amanda,"
Title: "Speed dating beats the internet every time"
description: "Talks to managers of speed-dating services and speed-dating participants about the advantages of speed-dating, especially compared to the downsides of internet dating. Notes how speed-dating works and that there are speed-dating nights for niche participants such as sporty types, solo parents, Christians, seniors and the university educated. Reports that there can be problems matching enough men and women in the right age bracket."

Author: "Romanos, Joseph"
Title: "Broadcaster loved life, sport and radio"
description: "Broadcaster loved life, sport and radio"

Author: "Grant, Nick"
Title: "The end of the golden weather by Bruce Mason"
description: "Reviews The End of the golden weather by Bruce Mason, directed by Murray Lynch, performed by the Auckland Theatre Company, Maidment Theatre Auckland until 24 Sep."

Author: "Donoghue, Tim"
Title: "A loyal friend and great entertainer"
description: "A loyal friend and great entertainer"

Author: "Black, Joanne"
Title: "Australia's two-speed Australian economy"
description: "Reports that while parts of the Australian economy, such as the mining industry, are booming most other parts of the economy are suffering. Explains that because of the high rate of the Australian dollar, fuelled by the booming mining industry, the exporting, farming, tourism and related industries have slumped. Notes that, apart from a few industries, work is very hard to find for Australians and migrants. Talks to Australians and NZers in Australia about the effects of the partial economic slump, and the effects of the mining boom."

Author: "Wichtel, Diana"
Title: "Neil Cross interview"
description: "Talks to Neil Cross, writer of bleak crime fiction featuring dark characters, such as his latest novel Luther : the calling, which has been turned into a TV series by the BBC. Compares current social dysfunction such as the UK riots to the dark subject matter of Cross' books and relates Cross' views on social ills and the themes of his books. Notes the author's dysfunctional upbringing which he wrote a book about."

Author: "Kitchin, Peter"
Title: "Friendly farmer's son helped forge NZ's economic ties with Asia"
description: "Friendly farmer's son helped forge NZ's economic ties with Asia"

Author: "Alley, Elizabeth"
Title: "Sarah Thornhill by Kate Grenville : review"
description: "Sarah Thornhill by Kate Grenville : review"

Author: "O'Brien, Louise"
Title: "The Circus of ghosts by Barbara Ewing : review"
description: "The Circus of ghosts by Barbara Ewing : review"

Author: "Laugesen, Ruth"
Title: "Keeping Labour afloat"
description: "Reports that the very low polling of Phil Goff and Labour makes it extremely difficult for Labour to win or do well in the election when faced with the high popularity of John Key and National. Talks to Phil Goff about the difficulties facing Labour in the 2011 election, his campaign plan and media speculation on leadership challenges. Talks to political scientists about likely results for 2011, and what the public want to see in a leader and how this compares with Phil Goff's and John Key's personal style. Examines different approaches for a political party to regain office after election defeat. Gives the pros and cons of the politics and personalities of likely contenders for Labour leadership after the election; David Cunliffe, David Parker, Andrew Little, Shane Jones, David Shearer."

Author: "Sandys, Elspeth"
Title: "Slouching towards Bethlehem by Dean Parker : review"
description: "Reviews Slouching towards Bethlehem by Dean Parker, produced by the Bacchanals, Bats Theatre Wellington, 31 Aug-10 Sep."

Author: "Van Beynen, Martin"
Title: "Lessons in grief; The 'worst day' for students' families"
description: "Visits Toyama, Japan, to talk to students and staff of the Toyama College of Foreign Languages about their experience of the 22 Feb 2011 earthquake which destroyed Christchurch's  CTV building in which they were attending English classes at King's Education language school. Talks to College deputy director Kuniaki Kawahata about reconciling the death of his daughter Kyoko Kawahata in the earthquake. Speaks with four Japanese survivors of the quake and a NZer language teacher. Records the experience of the parents while in Christchurch to recover their children's bodies. Remarks on the resilience of the students who have resumed their studies in Japan. Relays the experience of NZ firefighter Paul Rodwell who rescued Japanese students from the CTV building."

Author: "Reid, Nicholas,"
Title: "Hush now, don't cry by Bob Ellis : review"
description: "Hush now, don't cry by Bob Ellis : review"

Author: "Macdonald, Nikki"
Title: "Assyrians proud of history of struggle"
description: "Profiles the Assyrian community in Wellington after one of their community, Eman Jani Hurmiz, was murdered. Backgrounds the life of Assyrian church priest, Father Aprem Pithyou and Kiwi Cabs company director, Kamal Brikha prior to their coming to NZ. Notes Assyrians do not have a country to call their own and many have been persecuted and have fled war zones. Talks to NZ documentary maker, Newtown librarian, Helen Donnelly, who has made a documentary about Assyrian culture and talks to other Assyrians about what it means to be Assyrian."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "Nothing succeeds like failure"
description: "Discusses the strategy of intelligent failure, the business theory that success requires failure and learning from failure. Talks to Icehouse chief executive Andrew Hamilton about learning from failure, and to British economist Tim Harford about how smart organisations can speed up experimentation and lower the costs of failures, encouraging learning, the pitfalls preventing people from dealing with failure constructively, and examples from overseas of people successfully learning from failures. Contrasts the unadaptable Soviet system with capitalist companies such as Google and Whole Foods Market, and looks at complex, tightly coupled systems which are unable to contain failures. Talks to Grant Ryan, inventor of the YikeBike, about how the light-weight portable electric bicycle was developed, and how he has many ideas, most of which he assumes will fail."

Author: "Black, Joanne"
Title: "The strategy of intelligent failure"
description: "Discusses the strategy of intelligent failure, the business theory that success requires failure and learning from failure. Talks to Icehouse chief executive Andrew Hamilton about learning from failure, and to British economist Tim Harford about how smart organisations can speed up experimentation and lower the costs of failures, encouraging learning, the pitfalls preventing people from dealing with failure constructively, and examples from overseas of people successfully learning from failures. Contrasts the unadaptable Soviet system with capitalist companies such as Google and Whole Foods Market, and looks at complex, tightly coupled systems which are unable to contain failures. Talks to Grant Ryan, inventor of the YikeBike, about how the light-weight portable electric bicycle was developed, and how he has many ideas, most of which he assumes will fail."

Author: "Thomas, Paul"
Title: "Forged in adversity"
description: "Discusses public failure on the sports field. Mentions that sports, by their nature, involve defeat in front of an audience and looks at how this goes with success, examining the career of golfer Greg Masters and how the All Blacks turned a 2008 defeat to the Wallabies into winning a rematch. Considers the Rugby World Cup, pointing out that the All Blacks face unique public pressure to win the tournament and anything less will be seen as failure. Looks at the rugby-playing culture of the All Blacks that may inhibit changing their game."

Author: "Black, Joanne"
Title: "Out of the shadows"
description: "Talks to Margaret Pope, second wife of David Lange, and accused of helping bring down the Fourth Labour Government under Lange from 1987. Notes her replies to criticisms by Michael Basset. Recaps the political history of the Lange Government, looking at the account given in Pope's new memoir on the subject. Describes how the affair between Pope and Lange was conducted, the conflict between Lange and Minister of Finance Roger Douglas, and the undermining of Lange's leadership by Basset, Douglas and Douglas's press secretary Bevan Burgess. Relates Lange and Pope's life together following his resignation."

Author: "Black, Joanne"
Title: "Margaret Pope answers back"
description: "Talks to Margaret Pope, second wife of David Lange, and accused of helping bring down the Fourth Labour Government under Lange from 1987. Notes her replies to criticisms by Michael Basset. Recaps the political history of the Lange Government, looking at the account given in Pope's new memoir on the subject. Describes how the affair between Pope and Lange was conducted, the conflict between Lange and Minister of Finance Roger Douglas, and the undermining of Lange's leadership by Basset, Douglas and Douglas's press secretary Bevan Burgess. Relates Lange and Pope's life together following his resignation."

Author: "Laugesen, Ruth"
Title: "Charge of the emissions brigade"
description: "Looks at moves by the European Union to introduce charges for carbon emissions by airline travellers entering the EU, and protests and challenges from outside Europe. Comments on the reasons behind the EU policy, moves by China for exemption, and the possible impact on Air New Zealand charges. Appraises recent stalemating in climate change politics, describing stalling on implementing the Kyoto Protocol by developing nations and by the US, and relating comment by the EU Commissioner for Climate Action Connie Hedegaard on the need for countries outside the EU to commit and on the observed progress of climate changes. Examines recent findings on Arctic sea-ice loss."

Author: "Laugesen, Ruth"
Title: "Paying for airline carbon emissions"
description: "Looks at moves by the European Union to introduce charges for carbon emissions by airline travellers entering the EU, and protests and challenges from outside Europe. Comments on the reasons behind the EU policy, moves by China for exemption, and the possible impact on Air New Zealand charges. Appraises recent stalemating in climate change politics, describing stalling on implementing the Kyoto Protocol by developing nations and by the US, and relating comment by the EU Commissioner for Climate Action Connie Hedegaard on the need for countries outside the EU to commit and on the observed progress of climate changes. Examines recent findings on Arctic sea-ice loss."

Author: "Wade, Amelia"
Title: "Young mum 'shattered' over toddler son's death"
description: "Young mum 'shattered' over toddler son's death"

Author: "Milne, Jonathan"
Title: "Skirting the issues"
description: "Examines the 2011 general election contest for the Auckland Central seat between Nicola Laura Kaye (Nikki Kaye, National, 31) and Jacinda Kate Laurell Ardern (Labour, 31), dubbed 'The Battle of the Babes'. Notes a renewed interest by young people in the seat with both major parties fielding young women as candidates, and backgrounds the political careers and rivalry between Kaye and Ardern. Portrays Ardern out campaigning, with comments by party leader Phil Goff on why she was selected to run for Auckland Central. Portrays Kaye at work as the current MP for Auckland Central, with her comments on the pressure of the job. Gives comment by the pair on the media reaction to their contest."

Author: "Milne, Jonathan"
Title: "Nicola Laura Kaye vs Jacinda Kate Laurell Ardern"
description: "Examines the 2011 general election contest for the Auckland Central seat between Nicola Laura Kaye (Nikki Kaye, National, 31) and Jacinda Kate Laurell Ardern (Labour, 31), dubbed 'The Battle of the Babes'. Notes a renewed interest by young people in the seat with both major parties fielding young women as candidates, and backgrounds the political careers and rivalry between Kaye and Ardern. Portrays Ardern out campaigning, with comments by party leader Phil Goff on why she was selected to run for Auckland Central. Portrays Kaye at work as the current MP for Auckland Central, with her comments on the pressure of the job. Gives comment by the pair on the media reaction to their contest."

Author: "Johns, Geraldine"
Title: "Goodbye girls"
description: "Talks to clinical psychologist Gwendoline Smith about her double mastectomy for breast cancer, noting a new book she has written on her struggle with both depression and cancer. Gives her comments on getting over the cycle of worry and moving forward."

Author: "Johns, Geraldine"
Title: "Gwendoline Smith interview"
description: "Talks to clinical psychologist Gwendoline Smith about her double mastectomy for breast cancer, noting a new book she has written on her struggle with both depression and cancer. Gives her comments on getting over the cycle of worry and moving forward."

Author: "Manhire, Bill,"
Title: "Small holes in the silence : collected works"
description: "Small holes in the silence : collected works"

Title: "Benefits fraud paid for gambling habit"
description: "Benefits fraud paid for gambling habit"

Author: "Kilgallon, Steve"
Title: "It's all on Te Radar's screen"
description: "Talks to the comedian-actor-writer-historian-director-film maker about his busy working schedule. Includes biographical information."

Author: "Page, Emma"
Title: "Play the game"
description: "Looks at how rugby drama is flourishing and talks to the various playwrights and authors about their plays and the experience of writing them. Discusses how the game itself is a piece of performance theatre. Lists the seven rugby-related plays being staged around the country during the Rugby World Cup."

Author: "Reid, Nicholas,"
Title: "Simplest of history primers hits its target audience"
description: "Simplest of history primers hits its target audience"

Author: "Mead, Kate"
Title: "Calling the shots"
description: "Talks to Oliver Driver about returning to the 'Shortland Street' television programme as a director."

Author: "Wall, Tony"
Title: "The human toll of the latest 'wonder drug'"
description: "Investigates some of the adverse reactions in heart patients to the blood-thinning drug Pradaxa sent in by readers in response to a previous article. Discusses how critics are alarmed at the way it has been rushed on to the market. Highlights the differences between Warfarin and Pradaxa. Notes how caution is being urged in using the drug with elderly patients."

Author: "Wall, Tony"
Title: "Pharmac attacked for rushing drug"
description: "Reveals that dozens of elderly patients have suffered bleeds - and at least two have died - after taking the anti-blood clotting drug Pradaxa which was rushed onto the market by Pharmac in a deal worth more than $100m."

Author: "Hubbard, Anthony"
Title: "In the hands of fate"
description: "Visits the opposition leader at home on his farm and talks to him about how he's kept a sense of humour despite three years in the political wilderness, his attitude to the media, and why he has not given up all hope in the upcoming election. Includes biographical information."

Author: "Dudding, Adam"
Title: "All about you"
description: "Talks to political psychologist Dr Marc Wilson about how and why our answers betray our true selves in personality tests."

Author: "Bollinger, Nick,"
Title: "Family ties"
description: "Speaks to Che Fu and his father, Tigilau 'Tigi' Ness, ahead of the 'Fathers and Sons' concert at the Christchurch Arts Festival. Backgrounds Ness, describing how he got involved with Che Fu's mother, Meriama, and their political activism, including being members of the Polynesian Panthers, marching in the Maori Land March, and becoming associated with the Twelve Tribes of Israel Rastafarian movement through their respect for Bob Marley. Describes Che Fu's growing up with reggae and coming into his own as a hip-hop artist and vocalist, and looks at how Ness and Che Fu reconnected with Niue by headlining an Arts and Cultural Festival there, Apr 2011."

Author: "Bollinger, Nick,"
Title: "Che Fu and Tigilau Ness interview"
description: "Speaks to Che Fu and his father, Tigilau 'Tigi' Ness, ahead of the 'Fathers and Sons' concert at the Christchurch Arts Festival. Backgrounds Ness, describing how he got involved with Che Fu's mother, Meriama, and their political activism, including being members of the Polynesian Panthers, marching in the Maori Land March, and becoming associated with the Twelve Tribes of Israel Rastafarian movement through their respect for Bob Marley. Describes Che Fu's growing up with reggae and coming into his own as a hip-hop artist and vocalist, and looks at how Ness and Che Fu reconnected with Niue by headlining an Arts and Cultural Festival there, Apr 2011."

Author: "McLeod, Rosemary"
Title: "All aboard the rocket"
description: "Talks to Jeff Kennedy about how coffee has been a constant in his life and how his Italian-made coffee machines are taking off around the world."

Author: "Bowden, Jennifer"
Title: "Grappling with gout"
description: "Discusses gout, caused by high urate levels in the blood.  Looks at the role of diet, discussing links between dairy intake and gout, vitamin C supplements, the diseases gout aggrevates, and the risk factors for gout. Gives advice on preventing gout."

Author: "Griffin, Peter"
Title: "E-reading rekindled"
description: "Relates his experience of headaches while attempting to read e-books on the Apple iPad. Discusses the advantages of a Kindle 3G as an e-reader, and gives advice on why one would choose a Kindle or Kobo."

Title: "Exports key to architect's growth"
description: "Exports key to architect's growth"

Author: "Leask, Anna,"
Title: "Mystery as man fights to survive brain injury"
description: "Mystery as man fights to survive brain injury"

Author: "Laugesen, Ruth"
Title: "New Zealand stock exchange backing women at work"
description: "Discusses the pay gap between men and women. Looks at reasons for the lower average wage for women. Compares NZ pay rates for women with Americans and provides statistics from a recent survey on the subject. Gives some tips for increasing salaries or improving your conditions of work."

Author: "Bourke, Chris"
Title: "The band played on: remembering the Titanic's musicians"
description: "The band played on: remembering the Titanic's musicians"

Author: "White, Margo"
Title: "Common health myths"
description: "Dispels many common myths and beliefs. Lists and discusses six."

Author: "Wong, Helene"
Title: "New Zealand film: an illustrated history review"
description: "New Zealand film: an illustrated history review"

Author: "Pryor, Nicole"
Title: "Billy T James : Dean Ruscoe interview"
description: "Looks back at Comedian Billy T. James' career and speaks with his friend Ruscoe about him."

Author: "Wichtel, Diana"
Title: "Hannah Tamaki interview"
description: "Talks to Destiny Church's Hannah Tamaki, who is controversially contesting the Maori Women's Welfare League presidency. Discusses her bid for the presidency and speaks about the Destiny Church's stand on a number of issues."

Author: "Clark, Paul"
Title: "On China by Henry Kissinger review"
description: "On China by Henry Kissinger review"

Author: "Dunn, Megan"
Title: "Dazzling the RWC crowd with treasures from Oceania"
description: "Features the complementing Oceania exhibits which are running at the Real New Zealand Festival (Oceania : imagining Pacifica), City Gallery Wellington, and at Te Papa (Oceania : early encounters), both running until 6th November, 2011."

Author: "Black, Joanne"
Title: "Britain riots and crowd psychology"
description: "Draws from the recent street rioting in England, focusing on crowd behaviour. Talks to a number of people who have studied crowd psychology. Discusses some reasons why and how riots occur."

Author: "Bowden, Jennifer"
Title: "Persuading the vege-averse"
description: "Suggests a number of ways to get young children to eat more vegetables."

Author: "Harris, Ian"
Title: "400 years of the King James Bible"
description: "400 years of the King James Bible"

Title: "Rally couple a champion pairing again"
description: "Rally couple a champion pairing again"

Author: "Knight, Garrick"
Title: "Blanchard, Ross make move to Waikato"
description: "Blanchard, Ross make move to Waikato"

Author: "Bowen, Matt"
Title: "Chance discovery delights book lover"
description: "Chance discovery delights book lover"

Author: "Wright, Michael"
Title: "This pair are coming out of the ark"
description: "This pair are coming out of the ark"

Title: "Couple's deaths in Morocco 'bizarre'"
description: "Couple's deaths in Morocco 'bizarre'"

Title: "Waikato youngster's a team leader"
description: "Waikato youngster's a team leader"

Author: "McLean, Elspeth"
Title: "He stood up for what he believed in"
description: "Talks to the South Africa-born outgoing chief executive of the Southern District Health Board about his tenure in the health sector in the region over the past eight years. Comments on some of the challenges and controversies of the role, including the future of neurosurgery services. Mentions his new position as inaugural chief executive of the Central Adelaide Local Health Network, Australia."

Author: "Rudd, Allison"
Title: "No-nonsense straight-forward mayor"
description: "Pays tribute to the late former mayor of Dunedin. Describes some of his accomplishments during his long life, particularly in the area of city planning and development."

Title: "Never wavered from his socialist principles"
description: "Pays tribute to the late trade unionist. Overviews his upbringing, family life and service to the Labour Party and the trade union movement in the south of the South Island."

Author: "Hurley, Bevan"
Title: "UK law move kicks out Kiwis; Skilled sent packing"
description: "UK law move kicks out Kiwis; Skilled sent packing"

Author: "Cannan, Dave"
Title: "'Great rugby stalwart' had no regrets about tour"
description: "Pays tribute to the late rugby administrator and businessman who became a household name for his strong support of the Springbok tour in 1981."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1962"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1962.  Reports on the parcel bomb explosion that killed the well-known solicitor (26 Feb), the official opening of the new Dunedin Airport (23 May), the expulsion of two Russian diplomats (13 Jul) and the opening of the new Glenorchy-Queenstown road (14 Nov). Includes a photograph of the new airport. Touches on other events during the year."

Author: "Haggart, Matthew"
Title: "First among equals"
description: "Profiles the American-born psychologist who has become the first woman vice-chancellor of the University of Otago. Overviews her 20-year career with the university. Comments on its six key strategic imperatives, her upbringing and family life, and other aspects of her career.  Includes facts about her career and notable achievements."

Author: "Gray, Wynne"
Title: "Smith signs deal with Chiefs for next season"
description: "Smith signs deal with Chiefs for next season"

Author: "Taylor, Cliff"
Title: "Death by television; TV not an option for family"
description: "Focuses on the health effects of watching too much television (TV). Considers a report published by scientists at the University of Queensland which claims that watching TV for six hours a day could shorten our lives by up to five years. Speaks to a number of experts, including Richard Taylor, senior research fellow in early childhood obesity at the University of Otago, and Dr Robyn Toomath, diabetes specialist and founder of Fight the Obesity Epidemic (FOE), about the findings. Talks to Leigh couple Ritchie and Rebecca Watson about why they got rid of their TV."

Author: "Hannan, Hayley"
Title: "Tyre-biting dog 'haunted by accident'"
description: "Tyre-biting dog 'haunted by accident'"

Author: "Smith, Charmian"
Title: "An inspired restoration"
description: "Reports on the restoration of the distinctive tomb of the businessman and government minister, located in Northern Cemetery, Dunedin. Describes the damage to the 130-year-old tomb by vandals and weather, and the work done over a period of 18 months to bring it back to a pristine state.  Talks to stained-glass artist Peter Mackenzie and stonemason Marcus Wainwright about their contribution to its restoration. Includes a series of 'before and after' photographs and lists facts about William James Mudie Larnach."

Author: "Leask, Anna,"
Title: "Poisoning suspected in death of ex-Kiwi"
description: "Poisoning suspected in death of ex-Kiwi"

description: "Interviews the real estate agent and former journalist about his work."

Author: "Calder, Peter"
Title: "Magic pills no match for micro-monsters; Medicine lack meant one bug and you're out"
description: "Considers the end of the antibiotic era. Reports that doctors are worried about rampant strains of antibiotic-resistant bacteria. Speaks to Dr Rod Ellis-Pegler, who headed up the infectious diseases department at Auckland Hospital until 2006, and Associate Professor Mark Thomas, a senior infectious diseases physician at Auckland Hospital and the University of Auckland's medical school, about the growing problem. Talks to 95-year-old Len Lanigan about growing up in the age before antibiotics."

Author: "South, Gill"
Title: "Setting the stage for top dollar"
description: "Looks at how to improve a property's appeal when it is put on the market. Talks to successful home sellers Jane Tuson and Susannah Porter, home stager Kerry McComish, landscape designer Gail Farrell Nouveau, and real estate agent James Marshall for some tips and ideas. Suggests how to prepare for an open home."

Author: "Van Kempen, Lynda"
Title: "Fashioning a diversified career"
description: "Talks to the former Cromwell resident and former international model about her life and career. Informs that she is now back in NZ and has established the Catwalk Studios model and fashion retail training agency."

Author: "McDonald, Barney"
Title: "Almighty double duty"
description: "Talks to the actress about her career and her successive roles on 'The almighty Johnsons' and 'Shortland Street'."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1963"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1963.  Reports on the visit of Queen Elizabeth and the Duke of Edinburgh to Dunedin (15 Feb), a fire at McKenzie's department store, Dunedin (5 Jun), the death of 23 passengers after the crash of an National Airways Corporation Skyliner en route from Auckland to Tauranga (4 Nov), and mourning by US citizens after the assassination of President John Kennedy (25 Nov)."

Author: "Mackenzie, Dene"
Title: "IRD going after those cash-only jobs"
description: "Talks to Deloitte Dunedin tax partner Peter Truman about proposed changes to tax legislation to target the cash economy, whereby people accept cash for services without reporting it. Describes examples of this 'hidden economy' and the growing concern over the amount of lost tax income to Government."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1964"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1964. Reports on the start of the Manapouri power scheme tailrace tunnel project (5 Feb), a shark attack off St Clair Beach that claimed the life of 19-year-old Dunedin law student Leslie Francis Jordan (6 Feb), the controversial changes to Saddle Hill (15 Feb) and the reaction to Dunedin residents to a visit by the Beatles, including a photograph of the crowd surrounding their car (27 Jun).  Touches on other events during the year."

Title: "Survivor urges safety in the snow"
description: "Survivor urges safety in the snow"

Title: "The dead tell tales : Daniel Dee Hyde circa 1836-1894"

Author: "Robertson, Emily-Kate"
Title: "Dance student's fortunate decision before the earthquake hit; A name to remember; Massive upheaval; Home"
description: "Presents essays, a poem and an original work of art from six pupils at Bayfield High School. Relates the stories of two people, including a former pupil, who survived the 6.3 magnitude earthquake in Christchurch, 22 Feb 2011, as told by Emily-Kate Robinson and Victoria Saunders. Describes the qualities of her friend, a popular Swedish student named Agnes, who has since returned to Sweden. Includes the poem 'Home' by Britta Hamill, and a pop art work and commentary by Joshua Hunter."

Title: "'Caught in the wrong place' : rescuers tell of frantic calls to Kiwi radio star as surfing shortcut ends in tragedy on rocks"
description: "'Caught in the wrong place' : rescuers tell of frantic calls to Kiwi radio star as surfing shortcut ends in tragedy on rocks"

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1965"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1965. Reports on the upcoming Interdominion Championships, Forbury Park Raceway, Dunedin (20 Feb), the reduction in NZ's birthrate due to 'a phenomenal usage of contraceptive pills' (1 May), the opening of the Benmore power station (17 May) and the opening of the new Haast Pass highway (18 Nov). Includes a photograph of the winners of the 1965 Mobil Song Quest, Dunedin Town Hall. Touches on other events during the year."

Title: "Kiwi world croquet boss killed by thieves: sister"
description: "Kiwi world croquet boss killed by thieves: sister"

Author: "Porteous, Debbie"
Title: "Earthquake through police lenses"
description: "Talks to the police forensic photographer about his experience in the aftermath of the 22 Feb 2011 Christchurch earthquake, images of which have been published in the book 'Christchurch 22.2 : Beyond the cordon / through the eyes of New Zealand Police photographers', featuring photographs by about 20 forensic photographers in the weeks following the earthquake."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1966"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1966. Reports on the official opening of the Telford Farm Training Institute (6 Feb) and the decision by the Dunedin City Council to fluoridate the city water supply (5 Apr). Announces that the late resident has left her magnificent home, 'Olveston', to the city along with her art collection, which is one of the 'most outstanding private collections of art treasures in the country' (26 Oct). Includes a photograph of Princes St, Dunedin, looking south to Dowling St and Exchange. Touches on other events during the year."

Author: "Smith, Charmian"
Title: "Ode to joy - family first for Lemalu; Ode to joy - family first"
description: "Talks to the Dunedin-raised, London-based international opera singer and former Dunedin resident about the importance of his family to the success of his career. Informs that he is back in Dunedin for a visit along with his Croatian-born wife, mezzo-soprano and theatre director Sandra Martinovic, and their young son, Joshua Lemalu.  Talks about the organisational skills required to raise a child and maintain two successful careers. Notes that he will be joining the NZ Symphony Orchestra in its concert 'Odes to Joy', Dunedin Town Hall, 28 Sep 2011."

Title: "'Psychic' stalker told: You'll be jailed next time : judge gives widower, 52, a final warning on his 'bizarre' infatuation with teenager"

description: "Mother's claim adds to theories over fall deaths"

description: "Teen sent home twice beofre death : an earlier diagnosis would have saved young man's life, says distraught father"

description: "Hero's farewell for passionate soldier : mourners hear that shot SAS corporal was firm supporter of Afghan mission"

Author: "Clifton, Jane,"
Title: "Rush to justice"
description: "Comments on what she describes as the National Government's 'panicky' response to the Supreme Court finding that surveillances in the 2007 Urewera anti-terror raids were illegal. Looks at the politics and legal issues involved in the Government's response, the effects of secrecy on assessing the case, and a lack of direction by the Government over the issue of curtailing the right to silence."

Author: "White, Margo"
Title: "Eye health"
description: "Looks at how eye examinations can reveal early signs of diseases such as diabetes, hypertension, macular degeneration, gluacome and possibly brain tumors. Describes optical coherence tomography (OCT) and its use in diagnosing neurological conditions such as Alzheimer's disease and multiple sclerosis, and mentions recommendations by optometrists that everyone have a general eye examination around age 45."

Author: "Griffin, Peter"
Title: "Kindle vs Kobo vs iPad"
description: "Relates his experience of headaches while attempting to read e-books on the Apple iPad. Discusses the advantages of a Kindle 3G as an e-reader, and gives advice on why one would choose a Kindle or Kobo."

Title: "Surprise party to celebrate a century"
description: "Surprise party to celebrate a century"

Author: "Milne, Jonathan"
Title: "Culture clash"
description: "Looks at the state of MaÃÑori claims to ownership of their traditional arts, culture and medicine. Describes the battle by Haana Waitai Murray (Saana) and her family to have the Waitangi Tribunal recognise ownership over manuka honey as a medicine, among other claims (Wai 262). Looks at the appropriation of indigenous images such as the haka and moko by artists and corporations. Examines how German chemists have isolated the active compound in manuka honey, methylglyoxal, mentioning views on the rights of MaÃÑori and Aboriginal Australians, the economic size of Medihoney wound dressings in the European and American markets, and the share Comvita took of this.  Describes the stance taken by Haami Piripi, then chief executive of Te Tauri Whiri i te Reo Maori (Maori Language Commission) in 2004 on confiscation of MaÃÑori cultural property, his resignation, and his current position as a militant leader of northern iwi determined to use the law to protect MaÃÑori rights and fight the Government. Looks at the position of Christopher Finlayson, Minister for Treaty Negotiations, on the issue, notes MaÃÑori culture being showcased in the Rugby World Cup, and revisits Haana Murray's whanau who will still press her claims. Discusses MaÃÑori designers using traditional motifs and claims that they are being exploited by big business, looking at the work of ta moko artist Rangi Kipa and others with the moko and designs such as the koru. Gives a timeline of cases where companies or individuals appropriated MaÃÑori cultural property."

Title: "Safety was 'first class' : Safe Air man known for attention to detail"

Author: "Laugesen, Ruth"
Title: "Cold comfort"
description: "Looks at NZ families living in fuel poverty, unable to afford adequate heating of their homes during the colder months. Describes the health hazards of colder homes, including estimates of extra winter deaths in NZ. Describes the idea of fuel poverty, and looks at how this affects children and family health in poorer, badly insulated and under-heated homes. Shows examples of families struggling with the cold, and talks to Sarah Free of the Sustainability Trust about the types of people struggling with fuel poverty. Notes a rise in market-driven disconnections and discusses switching power companies, the rising prices for household users in comparison to industrial or commercial users, and initiatives by the government and changes to the Building Code to improve and insulate homes."

Gives Bale's career, including work as the managing editor of FTMarketWatch.com, editorial director for Times Online, and editor for MSN UK. Describes the role of CNN outside the USA and the role of news organisations in an interactive online world, including curation of conversations and making news financially sustainable."

Notes the audience interaction of the piece and her experience with nudity and capitalist exploitation of artists in Berlin incorporated into it."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1967"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1967.  Reports on the grim task of rescuers to retrieve the bodies of 19 men killed in an underground explosion in the Strongman State coalmine (20 Jan), the death of the St Kilda Surf Life-Saving Club captain in a shark attack (10 Mar), and the verdict of voters in referenda to support 10 o'clock closing of hotel bars and reject four-year parliamentary terms (25 Sep). Includes a photograph of the front cover of the 20 Jan 1967 edition, depicting coverage of the Strongman mine explosion."

Title: "Sweet as"
description: "Describes the antibacterial uses of manuka honey, looking at Dutch research on the reasons for its antibacterial properties. Reports on HoneyLab launching two new products, one for cuts and burns and one for acne and athletes foot, and examines HoneyLab and Professor Shaun Holt, talking to him about his plans for further development of medical honey-related products."

Title: "Over the limit"
description: "Discusses a new book by an English author on the limits of natural systems and the human responsibility for planetary management. Notes these limits requiring urgent attention by people, including climate change and biodiversity, and talks to author Mark Lynas about technological solutions and political action to address these issues much as the world addressed the effects of CFCs on the ozone layer."

Warns of the effect of insurance companies currently withholding cover to Christchurch businesses and individuals. Touches on the Government's financial support of AMI Insurance."

description: "Talks to the Templeton family now living in the Cliffside homestead once occupied by the family of the All Black captain.  Reveals the aspirations of 12-year-old Bailey Templeton and 11-year-old Lachlan Templeton to follow in the footsteps of the captain who is playing his historical 100th test match at Eden Park 24 Sep 2011.  Speaks with Kurow locals about their memories of the captain as a youngster and of his parents Donald McCaw and Margaret McCaw. Notes a dedicated display at the local museum."

Author: "Corry, Lucy"

description: "Profiles the eeler and his business, Moko Freshwater Eel, which he runs with wife Bev Dawson. Discusses how and where the eels are caught, the usefulness of farmers' markets, the awards the smoked product has won, and why his business is called Moko (grandchild)."

Author: "Macdonald, Nikki"
Title: "The E-lection"
description: "Follows election campaigners Hekia Parata (National Party), Grant Robertson (Labour Party), Gareth Hughes (Greens Party), and Heather Roy (ACT Party), evaluating their use of social media and their anticipation that the use of Facebook, blogs, tweets and websites will stimulate voting by young people. Enumerates the statistics for each candidate's Tweets, Twitter followers, and Facebook friends. Talks to Victoria University Phd student Hugo Gong about the use of e-campaigning by political parties."

Anticipates his next film project about the MaÃÑori battalion. Compares screenwriting to writing novels."

Author: "Kara, Scott"
Title: "When first shout rang out"
description: "Previews 'Ka mate : the haka legend, the story of the haka' broadcast on MaÃÑori  TV on October 1."

Author: "Wright, Michael"
Title: "Lack of cover puts life on hold"
description: "Highlights the problems faced by many would be new home owners in Christchurch. Speaks to a number of people who have had buildings insurance refused because of their proximity to Christchurch."

Author: "Smith, Tony"
Title: "Fond memories in McCaw country"
description: "Visits Kurow the hometown of All Blacks captain Richie McCaw. Discovers the huge local pride and support for their town hero. Illuminates his inspiration to young players of the town. Reports on the museum display dedicated to McCaw. Recalls stories of a young Richard McCaw by a number of Kurow residents who have known him."

Author: "Koubaridis, Andrew"
Title: "Quad bike victim's family tell of legacy"
description: "Quad bike victim's family tell of legacy"

Author: "Dally, Joelle"
Title: "Fighting the plight of women in Solomons"
description: "Introduces Beverley Herbert, Canterbury-born trained midwife, nurse and former lecturer at Massey University, now living in the Solomon Islands volunteering work at a cervical screening unit and also a nurse consultant in primary health. Discusses the plight of women in the Solomon Islands who are facing increasing numbers of teenage pregnancy, infant mortality, maternal morbidity and death from pregnancy and childbirth. Reports on the lack of basic health knowledge like washing hands. Talks also to Dr Alice Pollard, who coordinates the Honiora's Rural Women's Association. Advocates education as the key to helping women and giving them the ability to make choices about their lives and their bodies."

Author: "Hockley, Lorraine"
Title: "The gift that changed lives"
description: "Tells the colourful life and adventures of Gary Griffiths who many years after his original visit to India decided to set up a charitable trust to help the poor and destitute, supplying blankets to people and helping with educating children."

Author: "Backhouse, Matthew"
Title: "Death brings calls to take keys before breath-testing"
description: "Death brings calls to take keys before breath-testing"

Author: "Venter, Nick"
Title: "Ex-MP gets taste of his own advice"
description: "Chronicles the downward trend of Mark Peck's political career. Notes his ownership of a cafe 'Little Peckish' In Wellington's Duke's Arcade and comments on the effect of legislation and regulations from both central and local government have on small businesses. Mentions Labour's policy to exclude GST from fruit and vegetables."

Author: "Milne, Jonathan"
Title: "Maori cultural clash"
description: "Looks at the state of MaÃÑori claims to ownership of their traditional arts, culture and medicine. Describes the battle by Haana Waitai Murray (Saana) and her family to have the Waitangi Tribunal recognise ownership over manuka honey as a medicine, among other claims (Wai 262). Looks at the appropriation of indigenous images such as the haka and moko by artists and corporations. Examines how German chemists have isolated the active compound in manuka honey, methylglyoxal, mentioning views on the rights of MaÃÑori and Aboriginal Australians, the economic size of Medihoney wound dressings in the European and American markets, and the share Comvita took of this.  Describes the stance taken by Haami Piripi, then chief executive of Te Tauri Whiri i te Reo Maori (Maori Language Commission) in 2004 on confiscation of MaÃÑori cultural property, his resignation, and his current position as a militant leader of northern iwi determined to use the law to protect MaÃÑori rights and fight the Government. Looks at the position of Christopher Finlayson, Minister for Treaty Negotiations, on the issue, notes MaÃÑori culture being showcased in the Rugby World Cup, and revisits Haana Murray's whanau who will still press her claims. Discusses MaÃÑori designers using traditional motifs and claims that they are being exploited by bug business, looking at the work of ta moko artist Rangi Kipa and others with the moko and designs such as the koru. Gives a timeline of cases where companies or individuals appropriated MaÃÑori cultural property."

Author: "Heine, Conrad"
Title: "Peter Bale interview"
description: "Interviews expat journalist Peter Bale, now the London-based general manager of CNN International Digital. Discusses the current state of the UK media scene, including the ongoing effects of the Murdoch tabloid hacking scandals. Gives Bale's career, including work as the managing editor of FTMarketWatch.com, editorial director for Times Online, and editor for MSN UK. Describes the role of CNN outside the USA and the role of news organisations in an interactive online world, including curation of conversations and making news financially sustainable."

Author: "Laugesen, Ruth"
Title: "New Zealand houses too cold"
description: "Looks at NZ families living in fuel poverty, unable to afford adequate heating of their homes during the colder months. Describes the health hazards of colder homes, including estimates of extra winter deaths in NZ. Describes the idea of fuel poverty, and looks at how this affects children and family health in poorer, badly insulated and under-heated homes. Shows examples of families struggling with the cold, and talks to Sarah Free of the Sustainability Trust about the types of people struggling with fuel poverty. Notes a rise in market-driven disconnections and discusses switching power companies, the rising prices for household users in comparison to industrial or commercial users, and initiatives by the government and changes to the Building Code to improve and insulate homes."

Author: "Clifton, Jane,"
Title: "National's panicky law-changing"
description: "Comments on what she describes as the National Government's 'panicky' response to the Supreme Court finding that surveillances in the 2007 Urewera anti-terror raids were illegal. Looks at the politics and legal issues involved in the Government's response, the effects of secrecy on assessing the case, and a lack of direction by the Government over the issue of curtailing the right to silence."

Author: "McCrone, John"
Title: "Masterplan - major risk?"
description: "Investigates Christchurch's proposed reconstruction plans for the central city business district. Hears complaints from property owners who were not consulted by the city council when the plans were being drawn up. Discusses issues around parking and shop floor size restrictions. Looks at how the future re-build investment into the CBD is steering."

Author: "Hubbard, Anthony"
Title: "How to grow rich but stay green?"
description: "Looks at the value of the clean and green image of NZ, advocating cleaning up NZ industry to avoid damaging this. Looks at Green Party proposals and the policy recommendations of the Government in cleaning up the agricultural sector, home insulation, and clean energy. Speculates that NZ may need to tap more polluting sources of wealth for economic development, including minerals within the exclusive economic zone. Looks at controversies over Petrobras oil exploration off the East Cape and proposals for lignate mining onshore."

Author: "Kilgallon, Steve"
Title: "Keeping the faith"
description: "Visits Samoa. Describes the Island culture and life, including the dominance of religion and family as part of the Samoan way ('fa'a Samoa'). Looks at the friendliness of the locals as experienced by tourists, and describes the Sinalei Reef Resort and other attractions of Upolu. Describes the Le Lagoto Beach Resort and other attractions of Sava'ai, and of Apia (including the memory of Robert Louis Stevenson in Samoan life)"

Author: "Campbell, Gerard"
Title: "She's really blossomed"
description: "Talks to Jenny Gillies, floral costume and fabric artist, Christchurch about her work at the Floral Festival and the World of WearableArts."

Author: "Risk, Louise"
Title: "Still no sign of missing fishers"
description: "Still no sign of missing fishers"

Author: "Dixon, Rachel"
Title: "Strait ahead"
description: "Visits Stewart Island. Describes its only town, Oban, and the attractions of the beaches, flora and fauna, with conservation efforts aimed at returning much of the island to a pre-human state. Describes an encounter with a kiwi in the wild, and mentions visiting Ulva Island and sea kayaking."

Author: "Holmes, Stephanie"
Title: "Turning pro"
description: "Talks to nutritionist Nikki Hart, discussing common problems with digestion and examining the new supplement Probiotica P3 from Nutralife. Discusses probiotic supplements, whether they are necessary, and possible side effects. Gives Hart's comments on their advantages."

Author: "Dekker, Diana"
Title: "Paradise found"
description: "Talks to Derelie Cherry, author of recent publication 'Two dogs and a garden'. Discusses the book."

Author: "Burke, Roy"
Title: "'Master of Magic' conjured up a life of many parts"
description: "'Master of Magic' conjured up a life of many parts"

Author: "Cairns, Lois"
Title: "Brain drain claims third of New Zealand's PhDs"
description: "Reports on new research showing that only about two thirds of doctoral graduates are employed in NZ in the years following graduation. Examines implications from the study (by the Ministry of Education) on NZ losing talent overseas and also gaining it from overseas students. Talks to Dr Tom Wilson on his temptation to move to the UK following graduation, and to Professor Lucy Johnston (Canterbury University) on the job prospects for PhD students."

Author: "Morton, Jamie"
Title: "Plea change in referee assault case"
description: "Plea change in referee assault case"

Author: "Hallahan, Marnie"
Title: "Charity club's liberty swing a favourite"
description: "Charity club's liberty swing a favourite"

Author: "Plumb, Simon"
Title: "More poor supplements management revealed"
description: "Reports on further evidence on banned substances in NZ sports supplements. Notes a leading female cyclist (unnamed) who used Tribulus, claimed to boost testosterone production, and reports that this is considered a doping risk by the World Anti-Doping Agency. Gives comments from BikeNZ on the issue, including denials that the supplement has any effect. Looks at recent anti-doping measures by Sparc."

Author: "Mead, Kate"
Title: "Art for kids' sake"
description: "Visits the Muka lithograph workshop in Grey Lynn run by Frans Baetens and Magda Van Gils, home of the soon-to-close Muka Youth Print project.  Describes the 25 year old project, which gave NZ children the chance to appreciate and purchase original art.  Backgrounds the pair, including their reasons for shutting down the project, and gives their comments on the value of art for children. Notes some upcoming exhibitions and portfolios to mark its passing. Talks to Benedict Gordon, who purchased his first piece of art at age 5 through the project."

Author: "Neale, Imogen"
Title: "Showtime for arts hopeful"
description: "Reports on Young Sun Han, 28-year old Korean-American born former curator of the City Art Rooms Gallery in Auckland, who has moved back to the USA and is now participating in the reality show 'Work of Art : the Next Great Artist'. Describes the show and talks to him about participating, and his impressions of the NZ art scene."

Author: "Twentyman, Maryanne"
Title: "Kiwi twist on tandor oven finds a market"
description: "Kiwi twist on tandor oven finds a market"

Title: "Fruitful life with a honey of a business"
description: "Fruitful life with a honey of a business"

description: "Family of missing fisherman prepare for worst, seek closure"
