Author: "Milne, Jonathan"
Title: "Assisted suicide in New Zealand"
description: "Focuses on euthanasia. Considers the trauma of helping a sick person to kill themselves. Speaks to Yoka De Houwer, who has been diagnosed with leptomeningeal melanomatosis, and her partner Don Grant about the plans they have made for Yoka to control her own death, retired doctor Peter Hinds about the need for a law change, Dr Else Borst-Eilers, the architect of the Netherland's physician-assisted suicide law, about legalising euthanasia, and Lesely Martin who served half of her 15-month jail term for giving her mother, Joy, a fatal morphine overdose in 1999. Outlines the political position on the issue in NZ and overseas. Recalls the 2007 assisted suicide of Audrey Wallis with the help of American Susan Wilson."

Author: "Johns, Geraldine"
Title: "Overseas dental work : facts and fears"
description: "Focuses on the risks assoicated with dental tourism, which sees tourists get their dental work done in developing countries for noticeably less than they would expect to pay in NZ. Speaks to a number of experts, including Donald Schwass, a senior lecturer in the Department of Oral Rehabilitation at the University of Otago School of Dentistry, about the risks of getting dental work done overseas, and to David Crum, chief executive of the NZ Dental Association, about why dental fees are high in NZ. Talks to two dental tourists about their experiences. Spotlights the death of Melanie Heremaia after she had root canal surgery performed in Noumea. Outlines the normal NZ fees for some common treatments, as stated on the NZ Dental Association website."

Author: "Hunter, Tim"
Title: "Stepping out of the spotlight; Stepping out of spotlight with strong legacy intact"
description: "Looks at the achievements of the chief executive of NZX Ltd. (New Zealand Stock Exchange) and of the Stock Exchange itself. Touches on the political nature of the chief executive's position and including the strategic direction of the NZX, and the work he has been involved in concerning the promotion of capital markets. Comments on Mark Weldon's future plans and his replacement."

Title: "Kings of artisan cheese"

Title: "The 'yes' chef"
description: "Recounts Martin Bosley's cooking career in some well known restaurants in Wellington. Recalls how his initial efforts at starting a restaurant didn't blossom so called on his work experience at McDonald's to improve the running of his restaurant. Indicates how at an early age he became interested in preparing food to eat. Includes recipes which will be served to the Style Pacifica VIPs on October 19."

Author: "Thornley, Louise"
Title: "Back to basics"
description: "Talks to the founder of the McKenzie Method of Mechanical Diagnosis and Treatment, Robin McKenzie. Recounts how he came across the new method to reduce back pain by accidental observation and is now known as 'directional preference' where symptoms reduce with particular movements. Recalls the responses to his new method within the medical community. Notes the critical factor in back pain is posture, don't slouch. Includes a list of self help tips and books Robin has published."

description: "Backgrounds the 1984 murder of the author's aunt near Shrewsbury in Shropshire, England. Speaks to the retired Royal Navy commander who claims to have found evidence that she was murdered by secret services desperate to cover up Falklands War crimes, as outlined in the book he has written with his wife Kate Dewes."

Title: "Focus on simple, durable city plan"
description: "Talks to Otago Chamber of Commerce chief executive John Christie about his recent trip to Portland, Oregon, to research economic development tools that could be applied to Dunedin. Describes Portland's use of public-private partnerships (PPPs) to drive urban renewal, and the role of the Portland Development Commission."

Author: "Mackenzie, Dene"
Title: "McIntyre's mission - a dynamic Dunedin"
description: "Speaks to Otago Chamber of Commerce president Peter McIntyre about his vision of reshaping Dunedin into NZ's best place to live and work. References the transformation of Portland, Oregon from a city with an 'identity crisis' to a dynamic 'super city' through the efforts of the Portland Development Commission. Cites some of the lessons which Dunedin could emulate, including strategic partnerships."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1980"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1980. Announces that the Planning Tribunal has dismissed appeals against the 'granting of a 21-year water right for the construction of the DG3 high dam at Clyde' (17 Dec).  Reports that floodwaters have receded in the West Otago township of Kelso (19 Jan). Includes an update on the situation at 26 May, and a photograph of the floods. Lauds the success of Saturday trading in Dunedin (17 Nov). Touches on other events during the year."

Author: "De Reus, Helena"
Title: "Committed to the community, with a gift for finding water"
description: "Pays tribute to the Balclutha-born last mayor of Milton. Lauds his contributions to the community. Describes his gift for water divining, which he has passed on to one of his granddaughters."

Author: "Gilchrist, Shane"
Title: "Help yourself - get happy; Helping yourself to happiness"
description: "Chats to the psychologist about his forthcoming book, 'When happiness is not enough : balancing pleasure and achievement in your life', in which he provides tips about how to find true fulfilment amidst the pressures of modern life. Provides details about the Dunedin book launch. Lists five strategies being promoted by the Mental Health Foundation as part of Mental Health Awareness Week (10-16 Oct 2011), the main theme of which is 'Get in the game - training for happiness'."

Author: "Dungey, Kim"
Title: "All under the one roof"
description: "Talks to the retired High Court judge, now serving as the chairman of Dunedin Venues, about the importance of continuing to improve the customer experience at the new Forsyth Barr Stadium. Calls on local groups to take a combined approach to promote Dunedin. Mentions some of the confirmed bookings at the covered stadium, and signals that a covered stadium in Christchurch is a likely prospect if AMI Stadium is abandoned."

Author: "Cook, Marjorie"
Title: "Yarning in Wanaka"
description: "Drops in on the 'Stitch'n Bitch' knitting circle. Asks the knitting circle instigator/fibre artist and some of the other knitters if they would divulge the identity of the 'yarn-bomber' known only as 'Knitsy'. Talks to the knitters about the growing appeal and changing demographic of the knitting circle."

Title: "Orchestra history ends on optimistic note; Digging the dirt under the PR"
description: "Orchestra history ends on optimistic note; Digging the dirt under the PR"

description: "Talks to singer/guitarist Matiu Walters of the Auckland-based roots-reggae-rock quintet about its recent success, including the upcoming release of its major-label eponymous debut album. Explains the meaning behind the band's name and recalls their formation while studying at the University of Otago in 2005. Lists dates and venues of local gigs to promote the album."

Title: "Everything according to plan"
description: "Interviews the builder and project manager of NLB Ltd about the nature of his work."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1981"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1981. Sums up key findings of the royal commission of inquiry into the crash of the Air New Zealand DC10 Antarctic flight on 28 Nov 1979, which killed all 257 passengers and crew (28 Apr). Reports that 90 people were injured during demonstrations at the All Blacks-Springboks rugby test, Eden Park, Auckland (14 Sep), and includes a photograph of a clash between protesters and police. Describes the controversial under-arm bowl by Trevor Chappell that ended the third Benson and Hedges World Series Cup cricket final between Australia and NZ, Melbourne Cricket Ground (3 Feb), and includes a photograph. Touches on other events during the year."

description: "Talks to the Dutch-born internationally renowned scientist who has been appointed chief scientist at the Dunedin-based company. Overviews his career and describes some of the projects in which he and the company have been involved."

Encourages openness in the process of deciding what MPs are entitled to in conjunction with bringing Parliament under the Official Information Act."

Author: "Priestley, Rebecca,"
Title: "Square Kilometre Array race"
description: "Focuses on the proposed Square Kilometre Array (SKA) radio telescope and the Australia-NZ bid to host it. Speaks to Melanie Johnston-Hollitt, chairwoman of the NZ SKA Research and Development Consortium, about the project that will construct the world's most powerful telescope. Explains that the telescope will consist of thousands of antennas that could stretch from Western Australian to NZ."

description: "Offers some advice on the start of the new vegetable growing season, which traditionally beings at Labour Day weekend, including using seed-raising trays to start crops, transplanting seedlings, and making pots out of newspaper."

Title: "Brainscan"

Explains the survey was constructed to obtain data to test some theoretical arguments about why do people vote the way they do."

Author: "White, Margo"
Title: "Housing for all ages and stages"
description: "Talks about designing houses with possible future disabilities associated with aging in mind. Highlights the premise of the Lifemark programme, which provides an independent seal of approval for residential housing that is usable, adaptable, accessible and inclusive. Speaks to Wellington architect Ron Pynenberg who has been promoting accessible residential design since the 1970s."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1982"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1982. Announces the decision of the National government to abandon its proposed energy plan for the next 15 years following confirmation that the Aramoana aluminium smelter will not be built (20 Oct), and outlines alternative options and the Opposition's view to the announcement.  Reports on the invasion of the Falkland (Malvinas) islands by Argentine military forces (5 Apr), and updates the situation as at 31 May. Touches on other events during the year. Includes a photograph of the NZ players selected for the FIFA Football World Cup, Spain."

Chronicles the work of wine pioneers, Ata Rangi's Clive Paton, Dry River's Neil McCallum and later Palliser Estate's Richard Riddiford. Notes the importance of 'Toast Martinborough festival' as an event that has bought the Martinborough area into prominence as a quality wine producing area."

Title: "The habitat disasters before Rena arrived"
description: "Recaps ten environmental calamities experienced by NZ, citing comments by Otago University professor Tom Brooking about the most serious disasters having occurred over a long period of time. Briefly describes the events and issues surrounding the Tui mine waste deposits, Te Aroha; the ICI Riverview chemical plant chemicals spillage, Auckland; the Fruitgrowers Chemical Company plant pesticide contamination, Mapua; the 'Don Wong 529' oil spill, Breakside Island; the MV 'Rotoma' fuel spill, Tutukaka; the 'Seafresh 1' fuel spill, Hanson Bay; the 'Jody F Millennium' fuel spill, Gisborne Harbour; the Umuroa oil storage facility oil discharge, Taranaki; the Te Kuiti Meat Processors effluent contamination; and the diesel spill into the Heathcote River, Christchurch, from the Steelbro company."

Author: "Rogers, Claire"
Title: "How to get ahead in the iCloud"
description: "Examines the new iCloud service introduced by Apple which will be available from 20 Oct 2011, enabling users to access applications, music and photos on all their internet-connected devices without having to transfer files. Answers the questions: What is it, How you get it, What it costs, and What you don't get."

Title: "The ship that stole summer; Business in limbo, though costs remain; 'It's gonna be a very sad Christmas for a lot of people, a very sad summer'"
description: "Focuses on the response of the Mount Maunganui community to the running aground of the container ship 'Rena' off the coast of Tauranga. Looks at the environmental damage resulting from the spillage of oil and cargo, and the subsequent effect on the areas fishing and shellfish gathering, the beaches, and the tourism jobs that depend on the ocean. Talks to local business owners, including tourist operator Graeme Butler about his concern for the marine mammals, his business, and his disbelief at a ship grounding on the well-known Astrolabe Reef. Notes the potential effect on Motiti Island residents who rely heavily on the ocean for their food supply."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1984"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1984. Reports on the evacuation of two suburbs in Invercargill after 48 hours of torrential rain (28 Jan), and updates the situation as of 30 Jan. Announces the decisive defeat of Sir Robert Muldoon and his National Party Government after the snap election (16 Jan). Informs that the new Labour Government has acted quickly to devalue the NZ dollar to avert a currency crisis (19 Jan). Reports that the Wool Auction Sales Committee and the New Zealand Wool Board have rejected a last-minute bid by Otago woolgrowers to have all wool from Otago and Southland sold through Dunedin (17 May)."

Speaks to director Jill Thompson about its role in providing a creative venue for people who use mental health services. Informs of its concurrent exhibitions as part of Mental Health Awareness Week: 'Down the track', Art Station, Dunedin Railway Station, 19-29 Oct 2011, and Creative Arts Trust collection, Artsenta, Dunedin, 19-29 Oct 2011. Speaks to the surveyor and part-time student about how the centre has helped her to get back on her feet."

Reviews 'Homeward' by Julie Greig, The Artist's Room, Dunedin, until 22 Oct 2011."

Includes a photo of the stricken vessel. Reports that a man fatally shot his wife in view of hundreds of people on the main street of Gore, and was then fatally wounded by police (7 Jun).  Announces the realisation of the 20-year project to develop hydroelectric power stations in the Upper Waitaki (13 Dec). Touches on other events during the year."

Talks to career changers Amanda Holland (pharmacist to homecare designer), Kerry Prendergast (midwife to mayor), Sara Sadd and Ann Porter (art gallery owners to skin care producers), Stephen Daisley (shearer to author), Rachel Baskerville (anthropologist to accountant), and John Tucker (manager to academic)."

Looks at the environmental damage resulting from the spillage of oil and cargo, and the subsequent effect on the areas fishing and shellfish gathering, the beaches, and the tourism jobs that depend on the ocean. Author: "Laugesen, Ruth"
Title: "Under a cloud"
description: "Talks to GP Ken Greer and looks at research on the use of antidepressants (selective serotonin re-uptake inhibitors, SSRIs such as Prozac) in NZ and whether they work as well as previously thought. Discusses the debate on their use for mild to moderate cases of depression, looking at the uses of alternatives such as social networks, counselling and positive psychology; the issue of when to come off antidepressants; and whether research has been tainted by drug companies. Looks at research comparing the use of SSRIs to placebos, and at the pro-drug bias of published vs unpublished drug trials, noting criticisms of these findings. Discusses with professor Carl Burgess (University of Otago) the drawbacks and risks of SSRIs and SNRIs (serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors). Notes the history and use of antidepressants in NZ, and the complex nature of depression past a simple chemical imbalance. Talks to clinical psychologist Kerry Gibson about the use of psychotherapy, Government funding, and people's expectations of happiness. Looks at the case of blogger Cameron Slater who weaned himself off antidepressants with exercise and psychotherapy after having social and depersonalisation disorders. Looks at the case of journalist Pattrick Smellie who successfully used Prozac to help with depression."

Author: "Laugesen, Ruth"
Title: "Antidepressants - a discussion"
description: "Talks to GP Ken Greer and looks at research on the use of antidepressants (selective serotonin re-uptake inhibitors, SSRIs such as Prozac) in NZ and whether they work as well as previously thought. Discusses the debate on their use for mild to moderate cases of depression, looking at the uses of alternatives such as social networks, counselling and positive psychology; the issue of when to come off antidepressants; and whether research has been tainted by drug companies. Looks at research comparing the use of SSRIs to placebos, and at the pro-drug bias of published vs unpublished drug trials, noting criticisms of these findings. Discusses with professor Carl Burgess (University of Otago) the drawbacks and risks of SSRIs and SNRIs (serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors). Notes the history and use of antidepressants in NZ, and the complex nature of depression past a simple chemical imbalance. Talks to clinical psychologist Kerry Gibson about the use of psychotherapy, Government funding, and people's expectations of happiness. Looks at the case of blogger Cameron Slater who weaned himself off antidepressants with exercise and psychotherapy after having social and depersonalisation disorders. Looks at the case of journalist Pattrick Smellie who successfully used Prozac to help with depression."

Author: "Laugesen, Ruth"
Title: "Cruel & unusual"
description: "Marks the release of a report by the UN on torture of prisoners in Afghan detention centres, talking to Defence Minister Wayne Mapp about the responsibility faced by the NZ SAS for turning prisoners over to potential torture. Gives Mapp's comments that there is 'no evidence' that any person arrested by the Crisis Response Unit (with whom the SAS work) has been tortured, and notes a long delayed report on the SAS role which has yet to be publicly released. Discusses the moral and legal questions raised by the report, criticism of the NZ Government by Amnesty International on this issue, and Mapp's comments on NZ's responsibility."

Author: "Laugesen, Ruth"
Title: "Torture in Afghan jails and NZ SAS"
description: "Marks the release of a report by the UN on torture of prisoners in Afghan detention centres, talking to Defence Minister Wayne Mapp about the responsibility faced by the NZ SAS for turning prisoners over to potential torture. Gives Mapp's comments that there is 'no evidence' that any person arrested by the Crisis Response Unit (with whom the SAS work) has been tortured, and notes a long delayed report on the SAS role which has yet to be publicly released. Discusses the moral and legal questions raised by the report, criticism of the NZ Government by Amnesty International on this issue, and Mapp's comments on NZ's responsibility."

Author: "McCrone, John"
Title: "Store wars"
description: "Reports on the competition between NZ's two supermarket companies, Woolworths Australia owned Progressive enterprises (Countdown, Foodtown, Woolworths, SuperValue and Fresh Choice) and Foodstuffs cooperative (New World, Pak'n Save, Four Square, On the Spot, Write Price, Shoprites). Notes that NZ is the only country in the world where a supermarket duopoly dominates the market. Talks about the impact on consumers and suppliers. Presents a brief history of NZ supermarkets."

Author: "Daniell, Sarah"
Title: "'Go have a normal life'"
description: "Looks at the work of neonatal researcher Professor Jane Harding (Liggins Institute and the University of Auckland), recently given a research grant by the US National Institutes of Health for a study on the effects of low blood sugar (hypoglacaemia) just after birth and subsequent brain and health development. Talks to her about the research project, following around 600 children born in Hamilton, and her speculations on the links between low blood sugar, maternal diabetes, and later brain damage. Profiles Harding, a former Rhodes scholar and one of NZ's top researchers, and talks about a previous discovery in 1995 on the risks of a common neonatal therapy, and about funding for research in NZ."

Author: "Daniell, Sarah"
Title: "Jane Harding interview"
description: "Looks at the work of neonatal researcher Professor Jane Harding (Liggins Institute and the University of Auckland), recently given a research grant by the US National Institutes of Health for a study on the effects of low blood sugar (hypoglacaemia) just after birth and subsequent brain and health development. Profiles Harding, a former Rhodes scholar and one of NZ's top researchers, and talks about a previous discovery in 1995 on the risks of a common neonatal therapy, and about funding for research in NZ."

description: "Discusses the connection between the dental health of pregnant women and poor birth outcomes. Looks at research on peridontal disease (chronic infection of the gums and bone, often asymptomatic) and preterm labour or low birth weight. Notes signs of peridontal disease and the inclusion of dental care into Labour and Green Party political platforms."

Author: "Laredo, Rodney"
Title: "Saving lives through forgery and food"
description: "Speaks to the retired chemist about being a Jew during the Nazi occupation of the Netherlands during World War Two and the movement she helped set up to forge identification papers, food coupons and passports for Jewish people. Talks about her memories of Anne Frank, who was taught by her first husband Sal Breemer. Explains that she changed her maiden name to 'Molenaar' because the Polish 'Polenaar' was considered too risky."

Author: "Bowden, Jennifer"
Title: "When less is more"
description: "Looks at the large portion sizes now served in cafes, and gives advice on avoiding excessive calorie intakes when eating out, dealing with dressings and sauces, and cooking scones."

Author: "Bowden, Jennifer"
Title: "Simple tips to cut calories"
description: "Looks at the large portion sizes now served in cafes, and gives advice on avoiding excessive calorie intakes when eating out, dealing with dressings and sauces, and cooking scones."

Author: "Dekker, Diana"
Title: "'Quite simply a genius'"
description: "Presents an obituary for the potter."

Author: "Schouten, Hank,"
Title: "Lockwood founder a housing innovator"
description: "Presents an obituary for the co-creator of Lockwood homes."

Author: "Clements, R. T."
Title: "Mainland bounces back from quake"
description: "Presents an analysis and forecasts for the South Island economy. Talks about global concerns undermining business confidence, improved consumer confidence, increased house sales and consents, unemployment, and CPI (consumer price index) inflation."

Author: "Steeman, Marta"
Title: "Mainland monitor : city council business divide"
description: "Looks at the troubled relations between the Christchurch City Council and the business community over the city's rebuild after the 2010 and 2011 earthquakes. Talks to some critics of the council's draft city plan."

Author: "Dekker, Diana"
Title: "Encore careers"
description: "Looks at the redefinition of 'old age' and 'ageing', noting many people opt to eschew retirement, to study, or to start new careers. Talks to University of Waikato researcher Dr Margaret Richardson about her own experience of changing careers and the research she has done on positive ageing and 'encore careers'. Talks to career changers Amanda Holland (pharmacist to homecare designer), Kerry Prendergast (midwife to mayor), Sara Sadd and Ann Porter (art gallery owners to skin care producers), Stephen Daisley (shearer to author), Rachel Baskerville (anthropologist to accountant), and John Tucker (manager to academic)."

Author: "Eleven, Beck"
Title: "Doyenne of spin"
description: "Meets the internationally renowned spinner and weaver."

Author: "Catherall, Sarah"
Title: "Villa for our times"
description: "Features a modern villa in Grey Lynn designed by Auckland's RTA Studio, noting the house has been shortlisted for the World Architecture Festival award run from Barcelona."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1986"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1986. Reports and comments on the sinking of the Russian cruise ship 'Mikhail Lermontov' in the Marlborough Sounds (17 Feb), a melee as the Prime Minister, the Rt Hon D. R. Lange, was rushed away in a limousine from a tense official function at the Invermay Agricultural Centre in Mosgiel (16 Apr), and the melt down of a reactor at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant in the Ukraine (30 Apr). Touches on the passing of the Homosexual Law Reform Bill (10 Jul), a $2.5 million redevelopment programme for Queenstown's Skyline gondola (11 Jul), and a last minute flurry of shopping before the start of GST (Goods and Services Tax) (2 Oct)."

Author: "Cannan, Dave"
Title: "Wong's bwuddy adventurous life"
description: "Looks back over the life and times of the Central Otago 'character'."

Title: "Acquainted with many, close to few"
description: "Presents an obituary for the former Dunedin publican."

Author: "Price, Mark"
Title: "Showing some solar flair"
description: "Focuses on the future of photovoltaics (pv) in NZ. Explains that it is a system that turns sunlight into electricity via panels of solar cells usually made of silicon. Speaks to a number of experts, including University of Otago Professor Bob Lloyd and EECA's chief executive Mike Underhill, about its potential. Talks about the pv market in the region. Provides information on the best orientation and pitch for roofs where solar panels might be fitted in Dunedin. Highlights worldwide pv news from the past two months."

Author: "McKinney, Cushla"
Title: "Credentials confirmed in story of new beginnings"
description: "Credentials confirmed in story of new beginnings"

Author: "Gilchrist, Shane"
Title: "Still dreams to pursue"
description: "Speaks to the singer about his latest tour (Final bow farewell tour), career and ongoing success."

Author: "Matthews, Lee"
Title: "Cast in history; Monroe a man of many sports"
description: "Cast in history; Monroe a man of many sports"

Author: "Matthews, Lee"
Title: "Russian Front vet recalls Hitler's hell"
description: "Russian Front vet recalls Hitler's hell"

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1987"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1987. Reports and comments on the inaugural Rugby World Cup (22 Jun), anger at closures of post offices (16 Oct), and world sharemarkets caught in a selling panic (20 Oct). Touches on a strong earthquake centred on Whakatane damaging the Matahina dam (3 Mar), the announcement that the Luggate dam would not proceed (14 Jun), 21 Otago business installing Lotto terminals for the new lottery (26 Jun), and NZ's netballers winning the world title (31 Aug)."

Title: "Power to head up Westpac's Private Bank for wealthy clients"
description: "Power to head up Westpac's Private Bank for wealthy clients"

Title: "An odds-on favourite"
description: "Reports on Victoria University of Wellington's market-based political and economic forecasting system iPredict, which is being promoted as more accurate than most polls. Explains how it works. Lists the current prices for the 2011 general election."

Title: "Lifelong work in pursuit of peace and justice"
description: "Lifelong work in pursuit of peace and justice"

description: "Rapist, 20, weeps as he says sorry"

description: "Coroner hails brave response to shooting"

Author: "Barton, Chris"
Title: "From out of an old trunk hidden treasures"
description: "Tells the story of the pioneering photographer's quest to photograph kuia with moko in the 1960s and 1970s, which can be seen in the Monsoon Pictures documentary 'Allan Baldwin : in frame'. Talks about his work with historian Michael King in 1969-70."

Author: "Gray, Wynne"
Title: "The consummate pro nears his final hit"
description: "The consummate pro nears his final hit"

Author: "McNamara, T. J."

description: "Reviews 'Matters' by Peter Panyoczki at the Bath Street Gallery (to 29 Oct), 'Variations on a theme' by Alan Pearson at Sanderson Contemporary Art (to 30 Oct), 'Record' by Joe Sheehan at the Tim Melville Gallery (to 29 Oct), and 'Painted mind' by Lisa Crowley at the Fox/Jensen Gallery (to 29 Oct)."

Author: "McAllister, Janet"
Title: "Roll up, roll up for an arcade full of entertainment"
description: "Reviews the 'Performance arcade' at Auckland's Aotea Square (until 23 Oct)."

Author: "Clement, Diana"
Title: "Things to know when buying a business"
description: "Provides advice on what to consider when buying a business. Talks about doing research on the business, including getting a valuation."

Title: "New EMA chief tips hat to Napoleon"
description: "New EMA chief tips hat to Napoleon"

Author: "Manelis, Michele"
Title: "An eye to the future"
description: "Talks to the expatriate director about his latest movie."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1988"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1988."

Author: "Kara, Scott"
Title: "Retracing the Tiki Tour"
description: "Spotlights the second series. Talks to former Quin-Tikis instrumentalist Freddie Summers and Maori Hi Five member Wes Epae about their careers."

Title: "Quake in your boots"
description: "Talks to the band about their debut album."

Author: "Dixon, Greg"
Title: "Life after Lydia"
description: "Speaks to the award-winning singer-songwriter about her career, including her time with Fur Patrol."

Author: "Harrington, Suzanne"
Title: "The truth about gossip"
description: "Focuses on gossip. Suggests that there are three kinds of gossip: positive gossip, negative gossip, and industrial gossip. Explains the author's epiphany about gossip."

Author: "Jewell, Stephen"
Title: "Turning history on its head"
description: "Speaks to the author about his debut novel."

Author: "Cook, Marjorie"
Title: "Ballet, business proving a happy mix"
description: "Ballet, business proving a happy mix"

Author: "Green, Paula,"
Title: "Tales of what it is to be a man"
description: "Tales of what it is to be a man"

Author: "McGechan, Andy,"
Title: "Kiwi girl to take on the big boys"
description: "Kiwi girl to take on the big boys"

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1989"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1989. Focuses on the announcement of the splitting of North Otago between the Canterbury and Otago regions by the Local Government Commission (13 Jul). Highlights the falling of the Berlin Wall and opening of the East German border (11 Nov), including a photo of German citizens climbing on the wall. Reports on the shooting by Chinese soldiers of pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square (5 Jun). Includes brief reports of other events during the year."

Author: "Wade, Amelia"
Title: "Lomu leaves hospital after kidney scare"
description: "Lomu leaves hospital after kidney scare"

Author: "Lin, Chiao"
Title: "'The wrong one' an award-winning story"
description: "Presents a short story by a Columba College pupil, whose piece on sexism at home won the Young Writer Award at the 2011 BNZ Literary Awards."

Author: "Gray, Wynne"
Title: "Donald never relinquished dream"
description: "Donald never relinquished dream"

Author: "Johannsen, Dana"
Title: "Taumaunu to coach for Aussie series"
description: "Taumaunu to coach for Aussie series"

Author: "Marquet, Sarah"
Title: "Passion drives community radio"
description: "Recaps the history of the Maniototo volunteer run community radio station (Burn 729am) which is celebrating its 20th anniversary in Oct 2011. Talks to founding member Lawrence McCraw and current station manager Quentin McIntosh about the station's financial ups and downs and some of its memorable volunteers."

Author: "Smith, Charmian"
Title: "Art gym - but not as we know it"
description: "Talks to Jane Venis, creator of the 'Gymnauseum' exhibition showing at the Dunedin Public Art Gallery until 11 Dec 2011. Discusses her penchant for making cynical and humorous comments on popular culture, in this case, on the fitness industry and how ageing human bodies remind her of 'chindogu' (useless items)."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1990"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1990. Reports on the deaths in Aramoana of local residents who were shot by a lone gunman (14 Nov), and includes an update on the investigation (15 Nov). Features a photo of the ODT front page on 14 Nov. Reports on the damage caused by approximately 1500 student who rioted in North  Dunedin after leaving a party. Includes brief reports of other events during the year."

Author: "Johnston, Martin"
Title: "Watch the games on TV, surgeon tells McCaw"
description: "Watch the games on TV, surgeon tells McCaw"

Author: "Akuhata, Karla"
Title: "Goodbye, happy birthday, to man of grand ambition"
description: "Goodbye, happy birthday, to man of grand ambition"

Author: "Leggat, David"
Title: "Todd qualifies another horse for London"
description: "Todd qualifies another horse for London"

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1991"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1991. Reports on the beginnings of the Gulf war, announcing bombing raids in Iraq by the Americans in order to end Iraq's assault on Kuwait (18 Jan). Reviews the release of a report of the Waitangi Tribunal in which it states the Ngai Tahu people have legitimate Otago land grievances and recommends some compensation (8 Feb). Reports on the meeting that took place at Caroline Bay with Timaru residents and the Mayor, Mr Archie Houstoun to discuss the issue of gang warfare in their community (11 Dec)."

Author: "Goile, Aaron"
Title: "'Rocket arm' gets chance to seal world series place"
description: "'Rocket arm' gets chance to seal world series place"

Author: "Ansley, Greg"
Title: "Kiwi designer brings 'wow' factor to industrial innovation"
description: "Kiwi designer brings 'wow' factor to industrial innovation"

Title: "Council 'pioneering new ground'"
description: "Council 'pioneering new ground'"

Author: "Dickison, Michael"
Title: "Cruden's icy calm no surprise to first fans"
description: "Cruden's icy calm no surprise to first fans"

Author: "Donovan, Barry"
Title: "Turning silver to gold"
description: "Reminisces about going to Eden Park to watch the All Blacks-Springboks fourth test match in 1956 and the inaugural Rugby World Cup final between the All Blacks and France in 1987. Conveys the atmosphere of the stadium and match details. Lists other NZ international touring sides that the journalist, author and former rugby player considers exceptional."

Author: "Johnston, Alexia"
Title: "Grandfather snatches baby from flames as house burns"
description: "Grandfather snatches baby from flames as house burns"

Author: "Bidwell, Hamish"
Title: "Selection shocks 9th Ferns coach"
description: "Selection shocks 9th Ferns coach"

Author: "Williams, Celia"
Title: "On top of the world"
description: "Interviews the X Games freeski champion, charting his career from skier to action sports hero, model, and now the subject of a 52-minute documentary to be premiered in Austria, Oct 2011. Notes his three brothers are following in his wake. Includes the role played by his friend and award-winning sports cinematographer, Tim Pierce. Discusses the role of wealth, fame and Christian values in his public and private life."

Author: "Taylor, Cliff"
Title: "Gene lottery win an easy road to riches"
description: "Examines research by University of Texas economics professor Daniel Hamermesh that appearance is correlated with economic opportunities.  Cites the reaction to this idea of NZ model Colin Mathura-Jeffree.  Canvasses the views of New Zealand Association of Plastic Surgeons president Dr Howard Klein.  Includes the experience of University of Otago medical student Tristan Burnett whose looks have led to international modelling opportunities."

Author: "Crispe, Imogen"
Title: "Freedom at school of rough knocks"
description: "Freedom at school of rough knocks"

Author: "Mussen, Deidre"
Title: "Small-town jurors feel earthquake pressure; Jury trials to be held at former barracks site"
description: "Reviews the impact on jurors and the justice system after Christchurch courthouses were put out of action after the 22 Feb 2011 earthquake. Talks to a businessman, local residents, the Ministry of Justice, lawyers and Corrections officials about the implications of having to shift all trials from Christchurch to other South Island cities and towns. Informs that jury trials will resume in a temporary complex on the old King Edward Barracks site in the Christchurch CBD from early 2012."

Author: "Matthews, Philip"
Title: "At last, doors to open in the city"
description: "Talks to the chairman of the Restart the Heart Trust about the Re:Start project aimed at rebuilding the retail sector in the ruined city centre. Discusses the new retail area that will open to the public on 29 Oct 2011, made of repurposed shipping containers. Mentions a new Augmented Reality (AR) phone application developed at the University of Canterbury that will be released on the same day, allowing people to 'see life-sized virtual models of buildings ... where the real buildings used to be'.  Talks about the psychological impact of the earthquakes and their aftermath on residents, and the challenge of creating an economically viable city in partnership with property owners and the Christchurch City Council. Overviews his interest and experience in city revitalisation beginning in the late 1970s."

Author: "Matthews, Philip"
Title: "Fabric of memory falling to pieces; Fabric of memory falling to pieces in the demolished city centre"
description: "Focuses on the psychological impact for residents of Christchurch who will soon be re-entering an empty central city that has been demolished and cleared of earthquake debris. Observes that our memories, emotions and experiences help to form our mental pictures of cities, and when buildings are demolished or rebuilt in a short time it has a 'devastating effect' on these mental images. Includes remarks from design historian Douglas Lloyd Jenkins, writer Martin Edmond and others about their response to major changes to city architecture in Auckland, Sydney and elsewhere, and cites comment from Islay McLeod, Bruce Russell and Adrienne Rewi about the Christchurch CBD."

Author: "Crean, Mike"
Title: "A champion on stage and field"
description: "Celebrates the life of the late Christchurch resident and 'renaissance man', who succumbed after a two-year battle with cancer. Traces his eclectic career as a former operatic tenor of international renown, manager of the NZ International Festival of the Arts and the Christchurch Arts Centre, chief executive of New Zealand Cricket and director of many other sporting and cultural organisations."

Author: "Scherer, Karyn"
Title: "Fraud charges rock big-money deals"
description: "Fraud charges rock big-money deals"

Author: "Keown, Jenny"
Title: "Kiwi knowhow in sun-gel product"
description: "Interviews the couple about the process of developing their new NZ-made sun-gel, Skinnies. Comments on aspects of business and entrepreneurship."

Author: "Steeman, Marta"
Title: "Asian investors keen on organic baby food"
description: "Talks to the part-owner of the Christchurch-based, Napier-manufactured organic baby food company about hosting a visit from a group of Thai and Chinese businesspeople who are interested in investing in the company."

Author: "Harris, Catherine"
Title: "Mother England trims colonial apron strings; Shirlene's story; Changes to British immigration laws hit Kiwis"
description: "Backgrounds reasons for changes to British immigration laws effective Apr 2012, and the implications for NZers. Talks to the NZ academic whose future in Britain is uncertain despite having a British husband and son. Speaks to others including Stephen Dee, British regional manager of the expatriate network KEA and NZ's High Commissioner in Britain, Derek Leask."

Author: "McEwan, Ann"
Title: "Lost & lasting landmarks"
description: "Describes the fate of 10 of the city's most recognisable buildings after the series of earthquakes that rocked the city in 2010 and 2011."

Author: "Catherall, Sarah"
Title: "Our missing men"
description: "Reveals that not only is NZ experiencing a 'man drought', but that many of the most educated NZ men between the ages of 25 and 49 have left the country. Speaks to economist Paul Callister and research associate Zoe Lawton of Victoria University about the findings of a paper they have written as part of the university's 'missing men' project. Speaks to the career woman about her experiences, and to Kirsty Robertson of Relationship Services about some men's insecurity in dating women who are well educated and successful. Talks to migration expert Richard Bedford about the key findings of his new paper on the subject. Speaks to several couples about whether differing education levels matter to the success of a relationship. Provides information about enrollment by gender at Canterbury and Lincoln universities."

Author: "Thompson, Eric"
Title: "Millen hungry to crack targa Rally"
description: "Millen hungry to crack targa Rally"

Title: "Can't get rugby off his mind"
description: "Interviews the Huntly-raised lead rugby commentator for MaÃÑori Television."

Author: "Killick, David,"
Title: "Heritage preserved"
description: "Features 'Otahuna', a historic homestead in Canterbury designed by architect Frederick Strouts and built in 1895 by Sir Heaton Rhodes. Talks to one of the co-owners about the challenge of rebuilding the homestead, now a boutique luxury accommodation venue, after the earthquakes of 4 Sep 2010 and 22 Feb 2011. Traces the history of the homestead."

Author: "Rashbrooke, Max"
Title: "Inconvenient truths"
description: "Interviews the expatriate NZer, now a journalist in Britain, about coming back to NZ to write his new 'documentary novel' as part of his residency at the Randell House, Thorndon, Wellington. Comments on how he discovered the story behind his protagonist Reginald Pole."

Author: "Williams, David"
Title: "Food for those curious about NZ nature"
description: "Book review of 'Birds of New Zealand : Collins traveller's guide' by Julian Fitter and Don Merton."

Author: "Peka,  June"
Title: "Industrial growth"
description: "Talks to the former childhood neighbours from Ryan St, Linwood, Christchurch. Focuses on their work to transform the driveway of their workplace, Gary Clarke Plastics, into an attractive garden environment after the company suffered liquefaction damage."

Author: "Guild, Ben"
Title: "Club rowed to Olympic gold"
description: "Reviews important developments in the history of the club, which is celebrating its 125th anniversary at Labour Weekend 2011."

Author: "Hartley, Simon"
Title: "Chinese owners for NZ smelter"
description: "Explores future prospects for the aluminium company smelter at Tiwai Point near Bluff, one of seven assets to be amalgamated into a new company, Pacific Aluminium, by the multinational mining company Rio Tinto. Seeks comment from Craig Investments Partners broker Peter McIntyre about the possibilities of Tiwai Point being the focus of Chinese investment or a stock exchange float. Lists facts about the Tiwai Point smelter."

Author: "Sharpe, Marty"
Title: "How Izzy Dagg learnt to zigzag; The natural"
description: "Meets the fullback's family on the eve of the 2011 Rugby World Cup final. Talks about his early sporting skills."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1992"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1992.  Reports on community reaction to the sudden demolition of the historic Hoffman Kiln on order by the Clutha District Council, and provides an update on the situation (14 and 16 May). Announces that the Clyde power station has begun generating power to the national grid (28 May), and informs that it was operating at full capacity (2 Oct). Cites a call from Dunedin North MP Pete Hodgson to inform the public before Christmas of the details of a mixed member proportional (MMP) election system following the results of a referendum (21 Sep). Reveals the growing black market for wild Otago rabbit meat (13 May). Touches on other events during the year."

Author: "Ibbotson, Lucy"
Title: "'Old soldier' operated in the front line of life"
description: "Pays tribute to the insurance industry businessman and Freemason divisional grand master of Lodge Dunstan, Clyde."

Author: "Chug, Kiran"
Title: "Rena's wildlife toll will last for years"
description: "Reports on the impact of the 'Rena' grounding and oil spill on the wildlife on the Bay of Plenty coast."

Author: "Benson, Nigel"
Title: "'Remarkable New Zealander' who made things happen"
description: "Pays tribute to the late operatic tenor and sports administrator. Praises his administrative ability in a variety of sectors, including organising a benefit concert for Christchurch earthquake relief headlined by friend Placido Domingo."

Title: "Music was a way of life for Otaki gardener"
description: "Music was a way of life for Otaki gardener"

Author: "Gilchrist, Shane"
Title: "Survival of the fittest"
description: "Reflects on why sporting competitions are so compelling. Cites findings by Sigmund Freud and a personal example by Prof Robert Winston about his physiological response to England's 2002 World Cup soccer match against Argentina. Seeks comment from Auckland-based sociologist Nick Perry, and Dr Kristin Hillman and Ken Hodge of the University of Otago about factors influencing our responses to competitive situations."

Author: "Price, Mark"
Title: "1987 : when we were kings"
description: "Presents reports published in the newspaper about the inaugural Rugby World Cup, including the build-up to the match between France and the All Blacks, coverage of the match on 20 Jun 1987, and the aftermath of the All Blacks' win."

Author: "Vine, Geoffrey"
Author (detailed): "Geoffrey Vine, Peter Dowden and Ian Williams"
Title: "Two approaches to New Zealand history; Hyde disaster blame pinned on driver; Expat's summer journey around NZ"
description: "Two approaches to New Zealand history; Hyde disaster blame pinned on driver; Expat's summer journey around NZ"

Author: "Kara, Scott"
Title: "Youth raise the tempo"
description: "Speaks to lead guitarist Simon Oscroft and singer Jeremy Redmore of the rock quintet about their soon-to-be released second album. Talks about two gigs that have propelled them to wider recognition, and their experience trying to crack the Australian market."

Author: "Nichols, Lane"
Title: "ABs Inc : what a win is worth"
description: "Investigates the commercial success of the All Blacks brand. Asks what a Rugby World Cup victory might be worth. Talks about what the players earn and how the NZ Rugby Union (NZRU) generates its revenue. Spotlights the career and financial services offered to players by the NZ Rugby Players Association."

Author: "Kay, Martin"
Title: "But rugby was the winner"
description: "Looks back on the some of the off-field controversies of the 2011 Rugby World Cup."

Author: "Morris, Chris"
Title: "Resilience key attribute for council CEO"
description: "Interviews the Welsh-born chief executive of the Dunedin City Council about his job."

Author: "Harris, Catherine"
Title: "Mother England trims colonial apron strings; Shirlene's story"
description: "Backgrounds reasons for changes to British immigration laws effective Apr 2012, and the implications for NZers. Talks to the NZ academic whose future in Britain is uncertain despite having a British husband and son. Speaks to others including Stephen Dee, British regional manager of the expatriate network KEA and NZ's High Commissioner in Britain, Derek Leask."

Author: "Rae, Sally"
Title: "Dunedin agency's French connection"
description: "Meets the French-born couple who operate a Dunedin-based inbound French-speaking travel agency."

Author: "Milne, Jonathan"
Title: "Ties that bind"
description: "Questions whether cultural and family pressures enable Pacific Islanders to compete in business and commerce in the same way as in sport or music. Talks about the tradition of sending remittances home and the financial obligations this places on families here. Stresses the need for effective mentoring for Pacific Island businessmen and women."

Author: "Macdonald, Nikki"
Title: "A musical balancing act"
description: "Talks to the musician about her career and her debut album."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1993"
description: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1993  Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1993. Focuses on the presentation of a petition by Mr Bevan Smith, father of murdered Owaka schoolgirl Kylie Smith, urging the Government to hold a referendum on sentences for serious offenders (17 Feb). Reports on the announcement by Telecom to reduce staff numbers by 5200 over the next four years (17 Feb). Reprints an editorial opining that voters opt for the retention of the first-past-the-post (FPP) electoral system in the Nov 1993 referendum (19 Oct).  Includes a photograph of NZ Police forcibly moving University of Otago student protesters away from the registry building. Touches on other events during the year."

Author: "Macdonald, Nikki"
Title: "Kicking the bucket"
description: "Ponders the impact of earthquake strengthening on the character of the city's creative hub, Cuba Street. Talks about the Wellington City Council's latest earthquake risk assessment, which classified 44 Cuba Street buildings as earthquake prone. Speaks to number of Cuba Street building and business owners about the issue."

Author: "Hepburn, Steve"
Title: "Rugby World Cup 2011 special"
description: "Offers news and pictorial coverage of the Rugby World Cup final between NZ and France, 23 Oct 2011. Includes an assessment of the tense 8-7 match, reaction from All Blacks' coach Graham Henry and captain Richie McCaw, and player ratings."

Author: "Fitzsimons, Tom"
Title: "Fun at the fair"
description: "Talks to NZ publishers about their experiences at the Frankfurt Book Fair."

Author: "Catherall, Sarah"
Title: "Our missing men"
description: "Reveals that not only is NZ experiencing a 'man drought', but that many of the most educated NZ men between the ages of 25 and 49 have left the country. Speaks to economist Paul Callister and research associate Zoe Lawton of Victoria University about the findings of a paper they have written as part of the university's 'missing men' project. Speaks to the career woman about her experiences, and to Kirsty Robertson of Relationship Services about some men's insecurity in dating women who are well educated and successful. Talks to migration expert Richard Bedford about the key findings of his new paper on the subject. Speaks to several couples about whether differing education levels matter to the success of a relationship. Provides information about enrollment by gender at Canterbury and Lincoln universities."

Author: "Hepburn, Steve"
Title: "Rugby World Cup 2011 champions"
description: "Presents comprehensive coverage of the Rugby World Cup 2011. Overviews highlights of the tournament. Seeks comment from Rugby New Zealand 2011 chief executive Martin Snedden about the event, including the new Dunedin indoor stadium. Lists some of the best quotes from players, coaches and a fan. Presents lists of World Cup XVs. Reviews the good, bad and ugly moments.  Offers assessments of five of the best players, best tries, best young players and other information. Recaps tournament results. Includes a four-page photo essay."

Author: "Clifton, Jane,"
Title: "MMP : myths, merits and pitfalls"
description: "Examines a number of assumptions about the effects of the mixed member proportional (MMP) voting system on the political culture in NZ. Summarises the views of proponents and opponents of MMP (Sir Geoffrey Palmer and Roger Kerr) in light of the upcoming referendum."

Author: "Killick, David,"
Title: "Heritage preserved"
description: "Features 'Otahuna', a historic homestead in Canterbury designed by architect Frederick Strouts and built in 1895 by Sir Heaton Rhodes. Talks to one of the co-owners about the challenge of rebuilding the homestead, now a boutique luxury accommodation venue, after the earthquakes of 4 Sep 2010 and 22 Feb 2011. Traces the history of the homestead."

Author: "Thornley, Louise"
Title: "Fear & calm"
description: "Recalls climbing Mount Aspiring on New Year's Eve."

Author: "Macdonald, Nikki"
Title: "Going native"
description: "Talks to the horticulturist about his photographic quest for the new book."

Author: "Rashbrooke, Max"
Title: "Inconvenient truths"
description: "Interviews the expatriate NZer, now a journalist in Britain, about coming back to NZ to write his new 'documentary novel' as part of his residency at the Randell House, Thorndon, Wellington. Comments on how he discovered the story behind his protagonist Reginald Pole."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1994"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1994. Reports on the continuing Serious Fraud Office inquiry of the meat company (23 Apr); the direction of police investigations into the death of five members of the Bain family the day before (21 Jun); and the attendance of Prime Minister Jim Bolger and his wife Joan Bolger at the official opening of the Clyde dam (25 Apr). Touches on other events during the year."

Author: "Sandys, Elspeth"
Title: "Wheeled out"
description: "Reviews the play Sex Drive by Lorae Parry and Pinky Agnew which is showing at Circa One, Wellington."

Author: "Blundell, Sally,"
Title: "Finding a way through"
description: "Talks with poet and writer Fiona Farrell about her latest travel tome, The Broken Book. Mentions she added a post-earthquake chapter after experiencing the 2010 September quake. Traces her childhood love of walking in Oamaru through to her ruminative hikes in the countryside of southern France."

Author: "Hewitson, Michele"
Title: "Shane the man"
description: "Talks to the prolific television actor about his career and his family."

Author: "Savage, Jared"
Title: "Teen's death : driver was banned"
description: "Teen's death : driver was banned"

Author: "Harvey, Bob"
Title: "Wild west coast captured heart of artist"
description: "Wild west coast captured heart of artist"

Author: "Nissen, Wendyl"
Title: "Long list of ingredients complicates simple dish"
description: "Analyses the ingredients of La Baguette's ham and cheese 'Deli quiche'."

Author: "Dart, William"
Title: "Feast of Mozart immensely satisfying"
description: "Reviews the Auckland Philharmonia Orchestra's latest Thursday concert."

Author: "Goodwin, Eileen"
Title: "Reconnecting with daily life"
description: "Interviews the occupational therapist at Dunedin Hospital about the nature of her work. Informs that Occupational Therapy Week runs from 24-28 Oct 2011."

Author: "Hewitson, Michele"
Title: "Gordon Harcourt"
description: "Talks to the journalist who claims to lead a dull life compared to his famous thespian family."

Author: "Constantine, Ellie"
Title: "Watered-down milk and toast for tea; Group releases 'Voices of poverty'"
description: "Sums up key findings of the annual 'Voices of Poverty' report by Presbyterian Support Otago (PSO), featuring interviews with 11 families to ascertain their experiences before and after the changes to income tax and GST in 2010. Seeks comment from PSO chief executive Gillian Bremner about the implications of the findings. Includes quotes from interviewees."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1995"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1995.  Reports on the tragic loss of 13 Tai Poutaini Polytechnic students and a Dept of Conservation staff member when a viewing platform collapsed at Paparoa National Park, Greymouth, and informs of the condition of survivors (29 Apr). Celebrates the America's Cup win by Team New Zealand in San Diego, California (15 May), and includes an update on 25 May of the homecoming parade in Auckland. Reports on the abandonment of plans for a community-owned inpatient surgical service at Balclutha Hospital (6 Mar). Includes news of further closures at Tapanui Hospital (6 Mar) and Roxburgh Hospital (21 Apr)."

Author: "Young, Audrey"
Title: "Head to head"
description: "Examines the state of the two main parties, National and Labour, as the 2011 election campaign begins. Lists their recent election results. Highlights quotes from the respective leaders, John Key and Phil Goff."

Author: "Orsman, Bernard"
Title: "Year of the game changer"
description: "Looks back on the Auckland Super City Mayor's first year in office. Talks about what has been achieved and the challenges that lie ahead."

Author: "Taylor, Phil,"
Title: "The man who flipped the bird"
description: "Reflects on the conviction of repeat drunk driver Wally Watson for the manslaughter of his flatmate, Gavin Cuthbert. Asks why there is no life ban for repeat drunk drivers. Speaks to the Automobile Association's Mike Noon and Transport Minister Steven Joyce about the situation."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1996"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1996. Provides details of the new honours system, the NZ Order of Merit, announced by Prime Minister Jim Bolger (3 May). Reports on the NZ history-making second gold medal captured by the swimmer at the Olympic Games, Atlanta (25 Jul). Comments on the strategies of NZ First party leader Winston Peters in forming NZ's first MMP (mixed-member proportional) government with the National Party (11 Dec) after eight weeks of negotiations. Touches on other events during the year."

Author: "Jopp, Julie"
Title: "Art scene"
description: "Reviews 'Colourific', various artists, Association of New Zealand Embroiderers' Guilds, Lakes District Museum, Arrowtown, until 30 Oct 2011.  Reviews 'Oroua Valley' by Karl Maughan, Milford Galleries Dunedin, until 9 Nov 2011.  Reviews 'I see you' by Jo St Baker, Gallery De Novo, Dunedin, until 3 Nov 2011."

Author: "Herrick, Linda"
Title: "Hunter and collector"
description: "Talks about the life of the naturalist and the auction of his rare book collection in Auckland (2-3 Nov)."

Author: "McNamara, T. J."
Title: "Heroes to silliness - and stamp of oddity"
description: "Reviews 'Heroes' by Regan Tamanui at Orexart (to 5 Nov), 'Ordering nature' by Lianne Edwards at the Antoinette Godkin Gallery (to 19 Nov), 'Nature' videos by Richard Maloy, Christian Jankowski and Boyd Webb at the Sue Crockford Gallery (to 5 Nov), and 'Lady Chatterley's lover' by Jan Nigro at Jane Sanders ART Agent (to 19 Nov)."

Title: "Gulf boaties lose strong advocate"

description: "Rural women's advocate keen to recruit members"

Title: "Still here in the 'perfect job'"
description: "Meets the South Island regional policy manager for Federated Farmers. Describes his farming background, training and current role."

description: "Focuses on the role and activities of the meat organisation. Comments on overseas demand, the upcoming season and pricing, the Red Meat Sector Strategy and on-farm events including the annual Big Day Out, Lone Star Farms Caberfeidh property, Hakataramea Valley, 3 Nov 2011."

Author: "Rae, Sally"
Title: "Alliance director retires"
description: "Talks to the farmer about his decision to stand down as a director of the meat company after nearly 25 years. Reflects on highlights and challenges during his tenure and comments on the future of the industry."

Author: "Rae, Sally"

description: "Constant control keeps rabbits down"

Author: "Rae, Sally"

description: "Talks to the 2011 recipient of the PGG Wrightson Monaro scholarship, an agricultural exchange organised by the Otago Merino Association. Describes highlights of his trip to the Monaro region of New South Wales, focusing on visits to merino breeders."

Title: "In it for the long run"

description: "Talks to Sarah Hutchings, Fay and Ron Bishop, Charlie Borrell, Kelly Pigott, Pam Wadsworth and Lesley Elliott about how the pain of having their loved ones murdered never leaves them. States how they are part of the 120 people representing 50 familes affected by some of the country's high-profile murders who have come together to share their stories and send a message to politicians and law-makers in the run-up to next months general election. Notes academic research showing how grieving families feel betrayed by the lack of support they get from the criminal justice system."

Author: "McFadden, Suzanne"
Title: "In defence of chick lit"
description: "Speaks to the romantic comedy author about her career and the criticism directed towards 'chick lit'. Talks about the recent downturn in chick lit sales. Lists the top five chick lit authors."

description: "Presents information about the New Zealand Century Farm and Station Awards."

Talks to athletics coach Chris Pilone about the breakdown in the coaching relationship between coach Paul Hamblyn and runner Nikki Hamblin and her subsequent form. Talk to Elena Vinogradova, who coached decathlete Brent Newdick, about his results after he parted with her as coach. Highlights Sir Peter Snell's comments earlier this year on how the emphasis on athlete over coach is not new."

description: "Battle to save tolddler from rare brain tumour"

description: "Kora Jade - Earth's No 7 billion?"

Title: "There's a hole in the hill"
description: "Recounts the author's investigation as to the origin of the WWII tunnels at the Port of Lyttelton where he played as a young lad in the 1950's. Chronicles the War Department's decision to build fuel tank tunnels into the Lyttelton hillside. Details the progress made in their construction noting the tunnels were not completed by the war's end."

description: "Reviews Himalayan hospitals : Sir Edmund Hillary's Everest legacy by Michael Gill."

description: "Analyses the strengths and weaknesses of having a two leader debate and who, out of John Key and Phil Goff, is likely to win such a debate in the context of the up and coming election. Comments on the strategy of a personality driven campaign versus a campaign driven by policy."

description: "Profiles American ballet star Ethan Stiefel who has been appointed the artistic director of the New Zealand Ballet Company. Outlines his illustrious career, his assessment of the company, the intended programming schedule and his artistic direction."

Author: "Mackay, Scott"
Title: "The kiwi way"
description: "Describes the project being managed at Willowbank Wildlife Reserve in Christchurch where kiwi are hatched and then placed in the wild on a safe creÃÄche island in Southland, Rona Island. Notes both Rona and Pomona Island have been returned to their natural state by the Pomona Island Charitable Trust in order that the young kiwi can live in a predator free environment."

Recounts in the last 18 months, stringy seaweed, known as Undaria pinnatifida started to populate a remote part of Fiordland. Follows what has been done to ameliorate its spread and the role Fiordland Marine Guardians has played in conjunction with government departments and commercial organisations."

Title: "O'Sullivan recalls ups and downs at Valley"
description: "O'Sullivan recalls ups and downs at Valley"

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1997"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1997.  Focuses on the reaction of the Ministry of Agriculture after the discovery of the rabbit-killing RCD virus in Otago (27 Aug). Presents details of the car crash that killed Princess Diana and her companion, Dodi Al Fayed, in Paris (1 Sep). Reports on the floodwaters in Canterbury that partly destroyed the massive Opuha dam, resulting in evacuations of the riverside settlements of Stratheona and Butlers Crossing (7 Feb)."

description: "Recalls it is ten years since Sir Peter Blake was killed on the Amazon. Talks to Marc Shaw who was on the expedition and will return with ten others to leave a more permanent memorial to Sir Peter. Reveals the group will be involved in learning about the environment, ecology, medicine and the people in the Amazonas."

description: "Looks ahead to the four-week sprint of an election campaign about to unfold. Discusses the different approaches of the main parties with National focusing on leadership and Labour on policy. Highlights the campaign strategists of National, Labour and the Greens."

Author: "Chapman, Kate"
Title: "Call for wider adoption of Whanau Ora approach"

Author: "Crossley, Jazial"

description: "Talks to the Zimbabwean under-19 coach about his role within Zimbabwe Cricket and how he and his family have settled into life in their home on the outskirts of Harare."

Describes the initial shock of learning their first born was affected by Down Syndrome and the plethora of information that was available and how he and his wife, Suzi, developed Bella's abilities. Recounts the process of starting Bella a playcentre and primary school and notes Bella is visual in learning which gives her a high interest in books and television. Notes the next ten years will offer different challenges."

description: "Recounts the boxing career of James "Jimmy Thunder" Peau, how he ended up on the streets once his career ended, and his marriage to Native American Iris Whitemagpie Paeu."

Author: "Dekker, Diana"

description: "Speaks to the expat photographer about his career and work, which is deeply rooted in Pacific culture and iconography. Talks about his work 'The last cannibal' that has been shortlisted for the $45,000 Singapore Art Museum Signature prize."

description: "Talks to the author about his latest picture book, the various other books he has illustrated, his career as an illustrator, and his love of Taupo."

Author: "Kilgallon, Steve"
Title: "Beer money"
description: "Investigates why West Auckland's licensing trusts, the Portage and Waitakere Licensing Trusts, are not returning huge profits to the community. Explains that the $80 million the trusts have laid claim to have come from a completely unrelated poker machine trust, the Trusts Charitable Foundation, which by law must have nothing to do with them. Spotlights the claims of Portage Licensing Trust chairman Ross Low about the trust's $5.8 million donation to support the redevelopment of the Lopdell House arts and culture centre in Titirangi. Explains what a licensing trust is. Talks about the inconvenience for West Aucklanders of not being able to buy alcohol at supermarkets because of the trusts' monopoly on alcohol sales in the area."

Author: "Knight, Kim,"
Title: "The last laugh"
description: "Profiles the Melbourne-based street artist. Talks about his career."

Title: "Gin's a tonic"
description: "Talks to Gin Wigmore who is touring NZ to promote her latest album, Gravel and Vine. Describes her singing style and lists the names of recordings that have been successful. Comments on the background to her music writing and how her career has progressed."

Author: "Bowman, Glenys"
Title: "Not so sweet"
description: "Notes the change of style in children's clothing, which according to the author, is showing marked gender differentiation. Tries to explain the reversion to gender specific clothes and comments on Felicity Perry's PhD on fashion and identity."

Author: "Barnett, Sarah"
Title: "Fiona Farrell interview"
description: "Talks with Nicky Moore, dietitian for the Canterbury District Health Board about the role of food in the healing of sick people. Sums up the difficulties catering staff face, particularly when having to cater for a variety of dietary requirements."

description: "Discusses the results of the 2011 TIN100 report with Greg Shanahan of the Technology Investment Network, which produced the report. Explains that the TIN100 monitors data from NZ's largest 100 technology exporters and 100 emerging companies of information and communications, high tech manufacturing and biotechnology."

description: "Talks with Nicky Moore, dietitian for the Canterbury District Health Board about the role of food in the healing of sick people. Sums up the difficulties catering staff face, particularly when having to cater for a variety of dietary requirements."

Speaks to Martin Phillipps of The Chills and Graeme Downes of The Verlaines. Talks about the author's experiences as a member of The DoubleHappys."

Talks about the customers who went on to become members of Flying Nun Records music label bands, including David Kilgour, Martin Phillipps, Shayne Carter, Graeme Downes, and Alastair Galbraith. Speaks to Lesley Paris of Look Blue Go Purple, David Kilgour of The Clean, and Flying Nun Records label founder Roger Shepherd."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "Keep your balance"
description: "Notes volatile economic times, predictions of continuing global recession, and of low interest rates. Looks at the impact of low rates on those attempting to get an income from savings, such as retirees, and risk aversion in investors, and discusses investing in gold, investing in residential rental property, investments in the sharemarket, and investment in emerging markets (developing countries) as ways to deal with the uncertain environment. Gives suggestions from Mark Lister of Craigs Investment Partners on three stocks in which to invest. Looks at research on whether KiwiSaver is achieving its aim of improving the national savings rate."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"

description: "Notes volatile economic times, predictions of continuing global recession, and of low interest rates. Looks at the impact of low rates on those attempting to get an income from savings, such as retirees, and risk aversion in investors, and discusses investing in gold, investing in residential rental property, investments in the sharemarket, and investment in emerging markets (developing countries) as ways to deal with the uncertain environment. Gives suggestions from Mark Lister of Craigs Investment Partners on three stocks in which to invest. Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "Rush to ruin; Newcastle rising"
description: "Looks at the demolition of buildings in Christchurch, especially heritage buildings, and reports on criticism that this is unnecessary. Sketches the scale of demolitions and reports on international engineers Kit Miyamoto and Michael King's claims that many of the buildings could have been fixed for 20%-30% of the cost of new buildings. Discusses reasons why Christchurch owners might seek exaggerated damage estimates and settlements for demolitions through the Canterbury Earthquake Recovery Authority (CERA). Reports on the urban renewal of Newcastle in NSW following an earthquake and other urban revitilisation efforts in Australia."

Author: "Blundell, Sally,"
Title: "Christchurch's heritage buildings are a "must keep"; Newcastle rising"
description: "Looks at the demolition of buildings in Christchurch, especially heritage buildings, and reports on criticism that this is unnecessary. Discusses reasons why Christchurch owners might seek exaggerated damage estimates and settlements for demolitions through the Canterbury Earthquake Recovery Authority (CERA). description: "Women found unharmed on harsh track were inexperienced trampers"

Author: "Johns, Geraldine"
Title: "Take a bow"
description: "Looks at Sistema Aotearoa, a children's musical and social development programme run by the Auckland Philharmonia Orchestra. Describes the pilot scheme launched this year and funded by the Ministry for Culture and Heritage which offers workshops and intensive training in stringed orchestral instruments (violin, viola, cello or double bass) with skilled tutors and guests to six and seven year olds in Otara, Auckland (covering seven decile one schools) at no charge to parents. Portrays one school-holiday workshop, and outlines the background and goals of the international Sistema programme, talking to Sistema Aotearoa programme director Dr Joe Harrop."

Title: "Sistema Aotearoa - violins in Otara"
description: "Looks at Sistema Aotearoa, a children's musical and social development programme run by the Auckland Philharmonia Orchestra. Portrays one school-holiday workshop, and outlines the background and goals of the international Sistema programme, talking to Sistema Aotearoa programme director Dr Joe Harrop."

Describes the research and writing of the novel, developed from an earlier short story and covering the journey of Paratene te Manu (Ngati Wai) and other rangatira to England in 1863."

Talks about the tradition of sending remittances home and the financial obligations this places on families here. Stresses the need for effective mentoring for Pacific Island businessmen and women."

Title: "DIY therapy"

Describes the study and self-harming patients seen in Waitemata Health, and Problem Solving Therapy itself.  Notes Hatcher and his team planning a follow-up trial."

Author: "White, Margo"

description: "Discusses Problem Solving Therapy, demonstrated as being useful with people who attempted suicide or self-harm in recent research by Simon Hatcher, University of Auckland. Title: "E is for excess"
description: "Looks at the usefulness of vitamin E supplements. Outlines the nutritional role of vitamin E and mixed research on links with reduced risks of cardiovascular disease. Looks at recommendations on a healthy diet and possible problems with dietary supplements."

Author: "Bowden, Jennifer"
Title: "Vitamin E supplements"
description: "Looks at the usefulness of vitamin E supplements. Outlines the nutritional role of vitamin E and mixed research on links with reduced risks of cardiovascular disease. Looks at recommendations on a healthy diet and possible problems with dietary supplements."

Looks at the need for better infrastructure such as ultra-fast broadband and questions on whether content providers will set up in NZ. Looks at positions on other issues such as copyright law and downloading, and on the digital divide."

description: "Looks at the information and communications technology (ICT) issues of concern to politicians, as discussed in a recent InternetNZ debate in Wellington. description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1998. Announces how foul play is feared after Ben Smart and Olivia Hope went missing without a trace in the Marlborough Sounds on New Year's Day (5 Jan). Reports on how the split of ECNZ into three state-owned generating companies could reduce electricity prices (8 Apr). Celebrates Otago winning the National Provincial Championship (NPC) over Waikato at Carisbrook (26 Oct). Highlights mandatory photos on driver's licences, two casinos for Queenstown, and United States President Bill Clinton ending a 12-year blanket ban on military exercises between the two countries."

Title: "Parkinson's not the worst"

Author: "Salter, Jack"
Title: "Leave your egos at the door"
description: "Talks to the mixed martial arts master about his home training centre called the 'Power Booth'. Describes the various kinds of people he has trained."

Author: "Gilchrist, Shane"
Title: "A purely personal view"
description: "Talks to the painter about his latest book, a collection of photographs taken as a personal tribute to Central Otago. Includes a fact file about the artist."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1999"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1999. Recalls the day in Parliament when the drinking age was lowered to 18, by 59 votes to 55 (29 Jul). Presents the story when floodwaters flowed in from a heavily swollen Lake Wakatipu into Queenstown at around 10 pm. Has a picture of Alec McGregor standing in a flooded Beach Street (17 Nov). Includes details of the $7.6m irrigation scheme plan using Waitaki River water to irrigate about 3300 hectares of the North Otago downlands (24 Apr)."

Tells of her plans to conduct a research project speaking to others with disabilities about their experiences."

Title: "Southern sojourn just the tonic"
description: "Talks to the musician about following up her breakthrough debut album 'Holy Smoke' with her second album 'Gravel & Wine'. Highlights some of the songs."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 2000"

Announces how armed men launched a dramatic coup in Fiji, storming parliament and taking the Prime Minister and his cabinet hostage (20 May). Reports on the huge rock slip at Nevis Bluff on State Highway 6 (18 Sep)."

Gallery (until 19 Nov)."

Describes the role of the dairy sector in NZ employment, citing figures from the New Zealand Institute of Economic Research (NZIER).   Talks to Ashburton mayor Angus McKay about the contribution of dairy farms to the district's performance in the national and Canterbury economies."

Title: "Probe exposes fishing underbelly"
description: "Describes submissions to a ministerial inquiry into fishing practices in NZ waters. Looks at the use of foreign charter vessels (FCV) by NZ companies operating in NZ waters, noting their reputation for using foreign crews and for exploitative labour practices. Questions why FCVs catch almost all of MaÃÑori fishing quota yet do not employ MaÃÑori crews. Seeks comment from fishing companies Talleys, Sanfords and Sealords on the debate over whether the use of FCVs is harmful to NZ's reputation and economy. Notes the inquiry is due on Feb 24 2012."

Author: "Woulfe, Catherine"
